VISIT...

访问...

I dedicate this book to the memory of my mother,
Judith Lövi, 1919–2001. And to the memory of
Dr. Hans Selye, a twentieth-century Renaissance
man whose scientific insights and humane wisdom
continue to illuminate .

谨以此书纪念我的母亲，朱迪思·洛维（Judith Lövi），1919–2001。同时，也谨以此书纪念汉斯·塞利博士（Dr. Hans Selye），这位二十世纪的文艺复兴式人物，他的科学洞见和人文智慧至今仍启迪着世人。

It is not to see something first, but to establish solid connections between the previously known and the hitherto unknown, that constitutes the essence of scientific discovery. It is this process of tying together which can best promote true understanding and real progress .

科学发现的本质并非在于率先发现某物，而在于建立已知与未知之间的牢固联系。正是这种相互联系的过程，才能最大程度地促进真正的理解和进步。

HANS SELYE, M.D. , The Stress of Life

汉斯·塞利医学博士，《生活压力》

致谢

A Note to the Reader

致读者

P EOPLE HAVE ALWAYS UNDERSTOOD INTUITIVELY that mind and body are not separable. Modernity has brought with it an unfortunate dissociation, a split between what we know with our whole being and what our thinking mind accepts as truth. Of these two kinds of knowledge the latter, narrower, kind most often wins out, to our loss.

人们一直以来都凭直觉明白身心不可分割。现代性带来了一种不幸的分离，一种我们用全身心去感知的认知与我们理性思维所接受的真理之间的割裂。在这两种认知中，后者——一种更为狭隘的认知——往往占据上风，最终让我们蒙受损失。

It is a pleasure and a privilege, therefore, to bring in front of the reader the findings of modern science that reaffirm the intuitions of age-old wisdom. That was my primary goal in writing this book. My other purpose was to hold up a mirror to our stress-driven society so that we may recognize how, in myriad unconscious ways, we help generate the illnesses that plague us.

因此，能够将现代科学的研究成果呈现在读者面前，并印证古老智慧的直觉，我深感荣幸和喜悦。这正是我撰写本书的首要目标。我的另一个目的是让我们反思我们这个压力重重的社会，从而认识到，在无数无意识的层面上，我们是如何助长那些困扰我们的疾病的。

This is not a book of prescriptions, but I do hope it will serve its readers as a catalyst for personal transformation. Prescriptions come from the outside, transformation occurs within. There are many books of simple prescriptions of one sort or another—physical, emotional, spiritual—that appear each year. It was not my intention to write yet one more. Prescriptions assume that something needs to be fixed; transformation brings forth the healing—the coming to integrity, to wholeness—of what is already there. While advice and prescriptions may be useful, even more valuable to us is insight into ourselves and the workings of our minds and bodies. Insight, when inspired by the quest for truth, can promote transformation. For those seeking a healing message here, that message begins on page one with the very first case study. As the great physiologist Walter Cannon suggested, there is a wisdom in our bodies. I hope When the Body Says No will help people align with the inner wisdom we all possess.

这不是一本提供各种“处方”的书，但我真心希望它能成为读者个人转变的催化剂。“处方”来自外部，而转变则发生在内心。每年都有许多书籍提供各种各样的“处方”——无论是身体上的、情感上的还是精神上的——我原本并不打算再写一本。“处方”的前提是某些东西需要被修复；而转变则带来疗愈——回归完整，回归圆满——回归到早已存在的状态。虽然建议和“处方”或许有用，但对我们来说，更宝贵的是洞察自身以及身心运作的奥秘。当洞察源于对真理的追求时，它便能促进转变。对于那些寻求疗愈信息的人来说，这份信息从第一页的第一个案例研究就开始了。正如伟大的生理学家沃尔特·坎农所言，我们的身体蕴藏着智慧。我希望《当身体说不》这本书能够帮助人们与我们每个人都拥有的内在智慧相连接。

Some of the case examples in this book are derived from published biographies or autobiographies of well-known persons. The majority are taken from my clinical experience or from taped discussions with people who agreed to be interviewed and quoted regarding their medical and personal histories. For privacy reasons, names (and, in some instances, other circumstances) have been changed.

本书中的部分案例取材于已出版的名人传记或自传。大部分案例则来自我的临床经验，或来自与同意接受采访并讲述其病史和个人经历的人士的录音访谈。出于隐私考虑，书中所有姓名（以及在某些情况下，其他相关情况）均已更改。

To avoid making this work prohibitively academic for the lay reader, notes have been used only sparingly. References are provided for each chapter at the end of the book.

为了避免本书过于学术化，使非专业读者难以理解，注释的使用较为克制。每章末尾均附有参考文献。

Italics, unless otherwise noted, are mine.

除非另有说明，斜体字均为我所加。

I welcome comments at my e-mail address: gmate@telus.net .

欢迎您通过电子邮件 gmate@telus.net 向我提出意见。

1
1
The Bermuda Triangle
百慕大三角

M ARY WAS A NATIVE WOMAN in her early forties, slight of stature, gentle and deferential in manner. She had been my patient for eight years, along with her husband and three children. There was a shyness in her smile, a touch of self-deprecation. She laughed easily. When her ever-youthful face brightened, it was impossible not to respond in kind. My heart still warms—and constricts with sorrow—when I think of Mary.

玛丽是一位四十出头的土著妇女，身材娇小，举止温柔谦逊。她和她的丈夫及三个孩子曾是我的病人八年。她的笑容中带着一丝羞涩，又略带自嘲。她总是笑个不停。每当她那永远年轻的脸上绽放出笑容，你都会不由自主地跟着笑起来。每当想起玛丽，我的心中依然会涌起一股暖流，同时也夹杂着深深的悲伤。

Mary and I had never talked much until the illness that was to take her life gave its first signals. The beginning seemed innocent enough: a sewing-needle puncture wound on a fingertip failed over several months to heal. The problem was traced to Raynaud’s phenomenon, in which the small arteries supplying the fingers are narrowed, depriving the tissues of oxygen. Gangrene can set in, and unfortunately this was the case for Mary. Despite several hospitalizations and surgical procedures, she was within a year begging for an amputation to rid her of the throbbing ache in her finger. By the time she got her wish the disease was rampant, and powerful narcotics were inadequate in the face of her constant pain.

玛丽和我以前很少说话，直到夺走她生命的疾病开始显现征兆。起初，一切似乎都很正常：她指尖上的一个缝纫针扎伤，几个月都没能愈合。后来发现是雷诺氏现象，这种疾病会导致手指供血的小动脉变窄，组织缺氧。坏疽可能由此发生，不幸的是，玛丽就患上了这种疾病。尽管多次住院和手术，不到一年，她就恳求截肢，以摆脱手指的剧痛。等到她如愿以偿时，病情已经恶化，强效麻醉剂也无法缓解她持续不断的疼痛。

Raynaud’s can occur independently or in the wake of other disorders. Smokers are at greater risk, and Mary had been a heavy smoker since her teenage years. I hoped that if she quit, normal blood flow might return to her fingers. After many relapses she finally succeeded. Unfortunately, the Raynaud’s proved to be the harbinger of something far worse: Mary was diagnosed with scleroderma, one of the autoimmune diseases, which include rheumatoid arthritis, ulcerative colitis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and many other conditions that are not always recognized to be autoimmune in origin, such as diabetes, multiple sclerosis and possibly even Alzheimer’s disease. Common to them all is an attack by one’s own immune system against the body, causing damage to joints, connective tissue or to almost any organ, whether it be the eyes, the nerves, the skin, the intestines, the liver or the brain. In scleroderma (from the Greek word meaning “hardened skin”), the immune system’s suicidal assault results in a stiffening of the skin, esophagus, heart and tissues in the lungs and elsewhere.

雷诺氏症可单独发生，也可伴随其他疾病出现。吸烟者风险更高，而玛丽从青少年时期就一直是重度烟民。我希望她戒烟后，手指的血液循环就能恢复正常。经过多次复发，她最终成功戒烟。不幸的是，雷诺氏症预示着更严重的疾病：玛丽被诊断出患有硬皮病，这是一种自身免疫性疾病，包括类风湿性关节炎、溃疡性结肠炎、系统性红斑狼疮（SLE）以及许多其他并非总是被认为是自身免疫性疾病的疾病，例如糖尿病、多发性硬化症，甚至可能还有阿尔茨海默病。这些疾病的共同点是自身免疫系统攻击自身组织，导致关节、结缔组织或几乎任何器官受损，无论是眼睛、神经、皮肤、肠道、肝脏还是大脑。硬皮病（源自希腊语，意为“硬化的皮肤”）中，免疫系统的自杀式攻击导致皮肤、食道、心脏以及肺部和其他部位的组织变硬。

What creates this civil war inside the body?

是什么引发了体内的这场内战？

Medical textbooks take an exclusively biological view. In a few isolated cases, toxins are mentioned as causative factors, but for the most part a genetic predisposition is assumed to be largely responsible. Medical practice reflects this narrowly physical mindset. Neither the specialists nor I as her family doctor had ever thought to consider what in Mary’s particular experiences might also have contributed to her illness. None of us expressed curiosity about her psychological state before the onset of the disease, or how this influenced its course and final outcome. We simply treated each of her physical symptoms as they presented themselves: medications for inflammation and pain, operations to remove gangrenous tissue and to improve blood supply, physiotherapy to restore mobility.

医学教科书完全从生物学角度出发。虽然在少数个案中，毒素被提及为致病因素，但大多数情况下，遗传易感性被认为是主要原因。医疗实践也反映了这种狭隘的生理思维。无论是专科医生还是作为她家庭医生的我，都从未想过玛丽的个人经历中还有哪些因素可能导致了她的疾病。我们都没有对她发病前的心理状态，以及这种状态如何影响疾病的进程和最终结果表示过任何好奇。我们只是针对她出现的每一个生理症状进行治疗：服用消炎止痛药，进行手术切除坏疽组织并改善血液供应，以及进行物理治疗以恢复活动能力。

One day, almost on a whim, in response to a whisper of intuition that she needed to be heard, I invited Mary to make an hour-long appointment so that she would have the opportunity to tell me something about herself and her life. When she began to talk, it was a revelation. Beneath her meek and diffident manner was a vast store of repressed emotion. Mary had been abused as a child, abandoned and shuttled from one foster home to another. She recalled huddling in the attic at the age of seven, cradling her younger sisters in her arms, while her drunken foster parents fought and yelled below. “I was so scared all the time,” she said, “but as a seven-year-old I had to protect my sisters. And no one protected me.” She had never revealed these traumas before, not even to her husband of twenty years. She had learned not to express her feelings about anything to anyone, including herself. To be self-expressive, vulnerable and questioning in her childhood would have put her at risk. Her security lay in considering other people’s feelings, never her own. She was trapped in the role forced on her as a child, unaware that she herself had the right to be taken care of, to be listened to, to be thought worthy of attention.

有一天，几乎是出于一时兴起，或许是出于一种直觉——她需要被倾听——我邀请玛丽和我预约一个小时的会面，让她有机会向我讲述她自己和她的生活。当她开始讲述时，我恍然大悟。在她温顺腼腆的外表下，隐藏着大量被压抑的情感。玛丽童年时期遭受虐待，被遗弃，辗转于各个寄养家庭。她回忆起七岁那年，自己蜷缩在阁楼里，怀抱着年幼的妹妹们，而楼下醉醺醺的养父母则在争吵叫喊。“我一直都很害怕，”她说，“但作为一个七岁的孩子，我必须保护我的妹妹们。而没有人保护我。”她从未向任何人透露过这些创伤，甚至对结婚二十年的丈夫也从未提及。她学会了不向任何人表达自己的感受，包括她自己。在童年时期，表达自我、袒露脆弱、质疑一切都会让她身处险境。她的安全感来自于顾及他人的感受，而非自己的感受。她被困在童年时期被强加的角色中，全然不知自己也有权利被照顾、被倾听、被重视。

Mary described herself as being incapable of saying no, compulsively taking responsibility for the needs of others. Her major concern continued to be her husband and her nearly adult children, even as her illness became more grave. Was the scleroderma her body’s way of finally rejecting this all-encompassing dutifulness?

玛丽形容自己无法说“不”，总是不由自主地承担起照顾他人的责任。即使病情日益加重，她最关心的仍然是丈夫和即将成年的孩子们。硬皮病是不是她身体最终拒绝这种无所不包的责任感的一种方式呢？

Perhaps her body was doing what her mind could not: throwing off the relentless expectation that had been first imposed on the child and now was self-imposed in the adult—placing others above herself. I suggested as much when I wrote about Mary in my very first article as medical columnist for The Globe and Mail in 1993. “When we have been prevented from learning how to say no,” I wrote, “our bodies may end up saying it for us.” I cited some of the medical literature discussing the negative effects of stress on the immune system.

或许她的身体做到了她头脑无法做到的事：摆脱了最初强加于孩童时期、如今又自我强加于成年的那种无情的期望——将他人置于自身之上。我在1993年为《环球邮报》撰写的第一篇医学专栏文章中就表达了类似的观点，当时我写到玛丽的案例。“当我们被剥夺了说‘不’的权利时，”我写道，“我们的身体最终可能会替我们说‘不’。”我引用了一些医学文献，探讨了压力对免疫系统的负面影响。

The idea that people’s emotional coping style can be a factor in scleroderma or other chronic conditions is anathema to some physicians. A rheumatic diseases specialist at a major Canadian hospital submitted a scathing letter to the editor denouncing both my article and the newspaper for printing it. I was inexperienced, she charged, and had done no research.

认为人们的情绪应对方式可能是硬皮病或其他慢性疾病的诱因，这种观点令一些医生难以接受。加拿大一家大型医院的风湿病专家给我的文章以及刊登该文章的报社写了一封措辞严厉的信。她指责我缺乏经验，也没有做任何研究。

That a specialist would dismiss the link between body and mind was not astonishing. Dualism—cleaving into two that which is one—colours all our beliefs on health and illness. We attempt to understand the body in isolation from the mind. We want to describe human beings—healthy or otherwise—as though they function in isolation from the environment in which they develop, live, work, play, love and die. These are the built-in, hidden biases of the medical orthodoxy that most physicians absorb during their training and carry into their practice.

专家否认身心联系并不令人惊讶。二元论——将一体的事物割裂成二元——影响着我们对健康和疾病的所有认知。我们试图将身体与心灵割裂开来理解。我们想要描述人类——无论健康与否——仿佛他们脱离了自身成长、生活、工作、娱乐、恋爱和死亡的环境。这些都是医学正统观念中固有的、隐蔽的偏见，大多数医生在接受培训期间都会吸收这些偏见，并将其带入临床实践中。

Unlike many other disciplines, medicine has yet to assimilate an important lesson of Einstein’s theory of relativity: that the position of an observer will influence the phenomenon being observed and affect the results of the observation. The unexamined assumptions of the scientist both determine and limit what he or she will discover, as the pioneering Czech-Canadian stress researcher Hans Selye pointed out. “Most people do not fully realize to what extent the spirit of scientific research and the lessons learned from it depend upon the personal viewpoints of the discoverers,” he wrote in The Stress of Life . “In an age so largely dependent upon science and scientists, this fundamental point deserves special attention.” 1 In that honest and self-revealing assessment Selye, himself a physician, expressed a truth that even now, a quarter century later, few people grasp.

与其他许多学科不同，医学界尚未充分理解爱因斯坦相对论的一个重要教训：观察者的位置会影响被观察的现象，进而影响观察结果。正如捷克裔加拿大压力研究先驱汉斯·塞利所指出的，科学家未经检验的假设既决定又限制了他们的发现。他在《生活压力》一书中写道：“大多数人并没有充分意识到科学研究的精神及其所汲取的经验教训在多大程度上取决于发现者的个人观点。在一个如此依赖科学和科学家的时代，这一基本观点值得特别关注。”塞利本人也是一名医生，他在这段坦诚而又自省的评价中表达了一个真理，即使在四分之一世纪后的今天，也很少有人真正理解。

The more specialized doctors become, the more they know about a body part or organ and the less they tend to understand the human being in whom that part or organ resides. The people I interviewed for this book reported nearly unanimously that neither their specialists nor their family doctors had ever invited them to explore the personal, subjective content of their lives. If anything, they felt that such a dialogue was discouraged in most of their contacts with the medical profession. In talking with my specialist colleagues about these very same patients, I found that even after many years of treating a person, a doctor could remain quite in the dark about the patient’s life and experience outside the narrow boundaries of illness.

医生越是专精某一领域，就越了解身体的某个部位或器官，却往往越不了解居住于其中的那个人。我为本书采访的人几乎一致表示，他们的专科医生和家庭医生从未邀请他们探讨过生活中那些个人化的、主观的内容。相反，他们感觉在与医疗界的接触中，这种对话往往是不被鼓励的。在与我的专科同事讨论这些病人时，我发现，即使治疗病人多年，医生也可能对病人疾病之外的生活和经历知之甚少。

In this volume I set out to write about the effects of stress on health, particularly of the hidden stresses we all generate from our early programming, a pattern so deep and so subtle that it feels like a part of our real selves. Although I have presented as much of the available scientific evidence as seemed reasonable in a work for the lay public, the heart of the book—for me, at least—is formed by the individual histories I have been able to share with the readers. It so happens that those histories will also be seen as the least persuasive to those who regard such evidence as “anecdotal.”

在这本书中，我着手探讨压力对健康的影响，尤其关注我们每个人从早期经历中产生的隐性压力——这种模式根深蒂固、不易察觉，仿佛已成为我们真实自我的一部分。尽管我已尽可能地在面向普通读者的作品中呈现了现有的科学证据，但对我而言，本书的核心在于我与读者分享的个人经历。然而，对于那些将此类证据视为“轶事”的人来说，这些个人经历恰恰是最缺乏说服力的。

Only an intellectual Luddite would deny the enormous benefits that have accrued to humankind from the scrupulous application of scientific methods. But not all essential information can be confirmed in the laboratory or by statistical analysis. Not all aspects of illness can be reduced to facts verified by double-blind studies and by the strictest scientific techniques. “Medicine tells us as much about the meaningful performance of healing, suffering and dying as chemical analysis tells us about the aesthetic value of pottery,” Ivan Ilyich wrote in Limits to Medicine . We confine ourselves to a narrow realm indeed if we exclude from accepted knowledge the contributions of human experience and insight.

只有思想保守的卢德分子才会否认严谨运用科学方法给人类带来的巨大益处。然而，并非所有关键信息都能在实验室或通过统计分析得到证实。并非所有疾病的方方面面都能被简化为经双盲研究和最严格的科学技术验证的事实。“医学告诉我们关于治愈、痛苦和死亡的意义，正如化学分析告诉我们关于陶器的审美价值一样，”伊万·伊里奇在《医学的局限》一书中写道。如果我们把人类经验和洞察力的贡献排除在公认的知识之外，我们无疑会将自己局限于一个狭隘的领域。

We have lost something. In 1892 the Canadian William Osler, one of the greatest physicians of all time, suspected rheumatoid arthritis—a condition related to scleroderma—to be a stress-related disorder. Today rheumatology all but ignores that wisdom, despite the supporting scientific evidence accumulated in the 110 years since Osler first published his text. That is where the narrow scientific approach has brought the practice of medicine. In elevating modern science to be the final arbiter of our sufferings, we have been too eager to discard the insights of previous ages.

我们失去了一些东西。1892年，加拿大医生威廉·奥斯勒（William Osler）——有史以来最伟大的医生之一——怀疑类风湿性关节炎（一种与硬皮病相关的疾病）是一种应激性疾病。如今，风湿病学几乎完全忽视了这一智慧，尽管自奥斯勒首次发表其著作以来的110年间，积累了大量的科学证据来支持这一观点。这就是狭隘的科学方法将医学实践引向何方。我们过分高举现代科学，将其奉为解决我们痛苦的最终仲裁者，却急于抛弃前人的真知灼见。

As the American psychologist Ross Buck has pointed out, until the advent of modern medical technology and of scientific pharmacology, physicians traditionally had to rely on “placebo” effects. They had to inspire in each patient a confidence in his, the patient’s, inner ability to heal. To be effective, a doctor had to listen to the patient, to develop a relationship with him, and he had also to trust his own intuitions. Those are the qualities doctors seem to have lost as we have come to rely almost exclusively on “objective” measures, technology-based diagnostic methods and “scientific” cures.

正如美国心理学家罗斯·巴克所指出的，在现代医学技术和科学药理学出现之前，医生传统上不得不依赖“安慰剂效应”。他们必须激发每位患者对自身内在自愈能力的信心。为了有效治疗，医生必须倾听患者的心声，与患者建立良好的关系，并且还要相信自己的直觉。而随着我们几乎完全依赖“客观”指标、基于技术的诊断方法和“科学”疗法，这些品质似乎已被医生们所丧失。

Thus the rebuke from the rheumatologist was not a surprise. More of a jolt was another letter to the editor, a few days later—this time a supportive one—from Noel B. Hershfield, clinical professor of medicine at the University of Calgary: “The new discipline of psychoneuroimmunology has now matured to the point where there is compelling evidence, advanced by scientists from many fields, that an intimate relationship exists between the brain and the immune system…. An individual’s emotional makeup, and the response to continued stress, may indeed be causative in the many diseases that medicine treats but whose [origin] is not yet known—diseases such as scleroderma, and the vast majority of rheumatic disorders, the inflammatory bowel disorders, diabetes, multiple sclerosis, and legions of other conditions which are represented in each medical subspecialty….”

因此，风湿病学家的斥责并不令人意外。几天后，卡尔加里大学临床医学教授诺埃尔·B·赫什菲尔德（Noel B. Hershfield）给编辑写了一封信，这次是一封支持信，这封信写道：“心理神经免疫学这门新兴学科如今已发展成熟，许多领域的科学家都提出了令人信服的证据，表明大脑和免疫系统之间存在着密切的联系……个体的情绪构成以及对持续压力的反应，可能确实是许多医学上治疗但病因不明的疾病的致病因素——例如硬皮病、绝大多数风湿性疾病、炎症性肠病、糖尿病、多发性硬化症以及各个医学亚专科中涉及的众多其他疾病……”

The surprising revelation in this letter was the existence of a new field of medicine. What is psychoneuroimmunology? As I learned, it is no less than the science of the interactions of mind and body, the indissoluble unity of emotions and physiology in human development and throughout life in health and illness. That dauntingly complicated word means simply that this discipline studies the ways that the psyche—the mind and its content of emotions—profoundly interacts with the body’s nervous system and how both of them, in turn, form an essential link with our immune defences. Some have called this new field psychoneuroimmunoendocrinology to indicate that the endocrine, or hormonal, apparatus is also a part of our system of whole-body response. Innovative research is uncovering just how these links function all the way down to the cellular level. We are discovering the scientific basis of what we have known before and have forgotten, to our great loss.

这封信中最令人惊讶的发现是，它揭示了一个全新的医学领域。什么是心理神经免疫学？正如我所了解的，它正是研究身心互动、情感与生理在人类发展和生命历程中（无论健康还是疾病）不可分割的统一性的科学。这个看似复杂的词汇其实很简单，它研究的是心理——包括心灵及其情感内容——如何与身体的神经系统进行深刻的互动，以及二者如何反过来与我们的免疫防御系统形成至关重要的联系。有人将这个新领域称为心理神经免疫内分泌学，以表明内分泌系统（或激素系统）也是我们全身反应系统的一部分。创新性的研究正在揭示这些联系在细胞层面上的运作机制。我们正在重新发现那些我们曾经知道却又遗忘的知识的科学基础，而这无疑是我们的一大损失。

Many doctors over the centuries came to understand that emotions are deeply implicated in the causation of illness or in the restoration of health. They did research, wrote books and challenged the reigning medical ideology, but repeatedly their ideas, explorations and insights vanished in a sort of medical Bermuda Triangle. The understanding of the mind-body connection achieved by previous generations of doctors and scientists disappeared without a trace, as if it had never seen daylight.

几个世纪以来，许多医生逐渐认识到，情绪与疾病的发生和健康的恢复密切相关。他们进行研究、著书立说，挑战当时盛行的医学理论，但他们的思想、探索和洞见却一次又一次地消失在医学界的“百慕大三角”中。前几代医生和科学家对身心联系的理解，仿佛从未面世一般，彻底湮没无闻。

A 1985 editorial in the august New England Journal of Medicine could declare with magisterial self-assurance that “it is time to acknowledge that our belief in disease as a direct reflection of mental state is largely folklore.” 2

1985年，权威医学期刊《新英格兰医学杂志》的一篇社论以权威的自信宣称：“是时候承认，我们认为疾病直接反映精神状态的观点很大程度上是民间传说了。”

Such dismissals are no longer tenable. Psychoneuroimmunology, the new science Dr. Hershfield mentioned in his letter to the The Globe and Mail , has come into its own, even if its insights have yet to penetrate the world of medical practice.

这种轻蔑之词已不再站得住脚。赫什菲尔德博士在致《环球邮报》的信中提到的这门新兴科学——心理神经免疫学——已经发展成熟，即便其洞见尚未完全渗透到医学实践领域。

A cursory visit to medical libraries or to online sites is enough to show the advancing tide of research papers, journal articles and textbooks discussing the new knowledge. Information has filtered down to many people in popular books and magazines. The lay public, ahead of the professionals in many ways and less shackled to old orthodoxies, finds it less threatening to accept that we cannot be divided up so easily and that the whole wondrous human organism is more than simply the sum of its parts.

只需粗略浏览一下医学图书馆或网站，就能发现大量研究论文、期刊文章和教科书都在探讨新的知识。这些信息也通过大众书籍和杂志传播到许多人手中。在许多方面领先于专业人士，且较少受旧观念束缚的普通大众，更容易接受“我们并非如此轻易地被分割开来，整个奇妙的人体远非各部分之和”这一观点。

Our immune system does not exist in isolation from daily experience. For example, the immune defences that normally function in healthy young people have been shown to be suppressed in medical students under the pressure of final examinations. Of even greater implication for their future health and well-being, the loneliest students suffered the greatest negative impact on their immune systems. Loneliness has been similarly associated with diminished immune activity in a group of psychiatric inpatients. Even if no further research evidence existed—though there is plenty—one would have to consider the long-term effects of chronic stress. The pressure of examinations is obvious and short term, but many people unwittingly spend their entire lives as if under the gaze of a powerful and judgmental examiner whom they must please at all costs. Many of us live, if not alone, then in emotionally inadequate relationships that do not recognize or honour our deepest needs. Isolation and stress affect many who may believe their lives are quite satisfactory.

我们的免疫系统并非独立于日常经验而存在。例如，研究表明，在医学生期末考试的压力下，原本在健康年轻人体内正常运作的免疫防御机制会受到抑制。更重要的是，孤独感最强的学生，其免疫系统受到的负面影响最大，这将对他们未来的健康和福祉产生深远的影响。同样，在一组精神科住院患者中，孤独感也与免疫活性降低有关。即使没有进一步的研究证据——尽管相关研究已经很多——我们也必须考虑慢性压力的长期影响。考试的压力显而易见且是短暂的，但许多人却在不知不觉中终其一生都生活在一位强大而苛刻的考官的注视之下，他们必须不惜一切代价取悦这位考官。我们中的许多人，即便不是独居，也生活在情感上不健全的关系中，这些关系无法理解或尊重我们最深层的需求。孤独和压力会影响许多自认为生活相当令人满意的人。

How may stress be transmuted into illness? Stress is a complicated cascade of physical and biochemical responses to powerful emotional stimuli. Physiologically, emotions are themselves electrical, chemical and hormonal discharges of the human nervous system. Emotions influence—and are influenced by—the functioning of our major organs, the integrity of our immune defences and the workings of the many circulating biological substances that help govern the body’s physical states. When emotions are repressed, as Mary had to do in her childhood search for security, this inhibition disarms the body’s defences against illness. Repression—dissociating emotions from awareness and relegating them to the unconscious realm—disorganizes and confuses our physiological defences so that in some people these defences go awry, becoming the destroyers of health rather than its protectors.

压力如何转化为疾病？压力是对强烈的情绪刺激产生的一系列复杂的生理和生化反应。从生理学角度来看，情绪本身就是人体神经系统释放的电信号、化学物质和激素。情绪会影响——同时也会受到——我们主要器官的功能、免疫防御的完整性以及众多循环生物物质的运作，这些物质共同调节着身体的生理状态。当情绪被压抑时，就像玛丽在童年时期为了寻求安全感而不得不做的那样，这种抑制会削弱身体对疾病的防御能力。压抑——将情绪从意识中分离出来，并将其置于无意识领域——会扰乱和混乱我们的生理防御机制，以至于在某些人身上，这些防御机制会失灵，反而成为健康的破坏者而非保护者。

During the seven years I was medical coordinator of the Palliative Care Unit at Vancouver Hospital, I saw many patients with chronic illness whose emotional histories resembled Mary’s. Similar dynamics and ways of coping were present in the people who came to us for palliation with cancers or degenerative neurological processes like amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS, also known in North America as Lou Gehrig’s disease, after the great American baseball player who succumbed to it, and in Britain as motor neuron disease.) In my private family practice, I observed these same patterns in people I treated for multiple sclerosis, inflammatory ailments of the bowel such as ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease, chronic fatigue syndrome, autoimmune disorders, fibromyalgia, migraine, skin disorders, endometriosis and many other conditions. In important areas of their lives, almost none of my patients with serious disease had ever learned to say no. If some people’s personalities and circumstances appeared very different from Mary’s on the surface, the underlying emotional repression was an ever-present factor.

在温哥华医院姑息治疗科担任医疗协调员的七年间，我接触过许多慢性病患者，他们的情感经历与玛丽的相似。那些因癌症或退行性神经系统疾病（如肌萎缩侧索硬化症 (ALS)，在北美也被称为卢伽雷氏症，以纪念因该病去世的美国棒球巨星卢·格里克；在英国则被称为运动神经元疾病）前来接受姑息治疗的患者，也展现出类似的心理动态和应对方式。在我的私人家庭诊所里，我也观察到同样的模式，这些患者包括多发性硬化症、溃疡性结肠炎和克罗恩病等肠道炎症性疾病、慢性疲劳综合征、自身免疫性疾病、纤维肌痛、偏头痛、皮肤病、子宫内膜异位症以及其他许多疾病的患者。在他们生活的重要领域，几乎所有身患重病的患者都从未学会说“不”。如果某些人的性格和境遇表面上看起来与玛丽截然不同，那么潜在的情感压抑始终是一个重要因素。

One of the terminally ill patients under my care was a middle-aged man, chief executive of a company that marketed shark cartilage as a treatment for cancer. By the time he was admitted to our unit, his own recently diagnosed cancer had spread throughout his body. He continued to eat shark cartilage almost to the day of his death, but not because he any longer believed in its value. It smelled foul—the offensive stench was noticeable even some distance away—and I could only imagine what it tasted like. “I hate it,” he told me, “but my business partner would be so disappointed if I stopped.” I convinced him that he had every right to live his last days without feeling responsible for someone else’s disappointment.

我照料的一位绝症患者是一位中年男子，他是一家销售鲨鱼软骨作为癌症疗法的公司的首席执行官。他入院时，自己新确诊的癌症已经扩散到全身。他几乎一直吃鲨鱼软骨，直到去世前一天，但这并非因为他不再相信它的疗效。鲨鱼软骨气味难闻——即使隔着一段距离也能闻到那股令人作呕的恶臭——我只能想象它的味道。“我讨厌它，”他告诉我，“但如果我不吃了，我的合伙人会非常失望的。”我劝服他，他完全有权利安享晚年，不必为别人的失望而感到愧疚。

It is a sensitive matter to raise the possibility that the way people have been conditioned to live their lives may contribute to their illness. The connections between behaviour and subsequent disease are obvious in the case of, say, smoking and lung cancer—except perhaps to tobacco-industry executives. But such links are harder to prove when it comes to emotions and the emergence of multiple sclerosis or cancer of the breast or arthritis. In addition to being stricken with disease, the patient feels blamed for being the very person she is. “Why are you writing this book?” said a fifty-two-year-old university professor who has been treated for breast cancer. In a voice edged with anger she told me, “I got cancer because of my genes, not because of anything I did.”

提出人们的生活方式可能导致疾病的可能性，这是一个敏感的话题。行为与疾病之间的联系显而易见，例如吸烟与肺癌——或许烟草业高管们对此并不知情。但当涉及到情绪与多发性硬化症、乳腺癌或关节炎的发生时，这种联系就难以证实了。除了疾病本身带来的痛苦，患者还会因为自己的身份而感到自责。“你为什么要写这本书？”一位曾接受过乳腺癌治疗的52岁大学教授问道。她语气中带着一丝愤怒，告诉我：“我得癌症是因为我的基因，而不是因为我做了什么。”

“The view of sickness and death as a personal failure is a particularly unfortunate form of blaming the victim,” charged the 1985 editorial in the New England Journal of Medicine . “At a time when patients are already burdened by disease, they should not be further burdened by having to accept responsibility for the outcome.”

1985年《新英格兰医学杂志》的一篇社论指出：“将疾病和死亡视为个人失败是一种特别不幸的责备受害者的形式。在患者已经饱受疾病折磨的当下，他们不应该再因为要承担后果的责任而雪上加霜。”

We will return to this vexing question of assumed blame. Here I will only remark that blame and failure are not the issue. Such terms only cloud the picture. As we shall see, blaming the sufferer—apart from being morally obtuse—is completely unfounded from a scientific point of view.

我们将再次探讨这个令人困扰的“推定责任”问题。在此我只想指出，责任和失败并非问题的关键所在。这些词汇只会混淆视听。正如我们将看到的，责怪受害者——除了在道德上愚昧无知之外——从科学的角度来看也完全没有根据。

The NEJM editorial confused blame and responsibility. While all of us dread being blamed , we all would wish to be more responsible —that is, to have the ability to respond with awareness to the circumstances of our lives rather than just reacting. We want to be the authoritative person in our own lives: in charge, able to make the authentic decisions that affect us. There is no true responsibility without awareness. One of the weaknesses of the Western medical approach is that we have made the physician the only authority, with the patient too often a mere recipient of the treatment or cure. People are deprived of the opportunity to become truly responsible. None of us are to be blamed if we succumb to illness and death. Any one of us might succumb at any time, but the more we can learn about ourselves, the less prone we are to become passive victims.

《新英格兰医学杂志》的社论混淆了责备和责任。虽然我们都害怕被责备，但我们都希望自己更有责任感——也就是说，能够有意识地应对生活中的各种境遇，而不是仅仅被动反应。我们渴望成为自己人生的主导者：掌控一切，能够做出真正影响自身的决定。没有意识，就没有真正的责任。西方医学的弊端之一在于，我们赋予了医生唯一的权威，而患者往往只是治疗或治愈的接受者。人们因此失去了真正承担责任的机会。如果我们最终因疾病或死亡而倒下，我们任何人都不应该受到责备。我们每个人都可能在任何时候倒下，但我们越了解自己，就越不容易成为被动的受害者。

Mind and body links have to be seen not only for our understanding of illness but also for our understanding of health. Dr. Robert Maunder, on the psychiatric faculty of the University of Toronto, has written about the mind-body interface in disease. “Trying to identify and to answer the question of stress,” he said to me in an interview, “is more likely to lead to health than ignoring the question.” In healing, every bit of information, every piece of the truth, may be crucial. If a link exists between emotions and physiology, not to inform people of it will deprive them of a powerful tool.

我们必须认识到身心之间的联系，这不仅关系到我们对疾病的理解，也关系到我们对健康的理解。多伦多大学精神病学系的罗伯特·蒙德博士曾撰文探讨疾病中的身心互动。他在一次采访中对我说：“尝试识别并解答压力问题，比忽视这个问题更有可能带来健康。” 在康复过程中，每一条信息，每一段真相，都可能至关重要。如果情绪与生理之间存在联系，那么不告知人们这种联系，就等于剥夺了他们一种强大的工具。

And here we confront the inadequacy of language. Even to speak about links between mind and body is to imply that two discrete entities are somehow connected to each other. Yet in life there is no such separation; there is no body that is not mind, no mind that is not body. The word mindbody has been suggested to convey the real state of things.

而这正是语言的局限性所在。即便只是谈论身心之间的联系，也意味着两个截然不同的实体之间存在某种关联。然而，在生活中，这种分离并不存在；没有脱离心灵的身体，也没有脱离身体的心灵。“身心”一词被提出，旨在更准确地表达事物的真实状态。

Not even in the West is mind-body thinking completely new. In one of Plato’s dialogues, Socrates quotes a Thracian doctor’s criticism of his Greek colleagues: “This is the reason why the cure of so many diseases is unknown to the physicians of Hellas; they are ignorant of the whole. For this is the great error of our day in the treatment of the human body, that physicians separate the mind from the body.” 3 You cannot split mind from body, said Socrates—nearly two and a half millennia before the advent of psychoneuroimmunoendocrinology!

即使在西方，身心合一的理念也并非完全是新事物。在柏拉图的一篇对话录中，苏格拉底引用了一位色雷斯医生对其希腊同行的批评：“这就是为什么希腊的医生们不知道如何治愈这么多疾病的原因；他们对整体一无所知。因为这是我们今天在治疗人体方面的最大错误，医生们将身心割裂开来。” 3 苏格拉底说，身心是无法分离的——这比心理神经免疫内分泌学的出现早了近两千五百年！

Writing When the Body Says No has done more than simply confirm some of the insights I first articulated in my article about Mary’s scleroderma. I have learned a great deal and have come to appreciate deeply the work of hundreds of physicians, scientists, psychologists and researchers who have charted the previously unmapped terrain of mind-body. Work on this book has also been an inner exploration of the ways I have repressed my own emotions. I was prompted to make this personal journey in response to a question from a counsellor at the British Columbia Cancer Agency, where I had gone to investigate the role of emotional repression in cancer. In many people with malignancy, there seemed to be an automatic denial of psychic or physical pain and of uncomfortable emotions like anger, sadness or rejection. “Just what is your personal connection to the issue?” the counsellor asked me. “What draws you to this particular topic?”

写作《当身体说不》这本书，不仅仅印证了我最初在关于玛丽硬皮病的文章中提出的一些见解。我从中获益匪浅，也更加深刻地体会到数百位医生、科学家、心理学家和研究人员的辛勤工作，他们探索了身心这一此前未知的领域。创作这本书的过程，也是一次自我反思，审视我压抑自身情绪的方式。促使我踏上这段个人旅程的，是卑诗省癌症中心一位咨询师提出的问题。当时我去那里是为了调查情绪压抑在癌症中的作用。许多恶性肿瘤患者似乎都会下意识地否认精神或身体上的痛苦，以及诸如愤怒、悲伤或被拒绝等令人不适的情绪。“你与这个问题有何个人联系？”咨询师问我，“是什么吸引你关注这个话题？”

The question brought to mind an incident from seven years ago. One evening I arrived to see my seventy-six-year-old mother at the nursing home where she was a resident. She had progressive muscular dystrophy, an inherited muscle-wasting disease that runs in our family. Unable to even sit up without assistance, she could no longer live at home. Her three sons and their families visited her regularly until her death, which occurred just as I began to write this book.

这个问题让我想起七年前的一件事。一天晚上，我去养老院探望我七十六岁的母亲。她患有进行性肌营养不良症，这是一种家族遗传的肌肉萎缩症。她甚至无法独立坐起，已经无法在家生活。她的三个儿子和他们的家人定期去看望她，直到她去世——而她去世的时候，正是我开始写这本书的时候。

I had a slight limp as I walked down the nursing home corridor. That morning I had undergone surgery for a torn cartilage in my knee, a consequence of ignoring what my body had been telling me in the language of pain that occurred each time I jogged on cement. As I opened the door to my mother’s room, I automatically walked with a nonchalant, normal gait to her bed to greet her. The impulse to hide the limp was not conscious, and the act was done before I was aware of it. Only later did I wonder what exactly had prompted such an unnecessary measure—unnecessary because my mother would have calmly accepted that her fifty-one-year-old son would have a gimpy knee twelve hours post-surgery.

我沿着养老院走廊走着，一瘸一拐的。那天早上我做了膝盖软骨撕裂的手术，这都是因为我忽略了身体发出的疼痛信号——每次在水泥地上慢跑都会感到疼痛。打开母亲房间的门，我下意识地迈着正常、漫不经心的步伐走到她的床边，向她问好。想要掩饰跛行的冲动并非出于意识，而是在我意识到之前就已经完成了。直到后来我才明白，究竟是什么促使我做了这样一件完全没必要的事情——说它没必要，是因为我母亲肯定会平静地接受她51岁的儿子在术后12个小时膝盖有点跛的事实。

So what had happened? My automatic impulse to protect my mother from my pain, even in such an innocuous situation, was a deeply programmed reflex that had little to do with the present needs of either of us. That repression was a memory—a re-enactment of a dynamic that had been etched into my developing brain before I could possibly have been aware of it.

那么究竟发生了什么？即使在如此无关紧要的情况下，我保护母亲免受痛苦的本能冲动，也是一种根深蒂固的反射，与我们俩当下的需求几乎毫无关系。这种压抑是一种记忆——一种在我发育中的大脑中刻画的动态的重现，那时我根本不可能意识到它的存在。

I am both a survivor and a child of the Nazi genocide, having lived most of my first year in Budapest under Nazi occupation. My maternal grandparents were killed in Auschwitz when I was five months old; my aunt had also been deported and was unheard from; and my father was in a forced labour battalion in the service of the German and Hungarian armies. My mother and I barely survived our months in the Budapest ghetto. For a few weeks she had to part from me as the only way of saving me from sure death by starvation or disease. No great powers of imagination are required to understand that in her state of mind, and under the inhuman stresses she was facing daily, my mother was rarely up to the tender smiles and undivided attention a developing infant requires to imprint a sense of security and unconditional love in his mind. My mother, in fact, told me that on many days her despair was such that only the need to care for me motivated her to get up from bed. I learned early that I had to work for attention, to burden my mother as little as possible and that my anxiety and pain were best suppressed.

我既是纳粹种族灭绝的幸存者，也是纳粹种族灭绝的受害者，我出生后的第一年大部分时间都在纳粹占领下的布达佩斯度过。我的外祖父母在我五个月大的时候在奥斯维辛集中营遇难；我的姑姑也被驱逐出境，从此杳无音信；我的父亲则在德匈联军的强制劳动营服役。我和母亲在布达佩斯犹太区艰难地度过了几个月。有好几个星期，为了不让我饿死或染病，她不得不与我分离。不难想象，在她当时的精神状态和每天面对的非人压力下，我的母亲很少能像一个正在成长的婴儿那样，给予我温柔的微笑和全心全意的关注，而这些对于在他心中留下安全感和无条件的爱至关重要。事实上，我的母亲告诉我，很多时候，她绝望到只有照顾我的需要才能让她起床。我很早就明白，我必须努力才能获得关注，尽可能减少母亲的负担，而且最好压抑住我的焦虑和痛苦。

In healthy mother-infant interactions, the mother is able to nourish without the infant’s having in any way to work for what he receives. My mother was unable to provide that unconditional nourishing for me—and since she was neither saintly nor perfect, quite likely she would not have completely succeeded in doing so, even without the horrors that beset our family.

在健康的母婴互动中，母亲能够无条件地滋养婴儿，而婴儿无需付出任何努力。我的母亲无法给予我这种无条件的滋养——而且，由于她既非圣人也非完美，即便没有那些降临在我们家的苦难，她也未必能完全做到这一点。

It was under these circumstances that I became my mother’s protector—protecting her in the first instance against awareness of my own pain. What began as the automatic defensive coping of the infant soon hardened into a fixed personality pattern that, fifty-one years later, still caused me to hide even my slightest physical discomfort in front of my mother.

正是在这种情况下，我成了母亲的守护者——首先是为了保护她，不让她察觉到我自身的痛苦。这种最初作为婴儿本能的防御机制，很快便固化成一种固定的性格模式，以至于五十一年后，我仍然会在母亲面前隐藏哪怕最轻微的身体不适。

I had not thought about the When the Body Says No project in those terms. This was to be an intellectual quest, to explore an interesting theory that would help explain human health and illness. It was a path others had trod before me, but there was always more to be discovered. The counsellor’s challenge made me confront the issue of emotional repression in my own life. My hidden limp, I realized, was only one small example.

我之前从未从这个角度思考过“当身体说不”这个项目。它原本是一次智力探索，旨在研究一个有趣的理论，以解释人类的健康与疾病。这条路前人已走过，但总有更多东西等待我去发现。咨询师的挑战让我直面自己生活中的情感压抑问题。我意识到，我隐匿的跛行只是其中的一个小例子。

Thus, in writing this book, I describe not only what I have learned from others or from professional journals but also what I have observed in myself. The dynamics of repression operate in all of us. We are all self-deniers and self-betrayers to one extent or another, most often in ways we are no more aware of than I was conscious of while “deciding” to disguise my limp. When it comes to health or illness, it is only a matter of degree and, too, a matter of the presence or absence of other factors—such as heredity or environmental hazards, for example—that also predispose to disease. So in demonstrating that repression is a major cause of stress and a significant contributor to illness, I do not point fingers at others for “making themselves sick.” My purpose in this book is to promote learning and healing, not to add to the quotient of blame and shame, both of which already exist in overabundance in our culture. Perhaps I am overly sensitized to the issue of blame, but then most people are. Shame is the deepest of the “negative emotions,” a feeling we will do almost anything to avoid. Unfortunately, our abiding fear of shame impairs our ability to see reality.

因此，在撰写本书的过程中，我不仅描述了我从他人或专业期刊中学到的知识，也描述了我自身的观察。压抑的机制存在于我们所有人身上。在某种程度上，我们都在否认和背叛自己，而且大多数时候，我们对此浑然不觉，就像我当初“决定”掩盖自己的跛脚时一样。就健康或疾病而言，这只是程度的问题，也取决于是否存在其他因素——例如遗传或环境危害——这些因素也会导致疾病。因此，在论证压抑是压力的主要原因和疾病的重要诱因时，我并非指责他人“自作自受”。我写这本书的目的是为了促进学习和疗愈，而不是加剧我们文化中已经泛滥的责备和羞耻感。或许我对责备这个问题过于敏感，但大多数人都是如此。羞耻感是最深层的“负面情绪”，我们几乎会不惜一切代价去避免它。不幸的是，我们对羞耻感根深蒂固的恐惧会削弱我们看清现实的能力。

Despite the best efforts of many physicians, Mary died in Vancouver Hospital eight years after her diagnosis, succumbing to the complications of scleroderma. To the end she retained her gentle smile, though her heart was weak and her breathing laboured. Every once in a while she would ask me to schedule long private visits, even in hospital during her final days. She just wanted to chat, about matters serious or trivial. “You are the only one who ever listened to me,” she once said.

尽管许多医生竭尽全力，玛丽在确诊八年后还是在温哥华医院去世了，死于硬皮病的并发症。直到生命的最后一刻，她依然保持着温柔的微笑，尽管她的心脏虚弱，呼吸也十分困难。她偶尔会让我安排长时间的私人探望，即使是在她生命的最后几天住院期间也是如此。她只是想和我聊聊天，聊聊大事小事。“你是唯一一个真正倾听我心声的人，”她曾这样说过。

I have wondered at times how Mary’s life might have turned out if someone had been there to hear, see and understand her when she was a small child—abused, frightened, feeling responsible for her little sisters. Perhaps had someone been there consistently and dependably, she could have learned to value herself, to express her feelings, to assert her anger when people invaded her boundaries physically or emotionally. Had that been her fate, would she still be alive?

我有时会想，如果玛丽小时候有人在她身边，倾听她、看到她、理解她——在她遭受虐待、恐惧、还要照顾年幼的妹妹们时——她的人生会是怎样一番景象。或许，如果有人始终如一、可靠地陪伴在她身边，她就能学会珍视自己，学会表达自己的感受，学会在别人侵犯她的身心界限时勇敢地表达自己的愤怒。如果这就是她的命运，她是否还能活到现在？

2
2
The Little Girl Too Good to Be True
完美得难以置信的小女孩

I T WOULD BE AN UNDERSTATEMENT to say that the spring and summer of 1996 was a stressful time in Natalie’s life. In March her sixteen-year-old son was discharged from a six-month stay at a drug rehabilitation facility. He had used drugs and alcohol for the previous two years and was repeatedly expelled from school. “We were lucky we got him into the residential treatment program,” says the fifty-three-year-old former nurse. “He had only been home a short while when first my husband was diagnosed, and then me.” In July her husband, Bill, underwent surgery for a malignant bowel tumour. After the operation they were told the cancer had spread to his liver.

1996年的春夏两季对娜塔莉来说无疑是一段充满压力的时期。三月，她十六岁的儿子结束了为期六个月的戒毒治疗出院。此前两年，他一直酗酒吸毒，屡次被学校开除。“我们很幸运能让他进入戒毒治疗中心，”这位五十三岁的前护士说道，“他回家没多久，我丈夫就被确诊患病，然后我也被确诊了。”七月，她的丈夫比尔接受了肠道恶性肿瘤手术。术后，医生告知他们癌细胞已经扩散到肝脏。

Natalie had suffered fatigue, dizziness and ringing in her ears from time to time, but her symptoms were of short duration and resolved without treatment. In the year before her diagnosis she had felt more tired than usual. A bout of vertigo in June led to a CT scan, with negative results. Two months later an MRI of Natalie’s brain showed the characteristic abnormalities associated with multiple sclerosis: focal areas of inflammation where myelin, the fatty tissue lining nerve cells, was damaged and scarred.

娜塔莉偶尔会感到疲倦、头晕和耳鸣，但这些症状持续时间很短，无需治疗即可自行缓解。在确诊前的一年里，她感觉比平时更容易疲劳。六月份的一次眩晕促使她做了CT扫描，结果呈阴性。两个月后，娜塔莉的脑部MRI检查显示出多发性硬化症的特征性异常：髓鞘（包裹神经细胞的脂肪组织）受损并形成瘢痕，导致局部炎症区域出现。

Multiple sclerosis (from the Greek, “to harden”) is the most common of the so-called demyelinating diseases that impair the functioning of cells in the central nervous system. Its symptoms depend on where the inflammation and scarring occur. The main areas attacked are usually the spinal cord, the brain stem and the optic nerve, which is the bundle of nerve fibres carrying visual information to the brain. If the site of damage is somewhere in the spinal cord, the symptoms will be numbness, pain or other unpleasant sensations in the limbs or trunk. There may also be involuntary tightening of the muscles or weakness. In the lower part of the brain, the loss of myelin can induce double vision or problems with speech or balance. Patients with optic neuritis—inflammation of the optic nerve—suffer temporary visual loss. Fatigue is a common symptom, a sense of overwhelming exhaustion far beyond ordinary tiredness.

多发性硬化症（源自希腊语，意为“硬化”）是最常见的脱髓鞘疾病之一，这类疾病会损害中枢神经系统细胞的功能。其症状取决于炎症和瘢痕发生的部位。主要受累区域通常是脊髓、脑干和视神经，视神经是将视觉信息传递到大脑的神经纤维束。如果损伤部位位于脊髓，则会出现四肢或躯干麻木、疼痛或其他不适感。也可能出现肌肉不自主紧绷或无力。在大脑下部，髓鞘的丢失会导致复视或言语或平衡障碍。视神经炎（视神经炎症）患者会出现暂时性视力丧失。疲劳是常见症状，表现为远超普通疲倦的极度疲惫感。

Natalie’s dizziness continued through the fall and early winter while she nursed her husband through his convalescence from the bowel operation and a twelve-week course of chemotherapy. For a while afterwards Bill was able to resume his work as a real estate agent. Then in May 1997 a second operation was performed to excise the tumours in his liver.

娜塔莉在整个秋季和初冬都饱受眩晕的困扰，她悉心照料丈夫比尔，帮助他从肠道手术和为期十二周的化疗中恢复过来。之后的一段时间里，比尔得以重返房地产经纪人的工作岗位。1997年5月，他接受了第二次手术，切除了肝脏中的肿瘤。

“Following the resection, in which they removed 75 per cent of his liver, Bill developed a blood clot in his portal vein. * He could have died from that,” says Natalie. “He became very confused and combative.” Bill died in 1999, but not before subjecting his wife to more emotional agony than she could have foreseen.

“比尔做了肝切除手术，切除了75%的肝脏，之后他的门静脉出现了血栓。他差点因此丧命，”娜塔莉说。“他变得神志不清，而且极具攻击性。”比尔于1999年去世，但在此之前，他给妻子带来的精神痛苦远超她的想象。

Researchers in Colorado looked at one hundred people with the type of MS called relapsing-remitting, in which flare-ups alternate with symptom-free periods. This is the type Natalie has. Patients burdened by qualitatively extreme stresses, such as major relationship difficulties or financial insecurity, were almost four times as likely to suffer exacerbations. 1

科罗拉多州的研究人员观察了100名患有复发缓解型多发性硬化症（MS）的患者，这种类型的MS的特点是症状反复发作与无症状期交替出现。娜塔莉就患有这种类型的MS。研究发现，承受极端压力（例如严重的人际关系问题或经济困境）的患者，病情加重的可能性几乎是其他患者的四倍。

“I was still having a lot of vertigo over Christmas of 1996, but after that I was almost 100 per cent,” Natalie reports. “Only my gait was a little off. And despite all the problems with Bill’s liver resection—I had to take him to the emergency ward four times between July and August—I was fine. It appeared Bill was turning around, and we were hopeful there would be no more complications. Then I had another exacerbation.” The flare-up came when Natalie thought she could relax a little, when her services were no longer urgently needed.

“1996年圣诞节期间，我仍然经常感到眩晕，但之后就几乎完全康复了，”娜塔莉回忆道。“只是走路有点不稳。尽管比尔的肝切除手术带来了很多问题——7月到8月间我不得不四次送他去急诊室——但我一切都好。比尔的病情似乎正在好转，我们希望不会再出现并发症。然而，我的病情却再次加重了。” 就在娜塔莉以为自己可以稍微放松一下，不再需要她提供紧急服务的时候，病情却突然复发了。

“My husband was the type of person who felt that he shouldn’t have to do anything he didn’t want to do. He was always like that. When he was sick, he just figured he was definitely not going to do anything. He would sit down on the sofa and snap his fingers—and when he snapped, you jumped. Even the kids were getting very impatient with him. Finally, in the fall, when he was better, I sent him out of town for a few days with some friends. I said, ‘He needs to get out.’”

“我丈夫是那种觉得任何他不想做的事都不应该做的人。他一直都是这样。生病的时候，他更是觉得什么都不想做。他会坐在沙发上打响指——他一打响指，你都会吓一跳。就连孩子们都对他很不耐烦。最后，到了秋天，他病情好转后，我让他和朋友们去外地玩几天。我说：‘他需要出去走走。’”

“What did you need?” I ask.

我问：“你需要什么？”

“I was fed up. I said, ‘Take him away to play some golf for a few days,’ and this friend came and picked him up. And two hours later I knew I was having an exacerbation.”

“我当时真是受够了。我说，‘带他出去打几天高尔夫吧’，然后这个朋友就来把他接走了。两个小时后，我就知道我的病情又加重了。”

What might she have learned from this experience? “Well,” Natalie says hesitantly, “that I need to know when to withdraw from my helping mode. But I just can’t; if somebody needs help, I have to do it.”

她从这次经历中学到了什么？“嗯，”娜塔莉犹豫地说，“我需要知道什么时候该停止助人。但我就是做不到；如果有人需要帮助，我就必须去做。”

“Regardless of what’s happening for you?”

“无论你遇到了什么事？”

“Yes. Five years down the road, and I still have not learned that I have to pace myself. My body says no to me frequently, and I keep going. I don’t learn.”

“是的。五年过去了，我仍然没有学会控制节奏。我的身体经常发出警告，但我还是继续坚持。我就是学不会。”

Natalie’s body had many reasons to say no throughout her marriage. Bill was a heavy drinker and often embarrassed her. “When he would have a little too much to drink, he became ugly,” she says. “He would be argumentative, aggressive, lose his temper. We would be out at a party, and if something upset him, he would tear strips off people in public, for no reason. I would just turn around and walk away, and then he would be angry with me for not supporting him. I knew within forty-eight hours of being diagnosed with MS that Bill would not be there for me.”

娜塔莉的身体在婚姻中有很多理由拒绝她。比尔酗酒成性，经常让她难堪。“他只要喝多了，就会变得很丑陋，”她说，“他会变得爱争吵、咄咄逼人、动不动就发脾气。我们出去参加聚会，如果有什么事让他不高兴，他就会当众无缘无故地把人骂个狗血淋头。我只能转身走开，然后他就会因为我没有支持他而生我的气。确诊多发性硬化症后不到48小时，我就知道比尔不会再陪在我身边了。”

Returning from his golfing vacation, Bill experienced some months of physical vigour. He engaged in a relationship with another woman, a friend of the family. “I thought, Look what I’ve done for you,” says Natalie. “I’ve jeopardized my own health. I was there for you all summer. You were at death’s door, and I sat for seventy-two hours in that hospital waiting to see if you were going to die or recover. I looked after you when you came home, and this is how I get paid back. I get kicked in the teeth.”

比尔打完高尔夫球回来后，身体恢复了几个月的活力。他和家里的一个朋友——另一个女人——发展出了恋情。“我当时想，看看我为你做了什么，”娜塔莉说，“我把自己的健康都置于危险之中。整个夏天我都陪着你。你当时命悬一线，我在医院里守了72个小时，等着看你是会死还是会康复。你回家后我也照顾你，结果这就是我的回报？我被狠狠地打了一顿。”

The idea that psychological stress increases the risk for multiple sclerosis is not new. The French neurologist Jean-Martin Charcot was first to give a full clinical description of multiple sclerosis. Patients, he reported in a lecture in 1868, connect “long continued grief or vexation” with the onset of symptoms. Five years later a British physician described a case also associated with stress: “Aetiologically it is important to mention another statement the poor creature made when giving a more confidential account to the nurse—that the cause of her disease was having caught her husband in bed with another woman.” 2

心理压力会增加患多发性硬化症风险的观点并非新观点。法国神经学家让-马丁·沙尔科(Jean-Martin Charcot)最早对多发性硬化症进行了完整的临床描述。他在1868年的一次讲座中指出，患者往往将“长期持续的悲伤或烦恼”与症状的出现联系起来。五年后，一位英国医生描述了一个同样与压力相关的病例：“从病因学角度来看，值得一提的是，这位可怜的病人在向护士更私密地讲述病情时还说过另一句话——她患病的原因是撞见丈夫与另一个女人同床共枕。”

For this book I interviewed nine people with MS, eight of them women. (About 60 per cent of those affected are women.) The emotional patterns illustrated in Natalie’s story are evident in each person, if not always as dramatically.

为了撰写这本书，我采访了九位多发性硬化症患者，其中八位是女性。（约60%的患者是女性。）娜塔莉的故事中所展现的情感模式在每位患者身上都有所体现，尽管并非总是像娜塔莉那样强烈。

The evidence gathered from my interviews is consistent with the published research. “Many students of this disease have voiced the clinical impression that emotional stress may be somehow implicated in the genesis of MS,” a research article noted in 1970. 3 Excessive emotional involvement with a parent, a lack of psychological independence, an overwhelming need for love and affection, and the inability to feel or express anger have long been identified by medical observers as possible factors in the natural development of the disease. A study in 1958 found that in nearly 90 per cent of cases, “before the onset of symptoms … patients experienced traumatic life events that had threatened their ‘security system.’” 4

我从访谈中收集到的证据与已发表的研究结果一致。一篇1970年的研究文章指出：“许多研究这种疾病的学生都表达了这样的临床印象：情绪压力可能与多发性硬化症的发生有关。” 3 医学观察家长期以来认为，对父母过度的情感投入、缺乏心理独立性、对爱和关怀的强烈需求以及无法感受或表达愤怒可能是该疾病自然发展的因素。1958年的一项研究发现，在近90%的病例中，“在症状出现之前……患者经历过威胁其‘安全系统’的创伤性生活事件。” 4

A study done in 1969 looked at the role of psychological processes in thirty-two patients from Israel and the United States. Eighty-five per cent of these MS patients experienced the emergence of symptoms that were subsequently diagnosed as multiple sclerosis in the wake of recent highly stressful events. The nature of the stressor varied considerably, from the death or illness of loved ones to a sudden threat of loss of livelihood or perhaps to a family event that caused permanent change in a person’s life and demanded a flexibility or adaptation beyond his ability to manage. Protracted marital conflict was one such source of stress, increased responsibility at work another. “The common characteristic …” write the authors of the study, “is the gradual realization of the inability to cope with a difficult situation … provoking feelings of inadequacy or failure.” 5 These stresses held across different cultures.

1969年的一项研究调查了来自以色列和美国的32名患者的心理过程。其中85%的多发性硬化症患者在近期经历高度压力事件后出现了症状，随后被确诊为多发性硬化症。压力源的性质差异很大，从亲人的去世或疾病，到突然面临失去生计的威胁，再到导致个人生活发生永久性改变并需要超出其承受能力的灵活性或适应性的家庭事件。长期的婚姻冲突是其中一种压力来源，工作责任的增加也是另一种。“共同特征是……”该研究的作者写道，“逐渐意识到自己无法应对困境……从而引发无力感或失败感。”这些压力在不同的文化中普遍存在。

Another study compared MS patients with a group of healthy “controls.” Severely threatening events were ten times more common, and marital conflict five times more frequent, in the MS group. 6

另一项研究将多发性硬化症患者与一组健康“对照组”进行了比较。结果显示，多发性硬化症组中发生严重威胁事件的概率是对照组的十倍，婚姻冲突的发生率是对照组的五倍。

Of the eight women with multiple sclerosis I spoke with, only one was still in her first long-term relationship; the others had separated or divorced. Four of the women had been abused physically or psychologically by their partners sometime before the onset of illness. In the remaining cases their partners had been emotionally distant and unavailable.

在我采访的八位患有多发性硬化症的女性中，只有一位仍处于她的第一段长期恋爱关系中；其余三位都已分居或离婚。其中四位女性在发病前曾遭受伴侣的身体或心理虐待。其余女性的伴侣则在情感上疏远且冷漠。

Lois, a journalist, was twenty-four when she was diagnosed with MS in 1974. A brief episode of double vision was followed some months later by pins-and-needles sensations in her legs. She had lived the previous two years in a small Native settlement in the Arctic with a man nine years her senior, an artist whom she now describes as mentally unstable. Later he was hospitalized for manic-depressive illness. “I idolized him,” she recalls. “He was very talented, and I felt I didn’t know anything. Maybe I was a little afraid of him.”

记者洛伊斯在1974年被诊断出患有多发性硬化症，当时她24岁。几个月前，她经历了一次短暂的复视，之后双腿开始出现麻木刺痛感。此前两年，她一直和一位比她年长九岁的艺术家住在北极一个小型原住民聚居地。如今，她形容这位艺术家精神不稳定。后来，他因躁郁症住院治疗。“我崇拜他，”她回忆道，“他才华横溢，而我觉得自己一无所知。也许我当时有点害怕他。”

Lois found life in the Arctic extremely difficult. “For a sheltered West Coast girl, it was like moving to Timbuctoo. I saw a psychologist years afterwards, and he said, ‘You were lucky to get out of there alive.’ There was a lot of drinking, death and murder, isolation. There’s no road in there. I was physically afraid of my partner, of his judgment and his anger. It was a summer romance that should have lasted a few months, but it lasted a couple of years. I tried to hang on as hard as I could, but eventually he kicked me out.”

洛伊斯觉得北极的生活极其艰难。“对于一个从小生活在西海岸、与世隔绝的女孩来说，那里就像搬到了廷巴克图。几年后我去看了一位心理医生，他说：‘你能活着离开那里真是幸运。’那里酗酒成风，死亡和谋杀层出不穷，到处都是孤寂。那里根本没有路。我甚至害怕我的伴侣，害怕他的评判和愤怒。那本来只是一段应该持续几个月的夏日恋情，结果却持续了两年。我拼命地想要挽留，但最终他还是把我赶走了。”

The living conditions were bad. “We had an outhouse, and in −40 or −50 degree weather, that’s awful. Then he conceded and got a honey bucket, as they called it, that I could pee into at night because women have to pee more than men, right?”

生活条件很差。“我们用的是室外厕所，在零下40到50度的天气里，那简直太糟糕了。后来他妥协了，弄了个他们叫的‘蜜桶’，这样我晚上就可以往里面小便了，因为女人比男人尿得多，对吧？”

“That was a concession?” I inquire.

“那算是让步吗？”我问道。

“Yes, right. We had to cart it away to dump it, and he didn’t want to do that. One night he chucked it out in the snow and told me to use the outhouse. I also had to carry the water—we had no running water. There was no option. If I wanted to stay with him, I had to put up with that.

“没错。我们得把它运走倒掉，但他不愿意。有一天晚上，他把垃圾扔到雪地里，让我用旱厕。我还得挑水——我们家没有自来水。别无选择。如果我想和他住在一起，就只能忍受这些。”

“I remember saying the main thing I wanted from him was respect. I don’t know why, but that was the big thing for me. I wanted that so badly I was willing to put up with a lot.”

“我记得我说过，我最想要的就是得到他的尊重。我不知道为什么，但这对我来说至关重要。我太渴望得到尊重了，以至于我愿意忍受很多。”

Lois says that a desperate need for approval had characterized her earlier life as well, especially her relationship with her mother. “I transferred to him my mother always being in control of my life … telling me what to wear and decorating my room and telling me what I should do from the beginning. I was the little girl too good to be true. It means that you subjugate your own wants or needs in order to get approval. I was always trying to be who my parents wanted me to be.”

洛伊斯说，她早年生活中也一直极度渴望得到认可，尤其是在与母亲的关系中。“我把母亲掌控我人生的模式转移到了他身上……她告诉我穿什么衣服，布置我的房间，从一开始就告诉我该做什么。我简直就是个完美得不真实的小女孩。这意味着为了获得认可，你会压抑自己的欲望和需求。我总是努力成为父母希望我成为的那种人。”

Barbara, a psychotherapist—by reputation, a highly effective one—treats many people with chronic illness. She herself has multiple sclerosis. She strenuously objects to the suggestion that repression originating in her childhood experience has anything to do with the plaques of inflammation and scarring at the root of her MS symptoms.

芭芭拉是一位心理治疗师，以疗效显著著称，她治疗过许多慢性病患者。她本人患有多发性硬化症。她强烈反对任何关于童年经历造成的压抑与她多发性硬化症症状根源——炎症斑块和瘢痕——之间存在任何关联的说法。

Barbara’s multiple sclerosis presented eighteen years ago. The first symptoms erupted shortly after she invited a sociopathic man she had worked with at a correctional facility into her home for a two-week stay. “He had done a lot of therapy,” she says, “and the idea was to give him a fresh chance.” Instead, the client caused havoc and disruption in her home and her marriage. I ask Barbara if she does not see this invitation to a seriously troubled person as having represented a major boundary problem on her part.

芭芭拉的多发性硬化症是在十八年前出现的。在她邀请一位曾在惩教机构共事的、有反社会倾向的男子到她家暂住两周后不久，她的症状就出现了。“他接受了很多治疗，”她说，“我的想法是给他一次重新开始的机会。” 然而，这位患者却给她的家庭和婚姻带来了巨大的混乱和破坏。我问芭芭拉，她是否认为邀请一位有严重心理问题的人到她家暂住，是她自身在界限问题上犯下的重大错误。

“Well, yes and no. I thought it was fine, because it was a two-week deal. But I would never do it again, obviously. I’m so good on boundaries now that I have one client who calls me the boundary queen—and she is another therapist, so we joke about it. Unfortunately, I had to learn the hard way. Sometimes I think that my MS was a punishment for my foolishness.”

“嗯，算是吧，也不算。我觉得没问题，毕竟只是两周的短期合同。但我肯定不会再这么做了。我现在非常注重界限，以至于有个客户叫我‘界限女王’——她也是个心理咨询师，所以我们经常拿这个开玩笑。可惜的是，我得付出惨痛的代价才明白这个道理。有时候我觉得我得多发性硬化症就是对我愚蠢行为的惩罚。”

This reference to disease as punishment raises a key issue, since people with chronic illness are frequently accused, or may accuse themselves, of somehow deserving their misfortune. If the repression/stress perspective truly did imply that disease was punishment, I would agree with Barbara’s rejection of it. But a search for scientific understanding is incompatible with moralizing and judgment. To say that an ill-advised decision to invite a potentially harmful person into one’s home was a source of stress and played a role in the onset of illness is simply to point out a relationship between stress and disease. It is to discuss a possible consequence—not as punishment but as physiological reality.

这种将疾病视为惩罚的说法引出了一个关键问题，因为慢性病患者常常被指责，或者他们自己也会指责，自己罪有应得。如果压抑/压力理论真的暗示疾病是一种惩罚，我会同意芭芭拉对它的否定。但是，追求科学的理解与道德评判是不相容的。说邀请一个可能有害的人到家里做客这种不明智的决定是压力的来源，并且在疾病的发生中起到了一定的作用，这仅仅是在指出压力和疾病之间的联系。这是在讨论一种可能的后果——不是作为惩罚，而是作为生理现实。

Barbara insists she had nothing but a mutually loving and healthy relationship with her parents. “My mother and I were great together. We were always very close.”

芭芭拉坚称她与父母之间只有彼此相爱且健康的亲密关系。“我和母亲相处得很好。我们一直非常亲近。”

“Boundaries are learned in our formative years,” I say. “So why did you have to learn boundaries later, the hard way?”

“界限是在我们成长过程中学会的，”我说。“那么，为什么你后来却要以痛苦的方式去学习界限呢？”

“I knew boundaries, but my mother did not. That’s what most of our fights were about—about her inability to recognize where she ended and I began.”

“我懂得界限，但我母亲不懂。我们的大部分争吵都是因为这个——她无法分辨我的界限在哪里，她的界限在哪里。”

Barbara’s introduction of an unstable and dangerous man into her home would be defined in studies as a major stressor, but the chronic stress of poor boundaries that preceded it is not so easily identified. The blurring of psychological boundaries during childhood becomes a significant source of future physiological stress in the adult. There are ongoing negative effects on the body’s hormonal and immune systems, since people with indistinct personal boundaries live with stress; it is a permanent part of their daily experience to be encroached upon by others. However, that is a reality they have learned to exclude from direct awareness.

在研究中，芭芭拉将一个不稳定且危险的男人带回家会被视为重大压力源，但此前因界限不清而造成的慢性压力却难以察觉。童年时期心理界限的模糊会成为成年后生理压力的重要来源。由于个人界限不清的人生活在压力之中，身体的激素和免疫系统会持续受到负面影响；被他人侵犯已成为他们日常生活中挥之不去的常态。然而，他们已经学会将这种现实排除在直接意识之外。

“The cause, or causes, of multiple sclerosis remain unknown,” notes a respected textbook of internal medicine. 7 Most research refutes a contagious origin, although a virus may possibly be indicated. There are probably genetic influences, since a few racial groups do seem to be free of it—for example, the Inuit in North America and the Bantus of southern Africa. But genes do not explain who gets the disease or why. “While it is possible to inherit a genetic susceptibility to MS, it is not possible to inherit the disease ,” writes the neurologist Louis J. Rosner, former head of the UCLA Multiple Sclerosis Clinic. “And even people who have all the necessary genes do not necessarily get MS. The disease, experts believe, must be triggered by environmental factors.” 8

“多发性硬化症的病因仍然未知，”一本权威的内科教科书指出。大多数研究否定了传染性起源，尽管病毒感染可能是一个可能的因素。遗传因素可能也起作用，因为一些种族群体似乎没有患病——例如北美的因纽特人和南部非洲的班图人。但基因并不能解释谁会患上这种疾病，也不能解释患病的原因。“虽然有可能遗传对多发性硬化症的易感基因，但不可能遗传这种疾病，”加州大学洛杉矶分校多发性硬化症诊所前主任、神经学家路易斯·J·罗斯纳写道。“即使是拥有所有必要基因的人，也不一定都会患上多发性硬化症。专家认为，这种疾病必定是由环境因素引发的。”

Complicating matters are MRI studies and autopsies that identify the characteristic signs of demyelination in the central nervous system of persons who never exhibited any overt signs or symptoms of the disease. Why is it that some people with these neuropathological findings escape the frank development of illness while others do not?

更复杂的是，核磁共振成像研究和尸检发现，一些从未表现出任何明显疾病体征或症状的人，其中枢神经系统存在脱髓鞘的特征性迹象。为什么有些具有这些神经病理学发现的人不会发展成明显的疾病，而另一些人却会呢？

What could be the “environmental factors” alluded to by Dr. Rosner?

罗森博士提到的“环境因素”究竟是什么？

Dr. Rosner’s otherwise excellent primer on multiple sclerosis summarily dismisses exploration of emotional stress as contributing factor to the onset. Instead, he concludes that the disease is probably best explained by autoimmunity. “A person becomes allergic to his own tissue,” he explains, “and produces antibodies that attack healthy cells.” He ignores the abundant medical literature linking autoimmune processes themselves to stress and personality, a vital link to be explored more fully in later chapters.

罗纳博士关于多发性硬化症的入门读物虽然其他方面都很出色，却草率地否定了情绪压力作为发病因素的可能性。相反，他认为自身免疫可能是该疾病的最佳解释。“患者会对自身组织产生过敏反应，”他解释说，“并产生攻击健康细胞的抗体。”他忽略了大量医学文献，这些文献将自身免疫过程本身与压力和人格联系起来，而这正是本书后续章节将深入探讨的关键联系。

A 1994 study done in the Department of Neurology at the University of Chicago Hospital looked at nervous system–immune system interactions and their potential role in multiple sclerosis. 9 Rats were used to demonstrate that artificially induced autoimmune disease would worsen when the flight-or-fight response was blocked. Had it not been interfered with, the animals’ ability to respond normally to stress would have protected them.

1994年，芝加哥大学医院神经内科的一项研究探讨了神经系统与免疫系统的相互作用及其在多发性硬化症中的潜在作用。该研究使用大鼠作为实验对象，结果表明，当大鼠的“战斗或逃跑”反应被阻断时，人工诱导的自身免疫性疾病会加重。如果这种反应不被干扰，大鼠对压力的正常反应能力本可以保护它们免受疾病侵害。

The MS patients described in the stress literature, and all the ones I interviewed, have been placed in positions akin to that of the unfortunate laboratory animals in the Chicago study: they were exposed to acute and chronic stress by their childhood conditioning, and their ability to engage in the necessary flight-or-fight behaviour was impaired. The fundamental problem is not the external stress, such as the life events quoted in the studies, but an environmentally conditioned helplessness that permits neither of the normal responses of fight or flight. The resulting internal stress becomes repressed and therefore invisible. Eventually, having unmet needs or having to meet the needs of others is no longer experienced as stressful. It feels normal. One is disarmed.

压力相关文献中描述的多发性硬化症患者，以及我采访过的所有患者，都处于类似于芝加哥研究中那些不幸的实验动物的境地：他们童年时期受到的条件反射影响，长期暴露于急性和慢性压力之下，导致他们无法做出必要的战斗或逃跑反应。根本问题不在于外部压力，例如研究中提到的生活事件，而在于一种环境造成的无助感，这种无助感使他们无法做出正常的战斗或逃跑反应。由此产生的内部压力被压抑，因此变得难以察觉。最终，未被满足的需求或不得不满足他人的需求不再被视为压力，反而感觉很正常。他们仿佛失去了武装。

Véronique is thirty-three; she was diagnosed with MS three years ago. “I had a major episode,” she relates, “which I didn’t know was an episode … pain in my feet, numbness and tingling going all the way up to about the upper chest and then back down, over about three days. I thought it was cool—I was poking myself and couldn’t feel anything! I didn’t say anything to anybody.” A friend finally convinced her to seek medical help.

维罗妮卡今年33岁，三年前被诊断出患有多发性硬化症。“我经历了一次严重的发作，”她回忆道，“当时我根本不知道那是发作……我的脚很痛，麻木和刺痛感一直蔓延到上胸部，然后又向下蔓延，持续了大约三天。我当时觉得这很酷——我戳自己竟然一点感觉都没有！我没跟任何人说。”最终，一位朋友劝她去看医生。

“You had numbness and pain from your feet to your upper chest and you didn’t tell anybody? Why is that?”

“你从脚到上胸部都感到麻木和疼痛，却没告诉任何人？这是为什么呢？”

“I didn’t think it was worth telling anybody. And if I told somebody like my parents, they would be upset.”

“我觉得没必要告诉任何人。而且如果我告诉父母，他们会不高兴的。”

“But if someone else had numbness and pain from the feet up to the mid-chest, would you ignore it?”

“但如果其他人从脚部到胸部中间都感到麻木和疼痛，你会置之不理吗？”

“No, I would rush him to the doctor.”

“不，我会赶紧带他去看医生。”

“Why were you treating yourself worse than you would another person? Any idea?”

“你为什么对自己比对别人更苛刻？有什么想法吗？”

“No.”

“不。”

Most instructive is Véronique’s response to the question about any possibly stressful experiences prior to the onset of her multiple sclerosis. “Not necessarily bad things,” she says.

最能说明问题的是维罗妮卡对“在她患上多发性硬化症之前是否经历过任何压力事件”这个问题的回答。她说：“不一定是坏事。”

“I’m an adopted child. Finally, after fifteen years of pressure from my adoptive mom, I looked up my biological family, which I didn’t want to do. But it’s always easier to give in to my mom’s demands than argue about it—always!

“我是个被收养的孩子。最终，在养母十五年的压力下，我找到了我的亲生家庭，而我并不想这样做。但总是比跟妈妈争论容易得多——总是如此！”

“I found them and met them, and my very first impression was, Ugh, we can’t possibly be related. It was stressful for me to find out about my family history because I didn’t need to know that I was possibly a child of incestuous rape. That’s how it appears; nobody’s telling the whole story, and my biological mother won’t say anything.

“我找到了他们，见到了他们，我的第一印象是，唉，我们不可能有血缘关系。了解我的家族史让我压力很大，因为我根本不想知道我可能是乱伦强奸的产物。事情看起来就是这样；没有人说出全部真相，我的生母也什么都不肯说。”

“Also at that time I was unemployed, waiting for EI, on welfare. And I’d kicked out my boyfriend a few months before this, because he was an alcoholic and I couldn’t handle that any more either. It wasn’t worth my sanity.”

“当时我也失业了，靠失业救济金度日。几个月前我把男朋友赶出了家门，因为他酗酒，我再也受不了了。为了他，我得牺牲自己的理智。”

Such are the stresses this young woman describes as not necessarily bad: ongoing pressure from her adoptive mother, who ignored Véronique’s own wishes, to find and reunite with her dysfunctional biological family; discovering that her conception may have been the result of incestuous rape (by a cousin; Véronique’s biological mother was sixteen at the time); financial destitution; her break with an alcoholic boyfriend.

这位年轻女子将以下这些压力描述为不一定是坏事：养母不断施压，不顾维罗妮卡自己的意愿，强迫她找到并与她功能失调的亲生家庭团聚；发现自己的受孕可能是乱伦强奸的结果（施暴者是她的表兄；维罗妮卡的生母当时只有十六岁）；经济拮据；与酗酒的男友分手。

Véronique identifies with her adoptive father. “He’s my hero,” she says. “He was always there for me.”

维罗妮卡很认同她的养父。“他是我的英雄，”她说。“他一直都在我身边。”

“So why didn’t you go to him for help when you felt pressured by your mother?”

“那么，当你感到母亲的压力时，为什么不去找他寻求帮助呢？”

“I could never get him alone. I always had to go through her to get to him.”

“我从来没办法单独和他见面。我总是得先过她那关才能见到他。”

“And what did your father do with all this?”

“那你父亲又是怎么处理这一切的呢？”

“He just stood by. But I could tell he didn’t like it.”

“他只是站在一旁。但我看得出来他不喜欢这样。”

“I’m glad you feel close to your dad. But you may wish to find yourself a new hero—one who can model some self-assertion. In order to heal, you may wish to become your own hero.”

“我很高兴你和父亲关系亲密。但你或许应该寻找一位新的英雄——一位能够教会你如何自信自强的榜样。为了疗愈伤痛，你或许应该成为自己的英雄。”

____

The gifted British cellist Jacqueline du Pré died in 1987, at the age of forty-two, from complications of multiple sclerosis. When her sister, Hilary, wondered later whether stress might have brought on Jackie’s illness, the neurologists firmly assured her that stress was not implicated.

才华横溢的英国大提琴家杰奎琳·杜普蕾于1987年去世，年仅42岁，死于多发性硬化症并发症。后来，当她的妹妹希拉里怀疑压力是否是导致杰奎琳患病的原因时，神经科医生向她明确表示，压力与此无关。

Orthodox medical opinion has shifted very little since then. “Stress does not cause multiple sclerosis,” a pamphlet recently issued by the University of Toronto’s MS clinic advised patients, “although people with MS are well advised to avoid stress.” The statement is misleading. Of course stress does not cause multiple sclerosis—no single factor does. The emergence of MS no doubt depends on a number of interacting influences. But is it true to say that stress does not make a major contribution to the onset of this disease? Research studies and the lives of the persons we have looked at strongly suggest that it does. Such also is the evidence of the life Jacqueline du Pré, whose illness and death are a virtual textbook illustration of the devastating effects of the stress brought on by emotional repression.

自那时以来，正统医学观点几乎没有改变。多伦多大学多发性硬化症诊所最近发布的一份小册子建议患者：“压力不会导致多发性硬化症，但建议多发性硬化症患者避免压力。”这种说法具有误导性。当然，压力不会导致多发性硬化症——没有任何单一因素会导致多发性硬化症。多发性硬化症的发生无疑取决于多种相互作用的影响因素。但是，说压力对这种疾病的发生没有重大影响，这种说法正确吗？研究和我们所观察的个体的生活经历都强烈表明，压力确实会造成影响。杰奎琳·杜普雷的一生也证明了这一点，她的疾病和死亡几乎就是情感压抑带来的压力所造成毁灭性后果的教科书式例证。

People often wept at du Pre’s concerts. Her communication with audiences, someone remarked, “was quite breathtaking and left everyone spellbound.” Her playing was passionate, sometimes unbearably intense. She blazed a direct path to the emotions. Unlike her private persona, her stage presence was completely uninhibited: hair flying, body swaying, it was more typical of rock ‘n’ roll flamboyance than of classical restraint. “She appeared to be a sweet, demure milkmaid,” an observer recalled, “but with cello in hands she was like one possessed.” 10

人们常常在杜普蕾的音乐会上落泪。有人评论说，她与观众的互动“令人叹为观止，让每个人都如痴如醉”。她的演奏充满激情，有时甚至强烈到令人难以承受。她直击人心，直抵情感深处。与她私下的形象不同，她的舞台表现完全不受拘束：头发飞扬，身姿摇摆，与其说是古典音乐的克制，不如说是摇滚乐的张扬。“她看起来像个甜美、端庄的挤奶女工，”一位观察者回忆道，“但当她拿起大提琴时，就像着了魔一样。”

To this day some of du Pré’s recorded performances, notably of the Elgar cello concerto, are unsurpassed—and are likely to remain so. This concerto was the eminent composer’s last major work, created in a mood of despondency in the wake of the First World War. “Everything good and nice and clean and fresh and sweet is far away, never to return,” Edward Elgar wrote in 1917. He was in his seventh decade, in the twilight of his years. “Jackie’s ability to portray the emotions of a man in the autumn of his life was one of her extraordinary and inexplicable capacities,” writes her sister, Hilary du Pré, in her book, A Genius in the Family. 11

时至今日，杜普蕾的一些录音作品，尤其是她演奏的埃尔加大提琴协奏曲，依然无人能及，而且很可能还会保持这种地位。这部协奏曲是这位杰出作曲家的最后一部重要作品，创作于第一次世界大战后，当时他正处于人生低谷。“一切美好、纯洁、清新、甜蜜的事物都已远去，永不再来，”爱德华·埃尔加在1917年写道。那时他已年过七旬，步入晚年。“杰奎琳能够如此精准地刻画一位垂暮老人的情感，这是她非凡而又难以言喻的天赋之一，”她的妹妹希拉里·杜普蕾在《家族中的天才》一书中写道。

Extraordinary, yes. Inexplicable? Perhaps not. Although she was unaware of it, by the time she was twenty, Jacqueline du Pré was also in the autumn of her life. The illness that was soon to end her musical career was only a few years away. Regret, loss and resignation had all been too abundantly a part of her unspoken emotional experience. She understood Elgar because she had partaken of the same suffering. His portrait always disturbed her. “He had a miserable life, Hil,” she told her sibling, “and he was ill, yet through it all he had a radiant soul, and that’s what I feel in his music.”

非凡，的确如此。难以解释？或许并非如此。尽管她当时并未意识到，但到了二十岁，杰奎琳·杜普蕾的人生也已步入暮年。那场即将终结她音乐生涯的疾病，距离她也只有几年之遥。悔恨、失落和无奈，早已深深地烙印在她未曾言说的内心深处。她理解埃尔加，因为她也曾经历过同样的苦难。埃尔加的画像总是让她感到不安。“他的一生很悲惨，希尔，”她对妹妹说，“他身患重病，但即便如此，他依然拥有一颗光芒四射的灵魂，而这正是我从他的音乐中感受到的。”

She was describing herself, from her earliest beginnings. Jackie’s mother, Iris, suffered the death of her own father while she was still in the maternity hospital with Jackie. From then on, Jackie’s relationship with her mother became one of symbiotic dependence from which neither party could free herself. The child was neither allowed to be a child nor permitted to grow up to be an adult.

她描述的是她自己，从她最早的童年开始。杰奎琳的母亲艾瑞斯在杰奎琳还在产科医院时，就失去了自己的父亲。从那时起，杰奎琳和母亲的关系就变成了一种共生依赖，双方都无法从中挣脱。这个孩子既没有机会享受童年，也没有机会成长为成年人。

Jackie was a sensitive child, quiet and shy, sometimes mischievous. She was said to have been placid, except when playing the cello. A music teacher recalls her at age six as having been “terribly polite and nicely brought up.” She presented a pleasant and compliant face to the world. The secretary at the girls’ school Jackie attended remembers her as a happy and cheerful child. A high-school classmate recalls her as a “friendly, jolly girl who fitted in well.”

杰基是个敏感的孩子，安静内向，有时也有些调皮。据说她平时很温顺，只有拉大提琴的时候才会如此。一位音乐老师回忆起她六岁时的样子，说她“非常有礼貌，家教很好”。她给人的印象总是和蔼顺从。杰基就读的女子学校的秘书记得她是个快乐开朗的孩子。一位高中同学回忆说，她是个“友善开朗、很合群的女孩”。

Jackie’s inner reality was quite different. Hilary recounts that her sister burst into tears one day: “No one likes me at school. It’s horrible. They all tease me.” In an interview Jacqueline portrayed herself as “one of those children other children can’t stand. They used to form gangs and chant horrid things.” She was an awkward youngster, socially gauche, with no academic interests and little to say. According to her sister, Jackie always had difficulty expressing herself in words. “Observant friends noted an incipient strain of melancholy underneath Jackie’s sunny exterior,” writes her biographer, Elizabeth Wilson, in Jacqueline du Pré. 12

杰奎琳的内心世界却截然不同。希拉里回忆说，有一天，姐姐突然嚎啕大哭：“学校里没人喜欢我。太可怕了。他们都嘲笑我。”在一次采访中，杰奎琳把自己描述成“那种其他孩子都讨厌的孩子。他们以前会结伙，喊一些难听的话。”她小时候性格笨拙，不善交际，对学习没有兴趣，也很少说话。据她姐姐说，杰奎琳一直难以用语言表达自己。“细心的朋友注意到，在杰奎琳阳光的外表下，隐隐透着一丝忧郁，”她的传记作者伊丽莎白·威尔逊在《杰奎琳·杜普蕾》一书中写道。

All her life, until her illness, Jackie would hide her feelings from her mother. Hilary recalls a chilling childhood memory of Jacqueline’s intense expression and secretive whisper, “Hil, don’t tell Mum but … when I grow up, I won’t be able to walk or move.” How are we to understand that horrific self-prophecy? Either as something uncanny or as the projection of exactly how, in her unconscious depths, the child Jackie already felt: incapable of moving independently, fettered, her vital self paralyzed. And “don’t tell Mum”? The resignation of someone already aware of the futility of trying to convey her pain, fear and anxiety—her shadow side—to a parent unable to receive such communication. Much later, when multiple sclerosis struck, all Jackie’s lifelong resentment toward her mother erupted in bursts of uncontrolled, profane rage. The docile child became a profoundly hostile adult.

在生病之前，杰奎琳一生都在向母亲隐藏自己的感受。希拉里回忆起童年时杰奎琳神情凝重、低声耳语的一段令人不寒而栗的记忆：“希尔，别告诉妈妈……等我长大了，我就不能走路也不能动了。”我们该如何理解这可怕的自我预言呢？或许它只是某种诡异的预兆，又或许它正是童年杰奎琳潜意识深处早已感受到的投射：无法独立行动，被束缚，她鲜活的生命力仿佛被麻痹。“别告诉妈妈”？这或许是她早已意识到，试图向无法理解她内心痛苦、恐惧和焦虑——她阴暗的一面——传达信息是徒劳的无奈之举。多年以后，当多发性硬化症袭来，杰奎琳对母亲积攒已久的怨恨化作无法控制的、粗俗的怒火爆发。那个温顺的孩子变成了一个充满敌意的成年人。

As much as Jacqueline du Pré loved and craved the cello, something in her resisted the role of cello virtuoso. This virtuoso persona pre-empted her true self. It also became her only mode of emotional communication and her only way of keeping her mother’s attention. Multiple sclerosis was to be her means of casting off this role—her body’s way of saying no.

尽管杰奎琳·杜普蕾无比热爱并渴望演奏大提琴，但她内心深处却抗拒着大提琴演奏家的角色。这种演奏家的形象掩盖了她真实的自我。它也成了她唯一的情感交流方式，以及维系母亲关注的唯一途径。多发性硬化症最终让她摆脱了这个角色——这是她身体对这个角色的拒绝。

Jacqueline herself was incapable of refusing the world’s expectations directly. At the age of eighteen, already in the public eye, she was wistfully envious of another young cellist who was then experiencing a crisis. “That girl is lucky,” she told a friend. “She could give up music if she wanted to. But I could never give it up because too many people have spent too much money on me.” The cello enabled her to soar to unimaginable heights and it shackled her. Terrified as she was of the toll a musical career would take on her, she succumbed to the impositions of her talent and her family’s needs.

杰奎琳本人无法直接拒绝世人的期望。十八岁时，她已是公众人物，却对另一位正经历事业危机的年轻大提琴手心生羡慕。“那个女孩真幸运，”她对朋友说，“她想放弃音乐就能放弃。但我永远也放弃不了，因为太多人为我花了太多钱。”大提琴让她飞跃到难以想象的高度，同时也束缚了她。尽管她害怕音乐事业会给她带来沉重的负担，但她最终还是屈服于天赋和家庭的期望。

Hilary speaks of Jackie’s “cello voice.” Because Jackie’s direct means of emotional expression had been stifled early on, the cello became her voice. She poured all her intensity, pain, resignation—all her rage—into her music. As one of her cello teachers astutely observed when Jackie was an adolescent, she was forcing the instrument to express her internal aggression through her playing. When engaged in music, she was fully animated by emotions that were diluted or absent everywhere else in her life. This is why she was so was riveting to watch and so often painful to listen to—“almost scary” in the words of the Russian cellist Misha Maisky.

希拉里谈到杰奎琳的“大提琴之声”。由于杰奎琳早期直接表达情感的方式受到压抑，大提琴便成了她的代言人。她将所有的强烈情感、痛苦、无奈——以及所有的愤怒——都倾注于音乐之中。正如她的一位大提琴老师在杰奎琳青少年时期敏锐地观察到的那样，她强迫乐器通过演奏来表达她内心的攻击性。当她沉浸在音乐中时，那些在她生活其他方面被淡化或缺失的情感便会完全涌现。这就是为什么她的演奏如此引人入胜，却又如此令人痛苦——用俄罗斯大提琴家米沙·麦斯基的话来说，几乎“令人恐惧”。

Twenty years after her childhood debut, now ill with MS, Jackie told a friend what she had felt on first finding herself on stage. “It was as if until that moment she had in front of her a brick wall which blocked her communication with the outside world. But the moment Jackie started to play for an audience, that brick wall vanished and she felt able to speak at last. It was a sensation that never left her when she performed.” As an adult she was to write in her diary that she had never known how to speak in words, only through music.

在童年时期首次登台演出二十年后，身患多发性硬化症的杰基向一位朋友讲述了她第一次站在舞台上的感受。“仿佛在那之前，她面前有一堵砖墙，阻隔了她与外界的交流。但当杰基开始为观众演奏时，那堵砖墙消失了，她终于感觉自己能够表达自己了。这种感觉在她每次演出时都挥之不去。”成年后，她在日记中写道，她从未懂得如何用语言表达自己，她只能通过音乐来表达。

Her relationship with her husband, Daniel Barenboim, dominated the last phase of Jacqueline du Pré’s life before multiple sclerosis ended her cello playing. A charming, cultured and cosmopolitan Argentine Jew who had grown up in Israel, Barenboim by his early twenties was a supernova in the international musical galaxy. He was a sought-after concert pianist and chamber musician and was also making a name for himself as a conductor. When du Pré and Barenboim met, the musical communication between them was spontaneously electric, passionate, even mystical. A love affair and marriage were inevitable. It seemed a fairy-tale romance; they became the glamour couple of the classical music world.

在多发性硬化症最终结束杰奎琳·杜普蕾的大提琴演奏生涯之前，她与丈夫丹尼尔·巴伦博伊姆的感情占据了她生命最后阶段的主导地位。巴伦博伊姆是一位魅力四射、博学多才、见多识广的阿根廷犹太人，在以色列长大。二十出头，他便已是国际乐坛一颗耀眼的新星。他是一位炙手可热的音乐会钢琴家和室内乐演奏家，同时也是一位声名鹊起的指挥家。杜普蕾和巴伦博伊姆相遇后，彼此间迸发出音乐的火花，激情澎湃，甚至带有一丝神秘的意味。一段恋情和婚姻似乎在所难免。他们的爱情故事宛如童话，成为了古典音乐界最耀眼的明星夫妇。

Unfortunately, Jackie could no more be her true self in her marriage than in her family of origin. People who knew her well soon noticed that she spoke with a curious, “indefinable” mid-Atlantic accent. This unconscious adoption of her husband’s mode of speaking signalled the merging of her identity with that of another, more dominant personality. Hilary writes that once more Jackie was fitting herself to someone else’s needs and expectations: “The wide-open spaces of her personality had little chance for expression except through their music-making. She had to be the Jackie the circumstances demanded.”

不幸的是，杰奎琳在婚姻中无法做真实的自己，就像在原生家庭中一样。熟悉她的人很快注意到，她说话带着一种奇特的、难以名状的中大西洋口音。这种无意识地模仿丈夫说话方式的行为，标志着她的身份与另一个更强势的人格融合在了一起。希拉里写道，杰奎琳又一次为了迎合他人的需求和期望而改变自己：“她广阔的个性空间几乎没有机会表达，只能通过音乐创作来展现。她必须成为环境所要求的杰奎琳。”

When her yet-undiagnosed progressive neurological disease began to cause serious symptoms like weakness and falling, she followed a lifelong pattern of silence. Rather than alarm her husband, she hid her problems, pretending that other causes had slowed her down.

当她尚未确诊的进行性神经系统疾病开始出现严重的症状，例如虚弱和跌倒时，她延续了她一贯的沉默模式。为了不让丈夫担心，她隐瞒了自己的病情，假装是其他原因导致她行动迟缓。

“Well, I can only say that it doesn’t feel like stress,” Jackie said one time, early in her marriage, when Hilary asked how she coped with the strain of both a personal and professional relationship with her husband. “I find myself a very happy person. I love my music and I love my husband and there seems to be ample time for both.” A short while later she fled husband and career. She came to believe that her husband stood between her and her true self. She briefly left the marriage, acting out her unhappiness through a sexual affair with her brother-in-law—a further example of her uncertain boundaries. Deeply depressed, for a while she wanted nothing to do with the cello. Soon after she returned to both marriage and music, she was diagnosed with MS.

“嗯，我只能说我感觉不到压力，”杰基在婚后不久曾这样回答。当时希拉里问她如何应对与丈夫在个人生活和事业上的双重压力。“我觉得自己非常幸福。我热爱我的音乐，也深爱我的丈夫，而且似乎有足够的时间兼顾两者。”不久之后，她便离开了丈夫和事业。她开始觉得丈夫阻碍了她成为真正的自己。她短暂地离开了婚姻，并通过与姐夫发生婚外情来发泄内心的不满——这再次体现了她界限不清的问题。她一度陷入深深的抑郁，甚至一度对大提琴失去了兴趣。不久之后，她重返婚姻和音乐，却被诊断出患有多发性硬化症。

Jacqueline du Pré’s cello voice remained her only voice. Hilary called it her sister’s salvation. It was not. It worked for audiences, but it did not work for her. People loved her impassioned music making, but no one who mattered ever truly listened. Audiences wept and critics sang her praises, but no one heard her.
