Tragically, she, too, was deaf to her true self. Artistic expression by itself is only a form of acting out emotions, not a way of working them through.

杰奎琳·杜普蕾的大提琴之声始终是她唯一的声音。希拉里称之为妹妹的救赎。然而并非如此。它或许能打动观众，却无法治愈她自己。人们喜爱她充满激情的演奏，但真正重要的人却从未真正倾听过。观众为之落泪，评论家对她赞不绝口，但无人真正理解她。悲剧的是，她也同样对真实的自我充耳不闻。艺术表达本身只是情感的表演，而非情感的梳理和疗愈。

After her sister’s death, Hilary listened to a 1973 BBC tape of the Elgar concerto, with Zubin Mehta conducting. It had been Jackie’s final public performance in Britain. “A few moments of tuning, a short pause, and she began. I suddenly jumped. She was slowing the tempo down. A few more bars and it became vividly clear. I knew exactly what was happening. Jackie, as always, was speaking through her cello. I could hear what she was saying…. I could almost see tears on her face. She was saying goodbye to herself, playing her own requiem.”

姐姐去世后，希拉里听了一盘1973年BBC录制的埃尔加大提琴协奏曲，由祖宾·梅塔指挥。那是杰基在英国的最后一场公开演出。“她调音了一会儿，短暂的停顿后，就开始演奏了。我突然吓了一跳。她正在放慢速度。又过了几小节，一切都变得清晰起来。我完全明白发生了什么。杰基一如既往地通过她的大提琴诉说着什么。我能听到她在说什么……我几乎能看到她脸上的泪水。她是在和自己告别，演奏着她自己的安魂曲。”

* The portal vein is the major vessel conveying blood from abdominal organs to the liver .

门静脉是将血液从腹部器官输送到肝脏的主要血管。

3
3
Stress and Emotional Competence
压力与情绪能力

A PERENNIAL GIVE-AND-TAKE has been going on between living matter and its inanimate surroundings, between one living being and another, ever since the dawn of life in the prehistoric oceans,” wrote Hans Selye in The Stress of Life. 1 Interactions with other human beings—in particular, emotional interactions—affect our biological functioning in myriad and subtle ways almost every moment of our lives. They are important determinants of health, as we will see throughout this book. Understanding the intricate balance of relationships among our psychological dynamics, our emotional environment and our physiology is crucial to well-being. “This may seem odd,” wrote Selye. “You may feel that there is no conceivable relationship between the behaviour of our cells, for instance in inflammation, and our conduct in everyday life. I do not agree.” 2

“自史前海洋生命诞生之初，生命体与无生命环境之间，以及生命体与生命体之间，就一直存在着永恒的互动，”汉斯·塞利在《生活的压力》一书中写道。与他人的互动——尤其是情感互动——几乎在我们生命的每一刻，都以无数微妙的方式影响着我们的生理机能。正如我们将在本书中看到的，它们是健康的重要决定因素。理解我们心理动力、情感环境和生理机能之间错综复杂的平衡关系，对身心健康至关重要。“这或许听起来很奇怪，”塞利写道，“你可能觉得，例如炎症中细胞的行为，与我们日常生活中的行为之间，没有任何可以想象的联系。我并不认同这种观点。”

Despite the intervening six decades of scientific inquiry since Selye’s groundbreaking work, the physiological impact of the emotions is still far from fully appreciated. The medical approach to health and illness continues to suppose that body and mind are separable from each other and from the milieu in which they exist. Compounding that mistake is a definition of stress that is narrow and simplistic.

尽管自塞利耶的开创性工作以来，六十年间科学界进行了大量的研究，但人们对情绪的生理影响仍然远未充分认识。医学界对健康和疾病的理解仍然假定身心是彼此分离的，并且与它们所处的环境也分离。而对压力的狭隘和简单化定义则加剧了这种误解。

Medical thinking usually sees stress as highly disturbing but isolated events such as, for example, sudden unemployment, a marriage breakup or the death of a loved one. These major events are potent sources of stress for many, but there are chronic daily stresses in people’s lives that are more insidious and more harmful in their long-term biological consequences. Internally generated stresses take their toll without in any way seeming out of the ordinary.

医学界通常将压力视为令人极度不安但又孤立的事件，例如突然失业、婚姻破裂或亲人去世。这些重大事件对许多人来说确实是巨大的压力来源，但人们生活中还存在着一些慢性日常压力，这些压力更为隐蔽，其长期的生物学后果也更为严重。内在压力会在不知不觉中悄然侵蚀人体健康。

For those habituated to high levels of internal stress since early childhood, it is the absence of stress that creates unease, evoking boredom and a sense of meaninglessness. People may become addicted to their own stress hormones, adrenaline and cortisol, Hans Selye observed. To such persons stress feels desirable, while the absence of it feels like something to be avoided.

对于那些从小就习惯于承受巨大内在压力的人来说，压力的缺失反而会让他们感到不安，引发无聊和无意义感。汉斯·塞利观察到，人们可能会对自身分泌的压力激素——肾上腺素和皮质醇——产生依赖。对这些人来说，压力是令人向往的，而压力的缺失则是一种应该避免的东西。

When people describe themselves as being stressed, they usually mean the nervous agitation they experience under excessive demands—most commonly in the areas of work, family, relationships, finances or health. But sensations of nervous tension do not define stress—nor, strictly speaking, are they always perceived when people are stressed. Stress, as we will define it, is not a matter of subjective feeling. It is a measurable set of objective physiological events in the body, involving the brain, the hormonal apparatus, the immune system and many other organs. Both animals and people can experience stress with no awareness of its presence.

人们描述自己感到压力时，通常指的是在过度需求下产生的神经紧张——这些需求最常见于工作、家庭、人际关系、财务或健康方面。但神经紧张的感觉并不能定义压力——严格来说，人们并非总能在压力下感知到这种感觉。我们所说的压力，并非一种主观感受。它是一系列可测量的客观生理事件，涉及大脑、激素系统、免疫系统以及许多其他器官。无论是动物还是人类，都可能在不知不觉中感受到压力。

“Stress is not simply nervous tension,” Selye pointed out. “Stress reactions do occur in lower animals, and even in plants, that have no nervous systems…. Indeed, stress can be produced under deep anaesthesia in patients who are unconscious, and even in cell cultures grown outside the body.” 3 Similarly, stress effects can be highly active in persons who are fully awake, but who are in the grip of unconscious emotions or cut off from their body responses. The physiology of stress may be triggered without observable effects on behaviour and without subjective awareness, as has been shown in animal experiments and in human studies.

“压力并非仅仅是神经紧张，”塞利耶指出。“低等动物，甚至没有神经系统的植物，也会产生压力反应……事实上，即使在深度麻醉下，处于无意识状态的患者，甚至在体外培养的细胞中，也会产生压力。”同样，即使完全清醒，但受无意识情绪控制或与自身身体反应脱节的人，也可能感受到强烈的压力效应。正如动物实验和人体研究所示，压力的生理反应可能在没有明显行为表现和主观意识的情况下被触发。

What, then, is stress? Selye—who coined the word in its present usage and who described with mock pride how der stress, le stress and lo stress entered the German, French and Italian languages respectively—conceived of stress as a biological process, a wide-ranging set of events in the body, irrespective of cause or of subjective awareness. Stress consists of the internal alterations—visible or not—that occur when the organism perceives a threat to its existence or well-being. While nervous tension may be a component of stress, one can be stressed without feeling tension. On the other hand, it is possible to feel tension without activating the physiological mechanisms of stress.

那么，压力究竟是什么？塞利耶（Selye）——他创造了“压力”一词的现代用法，并带着一丝自嘲地描述了德语、法语和意大利语中“der stress”、“le stress”和“lo stress”这三个词是如何分别出现的——将压力视为一种生物过程，即身体内一系列广泛的事件，无论其原因或主观意识如何。压力是指当机体感知到自身生存或健康受到威胁时发生的内部变化——无论这些变化是可见的还是不可见的。虽然神经紧张可能是压力的一个组成部分，但一个人可能在感到压力的情况下却没有感受到紧张。另一方面，一个人也可能在不激活压力生理机制的情况下感受到紧张。

In searching for a word to capture the meaning of the physical changes he observed in his experiments, Selye “stumbled upon the term stress , which had long been used in common English, and particularly in engineering, to denote the effects of a force acting against a resistance.” He gives the example of changes induced in a stretched rubber band or in a steel spring under pressure. These changes may be noted with the naked eye or may be evident only on microscopic examination.

为了找到一个词来准确描述他在实验中观察到的物理变化，塞利偶然发现了“应力”这个词。这个词在日常英语中，尤其是在工程领域，早已被用来表示力与阻力相互作用所产生的效应。他举例说，拉伸的橡皮筋或受压的钢弹簧都会发生变化。这些变化可能肉眼可见，也可能只有在显微镜下才能观察到。

Selye’s analogies illustrate an important point: excessive stress occurs when the demands made on an organism exceed that organism’s reasonable capacities to fulfill them. The rubber band snaps, the spring becomes deformed. The stress response can be set off by physical damage, either by infection or injury. It can also be triggered by emotional trauma or just by the threat of such trauma, even if purely imaginary. Physiological stress responses can be evoked when the threat is outside conscious awareness or even when the individual may believe himself to be stressed in a “good” way.

塞利的比喻阐明了一个重要的观点：当对生物体的需求超过其合理承受能力时，就会产生过度压力。就像橡皮筋断裂、弹簧变形一样。应激反应可能由身体损伤引发，例如感染或受伤。它也可能由情绪创伤或仅仅是此类创伤的威胁（即使是纯粹想象的）引发。即使威胁超出意识范围，甚至个体认为自己正处于一种“良性”压力状态，生理应激反应也可能被激发。

Alan, a forty-seven-year-old engineer, was diagnosed with cancer of the esophagus—the swallowing tube that carries food from the throat to the stomach—a few years ago. He spoke of “good stress” when he described the relentless, self-driven existence he had led in the year before he was diagnosed with his malignancy. That “good stress” not only helped undermine his health, but it also served to distract him from painful issues in his life that were themselves constant sources of ongoing physiological disturbance in his system.

47岁的工程师艾伦几年前被诊断出患有食道癌——食道是连接咽喉和胃部的管道。在描述确诊癌症前一年他那种永不停歇、自我驱动的生活方式时，他称之为“良性压力”。这种“良性压力”不仅损害了他的健康，还让他无暇顾及生活中那些持续不断的、令他身心俱疲的痛苦问题。

Alan’s lower esophagus has been removed, along with the upper portion of the stomach where the tumour had invaded. Because the cancer had spread to several lymph nodes outside the gut, he received five courses of chemotherapy. His white blood cells became so depleted that another round of chemo would have killed him.

艾伦的下段食道被切除，同时被切除的还有肿瘤侵袭的上段胃。由于癌细胞已经扩散到肠外多个淋巴结，他接受了五个疗程的化疗。他的白细胞数量已经严重下降，如果再进行一轮化疗，将会危及生命。

A non-smoker or drinker, he was shocked by the diagnosis, since he always considered that he lived a healthy life. But he has thought for a long time that he has a “weak stomach.” He often suffered indigestion and heartburn, a symptom of the reflux of stomach acid into the esophagus. The lining of the esophagus is not designed to withstand the corrosive bath of hydrochloric acid secreted in the stomach. A muscular valve between the two organs and complex neurological mechanisms ensure that food can move downward from throat to stomach without permitting acid to flow back upward. Chronic reflux can damage the surface of the lower esophagus, predisposing it to malignant change.

他既不吸烟也不喝酒，因此对诊断结果感到震惊，因为他一直认为自己生活方式健康。但他长期以来都觉得自己“胃不好”。他经常消化不良和烧心，这是胃酸反流到食道的症状。食道内壁无法承受胃分泌的盐酸的腐蚀。连接食道和胃的肌肉瓣膜以及复杂的神经机制确保食物能够从咽喉向下进入胃部，而不会导致胃酸反流。慢性反流会损伤食道下段的内壁，使其容易发生恶性病变。

Not being one to complain, Alan had only once mentioned this problem to doctors. He thinks fast, speaks fast, does everything fast. He believed, quite plausibly, in fact, that his habit of eating on the run was responsible for the heartburn. However, excessive acid production due to stress and disordered neural input from the autonomic nervous system also play a role in reflux. The autonomic part of the nervous system is the part not under our conscious control, and—as the name implies—it is responsible for many automatic body functions such as heart rate, breathing and the muscle contractions of internal organs.

艾伦向来不爱抱怨，只跟医生提过一次这个问题。他思维敏捷，说话迅速，做事也总是很快。事实上，他很有道理地认为，自己边走边吃的习惯是导致胃灼热的原因。然而，压力过大导致的胃酸分泌过多以及自主神经系统神经输入紊乱也是胃酸反流的诱因。自主神经系统是指不受我们意识控制的那部分神经系统，顾名思义，它负责许多自动的身体功能，例如心率、呼吸和内脏器官的肌肉收缩。

I asked Alan if there had been any stresses in his life in the period preceding the diagnosis. “Yes. I had been under stress, but there are two kinds of stress. There is stress that is bad and stress that is good.” In Alan’s estimation the “bad stress” was the complete lack of intimacy in his ten-year marriage to Shelley. He sees that as the main reason the couple have not had children. “She just has some very serious problems. Because of her inability to be romantic, intimate and all the things that I need, my frustrations with our marriage were at their absolute peak at the point I got the cancer. I’ve always felt that that was a really major thing.” The “good stresses,” in Alan’s view, came from his work. In the year prior to his diagnosis he worked eleven hours a day, seven days a week. I asked him if he has ever said no to anything.

我问艾伦，在确诊癌症前的这段时间里，他的生活是否经历过什么压力。“是的，我一直承受着压力，但压力有两种：一种是坏的压力，一种是好的压力。”在艾伦看来，“坏的压力”来自于他和妻子雪莉十年婚姻中完全缺乏亲密感。他认为这是他们没有孩子的主要原因。“她确实有一些非常严重的问题。因为她无法浪漫地对待我，无法给予我亲密感，也无法满足我所有的需求，所以在我确诊癌症的时候，我对我们婚姻的失望达到了顶峰。我一直觉得这件事非常严重。”在艾伦看来，“好的压力”则来自于他的工作。在确诊癌症的前一年，他每天工作11个小时，每周工作7天。我问他是否曾经拒绝过什么。

“Never. In fact, I love being asked. Almost never have I said yes with deep regret. I like doing things, I like taking things on. All somebody has to do is ask me and they got me.”

“从来没有。事实上，我很喜欢别人邀请我。我几乎从来没有后悔答应过。我喜欢做事，喜欢接受挑战。只要有人邀请我，我就能做到。”

“What about since the cancer?”

“自从患上癌症之后情况如何？”

“I’ve learned to say no—I say it all the time. I want to live! I think saying no plays a big role in getting better. Four years ago they gave me a 15 per cent chance of survival. I made a conscious decision that I wanted to live, and I set a timeline somewhere between five and seven years.

“我已经学会了说‘不’——我经常说‘不’。我想活下去！我认为说‘不’对我的康复起着至关重要的作用。四年前，医生说我只有15%的生存几率。我下定决心要活下去，并给自己设定了五到七年的生存期限。”

“How do you mean?”

“你是什么意思？”

“Five years is supposed to be the magical thing, but I know it’s just an arbitrary timeline. I figure I’ll cheat and get two more years. Then, after seven …”

“五年本该是神奇的，但我知道这只是人为设定的期限。我想我会作弊，再延长两年。然后，七年之后……”

“Are you saying that after seven years you can go back to living crazily again?”

“你是说七年后你就可以重新过上疯狂的生活了吗？”

“Yes, I might. I don’t know.”

“是的，也许会。我不知道。”

“Big mistake!”

“大错特错！”

“Probably—we’ll talk about that. But right now I’m a good boy. I really am. I say no to everybody.”

“也许吧——我们以后会谈的。但现在我可是个乖孩子，真的。我对谁都说不。”

The experience of stress has three components. The first is the event, physical or emotional, that the organism interprets as threatening. This is the stress stimulus, also called the stressor . The second element is the processing system that experiences and interprets the meaning of the stressor. In the case of human beings, this processing system is the nervous system, in particular the brain. The final constituent is the stress response, which consists of the various physiological and behavioural adjustments made as a reaction to a perceived threat.

压力体验包含三个要素。首先是机体感知到的威胁事件，无论是生理上的还是心理上的。这就是压力刺激，也称为应激源。其次是处理系统，它负责体验和解读压力源的意义。对人类而言，这个处理系统就是神经系统，特别是大脑。最后是应激反应，它包括机体对感知到的威胁所做出的各种生理和行为调整。

We see immediately that the definition of a stressor depends on the processing system that assigns meaning to it. The shock of an earthquake is a direct threat to many organisms, though not to a bacterium. The loss of a job is more acutely stressful to a salaried employee whose family lives month to month than to an executive who receives a golden handshake.

我们立刻就能看出，压力源的定义取决于赋予其意义的处理系统。地震的冲击对许多生物体构成直接威胁，但对细菌则不然。对于一个靠月供勉强维持生计的领固定工资员工来说，失业带来的压力远比对一个拿到巨额离职补偿金的高管要大得多。

Equally important is the personality and current psychological state of the individual on whom the stressor is acting. The executive whose financial security is assured when he is terminated may still experience severe stress if his self-esteem and sense of purpose were completely bound up with his position in the company, compared with a colleague who finds greater value in family, social interests or spiritual pursuits. The loss of employment will be perceived as a major threat by the one, while the other may see it as an opportunity. There is no uniform and universal relationship between a stressor and the stress response. Each stress event is singular and is experienced in the present, but it also has its resonance from the past. The intensity of the stress experience and its long-term consequences depend on many factors unique to each individual. What defines stress for each of us is a matter of personal disposition and, even more, of personal history.

同样重要的是承受压力者的性格和当前的心理状态。即使一位高管被解雇后经济保障得到保障，但如果他的自尊和使命感完全依赖于他在公司的地位，那么他仍然可能承受巨大的压力；而另一位同事则可能更看重家庭、社交活动或精神追求。失业对前者而言是巨大的威胁，而后者则可能将其视为机遇。压力源与压力反应之间并不存在统一的模式。每一次压力事件都是独特的，发生在当下，但同时也与过去的经历息息相关。压力体验的强度及其长期后果取决于许多因人而异的因素。对我们每个人而言，压力的定义取决于个人的性格，更取决于个人的经历。

Selye discovered that the biology of stress predominantly affected three types of tissues or organs in the body: in the hormonal system, visible changes occurred in the adrenal glands; in the immune system, stress affected the spleen, the thymus and the lymph glands; and the intestinal lining of the digestive system. Rats autopsied after stress had enlarged adrenals, shrunken lymph organs and ulcerated intestines.

塞利发现，应激的生物学效应主要影响体内三种组织或器官：在激素系统中，肾上腺发生了明显变化；在免疫系统中，应激影响脾脏、胸腺和淋巴结；以及消化系统的肠道内壁。应激后解剖的大鼠发现，其肾上腺肿大、淋巴器官萎缩、肠道溃疡。

All these effects are generated by central nervous system pathways and by hormones. There are many hormones in the body, soluble chemicals that affect the functioning of organs, tissues and cells. When a chemical is secreted into the circulation by one organ to influence the functioning of another, it is called an endocrine hormone. On the perception of a threat, the hypothalamus in the brain stem releases corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), which travels a short distance to the pituitary, a small endocrine gland embedded in the bones at the base of the skull. Stimulated by CRH, the pituitary releases adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

所有这些效应都是由中枢神经系统通路和激素产生的。人体内有许多激素，它们是可溶性化学物质，会影响器官、组织和细胞的功能。当一种化学物质由一个器官分泌到血液循环中以影响另一个器官的功能时，它被称为内分泌激素。当感知到威胁时，脑干中的下丘脑会释放促肾上腺皮质激素释放激素（CRH），CRH 会短距离到达垂体——一个位于颅底骨骼中的小型内分泌腺。在 CRH 的刺激下，垂体会释放促肾上腺皮质激素（ACTH）。

ACTH is in turn carried by the blood to the adrenals, small organs hidden in the fatty tissue on top of the kidneys. Here ACTH acts on the adrenal cortex, a thin rind of tissue that itself functions as an endocrine gland. Stimulated by ACTH, this gland now secretes the corticoid hormones (corticoid, from “cortex”), the chief among them being cortisol. Cortisol acts on almost every tissue in the body one way or another—from the brain to the immune system, from the bones to the intestines. It is an important part of the infinitely intricate system of physiological checks and balances by which the body mounts a response to threat. The immediate effects of cortisol are to dampen the stress reaction, decreasing immune activity to keep it within safe bounds.

促肾上腺皮质激素（ACTH）随后由血液输送到肾上腺，肾上腺是隐藏在肾脏上方脂肪组织中的小器官。ACTH作用于肾上腺皮质，肾上腺皮质是一层薄薄的组织，本身也具有内分泌腺的功能。在ACTH的刺激下，肾上腺分泌皮质类激素（皮质类激素，源自“皮质”），其中最主要的是皮质醇。皮质醇以各种方式作用于体内几乎所有组织——从大脑到免疫系统，从骨骼到肠道。它是人体应对威胁的极其复杂的生理制衡系统的重要组成部分。皮质醇的直接作用是抑制应激反应，降低免疫活性，使其保持在安全范围内。

The functional nexus formed by hypothalamus, pituitary and adrenal glands is referred to as the HPA axis . The HPA axis is the hub of the body’s stress mechanism. It is implicated in many of the chronic conditions we will explore in later chapters. Because the hypothalamus is in two-way communication with the brain centres that process emotions, it is through the HPA axis that emotions exert their most direct effects on the immune system and on other organs.

由下丘脑、垂体和肾上腺组成的功能性枢纽被称为下丘脑-垂体-肾上腺轴（HPA轴）。HPA轴是人体应激机制的核心，与我们将在后续章节探讨的许多慢性疾病密切相关。由于下丘脑与大脑中处理情绪的中心区域存在双向沟通，因此情绪正是通过HPA轴对免疫系统和其他器官产生最直接的影响。

Selye’s triad of adrenal enlargement, lymphoid tissue shrinkage and intestinal ulcerations are due, then, to the enhancing effect of ACTH on the adrenal, the inhibiting effect of cortisol on the immune system and the ulcerating effect of cortisol on the intestines. Many people who are prescribed cortisol-type drugs in treatment for, say, asthma, colitis, arthritis or cancer are at risk for intestinal bleeding and may need to take other medications to protect the gut lining. This cortisol effect also helps to explain why chronic stress leaves us more susceptible to developing intestinal ulcers. Cortisol also has powerful bone-thinning actions. Depressed people secrete high levels of cortisol, which is why stressed and depressed postmenopausal women are more likely to develop osteoporosis and hip fractures.

塞利氏三联征——肾上腺肿大、淋巴组织萎缩和肠道溃疡——是由于促肾上腺皮质激素（ACTH）对肾上腺的增强作用、皮质醇对免疫系统的抑制作用以及皮质醇对肠道的溃疡作用所致。许多因哮喘、结肠炎、关节炎或癌症等疾病而服用皮质醇类药物的患者存在肠道出血的风险，可能需要服用其他药物来保护肠道内壁。皮质醇的这种作用也有助于解释为什么慢性压力会使我们更容易患上肠道溃疡。皮质醇还具有强大的骨质疏松作用。抑郁症患者会分泌高水平的皮质醇，这就是为什么压力过大且抑郁的绝经后妇女更容易患骨质疏松症和髋部骨折的原因。

This cursory description of the stress reaction is necessarily incomplete, for stress affects and involves virtually every tissue in the body. As Selye noted, “A general outline of the stress response will not only have to include brain and nerves, pituitary, adrenal, kidney, blood vessels, connective tissue, thyroid, liver, and white blood cells, but will also have to indicate the manifold interrelations between them.” 4 Stress acts on many cells and tissues in the immune system that were largely unknown when Selye was conducting his pioneering research. Also involved in the immediate alarm response to threat are the heart, lungs, skeletal muscles and the emotional centres in the brain.

对压力反应的这种粗略描述必然是不完整的，因为压力会影响并涉及身体的几乎所有组织。正如塞利所指出的，“对压力反应的总体概述不仅需要包括大脑和神经、垂体、肾上腺、肾脏、血管、结缔组织、甲状腺、肝脏和白细胞，还需要指出它们之间错综复杂的相互关系。”压力作用于免疫系统中的许多细胞和组织，而这些细胞和组织在塞利进行开创性研究时大多不为人知。心脏、肺、骨骼肌和大脑中的情绪中枢也参与了对威胁的即时警报反应。

We need to mount a stress response in order to preserve internal stability. The stress response is non-specific. It may be triggered in reaction to any attack—physical, biological, chemical or psychological—or in response to any perception of attack or threat, conscious or unconscious. The essence of threat is a destabilization of the body’s homeostasis, the relatively narrow range of physiological conditions within which the organism can survive and function. To facilitate fight or escape, blood needs to be diverted from the internal organs to the muscles, and the heart needs to pump faster. The brain needs to focus on the threat, forgetting about hunger or sexual drive. Stored energy supplies need to be mobilized, in the form of sugar molecules. The immune cells must be activated. Adrenaline, cortisol and the other stress substances fulfill those tasks.

为了维持体内稳定，我们需要启动应激反应。应激反应是非特异性的，它可能由任何形式的攻击——无论是物理的、生物的、化学的还是心理的——触发，也可能由任何对攻击或威胁的感知触发，无论这种感知是有意识的还是无意识的。威胁的本质在于破坏身体的稳态，即机体能够生存和正常运作的相对狭窄的生理条件范围。为了便于战斗或逃跑，血液需要从内脏器官流向肌肉，心脏需要加快跳动。大脑需要专注于威胁，忽略饥饿或性欲。储存的能量（以糖分子的形式）需要被动员起来。免疫细胞必须被激活。肾上腺素、皮质醇和其他应激物质负责完成这些任务。

All these functions must be kept within safe limits: too much sugar in the blood will cause coma; an overactive immune system will soon produce chemicals that are toxic. Thus, the stress response may be understood not only as the body’s reaction to threat but also as its attempt to maintain homeostasis in the face of threat. At a conference on stress at the National Institutes of Health (U.S.), researchers used the concept of the stable internal milieu to define stress itself “as a state of disharmony or threatened homeostasis.” 5 According to such a definition, a stressor “is a threat, real or perceived, that tends to disturb homeostasis.” 6

所有这些功能都必须保持在安全范围内：血糖过高会导致昏迷；免疫系统过度活跃很快就会产生有毒化学物质。因此，应激反应不仅可以理解为身体对威胁的反应，还可以理解为身体在面临威胁时试图维持体内平衡。在美国国立卫生研究院举办的一次压力会议上，研究人员运用“稳定的内部环境”这一概念，将压力本身定义为“一种失调状态或体内平衡受到威胁的状态”。根据这一定义，压力源“是一种可能扰乱体内平衡的威胁，无论这种威胁是真实存在的还是感知到的”。

What do all stressors have in common? Ultimately they all represent the absence of something that the organism perceives as necessary for survival—or its threatened loss. The threatened loss of food supply is a major stressor. So is—for human beings—the threatened loss of love. “It may be said without hesitation,” Hans Selye wrote, “that for man the most important stressors are emotional.” 7

所有压力源的共同点是什么？归根结底，它们都代表着生物体认为生存必需之物的缺失——或者说是这种缺失的威胁。食物供应的威胁是一种主要的压力源。对人类而言，失去爱的威胁也是如此。“可以毫不犹豫地说，”汉斯·塞利写道，“对人类而言，最重要的压力源是情感上的。”

The research literature has identified three factors that universally lead to stress: uncertainty, the lack of information and the loss of control. 8 All three are present in the lives of individuals with chronic illness. Many people may have the illusion that they are in control, only to find later that forces unknown to them were driving their decisions and behaviours for many, many years. I have found that in my life. For some people, it is disease that finally shatters the illusion of control.

研究文献指出，压力普遍源于三个因素：不确定性、信息匮乏和失控感。 8 这三者都存在于慢性病患者的生活中。许多人可能误以为自己能够掌控一切，但后来却发现，多年来，一些他们并不知晓的力量一直在左右着他们的决定和行为。我自己的经历就是如此。对某些人来说，疾病最终会打破他们掌控一切的幻觉。

Gabrielle is fifty-eight, active in a local scleroderma society. Her naturally large eyes are magnified by the effect of her skin being stretched tightly on her face, her smile a barely perceptible movement of her lips over perfect white teeth. Her narrow fingers shine with the waxy translucency characteristic of scleroderma, but they also display some of the deformity of rheumatoid arthritis. Several digits have “drifted” off centre and are swollen at the joints. Gabrielle was diagnosed with scleroderma in 1985. Usually the disease’s onset is slow and insidious, but the first symptoms she experienced came on with flu-like suddenness—probably because in her case the scleroderma is associated with a more generalized rheumatic arthritis. “I was very, very ill for close to a year,” she recalls.

加布里埃尔今年五十八岁，积极参与当地的硬皮病协会活动。她天生的大眼睛因为面部皮肤紧绷而显得更加明亮，微笑时嘴唇微微翕动，露出洁白的牙齿。她纤细的手指泛着硬皮病特有的蜡状半透明光泽，但也显露出类风湿性关节炎的畸形。她的几个手指已经偏离中心，关节处肿胀。加布里埃尔于1985年被确诊为硬皮病。通常情况下，这种疾病的起病缓慢而隐匿，但她最初的症状却像流感一样突然出现——这可能是因为她的硬皮病伴有更广泛的类风湿性关节炎。“我病得很重，持续了将近一年，”她回忆道。

“The first five or six months I was hardly able to get out of bed. It was an effort to get up and do anything because of pain everywhere there is a joint. I would respond to an anti-inflammatory or Tylenol 3 for maybe three or four weeks. Then it wouldn’t be effective any more, so we would change and try something else. I was unable to eat. In five weeks I lost thirty pounds. I was down to ninety-one pounds…. I had read in different articles that people who come down with scleroderma are those who’ve always had to feel in control. All my life I’d been the one in charge, taking care of everything. Suddenly now with the disease you are totally out of control.”

“头五六个月我几乎下不了床。因为浑身关节都疼，起床做任何事都异常艰难。一开始吃点消炎药或者泰诺3号之类的止痛药，大概能缓解三四个星期。之后就没效了，我们就得换药。我吃不下东西。五个星期下来，我瘦了30磅，只剩下91磅……我之前看过一些文章，说患上硬皮病的人往往都是那些一直以来都习惯掌控一切的人。我这辈子都是掌控一切的人，什么都自己做主。可现在，突然间，这种病让我彻底失去了控制。”

It may seem paradoxical to claim that stress, a physiological mechanism vital to life, is a cause of illness. To resolve this apparent contradiction, we must differentiate between acute stress and chronic stress . Acute stress is the immediate, short-term body response to threat. Chronic stress is activation of the stress mechanisms over long periods of time when a person is exposed to stressors that cannot be escaped either because she does not recognize them or because she has no control over them.

压力作为一种对生命至关重要的生理机制，却被认为是疾病的成因，这听起来似乎自相矛盾。为了解决这一明显的矛盾，我们必须区分急性压力和慢性压力。急性压力是指身体对威胁的即时、短期反应。慢性压力是指当个体长期暴露于无法逃避的压力源时，压力机制被激活的情况，这种压力源可能是个体无法识别，也可能是个体无法控制。

Discharges of nervous system, hormonal output and immune changes constitute the flight-or-fight reactions that help us survive immediate danger. These biological responses are adaptive in the emergencies for which nature designed them. But the same stress responses, triggered chronically and without resolution, produce harm and even permanent damage. Chronically high cortisol levels destroy tissue. Chronically elevated adrenalin levels raise the blood pressure and damage the heart.

神经系统放电、激素分泌和免疫系统变化构成了“战斗或逃跑”反应，帮助我们在危急时刻生存下来。这些生物反应在自然界设计的紧急情况下具有适应性。但是，同样的应激反应如果长期持续且无法消除，就会造成伤害，甚至永久性损伤。长期高水平的皮质醇会破坏组织。长期高水平的肾上腺素会升高血压并损害心脏。

There is extensive documentation of the inhibiting effect of chronic stress on the immune system. In one study, the activity of immune cells called natural killer (NK) cells were compared in two groups: spousal caregivers of people with Alzheimer’s disease, and age- and health-matched controls. NK cells are front-line troops in the fight against infections and against cancer, having the capacity to attack invading micro-organisms and to destroy cells with malignant mutations. The NK cell functioning of the caregivers was significantly suppressed, even in those whose spouses had died as long as three years previously. The caregivers who reported lower levels of social support also showed the greatest depression in immune activity—just as the loneliest medical students had the most impaired immune systems under the stress of examinations.

慢性压力对免疫系统的抑制作用已有大量文献记载。一项研究比较了两组人群中一种名为自然杀伤 (NK) 细胞的免疫细胞活性：一组是阿尔茨海默病患者的配偶照护者，另一组是年龄和健康状况匹配的健康对照组。NK 细胞是抵抗感染和癌症的第一道防线，能够攻击入侵的微生物并摧毁携带恶性突变的细胞。研究发现，即使是配偶去世长达三年的照护者，其 NK 细胞功能也显著受到抑制。那些报告社会支持水平较低的照护者，其免疫活性也表现出最严重的下降——正如考试压力下最孤独的医学生免疫系统受损最为严重一样。

Another study of caregivers assessed the efficacy of immunization against influenza. In this study 80 per cent among the non-stressed control group developed immunity against the virus, but only 20 per cent of the Alzheimer caregivers were able to do so. The stress of unremitting caregiving inhibited the immune system and left people susceptible to influenza. 9 Research has also shown stress-related delays in tissue repair. The wounds of Alzheimer caregivers took an average of nine days longer to heal than those of controls.

另一项针对照护者的研究评估了流感疫苗的有效性。该研究发现，在未受压力的对照组中，80%的人对流感病毒产生了免疫力，而阿尔茨海默病照护者中只有20%的人能够做到这一点。持续不断的照护压力抑制了免疫系统，使人们更容易感染流感。研究还表明，压力会导致组织修复延迟。阿尔茨海默病照护者的伤口平均比对照组的伤口愈合时间长9天。

Higher levels of stress cause higher cortisol output via the HPA axis, and cortisol inhibits the activity of the inflammatory cells involved in wound healing. Dental students had a wound deliberately inflicted on their hard palates while they were facing immunology exams and again during vacation. In all of them the wound healed more quickly in the summer. Under stress, their white blood cells produced less of a substance essential to healing.

压力水平升高会导致下丘脑-垂体-肾上腺轴（HPA轴）皮质醇分泌增加，而皮质醇会抑制参与伤口愈合的炎症细胞的活性。研究人员在牙科学生准备免疫学考试期间和假期期间分别故意在他们的硬腭上制造伤口。结果发现，所有学生的伤口在夏季愈合得更快。压力之下，他们的白细胞产生的一种对伤口愈合至关重要的物质减少了。

The oft-observed relationship between stress, impaired immunity and illness has given rise to the concept of “diseases of adaptation,” a phrase of Hans Selye’s. The flight-or-fight response, it is argued, was indispensable in an era when early human beings had to confront a natural world of predators and other dangers. In civilized society, however, the flight-fight reaction is triggered in situations where it is neither necessary nor helpful, since we no longer face the same mortal threats to existence. The body’s physiological stress mechanisms are often triggered inappropriately, leading to disease.

压力、免疫力下降和疾病之间经常观察到的关联催生了“适应性疾病”的概念，这是汉斯·塞利提出的一个术语。有人认为，在早期人类必须面对充满捕食者和其他危险的自然世界的时代，“战斗或逃跑”反应是必不可少的。然而，在文明社会中，由于我们不再面临同样的生存威胁，这种“战斗或逃跑”反应却在既不必要也无益的情况下被触发。身体的生理应激机制常常被不恰当地激活，从而导致疾病。

There is another way to look at it. The flight-or-fight alarm reaction exists today for the same purpose evolution originally assigned to it: to enable us to survive. What has happened is that we have lost touch with the gut feelings designed to be our warning system. The body mounts a stress response, but the mind is unaware of the threat. We keep ourselves in physiologically stressful situations, with only a dim awareness of distress or no awareness at all. As Selye pointed out, the salient stressors in the lives of most human beings today—at least in the industrialized world—are emotional. Just like laboratory animals unable to escape, people find themselves trapped in lifestyles and emotional patterns inimical to their health. The higher the level of economic development, it seems, the more anaesthetized we have become to our emotional realities. We no longer sense what is happening in our bodies and cannot therefore act in self-preserving ways. The physiology of stress eats away at our bodies not because it has outlived its usefulness but because we may no longer have the competence to recognize its signals.

还有另一种看待这个问题的方式。如今的“战斗或逃跑”警报反应，其目的与进化最初赋予它的目的相同：帮助我们生存。然而，我们已经失去了与本应作为预警系统的直觉的联系。身体启动了应激反应，但大脑却对威胁浑然不觉。我们让自己长期处于生理压力之下，却对痛苦只有模糊的感知，甚至完全没有感知。正如塞利所指出的，如今大多数人——至少在工业化国家——生活中最显著的压力源是情绪性的。就像无法逃脱的实验室动物一样，人们发现自己被困在不利于健康的生活方式和情绪模式中。似乎经济发展水平越高，我们对自身的情感现实就越麻木。我们不再感知身体正在发生什么，因此也无法采取自我保护的行动。压力的生理反应侵蚀着我们的身体，并非因为它失去了作用，而是因为我们可能已经丧失了识别其信号的能力。

Like stress, emotion is a concept we often invoke without a precise sense of its meaning. And, like stress, emotions have several components. The psychologist Ross Buck distinguishes between three levels of emotional responses, which he calls Emotion I, Emotion II and Emotion III, classified according to the degree we are conscious of them.

就像压力一样，情绪也是一个我们经常提及却并不真正理解其含义的概念。而且，和压力一样，情绪也包含多个组成部分。心理学家罗斯·巴克将情绪反应分为三个层次，他称之为情绪I、情绪II和情绪III，分类依据是我们对它们的感知程度。

Emotion III is the subjective experience, from within oneself. It is how we feel. In the experience of Emotion III there is conscious awareness of an emotional state, such as anger or joy or fear, and its accompanying bodily sensations.

第三类情绪是源于内心的主观体验，是我们自身的感受。在第三类情绪的体验中，我们会有意识地觉察到某种情绪状态，例如愤怒、喜悦或恐惧，以及伴随而来的身体感觉。

Emotion II comprises our emotional displays as seen by others, with or without our awareness. It is signalled through body language—“non-verbal signals, mannerisms, tones of voices, gestures, facial expressions, brief touches, and even the timing of events and pauses between words. [They] may have physiologic consequences—often outside the awareness of the participants.” 10 It is quite common for a person to be oblivious to the emotions he is communicating, even though they are clearly read by those around him. Our expressions of Emotion II are what most affect other people, regardless of our intentions.

第二类情绪是指我们向他人表达的情绪，无论我们是否意识到。它通过肢体语言传递——“非语言信号、举止、语调、手势、面部表情、短暂的触碰，甚至事件发生的时机和言语间的停顿。[它们]可能会产生生理反应——而这些反应往往在参与者的意识之外。” 10 一个人常常会忽略自己正在表达的情绪，即使周围的人能够清晰地解读出来。无论我们的意图如何，我们表达的第二类情绪最能影响他人。

A child’s displays of Emotion II are also what parents are least able to tolerate if the feelings being manifested trigger too much anxiety in them. As Dr. Buck points out, a child whose parents punish or inhibit this acting-out of emotion will be conditioned to respond to similar emotions in the future by repression. The self-shutdown serves to prevent shame and rejection. Under such conditions, Buck writes, “emotional competence will be compromised…. The individual will not in the future know how to effectively handle the feelings and desires involved. The result would be a kind of helplessness.” 11

如果孩子表现出的情绪（第二类情绪）引发父母过多的焦虑，那么父母往往最难以容忍。正如巴克博士所指出的，如果父母惩罚或压制孩子这种情绪的表达，孩子将来面对类似的情绪就会习惯性地压抑。这种自我封闭是为了避免羞耻感和被拒绝的感觉。巴克写道，在这种情况下，“情绪能力会受到损害……个体将来将不知道如何有效地处理相关的情绪和欲望。结果会导致一种无助感。”

The stress literature amply documents that helplessness, real or perceived, is a potent trigger for biological stress responses. Learned helplessness is a psychological state in which subjects do not extricate themselves from stressful situations even when they have the physical opportunity to do so. People often find themselves in situations of learned helplessness—for example, someone who feels stuck in a dysfunctional or even abusive relationship, in a stressful job or in a lifestyle that robs him or her of true freedom.

压力研究文献充分表明，无助感，无论是真实的还是感知到的，都是引发生物应激反应的强效诱因。习得性无助是一种心理状态，在这种状态下，即使个体拥有摆脱压力情境的实际机会，他们也无法做到。人们常常会陷入习得性无助的境地——例如，身陷一段功能失调甚至虐待的关系、一份压力巨大的工作，或者一种剥夺了他们真正自由的生活方式。

Emotion I comprises the physiological changes triggered by emotional stimuli, such as the nervous system discharges, hormonal output and immune changes that make up the flight-or-fight reaction in response to threat. These responses are not under conscious control, and they cannot be directly observed from the outside. They just happen. They may occur in the absence of subjective awareness or of emotional expression. Adaptive in the acute threat situation, these same stress responses are harmful when they are triggered chronically without the individual’s being able to act in any way to defeat the perceived threat or to avoid it.

情绪 I 包括由情绪刺激引发的生理变化，例如神经系统放电、激素分泌和免疫系统变化，这些变化构成了应对威胁的“战斗或逃跑”反应。这些反应不受意识控制，也无法从外部直接观察到。它们自然发生，可能在缺乏主观意识或情绪表达的情况下出现。在急性威胁情境下，这些应激反应具有适应性；但如果长期持续触发，而个体又无法采取任何措施来战胜或规避感知到的威胁，则这些应激反应会造成伤害。

Self-regulation, writes Ross Buck, “involves in part the attainment of emotional competence , which is defined as the ability to deal in an appropriate and satisfactory way with one’s own feelings and desires.” 12 Emotional competence presupposes capacities often lacking in our society, where “cool”—the absence of emotion—is the prevailing ethic, where “don’t be so emotional” and “don’t be so sensitive” are what children often hear, and where rationality is generally considered to be the preferred antithesis of emotionality. The idealized cultural symbol of rationality is Mr. Spock, the emotionally crippled Vulcan character on Star Trek .

罗斯·巴克写道，自我调节“部分涉及情绪能力的获得，情绪能力被定义为以恰当且令人满意的方式处理自身感受和欲望的能力。” 12 情绪能力的前提是，我们这个社会往往缺乏某些能力。在这个社会里，“冷静”（即缺乏情感）是主流伦理，孩子们经常听到“别那么情绪化”和“别那么敏感”之类的话，而理性通常被认为是情绪化的反面。理性的理想化文化象征是《星际迷航》中情感缺失的瓦肯人斯波克先生。

Emotional competence requires

情绪能力需要

  • the capacity to feel our emotions, so that we are aware when we are experiencing stress;

    感受自身情绪的能力，使我们能够意识到自己何时处于压力之下；

  • the ability to express our emotions effectively and thereby to assert our needs and to maintain the integrity of our emotional boundaries;

    能够有效地表达我们的情感，从而维护我们的需求并保持我们情感边界的完整性；

  • the facility to distinguish between psychological reactions that are pertinent to the present situation and those that represent residue from the past. What we want and demand from the world needs to conform to our present needs, not to unconscious, unsatisfied needs from childhood. If distinctions between past and present blur, we will perceive loss or the threat of loss where none exists; and

    区分与当前情境相关的心理反应和源于过去的心理反应的能力至关重要。我们对世界的渴望和需求必须符合我们当下的需求，而不是童年时期未被满足的无意识需求。如果过去与现在的界限模糊不清，我们就会在并不存在损失或损失威胁的地方感知到损失；

  • the awareness of those genuine needs that do require satisfaction, rather than their repression for the sake of gaining the acceptance or approval of others.

    意识到那些真正需要满足的需求，而不是为了获得他人的认可或赞同而压抑这些需求。

Stress occurs in the absence of these criteria, and it leads to the disruption of homeostasis. Chronic disruption results in ill health. In each of the individual histories of illness in this book, one or more aspect of emotional competence was significantly compromised, usually in ways entirely unknown to the person involved.

即使缺乏这些条件，压力依然存在，并会导致体内平衡被打破。长期的体内平衡紊乱会导致健康问题。本书中每个病例的病史都显示，患者的情绪能力在一个或多个方面受到了显著损害，而这些损害通常是患者本人完全不知情的。

Emotional competence is what we need to develop if we are to protect ourselves from the hidden stresses that create a risk to health, and it is what we need to regain if we are to heal. We need to foster emotional competence in our children, as the best preventive medicine.

如果我们想要保护自己免受那些会危害健康的隐性压力的影响，就必须培养情绪能力；如果我们想要疗愈身心，就必须重拾情绪能力。我们应该从小培养孩子的情绪能力，因为这是预防疾病的最佳良方。

4
4
Buried Alive
活埋

A LEXA AND HER HUSBAND, PETER , wanted a second opinion. A death sentence had been pronounced on her, and they hoped I would be able to repeal it. Alexa was an elementary teacher in her early forties. In the year preceding our meeting, the small muscles in her hands had begun to shrivel up and she had increasing difficulty grasping objects. She also suffered inexplicable falls. She sought advice from Dr. Gordon Neufeld, a noted developmental psychologist in British Columbia whom she had come to know through his consulting work in the school system. Believing it was “only stress,” she avoided considering a medical explanation.

艾莉克莎和她的丈夫彼得想听听第二意见。医生已经判了她死刑，他们希望我能帮她扭转乾坤。艾莉克莎是一位四十出头的小学老师。在我们见面之前的一年里，她手部的小肌肉开始萎缩，抓握东西也越来越困难。她还经常莫名其妙地摔倒。她向戈登·纽菲尔德博士寻求帮助，纽菲尔德博士是卑诗省一位著名的发展心理学家，艾莉克莎之前在学校系统做咨询工作时认识了他。艾莉克莎认为这“只是压力造成的”，所以一直没有考虑过医学上的原因。

Alexa forced herself to carry on with her professional duties; she struggled to maintain her routine beyond any reasonable point, well past the line most people would draw in taking care of themselves. “She worked incredibly long hours and was overextended,” Dr. Neufeld recalls. “I’ve never seen anybody push herself to the extent that she did.” Because she could barely hold pen or pencil, Alexa often stayed up long after midnight to complete her daily marking of student assignments. In the morning she would arise at five-thirty, in order to arrive at school early enough to scrawl the day’s lesson on the blackboard, the chalk gripped in her closed fist. As her condition deteriorated further, she finally accepted a referral to an international authority on amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Dr. Andrew Eisen. Electrophysiological testing and clinical examination left no doubt in Dr. Eisen’s mind that the patient had ALS. At this point Peter and Alexa asked me to review the medical evidence, hoping I would discover something to challenge the specialist’s opinion—or, more precisely, hoping I would support their belief that the symptoms were purely stress related. The diagnosis was irrefutable—as Dr. Eisen said, “a classic case.”

艾莉克莎强迫自己继续履行工作职责；她竭尽全力维持日常作息，远远超出了大多数人照顾自己的底线。“她工作时间长得惊人，早已不堪重负，”纽菲尔德医生回忆道，“我从未见过有人像她那样拼命。”由于几乎无法握笔，艾莉克莎经常熬夜到午夜之后才完成学生作业的批改工作。早上，她五点半就得起床，以便早点到学校，用紧握的粉笔在黑板上写下当天的课程内容。随着病情进一步恶化，她最终接受了转诊，去看肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）领域的国际权威安德鲁·艾森医生。电生理检查和临床检查让艾森医生确信无疑，艾莉克莎患有ALS。这时，彼得和艾莉克莎让我重新审视一下医疗证据，希望我能发现一些可以挑战专家意见的东西——或者更确切地说，他们希望我能支持他们的观点，即这些症状纯粹是由压力引起的。诊断结果无可辩驳——正如艾森医生所说，“这是一个典型的病例”。

In ALS the motor neurons, nerve cells that initiate and control muscle movement, gradually die. Without electical discharges from the nerves, the muscles wither. As the Web site of the ALS Society explains: “ A-myotrophic comes from the Greek language. ‘A’ means no or negative. ‘Myo’ refers to muscle, and ‘trophic’ means nourishment—‘No muscle nourishment.’ When a muscle has no nourishment, it ‘atrophies’ or wastes away. ‘Lateral’ identifies the areas in a person’s spinal cord where portions of the nerve cells that nourish the muscles are located. As this area degenerates it leads to scarring or hardening (‘sclerosis’) in the region.”

在肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）中，运动神经元（启动和控制肌肉运动的神经细胞）会逐渐死亡。由于神经无法发出电信号，肌肉就会萎缩。正如ALS协会网站解释的那样：“肌萎缩（Myotrophic）一词源于希腊语。‘A’表示没有或否定。‘Myo’指肌肉，‘trophic’指营养——‘肌肉缺乏营养’。当肌肉缺乏营养时，就会‘萎缩’或逐渐消失。‘Lateral’指的是脊髓中负责滋养肌肉的神经细胞所在的区域。随着该区域的退化，会导致该区域出现瘢痕或硬化（‘硬化症’）。”

Initial symptoms depend on the area of the spinal cord or the brain stem where the disease first strikes: people may experience muscle twitching or cramps, loss of normal speech or difficulties swallowing. Mobility and limb movement are eventually lost, as is speech, swallowing and the capacity to move air in and out of the lungs. Despite a few reported cases of recovery, early death is usually inevitable. About 50 per cent of patients succumb within five years, although some may survive much longer. The British cosmologist Stephen Hawking, author of A Brief History of Time , has lived with the diagnosis for decades—for reasons that may emerge when we come to study his example. In contrast with other degenerative diseases of the nervous system, ALS patients lose muscle control without suffering intellectual decline. As a research paper by Suzannah Horgan, a Calgary psychologist, puts it, “Most stories from patients convey the strains of having to manage the combination of an intact mind and an impaired body.” 1

初期症状取决于疾病首先侵袭脊髓或脑干的哪个区域：患者可能出现肌肉抽搐或痉挛、丧失正常言语能力或吞咽困难。最终，患者会丧失行动能力和肢体活动能力，言语能力、吞咽能力以及肺部呼吸功能也会丧失。尽管有少数康复病例的报道，但早期死亡通常是不可避免的。约50%的患者会在五年内去世，尽管有些人可能存活更长时间。英国宇宙学家、《时间简史》的作者斯蒂芬·霍金与这种疾病抗争了几十年——当我们研究他的案例时，或许会发现其中的原因。与其他神经系统退行性疾病不同，肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）患者会失去肌肉控制能力，但不会伴有智力衰退。正如卡尔加里心理学家苏珊娜·霍根在一篇研究论文中所说：“大多数患者的故事都传达了他们必须努力维持健全的思维和受损的身体所带来的压力。”

What causes the neurological degeneration from ALS is not known. There is some evidence there may be immune system involvement, including a dysfunction of the cells in the nervous system that have an immune role. A class of cells called microglia serve a protective role in the brain, but when hyperstimulated they may become destructive. An article in Scientific American in 1995 cited tantalizing preliminary data pointing to microglia as possible participants in multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s disease and ALS. 2

肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）的神经退行性变原因尚不清楚。一些证据表明，免疫系统可能参与其中，包括神经系统中具有免疫功能的细胞功能障碍。一类称为小胶质细胞的细胞在大脑中发挥保护作用，但过度刺激时，它们可能会变得具有破坏性。1995 年《科学美国人》杂志上的一篇文章引用了一些令人振奋的初步数据，这些数据表明小胶质细胞可能参与了多发性硬化症、帕金森病和 ALS 的发病过程。

Alexa and Peter were striking in their desperation to think their way past their tragic situation. Peter, a retired engineer, would get bogged down in arcane details of muscle electrophysiology, quoting research of dubious significance and proposing theories that would have made an expert’s hair stand on end. He would often interrupt his wife when I asked her a question; she, in turn, would cast sidelong glances at him, as if for approval, as she gave her answers. It was evident that he found the prospect of Alexa’s death unbearably frightening, and also that she appeared to deny the diagnosis more for his sake than her own. I felt as though I was engaged in conversation not with two separate individuals, but with one possessed of two bodies. “Alexa could not afford to think a separate thought,” says Dr. Neufeld. “She could not afford to say anything about Peter that would have indicated she was a separate person from him.”

艾莉克莎和彼得绝望地试图从悲剧的困境中解脱出来，他们的这种绝望令人震惊。彼得是一位退休工程师，他常常沉迷于肌肉电生理学的晦涩细节，引用一些意义存疑的研究，提出一些连专家听了都会毛骨悚然的理论。当我问妻子问题时，他经常打断她；而她则会一边回答，一边斜眼看着他，仿佛在寻求他的认可。很明显，彼得对艾莉克莎的死亡感到难以承受的恐惧，而她似乎也更愿意为了他而非自己而否认诊断结果。我感觉自己仿佛不是在和两个独立的个体对话，而是在和一个拥有两个身体的人对话。“艾莉克莎无法独立思考，”纽菲尔德医生说，“她无法说出任何关于彼得的话，表明她与彼得是两个独立的个体。”

Also painfully obvious was Alexa’s inability to speak emotional language. She simply had no vocabulary to express her feelings directly: any question related to emotion would be answered by thoughts, delivered in a hyperarticulate but confused fashion. She seemed to perceive the world through abstract ideas instead of felt experience. “All of the emotions seemed completely frozen,” confirms Neufeld.

同样显而易见的是，Alexa 无法表达情感。她根本没有词汇来直接表达自己的感受：任何与情感相关的问题都会以思维导图的形式回答，虽然表达得异常清晰，但却语无伦次。她似乎是通过抽象概念而非切身感受来感知世界。“所有的情感似乎都完全冻结了，”纽菲尔德证实道。

What froze Alexa was her overwhelming fear of abandonment. Given up by her birth parents, she had never established a connection with her adoptive mother. “There was nothing in that relationship; it never worked,” says Dr. Neufeld, who came to know Alexa closely in her last three years of life. “The adoptive mother had another child whom she favoured, and there was nothing Alexa could do, try as she might. She became estranged as an adolescent, finally, because she gave up. Until then, she worked desperately to make a connection with her adoptive mother and couldn’t. It was a total vacuum. Alexa felt like there was a huge cavern where the sense of self should be.” Her first marriage quickly fell apart. She grew up believing she had to take care of everybody. “There was never any respite in her,” says Neufeld. “There was no internal resting place.”

真正让艾莉克莎噤若寒蝉的是她对被抛弃的极度恐惧。被亲生父母遗弃后，她从未与养母建立起任何联系。“那段关系里什么都没有，根本行不通，”纽菲尔德医生说道，她在艾莉克莎生命的最后三年里与她密切接触。“养母还有另一个孩子，她更偏爱那个孩子，无论艾莉克莎如何努力，都无济于事。最终，在青少年时期，她彻底放弃了，与养母疏远了。在此之前，她拼命想要与养母建立联系，却始终无法如愿。那对她来说就像一个真空。艾莉克莎感觉自己的内心空空如也，仿佛被一个巨大的洞穴填满，失去了自我。”她的第一次婚姻很快就破裂了。她从小就被灌输要照顾所有人的观念。“她从未感到过一丝喘息，”纽菲尔德说，“她内心没有一丝安宁。”

In a 1970 research article, two psychiatrists at the Yale University School of Medicine, Walter Brown and Peter Mueller, recorded dramatically similar impressions of ALS patients. “They invariably evoked admiration and respect from all staff who came into contact with them,” wrote Drs. Brown and Mueller. “Characteristic was their attempt to avoid asking for help.” 3 This Yale study of ten patients employed interviews, clinical evaluations and self-administered psychological tests. The authors concluded that people with ALS seemed to have two lifelong patterns distinguishing them: rigidly competent behaviour—that is, the inability to ask for or receive help, and the chronic exclusion of so-called negative feelings. “Hard, steady work without recourse to help from others was pervasive,” the study notes. There seemed to have been a “habitual denial, suppression or isolation of … fear, anxiety, and sadness…. Most expressed the necessity to be cheerful…. [Some] spoke casually of their deterioration or did so with engaging smiles.” The conclusions of this 1970 Yale paper were not confirmed by a study seven years later, at the Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco. One might say the jury is out, except that the Yale study is consistent with everything that can possibly be read about ALS patients, observed about them, or told by clinicians working with them. Studies in psychology—an art trying desperately to dress itself up as a pure science—often find only what the particular researchers have the eyes to see.

1970 年，耶鲁大学医学院的两位精神科医生沃尔特·布朗和彼得·穆勒在一篇研究文章中，记录了他们对肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）患者的惊人相似的印象。“他们总是能赢得所有接触过他们的工作人员的钦佩和尊重，”布朗和穆勒医生写道，“他们的一大特点是试图避免寻求帮助。”这项耶鲁大学对十名患者的研究采用了访谈、临床评估和自我心理测试等方法。作者得出结论，ALS 患者似乎具有两种终生不变的显著特征：一是固执的胜任行为——即无法寻求或接受帮助；二是长期排斥所谓的负面情绪。“不求助于他人的艰苦而稳定的工作是普遍存在的，”该研究指出。似乎存在一种“习惯性的否认、压抑或隔离……恐惧、焦虑和悲伤……大多数人表示必须保持乐观……[有些人]轻描淡写地谈论病情恶化，或者面带微笑地谈论病情恶化。”这篇1970年耶鲁大学的论文的结论，七年后在旧金山长老会医院进行的一项研究并未证实。人们可能会说，目前尚无定论，但耶鲁大学的研究结果与所有关于肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）患者的资料、观察结果以及临床医生的描述都相符。心理学研究——这门艺术竭力想把自己包装成一门纯科学——往往只能发现特定研究者能够看到的东西。

“Why Are Patients with ALS So Nice?” was the title of an intriguing paper presented by neurologists from the Cleveland Clinic at an international symposium in Munich a few years ago. 4 It discussed the impression of many clinicians that people with Lou Gehrig’s disease nearly all seem to “cluster at the MOST PLEASANT end” of the personality spectrum, in contrast to persons with other diseases.

几年前，克利夫兰诊所的神经科医生在慕尼黑举行的一次国际研讨会上发表了一篇题为《为什么ALS患者如此友善？》的引人入胜的论文。该论文探讨了许多临床医生的印象，即患有渐冻症（肌萎缩侧索硬化症）的人几乎都“聚集在人格光谱中最令人愉快的一端”，这与其他疾病患者形成了鲜明对比。

At the Cleveland Clinic, a major referral centre for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the protocol for suspected ALS patients begins with electrodiagnostic testing (EDX). By measuring electrical conductivity, EDX detects the viability or death of motor neurons, the nerve cells that act on muscle fibres. Niceness is commonly perceived by staff to be a feature of the ALS personality, reports Dr. Asa J. Wilbourn, senior author of the paper. His article noted: “This occurs so consistently that whenever the EDX technologists have completed their work and deliver the results … they usually accompany it with some comment [e.g., ‘This patient cannot have ALS, he (or she) is not nice enough…. ’] In spite of the briefness of their contact with the patients, and the obvious unscientific method by which they form their opinions, almost invariably these prove to be correct.”

在克利夫兰诊所——肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）的主要转诊中心——疑似ALS患者的诊疗流程首先是进行电诊断测试（EDX）。EDX通过测量电导率来检测运动神经元（作用于肌肉纤维的神经细胞）的存活或死亡情况。该论文的资深作者阿萨·J·威尔伯恩博士指出，医护人员普遍认为ALS患者的性格特征之一是和蔼可亲。他的文章指出：“这种情况如此普遍，以至于每当EDX技术人员完成工作并告知结果时……他们通常都会附上一些评论[例如，‘这位患者不可能患有ALS，他（或她）不够和蔼可亲……’]。尽管他们与患者的接触时间很短，而且他们形成意见的方法显然不科学，但几乎无一例外，他们的判断都被证明是正确的。”

“The interesting thing in Munich was that when we presented our paper, everybody came around,” says Dr. Wilbourn. “‘Oh yeah,’ people commented, ‘I’ve noticed that—I’ve just never thought about it.’ It’s almost universal. It becomes common knowledge in the laboratory where you evaluate a lot of patients of ALS—and we do an enormous number of cases. I think that anyone who deals with ALS knows that this is a definite phenomenon.”

“在慕尼黑，最有趣的是当我们发表论文时，大家都恍然大悟，”威尔伯恩博士说。“‘哦，是的，’人们评论道，‘我注意到了——只是以前从未想过。’这几乎是普遍现象。在实验室里，我们评估了大量的肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）患者，这几乎成了常识——而我们处理的病例数量非常庞大。我认为任何接触过ALS的人都知道，这确实是一个普遍存在的现象。”

Similar patterns emerge from my personal encounters with ALS patients in private practice and in palliative care. Emotional repression—in most cases expressed as niceness—can also be found on exploring the lives of famous persons with ALS, from the physicist Stephen Hawking, the baseball great Gehrig, to Morrie Schwartz, the professor whose television appearances on Ted Koppel’s show made him a much-admired figure in the last months of his life and whose story and wisdom form the subject of the best-seller Tuesdays with Morrie . In Canada, Sue Rodriguez, a person with ALS, gained national prominence with her determined legal battle for her right to assisted suicide. In the end not even a Supreme Court decision could deny her that right. Her story is congruent with what the lives of these others also teach us.

我个人在私人诊所和临终关怀中心接触渐冻症患者的经历也印证了类似的模式。情感压抑——通常表现为和善——在探索一些患有渐冻症的名人的生平时也能发现，例如物理学家斯蒂芬·霍金、棒球巨星卢卡·格里克，以及莫里·施瓦茨教授。施瓦茨教授在生命的最后几个月里，多次出现在泰德·科佩尔的电视节目中，深受人们的敬仰。他的故事和智慧也成为了畅销书《相约星期二》的主题。在加拿大，患有渐冻症的苏·罗德里格斯因其争取安乐死权利的坚定法律斗争而名声大噪。最终，即使是最高法院的裁决也无法剥夺她的这项权利。她的故事与这些其他人的经历所揭示的道理不谋而合。

The life histories of people with ALS invariably tell of emotional deprivation or loss in childhood. Characterizing the personalities of ALS patients are relentless self-drive, reluctance to acknowledge the need for help and the denial of pain whether physical or emotional. All these behaviours and psychological coping mechanisms far predate the onset of illness. The conspicuous niceness of most, but not all, persons with ALS is an expression of a self-imposed image that needs to conform to the individual’s (and the world’s) expectations. Unlike someone whose human characteristics emerge spontaneously, the individual seems trapped in a role, even when the role causes further harm. It is adopted where a strong sense of self should be—a strong sense of self that could not develop under early childhood conditions of emotional barrenness. In people with a weak sense of self, there is often an unhealthy fusion with others.

肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）患者的人生经历无一例外地揭示了童年时期情感的匮乏或丧失。ALS患者的性格特征是：极强的自我驱动力、不愿承认需要帮助以及否认身体或情感上的痛苦。所有这些行为和心理应对机制都远早于疾病的发生。大多数（但并非所有）ALS患者表现出的友善，是一种自我塑造的形象，需要符合他们自身（以及外界）的期望。与那些人性特征自然流露的人不同，ALS患者似乎被困于某种角色之中，即使这种角色会造成进一步的伤害。这种角色本应是他们拥有强大自我意识的地方——而这种强大的自我意识在童年早期情感匮乏的环境下是无法形成的。在自我意识薄弱的人身上，常常会出现一种不健康的与他人融合的状态。

The example of New York Yankees first baseman Lou Gehrig is instructive. Gehrig earned the sobriquet “the iron horse” for his implacable refusal to remove himself from the lineup regardless of illness or injury. In the 1930s, long before the days of sophisticated physiotherapy and sports medicine, he set a record for consecutive games played—2,130—that would stand for the next six decades. He seemed to feel that his prodigious talents and dedicated play when healthy were not enough, and he was too dutiful toward his fans and employers to ever take time off. Gehrig was caught up, according to his biographer, “in his self-designated role as a loyal son, loyal team player, loyal citizen, loyal employee.” 5

纽约扬基队一垒手卢·格里克的例子颇具启发性。格里克因无论生病还是受伤都坚持上场比赛而赢得了“铁马”的绰号。在20世纪30年代，远在先进的理疗和运动医学出现之前，他创造了连续出场2130场的纪录，这一纪录保持了六十年之久。他似乎觉得，即使拥有惊人的天赋和健康时的拼搏精神，也还不够，而且他对球迷和雇主太过尽责，以至于从不休息。据他的传记作者所说，格里克“沉浸在自己设定的角色中，他是一个忠诚的儿子、一个忠诚的队友、一个忠诚的公民、一个忠诚的员工。”

A teammate recalled Gehrig’s participation in a game despite a broken middle finger on his right hand. “Every time he batted a ball it hurt him. And he almost got sick to his stomach when he caught the ball. You could see him wince. But he always stayed in the game.” When his hands were X-rayed, it was found that every one of his fingers had been broken at one time or another—some more than once. Long before ALS forced him to retire, Gehrig had sustained seventeen separate fractures in his hands. “He stayed in games grinning crazily like a macabre dancer in a gruelling marathon,” someone wrote. The contrast between Gehrig’s unsparing attitude toward himself and his solicitude toward others was glaringly evident when a Yankee rookie was weak from a heavy cold. Placating the annoyed team manager, Gehrig took the young man home to be cared for by his mother, who treated the “patient” to hot wine and put him to bed in her son’s room. Lou slept on the couch.

一位队友回忆起格里格右手中指骨折后仍坚持上场比赛的情景。“他每次击球都疼得厉害。接球时几乎要吐出来。你可以看到他痛苦地皱着眉头。但他总是坚持打完比赛。” 拍X光片后发现，他的每一根手指都曾骨折过——有些手指甚至不止一次。早在渐冻症迫使他退役之前，格里格的双手就已经骨折过十七次。“他坚持打完比赛，脸上挂着疯狂的笑容，就像一个在艰苦马拉松中表演的怪诞舞者，”有人这样写道。格里格对自己毫不留情的态度和他对别人的体贴关怀形成了鲜明的对比。当一位洋基队的新秀因重感冒而虚弱时，格里格的举动更是令人动容。为了安抚恼火的球队经理，格里格把这位年轻人带回家，让他的母亲照顾。他的母亲给这位“病人”倒了热葡萄酒，并把他扶到自己儿子的房间里睡觉。卢睡在沙发上。

Gehrig has been described as a quintessential “mama’s boy.” He lived with his mother until his marriage, in his early thirties—a union the mother accepted only with marked ill grace.

格里格被形容为典型的“妈宝男”。他一直和母亲住在一起，直到三十岁出头结婚——母亲对这段婚姻非常不满。

Stephen Hawking was diagnosed at the age of twenty-one. His biographers write: “During his first two years at Cambridge, the effects of the ALS disease rapidly worsened. He was beginning to experience enormous difficulty in walking, and was compelled to use a stick in order to move just a few feet. His friends helped him as best they could, but most of the time he shunned any assistance. Using walls and objects as well as sticks, he would manage, painfully slowly, to traverse rooms and open areas. There were many occasions when these supports were not enough…. On some days Hawking would turn up at the office with a bandage around his head, having fallen heavily and received a nasty bump.” 6

斯蒂芬·霍金在21岁时被确诊患有肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）。他的传记作者写道：“在剑桥大学的头两年，ALS的病情迅速恶化。他开始行走极其困难，不得不拄着拐杖才能勉强走几步。朋友们尽力帮助他，但他大多数时候都拒绝任何帮助。他借助墙壁、物体以及拐杖，艰难地、缓慢地穿过房间和空地。很多时候，这些辅助手段都无济于事……有时，霍金会头上缠着绷带出现在办公室，因为他重重地摔倒在地，磕破了头。”

Dennis Kaye, a Canadian who died of ALS, published Laugh, I Thought I’d Die in 1993. His book has the reader doubled over with laughter, even knowing the author’s fate—exactly as Kaye had intended. Like several other writers with ALS, he remained undaunted by the exorbitant physical demands of writing without the use of his fingers or hands. “Let me start by saying that ALS is not for the faint of heart,” he begins his chapter titled “Lifestyles of the Sick and Feeble.” “In fact, I only recommend it to those who truly enjoy a challenge.” Kaye tapped out his volume with a stick fastened to his forehead. Here is his description of the “ALS personality”: “One seldom sees words like ‘deadbeat’ or ‘lazy’ used in the same sentence as ALS. In fact, one of the only traits ALSers seem to share is an energetic past. In almost every case, victims were either classic over-achievers or chronic workaholics…. I’ve been called a workaholic, and I suppose if the work-boot fits … but technically, even though I worked all the time, I was never driven by an addiction to work so much as an aversion to, perhaps even a disdain for, boredom.” 7

丹尼斯·凯伊是一位因渐冻症去世的加拿大作家，他于1993年出版了《笑吧，我以为我会死》。这本书即便让读者在知晓作者最终命运的情况下，依然捧腹大笑——这正是凯伊的初衷。与其他几位患有渐冻症的作家一样，他无惧于手指和双手无法使用带来的巨大身体负担。“首先我要说，渐冻症可不是胆小鬼能承受的，”他在题为“病弱者的生活方式”的章节中写道，“事实上，我只推荐给那些真正喜欢挑战的人。”说着，凯伊用一根绑在额头上的木棍敲出了书页。以下是他对“渐冻症患者人格”的描述：“人们很少会把‘游手好闲’或‘懒惰’这样的词和渐冻症联系在一起。事实上，渐冻症患者似乎唯一的共同点就是他们过去精力充沛。几乎所有患者要么是典型的成功人士，要么是长期工作狂……我曾被人称为工作狂，我想如果这个标签贴切的话……但严格来说，尽管我一直都在工作，但我并非出于对工作的沉迷，而是出于对无聊的厌恶，甚至可以说是鄙视。”

Another Canadian with ALS, Evelyn Bell, authored her book Cries of the Silent by wearing a laser light attached to a special glass frame, shining it on a spelling board, painstakingly pointing out each letter of each word to volunteer assistants for transcription. For her, too, such zealous dedication to a goal was not new. She relates that she had lived her life “at a feverish pace.” She was the mother of three children while building a successful business career: “It was a challenge to juggle home-making, parenting, business, gardening, interior decorating and chauffeuring, but I loved the roles and performed them with great intensity …. During the years of raising a family, my Nutri-Medics business grew extensively and I enjoyed many company cars and numerous trips to foreign lands. I reached many levels of success in the business, being top achiever in Canada for a number of years. I felt I wanted to be a success at parenting and everything I did.” With unconscious irony, Evelyn Bell reports all this just after writing that “we knew we could always replace money but not our health or our marriage.” 8

另一位患有渐冻症的加拿大人伊芙琳·贝尔（Evelyn Bell）为了完成她的著作《无声者的哭泣》（Cries of the Silent），佩戴着一个连接在特制玻璃镜框上的激光灯，将光束照射在拼写板上，一丝不苟地指出每个单词的每个字母，以便志愿者助手进行转录。对她而言，这种对目标的热忱投入并非新鲜事。她回忆说，她的人生“节奏飞快”。她既是三个孩子的母亲，又在事业上取得了成功：“兼顾家务、育儿、事业、园艺、室内装饰和接送孩子确实是个挑战，但我热爱这些角色，并且全情投入……在养育子女的那些年里，我的营养保健品公司（Nutri-Medics）发展迅猛，我享受着公司配发的车辆和无数次出国旅行。我在事业上取得了诸多成就，连续多年位居加拿大业绩榜首。我渴望在育儿和所有事情上都取得成功。”伊芙琳·贝尔在无意中讽刺地报道了这一切，而就在此前不久，她还写道：“我们知道金钱可以再赚，但健康和婚姻却无法挽回。”

Disease frequently causes people to see themselves in a different light, to reassess how they have lived their lives. A sudden realization hit Dennis Kaye one day as—with “glib satisfaction”—he watched his father, and two employees, doing work that he, Dennis, had always unquestioningly performed on his own. “Before long,” he writes, “satisfaction turned to frustration…. Almost all my accomplishments were in one way or another connected not to my aspirations, but to the aspirations of my father. I don’t want this to turn into an Oprah-style confession, but from the time I was a kid working my summer holidays, I’d been helping my father meet his goals and obligations. Except for a couple of years in my late teens, I’d spent the past fourteen years meeting someone else’s deadlines…. Suddenly, in the blink of an eye, I found myself pushing thirty and facing a deadline of my own … the ultimate deadline.”

疾病常常会让人重新审视自己，重新评估自己的人生轨迹。丹尼斯·凯伊（Dennis Kaye）有一天突然意识到，他带着“沾沾自喜”的心情，看着父亲和两个雇员做着他自己一直以来毫不犹豫地独自完成的工作。“没过多久，”他写道，“满足感就变成了沮丧……我几乎所有的成就，都或多或少与我父亲的抱负有关，而不是与我自己的抱负有关。我不想把这变成奥普拉式的忏悔，但从我小时候利用暑假打工开始，我就一直在帮父亲实现他的目标和履行他的义务。除了十几岁末的几年，过去十四年里，我一直在为别人完成任务……突然间，转眼间，我发现自己快三十岁了，面临着属于我自己的最后期限……一个终极的期限。”

The same compulsive sense of duty to others is evident in Laura, an ALS patient I met recently. A sixty-five-year-old former teacher of dance, Laura greets me at the door of her magazine-classic wood and glass West Coast home. Even leaning on her walker for support, she displays the grace and elegance of the ballet dancer. She was diagnosed with ALS four years ago, while undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer. “I went to a concert,” she relates, “and I couldn’t clap all of a sudden. My fingers were cramping and they just weren’t as dexterous as they usually are. It seemed to get worse as I went through the chemo. I had several bad falls; one time I broke my cheekbone and my eye socket.” Laura’s speech is halting, but the cadences of lively humour and a love for life can still be heard in the near-monotonous flow of her delivery.

我最近遇到的渐冻症患者劳拉身上，也体现了同样的对他人强烈的责任感。这位65岁的前舞蹈老师在她位于西海岸、宛如杂志封面般精美的木质玻璃住宅门口迎接了我。即使拄着助行器，她依然展现出芭蕾舞演员般的优雅。四年前，她在接受乳腺癌化疗期间被诊断出患有渐冻症。“我去听了一场音乐会，”她回忆道，“突然间我就拍不了手了。我的手指抽筋，不像平时那么灵活了。化疗期间，情况似乎越来越糟。我摔了好几次，有一次还摔断了颧骨和眼眶。”劳拉说话断断续续，但即便在她近乎单调的语调中，依然能感受到她活泼的幽默和对生活的热爱。

Laura’s medical troubles came on after a tense year during which she worked hard at the new bed-and-breakfast business she established in the home she shares with Brent, her second husband. “I had always wanted to open a B and B,” she says. “I found this place, but there was stress because we had to come up with more money than we could really afford. I felt guilty that Brent had to subsidize my financial venture. That first year was difficult, decorating the rooms. We built the carriage house. I ran the business, made the house, as well as decorating. It was practically a year to the day we moved in that I discovered the lump.” The ALS diagnosis followed a few months later.

劳拉的健康问题出现之前，她经历了一段紧张的时期。那一年，她辛勤经营着自己与第二任丈夫布伦特共同居住的房子里新开的民宿。“我一直想开一家民宿，”她说，“我找到了这个地方，但压力很大，因为我们需要筹集的资金远远超出了我们的承受能力。我感到很内疚，因为布伦特不得不补贴我的创业资金。第一年很艰难，我们忙着装修房间。我们还建了马车房。我既要经营民宿，又要打理房子，还要负责装修。几乎就在我们搬进去一年后，我发现了那个肿块。”几个月后，她被确诊为肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）。

Laura exemplifies just how impossible people with ALS find it to let go of self-imposed responsibilities long after their bodies have signalled rebellion. When we conducted our interview, the housekeeper for the bed and breakfast was away in Europe. “It turned out that 70 per cent of our clientele are repeats,” says Laura. “You get to know them as friends, you know. I’ve been feeling guilty because we said we are not going to take any guests for the month while Heidi was gone. But last weekend we had three rooms occupied because I couldn’t say no. They are repeats and I enjoy seeing them. And next week we have one repeat coming who’s been here a dozen times, a corporate guest.”

劳拉的经历充分体现了渐冻症患者即使身体早已发出抗争的信号，也很难放弃自己强加的责任。我们采访她时，这家民宿的管家正在欧洲外出。“结果发现，我们70%的客人都是回头客，”劳拉说，“你会和他们成为朋友。我一直很内疚，因为我们之前说过，海蒂不在的这个月不接待任何客人。但上周末，我们有三个房间被预订了，因为我实在无法拒绝。他们都是回头客，我很高兴见到他们。下周还有一位回头客要来，他已经来过十几次了，是一位公司客人。”

“How about saying,” I suggest, “‘Dear corporate guest: I have this condition that makes life very difficult for me. I am not up to the work involved in looking after people.’”

“不妨这样说，”我建议道，“‘尊敬的企业客户：我患有某种疾病，这使我的生活非常艰难。我无法胜任照顾他人的工作。’”

“I could say that. But the gal is coming, and I really enjoy her. She knows my condition, and she says, ‘I’ll clean up my own room, and I’ll get a bowl of cereal in the morning.’ That’s what they all say, but I can’t let them do that. Because I’ve never served a bowl of cereal for breakfast.”

“我当然可以这么说。但是那姑娘要来了，我真的很喜欢她。她了解我的情况，她说：‘我会自己收拾房间，早上我会吃碗麦片。’她们都这么说，但我不能让她们这么做。因为我从来没吃过麦片当早餐。”

“You still wouldn’t be serving one. They’d be serving it themselves.”

“你还是不会亲自去端盘子，他们会自己去端。”

Hearty laughter. “You make it sound so simple. I’d have to take a course, or maybe get some counselling with you.”

爽朗大笑。“你说的好像很简单似的。我得去上个课，或者找你咨询一下。”

Laura’s guilt around saying no to other people’s perceived needs was inculcated at an early age. Her mother developed breast cancer when Laura was twelve and died four years later. * From adolescence Laura was responsible for the care of her sister and brother, respectively five and ten years younger than she is. Even before then she was habituated to anticipating her parents’ wishes.

劳拉从小就对拒绝他人的需求感到内疚。她十二岁时，母亲患上了乳腺癌，四年后去世。从青少年时期开始，劳拉就承担起照顾弟弟妹妹的责任，他们分别比她小五岁和十岁。甚至在此之前，她就已经习惯于揣摩父母的心意。

“My mother was a dance teacher, so I danced as a very young child and all through my life. I went into the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, but I ended up being too tall, so I opened a dance school with a friend and taught children.”

“我母亲是位舞蹈老师，所以我从小就开始跳舞，而且一直跳到大半辈子。我曾加入温尼伯皇家芭蕾舞团，但后来发现我个子太高了，于是就和朋友一起开办了一所舞蹈学校，教孩子们跳舞。”

“It’s a very demanding life, ballet. Did you enjoy it as a child?”

“芭蕾舞演员的生活非常辛苦。你小时候喜欢跳芭蕾舞吗？”

“Sometimes. Sometimes I resented it. I resented not being able to go with my friends to a show on a Saturday afternoon, or it always seemed I was missing birthday parties.”

“有时候，我会感到不满。有时候，我会不满周六下午不能和朋友们一起去看演出，或者总是错过生日派对。”

“How did you deal with that?”

你是如何应对这件事的？

“My mother would give me a choice, and I think I would go dancing because I knew she preferred that I do that .”

“如果我妈妈让我自己选择，我想我会去跳舞，因为我知道她更希望我这样做。”

“What about what you preferred?”

“那你更喜欢什么呢？”

“I would have liked to go with my friends.”

“我本来想和朋友们一起去的。”

After her mother’s death, Laura functioned as the woman of the house, not only as caregiver to her siblings but, in some ways, also as companion to her father. “He’d say, ‘What are you doing tonight, Laura?’ I’d say, ‘I’m going to a show with Connie,’ my best friend. He’d say, ‘Oh, I think I’ll get a babysitter and come with you.’ All my friends came to our house ’cause they loved my dad. He was just great with everyone.”

母亲去世后，劳拉承担起了家里的重担，不仅照顾弟妹，在某种程度上也陪伴着父亲。“他会问，‘劳拉，你今晚有什么安排？’我会说，‘我要和我的好朋友康妮去看演出。’他会说，‘哦，我想我得找个保姆陪你一起去。’我的朋友们都来我家玩，因为他们都喜欢我爸爸。他对每个人都特别好。”

“How did you feel about your dad hanging out with you and your girlfriends?”

“你爸爸和你还有你的女朋友们一起出去玩，你感觉怎么样？”

“Well, what kind of teenager wants their dad hanging around!”

“哪有青少年希望自己的爸爸整天待在身边呢！”

“Did you ever say, ‘Dad, I just want to be with my friends’?”

“你有没有说过，‘爸爸，我只想和朋友们在一起’？”

“No … I didn’t like it, but I didn’t want to hurt his feelings.”

“不……我不喜欢那样，但我不想伤害他的感情。”

Laura’s first husband, whom she married to escape the family home, was a compulsive womanizer. He left her when she was pregnant with their third child, on her own, without any financial support. They had been childhood sweethearts.

劳拉的第一任丈夫是个花花公子，她嫁给他是为了逃离家庭。在她怀着第三个孩子的时候，他抛弃了她，让她孤身一人，没有任何经济支持。他们曾是青梅竹马。

“He was having affairs? For how long did you endure it?” I wonder.

“他有外遇？你忍受了多久？”我心想。

“Four years. I had two children, and I believed in marriage.” Laura slowly lifts a napkin to her eyes to wipe away some tears. “I’ve never talked about this.”

“四年了。我有两个孩子，而且我一直相信婚姻。”劳拉缓缓拿起餐巾纸擦去眼角的泪水。“我从来没跟人说过这件事。”

“It’s still very painful for you.”

“你现在仍然感到非常痛苦。”

“I don’t know why, it was a hundred years ago … Sorry, I do get emotional.”

“我也不知道为什么，那已经是上百年前的事了……抱歉，我有点激动。”

“What’s that like for you to get emotional?”

“你当时情绪激动是什么感觉？”

“Annoying, because it doesn’t do any good.”

“真烦人，因为它一点用都没有。”

“Is being emotional something you’ve found uncomfortable in your life?”

“你是否觉得在生活中表达情绪会让你感到不自在？”

“Well, if you’re emotional, it’s usually because something bad or sad has happened, so why would you like being emotional?”

“嗯，如果你情绪激动，通常是因为发生了不好的或悲伤的事情，那么你为什么会喜欢情绪激动呢？”

In a sense, Laura is right. For the child it is no relief to feel sadness or anger if no one is there to receive those emotions and to provide some comfort and containment. Everything had to be held in rigidly. The physical rigidity of ALS may well be a consequence. There is perhaps only so much energy the nervous system can expend pushing down powerful emotions that cry out for expression. At some point in particularly susceptible individuals, it seems reasonable to suppose, nerves may lose the ability to renew themselves. Could ALS be a result of an exhausted nervous system no longer being capable of replenishing itself?

从某种意义上说，劳拉是对的。对孩子而言，如果没有人接纳这些情绪，给予安慰和包容，那么悲伤或愤怒的情绪就无法得到缓解。一切都必须被紧紧压抑。肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）引起的身体僵硬很可能就是这种压抑的后果。神经系统能够用来压制那些渴望表达的强烈情绪的能量或许是有限的。可以合理推测，在某些特别易感的个体中，神经可能会在某个阶段失去自我修复的能力。ALS会不会是神经系统衰竭，最终无法自我修复的结果呢？

“Why has the fact that ALS patients, as a group, are strikingly congenial not been discussed in the literature?” asked the Cleveland neurologists in their Munich presentation. “Probably the principal reason is that it is based on subjective assessments, which lack a means of scientific verification. Thus, according to our psychiatric colleagues, ‘niceness’ is extremely difficult to quantify.” Perhaps if researchers took greater care to obtain patients’ life histories, much useful information now being missed would be forthcoming. The examples in this chapter illustrate that.

“为什么文献中从未讨论过肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）患者群体普遍表现出的亲和力这一事实？”克利夫兰的神经科医生在慕尼黑的报告中问道。“主要原因可能是，这种亲和力是基于主观评价，缺乏科学验证手段。因此，正如我们的精神科同事所说，‘友善’是极难量化的。”或许，如果研究人员更加注重了解患者的生活史，就能获得许多目前被忽略的有用信息。本章的例子便印证了这一点。

Rage and anguish exist underneath the veneer of niceness, no matter how sincerely a person mistakes the facade for her true self. “My mother is still alive, and I love her dearly,” says the sister of a man diagnosed with ALS two years ago, “but she is very domineering, superficial in her understanding of emotions and insensitive to other people’s needs and wants. She does not allow you to have your own self. It was very difficult to find your own identity with my mother. When I consider my brother’s illness, I think we all did our work to figure out how to become separate individuals. It’s been hard, but we did—except my brother, who somehow didn’t. He said to me last time I was there—I’m fifty-four now, and he’s forty-six—‘I hate Mom.’ And yet, he is the one who is the nicest to my mother of us all. He will go there—he has ALS and can hardly walk—but he will take soup to her. When he is in my mom’s presence he will be a cute little boy—the good little kid he always was, and I was not.”

无论一个人多么真诚地将外表的友善误认为是真实的自我，愤怒和痛苦都隐藏在友善的外表之下。 “我母亲还健在，我非常爱她，”一位两年前被诊断出患有肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）的男子的妹妹说道，“但她非常强势，对情感的理解肤浅，对别人的需求和愿望也漠不关心。她不允许你拥有自我。在母亲的掌控下，很难找到自己的身份认同。回想起我哥哥的病情，我觉得我们都在努力学习如何成为独立的个体。这很艰难，但我们都做到了——除了我哥哥，他不知为何没能做到。上次我去看望他时——我现在54岁，他46岁——他对我说：‘我恨妈妈。’然而，在我们所有人中，他对母亲却是最好的。他会去探望她——他患有ALS，几乎无法行走——但他会给她送汤。当他在母亲面前时，他会变成一个可爱的小男孩——一个他一直都很乖的小男孩，而我却不是。”

Joanne, a beautiful thirty-eight-year-old with black hair and luminous, sad blue eyes, was admitted to our palliative unit for terminal care a few months before her death. She had been a dancer. The sudden and bewildering refusal of her limbs to obey her will on the dance floor was traced to the onset of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Proud of her innate ability to move freely and creatively, Joanne experienced this diagnosis as the most devastating blow imaginable. “I’d rather die of some horrible cancer,” she said. Already at the end stages of the disease, she wanted me to promise to kill her when the time came. I guaranteed we would not let her suffer pain or breathlessness. That was a promise I could in good conscience make without compromising the principled rejection of euthanasia shared by most doctors and nurses who do palliative work.

乔安娜，一位美丽的38岁女子，有着一头乌黑的秀发和一双明亮而忧郁的蓝眼睛。在她去世前几个月，她被送进了我们的临终关怀病房。她曾是一名舞蹈演员。在舞池中，她的四肢突然变得不听使唤，最终被确诊为肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）。乔安娜为自己与生俱来的自由奔放和创造力而自豪，因此，这个诊断对她来说无疑是晴天霹雳。“我宁愿死于某种可怕的癌症，”她说。当时她已身患绝症，她希望我能答应她，在她生命的尽头，我会结束她的生命。我保证，我们绝不会让她遭受痛苦或呼吸困难。这是我能够凭良心做出的承诺，不会违背大多数从事临终关怀工作的医生和护士所秉持的拒绝安乐死的原则。

You can come to know people quickly and deeply when you look after them during their time of dying. Joanne and I had many talks. “All my life,” she once told me, “ever since childhood, I have been having this dream of being buried alive. I lie in my underground coffin, closed in, unable to breathe. When I was diagnosed three years ago I went to the office of the ALS Society for information. There on the wall was a poster that read ‘Having ALS Is Like Being Buried Alive.’”

在他们临终之际照顾他们，你会很快而深刻地了解他们。我和乔安娜有过很多次谈话。“我这辈子，”她曾经告诉我，“从孩提时代起，我就一直做着一个梦，梦见自己被活埋。我躺在地下的棺材里，被封闭起来，无法呼吸。三年前我被确诊后，去了渐冻症协会的办公室咨询。墙上贴着一张海报，上面写着‘患上渐冻症就像被活埋一样’。”

I do not believe Joanne’s recurrent nightmare was either coincidence or preternatural premonition. The image of being alone, confined, desperate and doomed, unheard by anyone, was the psychological truth of her childhood existence. She never experienced herself as an alive and free being in her relationships with her parents or siblings. I could only speculate what stresses over how many generations had finally created that situation for her in her family of origin. As it was, neither her parents nor her brothers and sisters visited during her terminal phase. A new family of devoted caregivers accompanied Joanne during her final weeks on earth and were with her to her dying breath. She was deeply asleep during her final days. The promise was kept: she did not suffer at the last.

我不认为乔安娜反复出现的噩梦是巧合，也不是超自然的预感。孤独、被困、绝望、注定毁灭，无人倾听的景象，正是她童年生活的真实写照。在与父母和兄弟姐妹的关系中，她从未体验过自己作为鲜活自由的生命。我只能猜测，究竟是几代人积累的压力，最终在她原生家庭中造成了这种境况。事实上，在她生命的最后阶段，她的父母和兄弟姐妹都没有来看望她。一群充满爱心的照护者陪伴乔安娜度过了她人生的最后几周，直到她咽下最后一口气。她在生命的最后几天里沉睡不醒。承诺兑现了：她没有遭受痛苦地离世。

Sue Rodriguez, the Victoria woman whose court-defying suicide was carried out in the presence of a member of Canada’s Parliament, was also emotionally isolated from her family. Her biographer, the journalist Lisa Hobbs-Birnie, describes the day Rodriguez’s diagnosis with ALS was confirmed:

苏·罗德里格斯，这位来自维多利亚的女子，在加拿大国会议员的见证下，无视法庭命令自杀身亡。她与家人在情感上也十分疏离。她的传记作者，记者丽莎·霍布斯-伯尼，描述了罗德里格斯被确诊患有肌萎缩侧索硬化症的那一天：

Sue felt her knees buckle, her legs turn to water. She knew what ALS was, had seen the documentary on the physicist-astronomer Stephen Hawking, knew his condition, tried to imagine her own life inside a body that couldn’t sit up, walk, talk, laugh, write or hug her child…. She leaned against a wall. She became aware of a terrible sound, as primal as the cry of a wounded animal, unlike anything she’d heard before. She realized only slowly, from the horrified expressions of passersby, that it was coming from her own mouth….

苏感到双膝一软，双腿像灌了铅一样。她知道什么是渐冻症，看过关于物理学家兼天文学家斯蒂芬·霍金的纪录片，了解他的病情，她试着想象自己身处一个无法坐起、行走、说话、欢笑、写作甚至拥抱孩子的躯体中……她靠在墙上。这时，她听到一个可怕的声音，如同受伤野兽的哀嚎般原始，是她从未听过的声音。她慢慢地从路人惊恐的表情中意识到，这声音竟然是从她自己的嘴里发出的……

She phoned to tell her mother and stepfather, Doe and Ken Thatcher. Doe said: “Ken and I thought it might be that.” Sue felt abandoned, and gave way to uncontrollable grief. 9

她打电话告诉了她的母亲和继父，Doe和Ken Thatcher。Doe说：“Ken和我猜想可能是这样。” Sue感到被抛弃，悲痛欲绝。

Sue was the second of the five children born to her parents within ten years. She was always the outsider. Her mother somehow believed that Sue made this choice: “It almost seemed,” she said, “from the moment she was born she didn’t feel part of the family in the same way as the others did. The illness only made it worse.” Mother and daughter had only occasional telephone contact during the final months of Sue’s life. Doe was characterized by her daughter and others as “not the caregiving type.”

苏是父母十年内生育的五个孩子中的第二个。她一直感觉自己像个局外人。她的母亲不知为何认为这是苏自己的选择：“似乎，”她说，“从她出生起，她就觉得自己不像其他孩子那样融入这个家庭。疾病更是加剧了这种情况。”在苏生命的最后几个月里，母女俩只有偶尔的电话联系。苏和其他人都认为她的母亲“不是那种会照顾别人的人”。

“The mother’s brusque reaction when Sue called from the hospital with her diagnosis,” writes Hobbs-Birnie, “was typical not only of Doe’s lack of caregiving skill, but of the kind of interaction mother and daughter had. Things did not improve as Sue’s disease progressed.” Emotional communication was foreign to the Rodriguez family, according to her brother, fourteen months her junior. He was the only sibling to maintain any regular contact with his dying sister. Most of the family, he said, preferred not to show their feelings.

霍布斯-伯尼写道：“苏从医院打电话告知诊断结果时，母亲的冷淡反应不仅体现了多伊缺乏照护能力，也反映了母女二人之间的互动模式。随着苏的病情加重，情况并没有好转。”据苏的弟弟（比她小十四个月）说，情感交流对罗德里格斯一家来说很陌生。他是家中唯一一个与即将离世的姐姐保持定期联系的人。他说，大多数家人都不愿表露自己的情感。

This is not some bizarre, unfeeling group of human beings here. The problem was not a lack of feeling but an excess of painful, unmetabolized emotion. The Rodriguez family dealt with emotional hurt by repressing it. Generations of family history had brought them to that coping pattern. Sue’s father, Tom, dead of alcohol-induced cirrhosis of the liver at age forty-five, had been an earlier victim of this surfeit of pain. He was a man of low self-esteem, all his life dominated by others.

这并非一群冷酷无情的怪异之人。问题不在于缺乏情感，而在于痛苦的、无法消化的情绪过载。罗德里格斯一家应对情感创伤的方式是压抑。世代相传的家族史使他们形成了这种应对模式。苏的父亲汤姆，45岁时因酒精性肝硬化去世，他早年也曾饱受这种痛苦的折磨。他是一个自卑的人，一生都受制于他人。

What drove a terminally ill Sue Rodriguez, the mother of a young child, to expend her diminishing physical and psychic resources on highly public court battles and media campaigns that taxed her vital energies to the limit? An articulate woman with an engaging personality and a beautiful smile, she became a hero to many who saw her as a crusader of indomitable courage and spirit. She was popularly viewed as someone fighting for her right to die at a time and in the manner of her own choosing.

是什么驱使身患绝症、育有一子的苏·罗德里格斯，将日渐衰弱的体力和精神，耗费在公开的法庭诉讼和媒体宣传中，最终耗尽了她全部的精力？她口齿伶俐，个性迷人，笑容灿烂，在许多人眼中，她是一位拥有不屈不挠的勇气和精神的斗士，成为了英雄。人们普遍认为，她是在为自己选择何时以自己想要的方式结束生命的权利而战。

There was always more to the Sue Rodriquez story than the simple issue of autonomy in death, though this was the part of her drama that caught the imagination of the public. Behind the popular facade of a confident and determined fighter, Ms. Rodriguez was a frightened and lonely person with a very fragile support system, alienated from her estranged husband and from her family. It was a multi-layered scenario. As usual, the most public layer was also the most superficial one.

苏·罗德里格斯的故事远不止于死亡自主权这一简单的议题，尽管这部分最能引起公众的关注。在人们眼中自信坚毅的斗士形象背后，罗德里格斯女士其实是一个恐惧孤独、支持系统极其脆弱的人，她与疏远的丈夫和家人都关系疏远。这是一个多层次的故事。而通常情况下，最广为人知的层面也往往是最肤浅的。

The biographer believes Sue Rodriguez was “a woman of strong convictions and a powerful sense of self. She had control over her life and preferred to have control over her death.” As with all ALS patients, the reality was rather more contradictory. Strong convictions do not necessarily signal a powerful sense of self: very often quite the opposite. Intensely held beliefs may be no more than a person’s unconscious effort to build a sense of self to fill what, underneath, is experienced as a vacuum.

传记作者认为苏·罗德里格斯是一位“信念坚定、自我意识强烈的女性。她能够掌控自己的人生，也希望能够掌控自己的死亡。” 然而，与所有渐冻症患者一样，现实情况却远比这复杂得多。坚定的信念并不一定意味着强大的自我意识：很多时候恰恰相反。强烈的信念或许仅仅是一个人无意识地试图构建自我认同，以填补内心深处的空虚。

Her history of deeply troubled personal relationships indicates that Sue Rodriguez had never been in control of her life. She had filled roles without ever being close to her real self. Her anguished question to the court and the public—“Who owns my life?”—was a summation of her whole existence. Her fight for control in death turned out to be her final and greatest role. By the time her legal case opened, writes Lisa Hobbs-Birnie, “Sue Rodriguez was fast becoming a national figure. She slid into the role as if her entire life had been a preparation for it, which indeed it had.”

苏·罗德里格斯过往坎坷的人际关系表明，她从未真正掌控过自己的人生。她扮演着各种角色，却始终与真实的自我渐行渐远。她向法庭和公众发出的痛苦质问——“谁拥有我的人生？”——是对她整个人生的总结。她为争取临终掌控权而进行的斗争，最终成为了她人生中最后也是最伟大的角色。正如丽莎·霍布斯-伯尼所写，在她案件开庭审理之时，“苏·罗德里格斯已迅速成为全国瞩目的人物。她完美地融入了这个角色，仿佛她的一生都在为此做准备，而事实也的确如此。”

When Sue Rodriguez was diagnosed with ALS, in her first despair she compared the impossibility of her situation with what she perceived were the relative advantages of fellow ALS sufferer Stephen Hawking.
