Writes Hobbs-Birnie, “She was given pamphlets on palliative care, and these pamphlets described patients who were ‘surrounded by loving family’ or who found joy in ‘living a life of the mind.’ What loving family? she thought. What life of the mind? Let a genius like Stephen Hawking live a life of the mind. But me, if I cannot move my own body, I have no life.”

苏·罗德里格斯被确诊患有肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）后，在最初的绝望中，她将自己处境的绝望与她所认为的同为ALS患者的斯蒂芬·霍金的优势进行了比较。霍布斯-伯尼写道：“她拿到了一些关于姑息治疗的小册子，这些小册子描述的病人‘被充满爱的家人围绕’，或者在‘精神生活’中找到快乐。什么充满爱的家人？”她想。什么精神生活？就让像斯蒂芬·霍金这样的天才去过精神生活吧。而我，如果我连自己的身体都无法活动，我就没有生命可言。”

If Stephen Hawking’s public status as a latter-day Einstein may be questioned by science cognoscenti, no one disputes his brilliance, originality of thought or intellectual fearlessness. There is universal admiration for the indomitable will that has sustained his life and work since a slight speech impediment signalled the onset of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis when he was only twenty years old. Diagnosed in 1963, Hawking was given the medical prognosis that he had, at most, two years to live. He has been near death on at least one occasion, ill with pneumonia and in a coma on a trip to Switzerland. Yet four decades after his diagnosis, paralyzed, wheelchair bound and completely dependent physically, he has, nonetheless, just published his second best-selling book. He has travelled ceaselessly around the world, a lecturer in great demand despite his inability to utter a word in his own voice. He has been the recipient of many scientific honours.

如果说斯蒂芬·霍金作为当代爱因斯坦的地位可能受到科学界权威人士的质疑，那么他的才华、思想的独创性和无畏的求知精神却无人否认。自20岁那年因轻微的语言障碍被确诊为肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）以来，他那不屈不挠的意志一直支撑着他的生命和事业，这令世人无比钦佩。1963年确诊后，霍金被医生预估最多只有两年的寿命。他至少有一次濒临死亡，在前往瑞士的旅途中，他患上了肺炎，一度陷入昏迷。然而，在确诊40年后，尽管瘫痪、只能依靠轮椅出行、身体完全依赖他人，他仍然出版了他的第二本畅销书。他不知疲倦地周游世界，尽管无法用自己的声音说话，他的演讲依然备受欢迎。他荣获了众多科学荣誉。

Although there are exceptions, the course of ALS is generally predictable. The vast majority of patients die within ten years of diagnosis, many much sooner. Very rarely people do make recovery from what seems like ALS, but it is extremely unusual for a person to live with its ravages for as long as Stephen Hawking has, continuing not only to work but to function at a high level. What has enabled him to confound medical opinion and those grim statistics?

尽管也有例外，但肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）的病程通常是可以预测的。绝大多数患者会在确诊后十年内去世，许多人甚至更早。极少数人能从看似ALS的症状中康复，但像斯蒂芬·霍金那样，在饱受ALS折磨的情况下还能如此长久地生存，不仅继续工作，而且保持着高水平的竞技状态，实属罕见。究竟是什么让他能够颠覆医学界的认知和那些令人沮丧的统计数据呢？

We cannot understand Hawking’s course as an isolated clinical phenomenon, separated from the circumstances of his life and relationships. His longevity is, without doubt, a tribute to his spirited determination not to allow the disease to defeat him. But I also believe that Sue Rodriguez’s bitter comparison was correct: the young Stephen had access to invisible resources denied to most people with ALS. Given the nature of ALS as a disease that destroys body while leaving the intellect intact, an abstract thinker was in an ideal position to “live a life of the mind.” Unlike the athletic rock climber and former marathoner Rodriguez and unlike the dancers Laura and Joanne, Hawking did not see his body’s deterioration as impairing the role that he chose for himself. On the contrary, it may have enhanced it. Prior to his diagnosis and its attendant debility, he had been somewhat aimless, his shining intellectual gifts notwithstanding.

我们不能将霍金的病情发展视为孤立的临床现象，脱离他的生活环境和人际关系。毫无疑问，他的长寿是对他不向疾病屈服的顽强意志的最好证明。但我认为苏·罗德里格斯的苦涩比喻也并非毫无道理：年轻的斯蒂芬拥有大多数肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）患者所不具备的无形资源。ALS是一种会摧毁身体却不影响智力的疾病，因此，像他这样一位抽象思维者，在精神层面上处于“过一种充满智慧的生活”的理想状态。与热爱攀岩和马拉松的罗德里格斯，以及舞蹈家劳拉和乔安妮不同，霍金并没有将身体的衰退视为对自己所选择角色的阻碍。相反，这或许反而增强了他的能力。在确诊ALS并开始出现身体虚弱之前，尽管他才华横溢，但生活却有些漫无目的。

Hawking had always possessed tremendous cognitive and mathematical capacities and confidence, but he never seemed to feel comfortable in his body. “He was eccentric and awkward, skinny and puny,” write Michael White and John Gribbin in Stephen Hawking, A Life in Science . “His school uniform always looked a mess and, according to his friends, he jabbered rather than talked clearly…. He was just that sort of kid—a figure of classroom fun, teased and occasionally bullied, secretly respected by some and avoided by most.” He did not look to fulfill the expectations those who had glimpsed his true abilities held for him. The young Stephen, it appears, was the chosen bearer of the frustrated ambitions of his father who was evidently determined that his son would succeed at educational and social goals he, the father, had never quite attained. One goal was to have Stephen attend one of England’s most prestigious private schools. The ten-year-old-boy was entered for the Westminster School scholarship examination: “ The day of the examination arrived, and Stephen fell ill . He never sat the entrance paper and consequently never obtained a place at one of England’s best schools.”

霍金一直拥有惊人的认知能力、数学天赋和自信心，但他似乎始终对自己的身体感到不自在。“他古怪笨拙，瘦弱不堪，”迈克尔·怀特和约翰·格里宾在《斯蒂芬·霍金：科学人生》一书中写道，“他的校服总是乱糟糟的，据他的朋友们说，他说话含糊不清，语无伦次……他就是那种孩子——课堂上的开心果，常被嘲笑甚至欺负，有些人暗自敬重他，而大多数人却避之不及。”他似乎并没有努力达到那些曾领略过他真正才华的人对他的期望。年轻的斯蒂芬似乎是他父亲未能实现的抱负的载体，他的父亲显然决心让儿子在教育和社会方面取得成功，实现他自己未能达成的目标。其中一个目标就是让斯蒂芬进入英国最负盛名的私立学校之一。这位十岁男孩报名参加了威斯敏斯特公学的奖学金考试：“考试当天，斯蒂芬生病了。他没能参加考试，因此也没能进入英国最好的学校之一。”

One may assume, of course, that this untimely illness was purely coincidental. We may also see it as the child’s only way of saying no to parental pressure. Given the Hawking family’s penchant for privacy, the facts would be difficult to discern. What we do know is that later on, with the young Hawking no longer living at home and at liberty to follow his preferences, these appeared to be more of a social than academic nature. Stephen engaged in a fair bit of indolence and alcohol consumption, with avoidance of classes or studying—those classic forms of passive resistance in college. For a while his academic career looked in jeopardy, and briefly he considered entering the civil service. It was only after his diagnosis that he began to focus his phenomenal intelligence on his work: elucidating the nature of the cosmos, bridging the theoretical gaps between Einsteinian relativity theory and quantum mechanics. With his physical disability, he was freed from many of the tasks of teaching and administration other scientists have to shoulder. His biographers write: “Some have attributed his great successes in cosmology to this enhanced cerebral freedom, yet others have claimed that the turning-point in the application of his abilities was the onset of his condition, and that before then he was no more than an averagely bright student.”

当然，人们可能会认为这场突如其来的疾病纯属巧合。我们也可以将其视为孩子对父母压力的唯一反抗方式。鉴于霍金一家一向注重隐私，真相难以辨明。我们所知道的是，后来，年轻的霍金离开家，可以自由地追求自己的喜好，而这些喜好似乎更多地体现在社交而非学术方面。斯蒂芬相当懒散，酗酒，逃避上课和学习——这些都是大学里典型的消极抵抗形式。他的学术生涯一度岌岌可危，他甚至短暂地考虑过进入公务员队伍。直到确诊之后，他才开始将自己惊人的智慧投入到工作中：阐明宇宙的本质，弥合爱因斯坦相对论和量子力学之间的理论鸿沟。由于身体残疾，他摆脱了其他科学家必须承担的许多教学和行政工作。他的传记作者写道：“有些人将他在宇宙学方面的巨大成功归功于这种增强的思维自由，而另一些人则声称，他能力的转折点是他患病的开始，在此之前，他只不过是一个普通的聪明学生。”

That latter point is difficult to accept, but even Hawking has acknowledged that it was only after the onset of his illness that he began to exert himself at anything: “I … started working for the first time in my life. To my surprise, I found I liked it. Maybe it’s not really fair to call it work. Someone once said, scientists and prostitutes get paid for doing what they enjoy.”

后一点很难让人接受，但就连霍金也承认，他是在患病之后才开始真正投入到工作中的：“我……生平第一次开始工作。令我惊讶的是，我发现自己喜欢上了工作。也许称之为工作并不恰当。有人说过，科学家和妓女都是因为做自己喜欢的事而获得报酬。”

Not much insight there about prostitutes, but it is clear Hawking has been in the extremely fortunate position of being able to pursue a genuine vocation, despite his extreme physical limitations.

虽然对妓女没有太多见解，但很明显，霍金非常幸运，尽管他身体有极大的缺陷，却能够追求一份真正的职业。

The other indispensable factor Hawking possessed and Rodriquez missed was the unconditional emotional support and practical caring of a loved one. For Stephen the source of this nurturing was his wife, now his former wife, Jane Hawking. In essence, she decided to devote her life to him—at great personal cost to herself, as she would come to learn. The two met just before Stephen’s diagnosis with ALS and were married shortly afterwards. Due to her own history, Jane was primed to accept the role of devoted and selfless caregiver. I write selfless here advisedly: there was lacking in her a developed, autonomous sense of self, and thus she completely identified with her role as Stephen’s nurse, mother and guardian angel. “I wanted to find some purpose to my existence,” she recalls in her 1993 memoir, Music to Move the Stars, “and I supposed I found it in the idea of looking after him.” When she doubted her ability to fulfill that daunting task, friends told her, “If he needs you, you must do it.” She took it on.

霍金拥有而罗德里格斯所缺乏的另一个不可或缺的因素，是来自爱人的无条件的情感支持和实际照料。对斯蒂芬而言，这种滋养的源泉是他的妻子，也就是现在的妻子简·霍金。实际上，她决定将自己的一生奉献给他——正如她后来所体会到的，这让她付出了巨大的个人代价。两人在斯蒂芬被确诊患有肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）前不久相识，并在不久后结婚。由于自身的经历，简早已准备好接受一位全心全意、无私奉献的照护者的角色。我在这里特意用了“无私”这个词：她缺乏成熟的、自主的自我意识，因此她完全认同自己作为斯蒂芬的护士、母亲和守护天使的角色。“我想找到我存在的意义，”她在1993年出版的回忆录《动人心弦的音乐》中写道，“我想我在照顾他的想法中找到了它。”当她怀疑自己是否有能力完成这项艰巨的任务时，朋友们告诉她：“如果他需要你，你就必须去做。”她接受了。

The two young people did not just join each other as equals in a spousal partnership: they fused. They became one body, heart and soul. Without the subordination of Jane’s life and independent strivings to his, Stephen likely would not have survived, let alone succeeded to such a spectacular degree. His biographers assert that “without the help that Jane gave him, he almost certainly would not have been able to carry on, or had the will to do so.” 10

这两个年轻人不仅仅是平等地结为夫妻，他们更是融为一体。他们心意相通，灵魂相连。如果没有简将自己的人生和独立追求奉献给他，斯蒂芬很可能无法生存，更遑论取得如此辉煌的成就。他的传记作者断言：“如果没有简的帮助，他几乎肯定无法坚持下去，或者说，他根本没有坚持下去的意志。”

The relationship worked as long as Jane accepted her self-abnegating position and the one-way flow of psychic energy between them, from wife to husband. The couple loved each other, but she would come to feel used. She recounts a strange incident when, in 1965, she arrived at her fiance’s apartment with a broken arm in a cast: “He was actually expecting that I would put my secretarial skills to good use by typing out a job application for him. The look of horrified dismay that spread across his face as I walked into his room with my left arm bulging beneath my coat in a white plaster cast dashed all my hopes of even the merest display of sympathy.”

只要简接受自己自我牺牲的处境，以及两人之间单向的、从妻子到丈夫的精神能量流动，这段关系就能维持下去。这对夫妻彼此相爱，但她最终会感到自己被利用了。她回忆起1965年发生的一件怪事：她胳膊骨折，打着石膏，来到未婚夫的公寓。“他竟然指望我能发挥我的秘书技能，帮他打一份求职申请。当我走进他的房间，左臂在白色石膏下鼓鼓囊囊地露出来时，他脸上露出惊恐的表情，这让我彻底粉碎了所有哪怕是最轻微的同情的希望。”

The episode encapsulated the nature of their relationship: she was the ever-available, unspeaking and compliant mother/nanny figure whose services are expected, taken for granted and noticed only in their absence. She travelled the world with her husband, daily confronting and overcoming myriad difficulties that were only much later—and even then only partially—eased once he became an internationally famous and high-earning author. She felt herself gradually disappear as an individual. She was sucked dry, sensing herself becoming a “brittle, empty shell, alone and vulnerable,” and nearly suicidal. Hawking, for his part, reacted to her strivings for independence with disdain and finally with the rage of a child deserted by his mother. The wife was eventually supplanted by a nurse who left her own husband to marry the scientist. Jane, too, had found another love. It was only this outside relationship that, in the final years of the marriage, allowed her to continue to serve Stephen as long as she did.

这一幕淋漓尽致地展现了他们关系的本质：她扮演着随叫随到、沉默寡言、百依百顺的母亲/保姆角色，她的付出被视为理所当然，只有在她缺席时才会被人察觉。她陪伴丈夫周游世界，每日面对并克服无数困难，而这些困难直到很久以后——即便如此也只是部分缓解——在他成为国际知名的高收入作家之后才有所减轻。她感觉自己逐渐失去了作为个体的独立性。她被榨干了所有能量，感觉自己变成了一个“脆弱、空洞、孤独而易受伤害的躯壳”，甚至一度想要自杀。而霍金则对她追求独立的努力嗤之以鼻，最终演变成一个被母亲抛弃的孩子般的愤怒。最终，一位护士取代了她，这位护士为了嫁给这位科学家而离开了自己的丈夫。简也找到了新的爱情。正是这段婚外情，让她在婚姻的最后几年里，得以继续服侍斯蒂芬那么久。

Hawking’s vocation and the unstinting support of his wife were accompanied by something else that has probably aided his survival: the liberation of his aggression by his illness. The “niceness” of most ALS patients represents more than the innate goodness and sweetness of some human beings; it is an emotion in extremis . It is magnified out of healthy proportion by a powerful suppression of assertiveness.

霍金的职业追求和妻子的全力支持，还伴随着另一种可能帮助他活下来的因素：疾病释放了他原本的攻击性。大多数渐冻症患者的“和善”不仅仅代表了某些人与生俱来的善良和温柔；它是一种极端的情感。这种和善被强烈压抑，从而不成比例地放大。

Assertiveness in defence of our boundaries can and should appear aggressive, if need be. Hawking’s intellectual self-assuredness became the ground for that aggression to manifest itself, particularly after the onset of his physical decline. Jane Hawking notes in her memoir that “curiously, as his gait became more unsteady so his opinions became more forceful and defiant.”

为了捍卫自身权益，必要时，我们的坚定立场可以而且应该显得咄咄逼人。霍金的自信，尤其是他身体状况开始恶化之后，成为了这种咄咄逼人的根源。简·霍金在回忆录中写道：“奇怪的是，随着他步履越来越不稳，他的观点也变得越来越强硬和桀骜不驯。”

Like that of all the ALS sufferers we have met, Hawking’s personality has been characterized by intense psychological repression. In his family of origin, healthy vulnerability and emotional interaction appear to have been perceived as foreign. At the supper table, the Hawkings would eat without communicating, each head lowered into reading matter. Stephen’s childhood home was in a state of physical neglect that went beyond eccentricity to indicate an emotional distance on the part of both parents. His biographers relate, “Neither Isobel nor Frank Hawking semed to care too much about the state of the house. Carpets and furniture remained in use until they began to fall apart; wallpaper was allowed to dangle where it had peeled through old age; and there were many places along the hallway and behind doors where plaster had fallen away, leaving gaping holes in the wall.”

和我们遇到的所有渐冻症患者一样，霍金的性格也带有强烈的心理压抑。在他的原生家庭中，健康的脆弱和情感交流似乎被视为异类。在餐桌上，霍金一家人默默地吃着饭，各自低头阅读。斯蒂芬童年的家破败不堪，这种状况不仅体现了他的古怪，更反映了父母情感上的疏离。他的传记作者写道：“伊莎贝尔和弗兰克·霍金似乎都不太在意房子的状况。地毯和家具一直用到破烂不堪；墙纸年久失修，摇摇欲坠；走廊和门后很多地方的石膏都脱落了，墙上留下一个个大洞。”

Of Stephen’s father, White and Gribbin write that he was a remote figure, “significant in Stephen’s childhood and adolescence by his absence.” According to Jane, the Hawkings regarded “any expression of emotion or appreciation as a sign of weakness, as loss of control or a denial of their own importance…. Strangely, they seemed ashamed of demonstrating any warmth.”

怀特和格里宾在书中写道，斯蒂芬的父亲是一个疏远的人物，“他的缺席对斯蒂芬的童年和青少年时期意义重大”。据简所说，霍金夫妇认为“任何情感或感激的表达都是软弱的表现，是失去控制或否定自身重要性的表现……奇怪的是，他们似乎羞于流露出任何热情。”

After Stephen and Jane married, his family withdrew from active involvement with his care, a fact Jane could barely fathom, let alone accept. Besides her responsibilities toward her husband, she also had full care of their three children. His refusal to acknowledge the pressures placed on her by his illness—and her compliant subjection to that attitude—meant that she never received any respite. “I was at the breaking-point,” she recalls, “but still Stephen was determined to reject any proposals which might have suggested that he was making concessions to the illness. These were the proposals which might have relieved the children and me of some of the strain.” He simply refused to discuss any problem, relying on Jane’s willingness to absorb all the resultant stress. “He had never liked to admit to emotions,” writes Jane, “regarding them as the fatal, irrational flaw in my character.” Her attempts to gain support from her husband’s family were met with cold incomprehension, even hostility. “You see,” her mother-in-law once told her, “we have never really liked you, Jane; you do not fit into our family.” This after decades of self-effacing service to her son.

斯蒂芬和简结婚后，他的家人便不再积极参与他的照护，简对此几乎难以理解，更遑论接受。除了对丈夫的责任，她还要全心全意地照顾三个孩子。他拒绝承认疾病给她带来的压力，而她却逆来顺受，这意味着她从未得到过任何喘息的机会。“我当时已经濒临崩溃，”她回忆道，“但斯蒂芬仍然执意拒绝任何可能暗示他向疾病妥协的提议。而这些提议本可以减轻我和孩子们的一些压力。”他干脆拒绝讨论任何问题，指望简独自承受所有压力。“他从来不喜欢承认自己的情感，”简写道，“他认为情感是我性格中致命的、非理性的缺陷。”她试图从丈夫的家人那里获得支持，却只换来冷漠的理解，甚至是敌意。 “你看，”她的婆婆曾经对她说，“我们从来都不喜欢你，简；你不适合我们家。”而在此之前，她已经默默地为儿子奉献了几十年。

Has it been shown in this chapter that ALS is caused by, or is at least potentiated by, emotional repression? That it is rooted in childhood emotional isolation and loss? That generally—even if not always—it strikes people who lead driven lives and whom others consider to be very “nice”? Until our understanding of the mind/body complex is more advanced, this must remain an intriguing hypothesis but a hypothesis one would be challenged to find any exceptions to. It seems far-fetched to suppose that such frequently observed associations can be all a matter of pure coincidence.

本章是否已证明，肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）是由情绪压抑引起的，或者至少会因情绪压抑而加剧？它是否根源于童年时期的情感孤立和丧失？它是否通常（即便并非总是如此）侵袭那些生活充实、性格温和的人？在我们对身心关系的理解更加深入之前，这只能算是一个引人入胜的假设，但要找到任何例外情况都并非易事。认为这些频繁出现的关联仅仅是巧合，似乎有些牵强。

A mind-body perspective may help those afflicted with ALS who are willing to look at some very painful realities fully and unflinchingly. In rare instances, people do seem to get over symptoms diagnosed as ALS. It would be worthwhile investigating such cases to find out why. One example is reported by Dr. Christiane Northrup in Women’s Bodies, Women’s Wisdom:

对于那些愿意坦然面对痛苦现实的渐冻症患者来说，身心合一的视角或许有所帮助。在极少数情况下，人们似乎确实能够克服被诊断为渐冻症的症状。研究这些案例以探究其原因将十分有意义。克里斯蒂安·诺斯鲁普博士在《女性的身体，女性的智慧》一书中报告了一个例子：

Dana Johnson, a researcher friend of mine and a registered nurse, even recovered from Lou Gehrig’s disease by learning to respect all aspects of her body.

我的研究员朋友兼注册护士达娜·约翰逊甚至通过学会尊重自己身体的各个方面，从肌萎缩侧索硬化症（卢伽雷氏症）中康复了。

After she had had the disease for some years, she began to lose control over her breathing muscles as well as the rest of her body. Her breathing difficulties made her think she was going to die. But she decided at that point that she wanted to experience unconditional love for herself at least once before dying. Describing herself as a “bowl of Jell-O in a wheelchair,” she sat every day for fifteen minutes in front of a mirror and chose different parts of herself to love. She started with her hands, because at that time they were the only parts of herself that she could appreciate unconditionally. Each day she went on to other body parts….

在患病几年后，她开始逐渐失去对呼吸肌以及身体其他部位的控制。呼吸困难让她觉得自己即将死去。但那时她决定，至少在临终前体验一次无条件的爱。她形容自己就像“坐在轮椅上的果冻”，每天在镜子前坐十五分钟，选择自己身体的不同部位去爱。她从双手开始，因为那时只有双手是她能够无条件欣赏的。之后，她每天都会选择身体的其他部位……

She also wrote in a journal about insights she had during this process, and she came to see that since childhood she had believed that in order to be of service, acceptable to others, and worthy of herself, she had to sacrifice her own needs. It took a life-threatening disease for her to learn that service through self-sacrifice is a dead end. 11

她还在日记中记录了这一过程中的感悟，她逐渐意识到，从孩提时代起，她就一直认为，为了服务他人、被他人接纳、有价值，她必须牺牲自己的需求。一场危及生命的疾病让她明白，通过自我牺牲来服务他人是一条死路。

According to Dr. Northrup, her friend healed through the conscious daily practice of emotional self-inventory and of self-love that, little by little, “unfroze” each part of her body. Had I read such a story when I graduated from medical school, I would have dismissed it out of hand. Even now, the scientifically trained physician in me would like to see direct proof that ALS was legitimately diagnosed in this case. In palliative work I once saw a person admitted for “respite care” who had convinced herself and her circle of friends that she suffered from ALS, despite the electrodiagnostic testing and neurological findings having all been, repeatedly, perfectly normal. The friends scarcely believed me when I informed them that the invalid they had been assiduously caring for was, from the narrow physical point of view, as healthy as they were.

据诺斯鲁普医生说，她的朋友通过每天有意识地进行情绪自我反思和自我关爱，一点一点地“解冻”了她身体的每一部分，最终痊愈了。如果我医学院毕业时读到这样的故事，我会毫不犹豫地否定它。即使现在，我作为一名受过科学训练的医生，仍然希望看到直接证据，证明这个病例中肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）的诊断是合法的。在临终关怀工作中，我曾遇到一位因“短期照护”入院的病人，尽管电诊断测试和神经系统检查结果反复显示一切正常，她仍然说服自己和朋友们相信她患有ALS。当我告诉她的朋友们，从生理角度来看，他们一直悉心照料的病人其实和他们一样健康时，他们几乎不敢相信。

Today I do not find Dr. Northrup’s report impossible to credit. It accords with my understanding of this disease. There was an intriguing incident in the story of Alexa, the teacher whose husband, Peter, could not accept the diagnosis of ALS. It revealed the potential of something that, perhaps, may have been. The psychologist Gordon Neufeld managed on only one occasion to see her alone, without her spouse. “It was absolutely clear to me that her emotions were tied up, that she had lost her vitality,” Dr. Neufeld says. “There was a two-hour session when Peter was away, and she grieved intensely about her life and about her illness. It made a huge difference to her. The physiotherapist saw her right afterwards and was amazed that her muscle tone was so much better. But I could never meet with her alone again, and I could never get her to that place again. The window just shut.”

今天，我并不觉得诺斯鲁普博士的报告完全不可信。它与我对这种疾病的理解相符。在教师艾莉克莎的故事中，有一件引人深思的事。她的丈夫彼得无法接受她被诊断为肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）。这件事揭示了某种可能性，或许原本可以实现。心理学家戈登·纽菲尔德只设法单独见过她一次，当时她的丈夫不在场。“我非常清楚地看到，她的情绪被压抑着，她失去了活力，”纽菲尔德博士说。“彼得不在的时候，我们进行了两个小时的会面，她深深地为自己的人生和疾病感到悲伤。这对她产生了巨大的影响。理疗师随后也见到了她，惊讶地发现她的肌肉张力有了很大的改善。但我再也无法单独与她见面，也无法让她再次达到那种状态。机会之窗已经关闭了。”

* A gene for breast cancer runs in Laura’s family. Her sister was also diagnosed, six months before Laura. Breast cancer will be the subject of a later chapter .

劳拉的家族有乳腺癌遗传基因。她的姐姐也于六个月前被确诊患有乳腺癌。乳腺癌将在后面的章节中详细探讨。

5
5
Never Good Enough
永远不够好

F OR SEVEN YEARS, MICHELLE had a lump in her breast. Periodically, it grew or shrank, but it never caused her or her physicians any concern. “Then all of a sudden it got really hard, got hot and started to grow almost overnight,” the thirty-nine-year-old Vancouverite says. A biopsy revealed that the tumour was malignant, and Michelle believes she knows why: stress. “It wasn’t until I shocked the hell out of my life that it changed,” she says. “I quit my job, without any income to go to…. My emotional state was horrible at the time. A lot of things hit me all at once, not only financial.” Michelle had a lumpectomy and was relieved to learn that her lymph glands were free of cancer. The surgery was followed by chemotherapy and radiation, but no physician ever asked her about what psychic stresses she might have suffered before the onset of her malignancy or what unresolved issues she had in her life.

米歇尔的乳房里一直长着一个肿块，长达七年之久。它时而增大时而缩小，但从未引起她或医生的担忧。“然后突然之间，它变得非常硬，发热，几乎一夜之间就开始生长，”这位39岁的温哥华居民说道。活检结果显示肿瘤是恶性的，米歇尔认为她知道原因：压力。“直到我的生活发生了翻天覆地的变化，一切才发生了改变，”她说。“我辞掉了工作，没有任何收入来源……当时我的情绪非常糟糕。很多事情一下子都压垮了我，不仅仅是经济上的。”米歇尔做了肿块切除术，得知淋巴结没有癌细胞后，她松了一口气。手术后，她接受了化疗和放疗，但没有一位医生问过她在患上恶性肿瘤之前可能承受过哪些精神压力，或者生活中有哪些未解决的问题。

Breast cancer patients often report that their doctors do not express an active interest in them as individuals or in the social and emotional context in which they live. The assumption is that these factors have no significant role in either the origins or the treatment of disease. That attitude is reinforced by narrowly conceived psychological research.

乳腺癌患者常常反映，医生对她们个人以及她们所处的社会和情感环境缺乏积极关注。这种观点认为，这些因素在疾病的发生或治疗中都无关紧要。而一些狭隘的心理学研究也强化了这种观念。

An article in the British Medical Journal reported on a five-year study of more than two hundred women with breast cancer that aimed to determine whether a recurrence of cancer can be triggered by severe life events, such as divorce or the death of someone close. The authors concluded that “women with breast cancer need not fear that stressful experiences will precipitate a return of their disease.” 1 Dr. Donna Stewart, a professor at the University of Toronto and chairwoman of women’s issues for the University Health Network, commented that the study’s results “made sense.”

《英国医学杂志》的一篇文章报道了一项历时五年、针对两百多名乳腺癌女性的研究，旨在确定诸如离婚或亲人去世等重大生活事件是否会引发癌症复发。作者得出结论：“乳腺癌患者无需担心压力事件会导致疾病复发。”多伦多大学教授、大学健康网络女性事务主席唐娜·斯图尔特博士评论说，这项研究的结果“合情合理”。

Dr. Stewart was the lead author of a study published in 2001 in the journal Psycho-Oncology . Nearly four hundred women with a history of breast cancer were asked what they thought had caused their malignancy. Forty-two per cent cited stress—much more than other factors such as diet, environment, genetics and lifestyle. 2 “I think it reflects what’s going on in society in general,” Dr. Stewart says. “People think stress causes everything. The evidence for stress is pretty low. And the evidence for hormones and genetics is pretty high.”

斯图尔特博士是2001年发表在《心理肿瘤学》杂志上的一项研究的主要作者。该研究询问了近400名有乳腺癌病史的女性，她们认为自己患癌的原因是什么。42%的女性认为是压力造成的——这一比例远高于其他因素，例如饮食、环境、遗传和生活方式。斯图尔特博士说：“我认为这反映了社会普遍存在的现象。人们认为压力是所有问题的根源。但压力导致乳腺癌的证据非常薄弱，而激素和遗传因素导致乳腺癌的证据则非常充分。”

Yet Michelle and the many other women who suspect a strong relationship between stress and their breast cancer have science and clinical insight on their side. No other cancer has been as minutely studied for the potential biological connections between psychological influences and the onset of the disease. A rich body of evidence, drawn from animal studies and human experience, supports the impression of cancer patients that emotional stress is a major contributing cause of breast malignancy.

然而，米歇尔和其他许多怀疑压力与乳腺癌之间存在密切联系的女性，她们的观点得到了科学和临床研究的支持。没有其他癌症像乳腺癌一样，在心理因素与疾病发生之间的潜在生物学联系方面得到如此细致的研究。大量来自动物实验和人类经验的证据支持了癌症患者的看法，即情绪压力是导致乳腺癌的主要因素之一。

Contrary to the assertions of the Toronto researchers, the “evidence for genetics” is not high. Only a small minority of women are at high genetic risk for breast cancer and only a small minority of women with breast cancer—about 7 per cent—acquire the disease for genetic reasons. Even for those genetically predisposed, environmental factors must be involved, since far from everyone with one of the three genes known to be associated with breast cancer will actually develop a malignant tumour. In the vast majority of women or men diagnosed with breast cancer, heredity makes little or no contribution.

与多伦多研究人员的断言相反，“遗传学证据”并不强。只有极少数女性具有较高的乳腺癌遗传风险，而乳腺癌患者中只有极少数（约占7%）是由遗传因素导致的。即使是那些具有遗传易感性的人，也必然受到环境因素的影响，因为并非所有携带已知与乳腺癌相关的三个基因之一的人都会发展成恶性肿瘤。在绝大多数被诊断患有乳腺癌的女性或男性中，遗传因素的影响微乎其微，甚至没有影响。

It is artificial to impose a separation between hormones and emotions. While it is perfectly true that hormones are active promoters or inhibitors of malignancy, it is not true that their actions have nothing to do with stress. In fact, one of the chief ways that emotions act biologically in cancer causation is through the effect of hormones. Some hormones—estrogen, for example—encourage tumour growth. Others enhance cancer development by reducing the immune system’s capacity to destroy malignant cells.

将激素和情绪割裂开来是人为的。虽然激素确实会促进或抑制恶性肿瘤的发生，但这并不意味着它们的作用与压力毫无关联。事实上，情绪在癌症发生过程中发挥生物学作用的主要途径之一就是通过激素的影响。某些激素——例如雌激素——会促进肿瘤生长。另一些激素则会通过降低免疫系统清除癌细胞的能力来促进癌症发展。

Hormone production is intimately affected by psychological stress. Women have always known that emotional stress affects their ovarian function and their menstrual cycles—excessive stress may even inhibit menstruation.

激素分泌与心理压力密切相关。女性一直都知道，情绪压力会影响卵巢功能和月经周期——过度压力甚至可能抑制月经。

The body’s hormonal system is inextricably linked with the brain centres where emotions are experienced and interpreted. In turn, the hormonal apparatus and the emotional centres are interconnected with the immune system and the nervous system. These are not four separate systems, but one super-system that functions as a unit to protect the body from external invasion and from disturbances to the internal physiological condition. It is impossible for any stressful stimulus, chronic or acute, to act on only one part of the super-system. What happens to one will affect all. In chapter 7 we will examine the workings of this supersystem more closely.

人体的激素系统与大脑中负责体验和解读情绪的中心密不可分。反过来，激素系统和情绪中心又与免疫系统和神经系统相互关联。这并非四个独立的系统，而是一个协同运作的超级系统，共同保护身体免受外部入侵和内部生理紊乱的影响。任何压力刺激，无论是慢性还是急性，都不可能只作用于这个超级系统的某个部分。一个部分的变化会影响到整个系统。在第七章中，我们将更深入地探讨这个超级系统的运作机制。

Emotions also directly modulate the immune system. Studies at the U.S. National Cancer Institute found that natural killer (NK) cells, an important class of immune cells we have already met, are more active in breast cancer patients who are able to express anger, to adopt a fighting stance and who have more social support. NK cells mount an attack on malignant cells and are able to destroy them. These women had significantly less spread of their breast cancer, compared with those who exhibited a less assertive attitude or who had fewer nurturing social connections. The researchers found that emotional factors and social involvement were more important to survival than the degree of disease itself. 3

情绪也会直接调节免疫系统。美国国家癌症研究所的研究发现，我们之前已经了解的一种重要的免疫细胞——自然杀伤（NK）细胞，在那些能够表达愤怒、采取积极应对的态度以及拥有更多社会支持的乳腺癌患者体内更为活跃。NK细胞会攻击并摧毁癌细胞。与那些态度较为消极或缺乏社会支持的女性相比，这些女性的乳腺癌扩散程度明显更低。研究人员发现，情绪因素和社会参与对生存的影响比疾病本身的严重程度更为重要。

Many studies, such as the one reported in The British Medical Journal article, fail to appreciate that stress is not only a question of external stimulus but also of individual response. It occurs in the real lives of real persons whose inborn temperament, life history, emotional patterns, physical and mental resources, and social and economic supports vary greatly. As pointed out in chapter 3 , there is no universal stressor.

许多研究，例如《英国医学杂志》文章中报道的那项研究，未能认识到压力不仅取决于外部刺激，也取决于个体的反应。压力存在于真实个体的生活中，而每个人的先天气质、人生经历、情绪模式、身心资源以及社会经济支持都存在巨大差异。正如第三章所指出的，并不存在普遍适用的压力源。

In most cases of breast cancer, the stresses are hidden and chronic. They stem from childhood experiences, early emotional programming and unconscious psychological coping styles. They accumulate over a lifetime to make someone susceptible to disease.

大多数乳腺癌病例中的压力都是隐性的、慢性的。这些压力源于童年经历、早期的情感影响以及无意识的心理应对方式。它们在人的一生中不断累积，最终使人更容易患病。

Michelle grew up in a home where both parents were alcoholics. She now believes that her malignancy is related to early experiences that shaped how she has faced life. She has tried to cope in ways that, unconsciously, increased the stress load she had to carry for many years—for example, by taking care of other people’s emotional needs rather than her own. “I’ve been confused all my life,” she says, “and I think my cancer had to do with confusion…. As much as I believe and understand my parents loved us the best way they knew how, it was the most confusing relationship and family environment because they were alcoholics, and still are. They’re unloving even though there is love.”

米歇尔在一个双亲都是酗酒者的家庭长大。她现在认为，她的恶性肿瘤与早年的经历有关，这些经历塑造了她面对生活的方式。多年来，她一直试图用一些无意识的方式应对困境，例如，她总是优先照顾他人的情感需求，而不是自己的。“我一生都感到困惑，”她说，“我认为我的癌症与这种困惑有关……尽管我相信并理解我的父母尽其所能地爱着我们，但由于他们是酗酒者，而且至今仍然如此，所以那段关系和家庭环境令人困惑。即使爱还在，他们也表现得冷漠无情。”

Research has suggested for decades that women are more prone to develop breast cancer if their childhoods were characterized by emotional disconnection from their parents or other disturbances in their upbringing; if they tend to repress emotions, particularly anger; if they lack nurturing social relationships in adulthood; and if they are the altruistic, compulsively caregiving types. In one study, psychologists interviewed patients admitted to hospital for breast biopsy, without knowing the pathology results. Researchers were able to predict the presence of cancer in up to 94 per cent of cases judging by such psychological factors alone. 4 In a similar German study, forty women with breast cancer were matched with forty controls similar in age, general health history and lifestyle considerations. Again, on psychological grounds the researchers were 96 per cent successful in identifying who was and who was not diagnosed with breast cancer. 5

数十年的研究表明，如果女性童年时期与父母情感疏离或成长过程中存在其他问题；如果她们倾向于压抑情绪，尤其是愤怒；如果她们成年后缺乏滋养性的社会关系；以及如果她们是无私奉献、过度照顾他人的类型，那么她们患乳腺癌的风险会更高。在一项研究中，心理学家在不知道病理结果的情况下，对因乳腺活检入院的患者进行了访谈。研究人员仅凭这些心理因素，就能预测高达94%的病例是否患有癌症。在另一项类似的德国研究中，研究人员将40名乳腺癌患者与40名年龄、一般健康史和生活方式相似的对照组女性进行匹配。同样，研究人员仅凭心理学因素，就能成功识别出96%的乳腺癌患者和非患者。

As a man, Melvin Crew * was at first embarrassed to learn of his diagnosis with breast cancer but decided that “there’s no sense just lying back and letting the disease consume you.” Now, several years after mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiation, he jokes about it. “At least if you fall down, you can’t go tits up because I only have one, you know.”

梅尔文·克鲁（Melvin Crew）最初得知自己被诊断出乳腺癌时感到很尴尬，但他转念一想，“与其坐以待毙，任由疾病吞噬自己，不如就此罢休。”如今，在经历了乳房切除术、化疗和放疗几年后，他开始拿这件事开玩笑。“至少就算摔倒了，也不会像我这样胸部朝上，因为我只有一个乳房，你知道的。”

Fifty-one-year-old Crew was diagnosed in 1994 immediately after a highly stressful period in his life, including a brush with the law over a fishing infraction, public embarrassment, humiliation at work and undue pressure from his employer. He had been on a boat with ten other men and had caught three fish. When fisheries officers made a raid at his house, he gave them a statement.

51岁的克鲁在1994年被确诊患有癌症，此前他经历了一段压力极大的时期，包括因违反捕鱼规定而触犯法律、在公众面前出丑、在工作中遭受羞辱以及来自雇主的过度压力。当时他与另外十名男子同乘一艘船，捕获了三条鱼。渔业官员突击搜查了他的住所，他向他们做了笔录。

“Two other chaps and myself took the brunt; the rest of the fellows denied it. It was hard on my family to have my name plastered across the papers—coast-guard employees charged with illegal fishing—and the whole works. And then, when I did go back on one of the other coast-guard ships, there was the heckling from the other crew members and the jokes that were made…. All the fellows at work said I should have denied it.”

“我和另外两个伙计成了替罪羊；其他人都否认了。我的名字赫然出现在报纸上——海岸警卫队员工被控非法捕鱼——这让我的家人非常难过。后来，当我回到另一艘海岸警卫队的船上时，其他船员又对我冷嘲热讽，还拿我开玩笑……所有同事都说我应该否认。”

This pressure was all the more stressful for Melvin, who describes himself as having always prided himself on his conscientiousness. “Some of my co-workers have said to me, you know, you take your job too serious. They think that I don’t relax enough.”

这种压力对梅尔文来说尤其令人焦虑，他一直以自己的认真负责而自豪。“我的一些同事跟我说，你知道吗，你工作太认真了。他们觉得我不够放松。”

“Do you ever feel you’re doing the work that other people should have done?” I ask.

“你有没有觉得自己在做别人本该做的工作？”我问。

“Yes, you do more than your share. That’s probably just my nature—you know, you don’t want to be looked upon as a slackass.”

“是的，你做的比你应做的要多得多。这大概就是我的性格吧——你知道，谁也不想被人看作是个懒汉。”

“If other people don’t do their share, one solution is to do it for them. The other is to get angry about it.”

“如果其他人不尽自己的一份力，一个解决办法是替他们做。另一个解决办法是对此感到愤怒。”

“If you get angry, it’s like adding fuel to the fire. You have your conscientious workers, and you have your workers that just go with the flow. I did feel angry sometimes. Well, if you express it, you just bring on more problems with the workforce.”

“如果你生气，就如同火上浇油。有些员工尽职尽责，有些员工则随波逐流。我有时确实会生气。但是，如果你把这种情绪表达出来，只会给员工带来更多问题。”

The source of his hyper-conscientiousness became evident when I asked Melvin about his childhood.

当我问梅尔文关于他的童年时，他过度认真负责的根源就显而易见了。

“Was there much affection in your home?”

“你家里充满爱吗？”

“Yes. My father was proud of my sister and me and our accomplishments in life. She’s a teacher. My father was an engineer, and I, of course, followed in his footsteps. Got my engineer’s licence, and my father was really proud of my being an aircraft engineer.”

“是的。我父亲为我和姐姐感到骄傲，也为我们取得的成就感到自豪。她是一名教师。我父亲是一名工程师，我当然也继承了他的事业。我拿到了工程师执照，我父亲为我成为一名飞机工程师而感到非常骄傲。”

“Warmth and affection have nothing to do with achievement: they are there regardless of achievement, just because the parents are emotionally connected with the child. But your answer had to do with accomplishment. I wonder why that is?”

“温暖和关爱与成就无关：它们的存在与成就无关，仅仅因为父母与孩子之间有情感上的联系。但你的回答却与成就有关。我想知道这是为什么？”

“Well, my father was always proud of us.”

“嗯，我父亲一直都为我们感到骄傲。”

“What about your mom—what kind of affection did you get from your mom?”

“那你妈妈呢？你从妈妈那里得到了什么样的爱？”

“Not overly affectionate. We loved our parents, and I feel they certainly provided a good upbringing for us. A good home.”

“我们并不特别亲昵。我们爱我们的父母，而且我觉得他们确实给了我们很好的成长环境。一个温暖的家。”

____

About 1 per cent of breast cancer patients are males. Their emotional histories parallel those of the women with the same disease. David Yeandle, a Toronto policeman, has had four separate cancers: in one of his kidneys, his breast and twice in his bladder. His upbringing was also characterized by a lack of warmth. Born in 1936, David was three when the Second World War broke out. His sister was born in 1940.

大约1%的乳腺癌患者是男性。他们的情感经历与患有同样疾病的女性相似。多伦多警察大卫·延德尔曾罹患四种不同的癌症：一次肾癌、一次乳腺癌，以及两次膀胱癌。他的成长经历也充满了冷漠和缺乏温暖。大卫出生于1936年，二战爆发时他才三岁。他的妹妹出生于1940年。

“My father was a warehouseman, and my mother worked at Cadbury’s chocolates…. I grew up during the war and actually didn’t see a lot of my parents. My mother was out during the day, and my sister and I used to take care of ourselves until she came home.

“我父亲是仓库管理员，母亲在吉百利巧克力厂工作……我是在战争时期长大的，实际上很少见到父母。母亲白天不在家，我和妹妹就自己照顾自己，直到她回家。”

“You must mean that as a very small child, you used to take care of your sister.”

“你的意思是说，你小时候就照顾过你的妹妹吧。”

“Yes.”

“是的。”

David recalls his parents’ marriage as an unhappy one. “They weren’t a loving couple,” he says. “My dad did his thing, and my mother did hers. My dad, most evenings, would go out and shoot pool with his friends. I didn’t have a lot of respect for my mother. She always expected me to give more than I could. I guess I wasn’t a brilliant student. And my mother always saw herself much better than what she was. She was working class, the whole family was, but she always gave the impression to people that we were better than what we were. You had to perform to her standards.”

大卫回忆起父母的婚姻，觉得并不幸福。“他们不是一对恩爱的夫妻，”他说。“我爸有他自己的生活，我妈也有她自己的生活。我爸大多数晚上都会出去和朋友们打台球。我不太尊重我妈。她总是期望我付出超出我能力范围的努力。我想我学习成绩并不好。而且我妈总是觉得自己比实际水平高得多。她出身工人阶级，我们全家都是，但她总是给人一种我们比实际出身更高的印象。你必须达到她的标准。”

“When you were upset as a child, when you felt not understood, when you felt emotionally troubled, whom did you talk to about it?”

“当你小时候感到难过、不被理解或情绪低落时，你会和谁倾诉？”

“Actually, you kept it within yourself. Dad was never there to talk to, and I certainly wouldn’t discuss it with my mother, because her favourite expression was ‘Oh, you’re being silly.’ I never showed anger with my parents. It was something you just didn’t do. I hold a lot of anger inside me.”

“其实，你都把这些情绪藏在心里。爸爸从来不在身边，我当然也不会跟妈妈说，因为她最爱说的一句话就是‘哦，你真是傻瓜’。我从没对父母发过脾气。那是不被允许的。我心里积压了很多怒气。”

“Extreme suppression of anger” was the most commonly identified characteristic of breast cancer patients in a 1974 British study. The investigators looked at a consecutive series of 160 women admitted to hospital for breast biopsy. All subjects were given a detailed psychological interview and self-administered questionnaire. For corroboration, spouses or other family members were also interviewed, separately. Since the psychological testing took place before the biopsy, neither the women nor the interviewers could have prior knowledge of the ultimate diagnosis. “Our principal finding was a significant association between the diagnosis of breast cancer and a behaviour pattern, persisting throughout adult life, of abnormal release of emotions. This abnormality was, in most cases, extreme suppression of anger and, in patients over 40, extreme suppression of other feelings.” 6

1974 年英国一项研究发现，“极度压抑愤怒”是乳腺癌患者最常见的特征。研究人员观察了连续 160 名因乳腺活检入院的女性。所有受试者都接受了详细的心理访谈和自填问卷。为了验证结果，研究人员还分别对她们的配偶或其他家庭成员进行了访谈。由于心理测试是在活检之前进行的，因此女性和访谈者都无法事先得知最终的诊断结果。“我们的主要发现是，乳腺癌的诊断与一种贯穿整个成年期的行为模式——情绪异常释放——之间存在显著关联。这种异常在大多数情况下表现为极度压抑愤怒，而在 40 岁以上的患者中，还表现为极度压抑其他情绪。”

A 1952 psychoanalytic evaluation of women with breast cancer had come to similar conclusions. These patients were said to demonstrate “an inability to discharge or deal appropriately with anger, agressiveness, or hostility (which, in turn, was masked by a facade of pleasantness).” The researchers felt that patients’ unresolved conflicts were “manifested through denial and unrealistic self-sacrificing behaviours.” 7

1952 年一项针对乳腺癌女性的精神分析评估得出了类似的结论。这些患者被描述为“无法妥善处理或排解愤怒、攻击性或敌意（而这些情绪又被一种和蔼可亲的外表所掩盖）”。研究人员认为，患者未解决的冲突“通过否认和不切实际的自我牺牲行为表现出来”。

The research conducted by Dr. Sandra Levy and her associates at the U.S. National Cancer Institute on the relationship between natural killer cell activity and emotional coping patterns in breast cancer concluded that “suppression of anger and a passive, stoic response style seem to be associated with biological risk sequelae.” 8

美国国家癌症研究所的桑德拉·利维博士及其同事开展了一项关于乳腺癌患者自然杀伤细胞活性与情绪应对模式之间关系的研究，研究结论是“压抑愤怒和被动、坚忍的应对方式似乎与生物学风险后遗症有关。”

Repression of anger increases the risk for cancer for the very practical reason that it magnifies exposure to physiological stress. If people are not able to recognize intrusion, or are unable to assert themselves even when they do see a violation, they are likely to experience repeatedly the damage brought on by stress. Recall, from chapter 3 , that stress is a physiological response to a perceived threat, physical or emotional, whether or not the individual is immediately aware of the perception.

压抑愤怒会增加患癌风险，原因很简单：它会加剧生理压力。如果人们无法识别侵犯行为，或者即使看到侵犯也无法维护自身权益，他们就可能反复遭受压力带来的伤害。回顾第三章，压力是对感知到的威胁（无论是生理上的还是情感上的）的一种生理反应，无论个体是否立即意识到这种感知。

“I obviously struggle with the first question that everyone I know who has had cancer asks: ‘What did I do to deserve this? Why me?’ Did I do something wrong? I went over and over everything. I’m not the one that was supposed to get breast cancer. I breast-fed my children to twenty-one months. I smoked a little, only when I was young. I didn’t drink too much. I exercised. I watched the fat in my diet. This wasn’t supposed to happen to me.” The speaker is Anna, a mother of three who was in her mid-forties when the suspicious lump was found eight years ago. Anna has one of the breast cancer genes.

“我当然也难以回答所有我认识的癌症患者都会问的第一个问题：‘我做错了什么才落得这下？为什么是我？’我做错了什么吗？我一遍又一遍地回想。我不应该得乳腺癌的。我给孩子们喂了21个月的母乳。我年轻的时候抽过一点烟。我不怎么喝酒。我坚持锻炼。我注意饮食中的脂肪摄入。这不应该发生在我身上。” 说话的是安娜，一位三个孩子的母亲。八年前，在她四十多岁的时候，医生发现了一个可疑的肿块。安娜携带一种乳腺癌基因。

Even in the small minority of cases where it is a major predisposing factor, heredity cannot by itself explain who gets breast cancer and who does not. DNA testing has shown that Anna inherited the breast cancer gene from her father. Other relatives with the same gene, older than she is, have not developed breast cancer. Anna is convinced that stress was instrumental in the development of her cancer. Her first husband, a businessman, mistreated her emotionally throughout her marriage. By the time the relationship ended, she was also being physically abused. “If you ask me why I got cancer, I would tell you it’s because I allowed myself to be so destroyed in that marriage. I was this close to suicide more times than I …

即使在极少数情况下，遗传是主要的诱发因素，但遗传本身并不能解释谁会患乳腺癌，谁不会患乳腺癌。DNA检测显示，安娜从父亲那里遗传了乳腺癌基因。其他携带相同基因且比她年长的亲戚都没有患上乳腺癌。安娜坚信压力是导致她患癌的关键因素。她的第一任丈夫是一名商人，在婚姻期间一直对她进行情感虐待。到婚姻结束时，她还遭受了身体虐待。“如果你问我为什么会得癌症，我会告诉你，那是因为我在那段婚姻中让自己彻底崩溃。我无数次徘徊在自杀的边缘……”

“I didn’t have enough self-respect. Am I good enough yet, could you love me yet? I married my mom. He was exactly like my mother. I was never good enough. When I look back, I think, How could I have stayed in such a marriage? I’ve cried plenty over that at the therapist’s. How could I have done that to my soul, because that’s what I hurt. I hurt the essence of who I was. And I think I hurt my body too.

“我缺乏自尊。我够好吗？你能爱我吗？我嫁给了我妈。他跟我妈一模一样。我永远都不够好。回想起来，我常常想，我怎么能忍受这样的婚姻？我在心理咨询师那里为此哭过无数次。我怎么能这样伤害我的灵魂？因为那才是真正让我痛苦的地方。我伤害了我的本质。而且我觉得我的身体也受到了伤害。”

“Finally, I felt there was very little of me left in my world. I was taking eight prescription drugs a day for depression, anxiety, insomnia, aches and pains, bowel problems. It was either die, or get out. At that point, the self-preservation kicked in and I got out.”

“最后，我觉得自己在这个世界上所剩无几了。我每天要服用八种处方药，治疗抑郁症、焦虑症、失眠症、各种疼痛和肠道问题。要么死，要么逃。那时，求生的本能驱使我离开了。”

Anna fits that pattern of “unrealistic self-sacrificing behaviours” noted in the 1952 psychoanalytic study of breast cancer patients. She is the only one among four siblings to take responsibility for her father, now in his eighties.

安娜符合1952年一项针对乳腺癌患者的精神分析研究中提到的那种“不切实际的自我牺牲行为”模式。在四个兄弟姐妹中，只有她承担起照顾父亲的责任，她的父亲现在已经八十多岁了。

“He pulls on my heartstrings. I feel awful when he has a problem. I feel terrible when he phones up and says, ‘I’m so lonesome—I’ve got nowhere to go and nothing to do today.’ My sister, who I think is a bitch, says, ‘Hey, that’s his problem, he had a million choices and chances.’

“他太让人心疼了。他遇到困难的时候，我感觉糟透了。他打电话来说：‘我好孤独——今天无处可去，也无事可做。’我感觉特别难受。我妹妹，我觉得她很刻薄，却说：‘嘿，那是他的问题，他本来有无数的选择和机会。’”

“We went through a hysterical scene with him a year and a half ago when I asked him to go into respite care for one month. He’d been in the hospital, and I had been at the hospital all day every day, sitting there for hours and hours and hours. He came out and I felt like I was having a nervous breakdown from looking after him. I pulled the cancer card—the big card—and said, ‘Dad, look’—with the social workers and everyone—‘I’ve had cancer and I have to look after myself. I cannot look after you like this. Please (I’m crying by this point because I am the crier in the family), please, stay here for one month.’ He said, ‘No. Why should I? I don’t want to.’

“一年半前，我请求他去短期照护中心住一个月，我们之间发生了一场歇斯底里的争吵。他当时在医院，我每天都待在医院，一坐就是几个小时。他出院后，我感觉自己快要崩溃了，因为一直在照顾他。我祭出了癌症这张牌——一张王牌——然后对社工和所有人说：‘爸，你看’，‘我得过癌症，我得照顾好自己。我不能再这样照顾你了。求求你（说到这里我已经哭了，因为我是家里唯一爱哭的人），求求你，在这里住一个月。’他说：‘不。我为什么要住？我不想住。’”

“The social worker and the head of the program are saying to him, ‘Mr. W., no one wants to come into a seniors’ home. Could you do it for your daughter? Look at your daughter—she’s crying and is really having a hard time. She needs time with her husband; she needs a break.’ ‘No, I won’t,’ he said. ‘Why should I?’

“社工和项目负责人对他说：‘W先生，没人愿意去养老院。您能为了您女儿去吗？看看您女儿——她哭了，日子过得很艰难。她需要和丈夫待在一起；她需要休息一下。’他说：‘不，我不会去。’‘我为什么要去？’”

“When I had my double mastectomy, I asked my brother and sisters if they would look after Dad for a while. ‘I can’t have him over for dinner for a couple of months,’ I told them. ‘I need to recover.’ Within ten days he was here for dinner because no one else was looking after him. And nobody even notices.”

“我做完双侧乳房切除手术后，问我的兄弟姐妹们能不能帮忙照顾爸爸一段时间。我告诉他们：‘我几个月内不能让他过来吃饭，我需要好好休养。’结果不到十天，他就过来吃饭了，因为没人照顾他。而且也没人注意到。”

“What you’ve assumed toward your dad is a maternal role. Which is also why you’ve been taken for granted. Mother is taken for granted. Mother is like the world—she’s just supposed to be there and provide.”

“你对父亲扮演的是母亲的角色。也正因如此，你的付出才被视为理所当然。母亲的付出也常常被视为理所当然。母亲就像整个世界——人们认为她就应该在那里，应该提供一切。”

“Absolutely. My brother does the same thing—I’m my brother’s mother as well. When he phones, my kids say, ‘Uncle Don must have a problem because he’s phoning again.’ He suffers from depression; he goes through relationships like you wouldn’t believe. He’s here day and night when there’s a problem. Then he won’t return my phone calls for months. He can’t be bothered.

“没错。我哥哥也一样——我也是他妈妈。他打电话来的时候，我的孩子们会说，‘唐叔叔肯定又出什么事了，又打电话来了。’他有抑郁症；他感情生活频繁得难以置信。出了问题，他就日夜守在我身边。然后几个月都不回我电话。他根本懒得理我。”

“He came once the whole time I had chemotherapy. I sat down with him about a year and a half after my diagnosis and my chemo was over. That was my first experience with trying to say what I needed really clearly. I said, ‘Don, I need something from you. When I go to the cancer clinic for checkups, I need you to ask me how it came out. It’s really important to me. I need you to ask me what happened when I went.’ He leaned back and said, ‘I need something from you too,’ and launched into this long thing about his relationship with this girl that was breaking up. I just sat there and thought that he just didn’t get it at all. You’re right—at some point I realized, I’m mom.”

“在我接受化疗的整个过程中，他只来过一次。确诊一年半后，化疗也结束了，我才和他坐下来好好聊了聊。那是我第一次尝试清晰地表达自己的需求。我说：‘唐，我需要你做件事。我去癌症诊所复查的时候，你需要问问我复查结果如何。这对我来说非常重要。我需要你问问我每次复查的情况。’他向后靠了靠，说：‘我也需要你做件事。’然后就开始滔滔不绝地讲他和女朋友分手的事。我当时就坐在那里，觉得他根本没明白我的意思。你说得对——后来我意识到，我就是妈妈。”

Anna felt repeatedly abandoned by her mother, who favoured her older sister. “I didn’t have a mom. My mom checked out,” she says, “and basically didn’t like me, so I really couldn’t afford to lose my dad, too. Kids are smart enough to understand they need a parent. And my father loved me the wrong way.” From adolescence on, Anna noticed her father casting undisguised sexual glances at her, particularly at her breasts.

安娜感觉自己一次又一次被母亲抛弃，母亲更偏爱姐姐。“我没有妈妈。我妈妈对我漠不关心，”她说，“她基本上不喜欢我，所以我真的承受不起再失去父亲。孩子们很聪明，他们明白自己需要父母。而且我父亲爱我的方式不对。”从青春期开始，安娜就注意到父亲毫不掩饰地用性暗示的目光打量她，尤其是她的胸部。

“I picked up something from him, which I spent most of my life denying until I got into some counselling. He didn’t, as far as I know, do anything, but he wanted to. He looked … There was a sexual intensity that for an eleven- or twelve-year-old girl … I’m hypersensitive to anything coming from men. Anything. But for a young woman to let herself believe that her father feels like that is really hard. I mean, Christ almighty, you make a million excuses for why it’s not real. My sister, though—there’s no way she would ever show up in a T-shirt when Dad was around.

“我从他身上学到了一些东西，我大半辈子都在否认，直到我接受心理咨询。据我所知，他什么也没做，但他想那样做。他眼神……那种性方面的强烈感觉，对于一个十一二岁的女孩来说……我对男人的任何举动都异常敏感。任何事。但对于一个年轻女孩来说，要让自己相信父亲会有那种感觉，真的很难。我的意思是，我的天哪，你会找无数个借口来证明这不是真的。不过，我妹妹——她绝对不会在爸爸在场的时候穿T恤衫。”

“My father is probably the only person who doesn’t know I’ve had my breasts removed because I’ve never told him. I don’t think anyone else is going to. He knows I had an operation that was cancer related. He asked Steve (Anna’s second husband), ‘Is this something to do with the breast?’ and Steve said, ‘Yes, it’s a continuation of the previous thing.’ Dad has never said anything to me. Through my chemo he was so ignorant and shitty to me. He’d come in the front door and say, ‘Go put your wig on. You don’t look pretty.’ I’d say, ‘You know what, I’m really, really sick and I just rolled out of bed to answer this door.’ Only I wouldn’t say it calmly like that—I’d get hysterical.

“我爸可能是唯一一个不知道我做过乳房切除手术的人，因为我从来没跟他说过。我觉得其他人也不会知道。他知道我做过一次和癌症相关的手术。他问史蒂夫（安娜的第二任丈夫），‘这跟乳房有关吗？’史蒂夫说，‘是的，这是之前手术的延续。’我爸从来没跟我说过这件事。我化疗期间，他对我又无知又恶劣。他会走进前门，然后说，‘去戴上你的假发。你看起来不好看。’我会说，‘你知道吗，我真的病得很重，我刚从床上爬起来就来开门了。’但我不会像他那样平静地说——我会歇斯底里地哭喊。”

“I was driving him home recently, and he said, ‘I’ve got to speak to you about something. I know you’re not the person I should tell, but I have no one else.’ Then he launches into this thing—he’s eighty-two years old—about how his girlfriend doesn’t want to have sex with him. ‘Men have needs.’ That’s something he taught me early. A wife must—he told me straight up—never say no to her husband when he wants sex because if she does, he has the right to get it somewhere else. It’s your duty to provide sex. Here he is telling me that he wants to have sex and his girlfriend won’t and he has needs and what is he supposed to do. I’m sitting there thinking, This is so inappropriate—you should not be talking to your daughter about this.”

“前几天我开车送他回家，他突然说：‘我得跟你说件事。我知道你不是我应该说的人，但我实在没别的可说了。’然后他就开始滔滔不绝地讲起来——他都八十二岁了——说他女朋友不想跟他做爱。‘男人也有需求。’这是他小时候教我的。他直截了当地告诉我，妻子绝对不能拒绝丈夫的性需求，因为如果拒绝了，他有权去别的地方解决。满足性需求是妻子的责任。可现在他却跟我说他想做爱，但他女朋友不肯，他有需求，他该怎么办？我当时就想，这太不合适了——你不应该跟女儿说这些。”

“Mind you … you could also say, ‘Dad, I don’t want to hear this.’”

“不过……你也可以说，‘爸爸，我不想听这些。’”

“But then he’d be embarrassed. He’d feel ashamed and think he’d done something. It’s my job to not let him feel ashamed.

“但他那样做会让他尴尬，会感到羞愧，会觉得自己做错了什么。我的工作就是不让他感到羞愧。”

“At what point do I get to say, ‘I don’t want to.’ These are strange words for me, in any situation. I’ll lie to people, I won’t answer the phone, I’ll say ‘I’m moving to Tibet so I can’t take part in that’—I’ll do anything but say ‘I don’t want to.’ And when there’s no lie that comes to mind, I just take it all on.”

“我什么时候才能说‘我不想’呢？对我来说，无论在什么情况下，这都是个很奇怪的词。我会对人撒谎，我会不接电话，我会说‘我要搬去西藏，所以参加不了’——我什么都愿意做，就是不说‘我不想’。如果实在想不出什么谎话，我就只能硬着头皮上了。”

The straightforward connection between childhood experience and adult stress has been missed by so many researchers over so many years that one almost begins to wonder if the oversight is deliberate. Adults with a history of troubled childhoods may not encounter more serious losses than others do, but their ability to cope will have been impaired by their upbringing. Stress does not occur in a vacuum. The same external event will have greatly varied physiological impact, depending on who is experiencing it. The death of a family member will be processed in a markedly different way by someone who is emotionally well integrated and in a supportive relationship than it will be by a person who is alone or—like Anna prior to her therapy—tormented by chronic guilt due to childhood conditioning.

多年来，许多研究者都忽略了童年经历与成年压力之间直接的联系，以至于人们不禁怀疑这种疏忽是否是故意的。有不幸童年经历的成年人或许不会比其他人经历更严重的损失，但他们的应对能力却会因成长经历而受损。压力并非孤立存在。同样的外部事件，对不同个体产生的生理影响却大相径庭。对于一个情感健全、拥有支持性关系的人来说，亲人去世的处理方式，与一个孤独无依或像安娜在接受治疗前那样，因童年经历而长期饱受内疚折磨的人来说，截然不同。

One person whose true childhood history would likely be missed on self-administered questionnaires of breast cancer patients is former U.S. first lady Betty Ford. Mrs. Ford has written courageously in her autobiography, The Times of My Life , about her alcoholism and her efforts at healing after a family intervention by her husband, her children and others. She has been equally forthright in revealing her diagnosis and treatment for breast cancer, but—it appears from her published accounts—when it comes to her childhood she is still wearing rose-coloured glasses. She is typical of the person who represses her own feelings in order to preserve a sense of idyllic relationship with the parent.

在乳腺癌患者的自填问卷中，最有可能遗漏一位真实童年经历的人，那就是美国前第一夫人贝蒂·福特。福特夫人在自传《我的人生岁月》中勇敢地讲述了她酗酒的经历，以及在丈夫、子女和家人的帮助下，她如何努力戒酒。她同样坦诚地公开了自己被诊断出乳腺癌以及接受治疗的过程，但从她公开的叙述来看，谈及童年，她似乎仍然戴着玫瑰色的眼镜。她就像那些为了维护与父母之间田园牧歌般的亲密关系而压抑自身感受的人一样，是典型的选择。

Betty Ford, married to a decent but ambitious politician whose career dominated her life, was emotionally deprived in her spousal relationship. “I probably encouraged my husband to drink. He was such a reserved man it was difficult for him even to tell me he loved me—he had proposed by saying, ‘I’d like to marry you.’” For many years she suffered from what were clearly stress-related low-back pains, diagnosed as “osteoarthritis” and treated with painkillers and tranquilizers. She also drank heavily to soothe physical and emotional pain. Ford describes herself as filled with self-doubt and unable to assert herself:

贝蒂·福特嫁给了一位品行端正但野心勃勃的政治家，他的事业占据了她生活的全部，导致她在婚姻关系中情感匮乏。“我可能怂恿丈夫喝酒。他性格非常内向，甚至很难对我说‘我爱你’——他求婚时说的是‘我想娶你’。”多年来，她饱受明显与压力相关的腰痛折磨，被诊断为“骨关节炎”，并服用止痛药和镇静剂治疗。她还大量饮酒以缓解身心痛苦。福特形容自己充满自我怀疑，无法坚持己见：

I was convinced that the more important Jerry became, the less important I became. And the more I allowed myself to become a doormat—I knew I was a doormat to the kids—the more self-pity overwhelmed me. Hadn’t I once been somebody in this world?

我深信杰瑞越重要，我就越不重要。我越是任由自己成为受气包——我知道在孩子们眼里我就是个受气包——我的自怜就越发强烈。难道我曾经在这个世界上就不是个重要人物吗？

Underneath, I guess I didn’t really believe I had been somebody. My career with Martha Graham hadn’t been a huge success—I had talent as a dancer, but I wasn’t a great dancer—and my confidence had always been shaky.

内心深处，我想我并不真正相信自己曾经是个了不起的人。我和玛莎·格雷厄姆的合作并不算成功——我有舞蹈天赋，但算不上优秀——而且我的自信心一直很薄弱。

I couldn’t accept that people liked me for myself. And I was self-conscious that I didn’t have a college degree….

我无法接受别人喜欢的是我这个人。而且，我没有大学学位，这让我很自卑……

Uneducated. No Pavlova. And not half the woman my mother had been. I was measuring myself against impossible ideals—Martha or my mother—and coming up short. That’s a good recipe for alcoholism.

我没受过什么教育，不会做帕夫洛娃蛋糕，更别提像我母亲那样优秀了。我总是拿自己和那些遥不可及的理想——玛莎或者我母亲——作比较，结果总是差那么一点点。这很容易导致酗酒。

My mother was a wonderful woman, strong and kind and principled, and she never let me down. She was also a perfectionist, and tried to program us children for perfection. My mother never came to us with her problems, she just shouldered them. And she was my strongest role model, so when I couldn’t shoulder my problems, I lost respect for myself. No matter how hard I tried, I couldn’t measure up to my own expectations. 9

我的母亲是一位了不起的女性，坚强、善良、有原则，她从未让我失望。她也是个完美主义者，试图让我们这些孩子也变得完美。母亲从不向我们倾诉她的烦恼，她总是默默承受。她是我最坚强的榜样，所以当我无法独自面对自己的问题时，我便失去了对自己的尊重。无论我多么努力，我都无法达到自己的期望。

The former first lady seems blind to her own disclosures here—about the way she experienced her childhood, about how her relationship with her mother and, no doubt, with her father, of whom she says very little—shaped her personality and coping style. She does not see that surrendering herself to her husband’s needs and expectations—becoming a “doormat”—resulted from childhood conditioning. The emotional repression, the harsh self-judgment and the perfectionism Betty Ford acquired as a child, through no fault of her own, are more than a “good recipe for alcoholism.” They are also a “good recipe” for cancer of the breast.

这位前第一夫人似乎对自己在此披露的信息视而不见——关于她的童年经历，关于她与母亲（以及无疑也包括她很少提及的父亲）的关系如何塑造了她的性格和应对方式。她没有意识到，屈从于丈夫的需求和期望——沦为“受气包”——是童年经历造成的。贝蒂·福特在童年时期（并非出于自身过错）养成的情感压抑、严苛的自我评判和完美主义，不仅是“酗酒的温床”，也是“乳腺癌的诱因”。

* Mr. Crew has already gone public with news of his breast cancer. Unlike the women interviewed, he does not need his identity protected .

克鲁先生已经公开了他患乳腺癌的消息。与接受采访的女性不同，他不需要保护自己的身份。

6
6
You Are Part of This Too, Mom
妈妈，你也是其中的一份子

I n Lock Me Up or Let Me Go , her second book of memoirs, Betty Krawczyk writes about the death from breast cancer of her twenty-seven-year-old daughter, Barbara Ellen:

在她的第二本回忆录《把我锁起来还是放我走》中，贝蒂·克拉夫奇克写到了她27岁的女儿芭芭拉·艾伦因乳腺癌去世的故事：

The last migraine I had was in the palliative care unit, almost three years ago, when the doctor in charge told me that I should tell Barbara Ellen it was okay for her to die.

我最后一次偏头痛是在临终关怀病房，差不多三年前，当时主管医生告诉我，我应该告诉芭芭拉·艾伦，她可以安心地死去。

“She wants your permission to die,” he said gently. We were in a private room reserved especially for people like me. The most wretched people of the earth.

“她想得到你的允许才能死去，”他轻声说道。我们身处一间专门为像我这样的人准备的私人房间。我们是世上最悲惨的人。

“To hell with that!” I flung at him, shocked and horrified at the very suggestion. “She doesn’t have my permission to die! I forbid it….”

“去他的！”我冲他吼道，震惊又恐惧于这个提议。“她没资格死！我禁止她死……”

I had broken down at that point and was sobbing wildly. The doctor waited patiently. He was used to this reaction. That was his job.

那时我彻底崩溃了，嚎啕大哭。医生耐心地等着。他早已习惯了这种反应。那是他的职责。

“Mrs. Krawczyk, I think you understand that Barbara Ellen’s suffering will simply increase now, by the hour.”

“克拉夫奇克夫人，我想您明白，芭芭拉·艾伦的痛苦只会每小时都在加剧。”

“She is not suffering! She has the butterfly in her arm. She talked to her sisters and her father this morning, she saw friends just yesterday, she was talking to her little boy, and hugging him….”

“她没有受苦！她手臂上抱着蝴蝶。今天早上她还和姐妹们、父亲通过电话，昨天也见了朋友，她还和她的小儿子说话、拥抱他……”

“That was a gift. A gift she gave loved ones. To tell everybody good-bye. You’re the only one she hasn’t told good-bye. She wants to do this now. She wants your permission to leave….”

“那是一份礼物。一份她送给亲人的礼物。一份向所有人道别的礼物。你是唯一一个她还没来得及道别的人。她现在想这么做。她想征得你的同意，离开……”

“Oh, please, don’t! Who do you think you are, God? How do you know this is the hour of her death?”

“哦，求求你，别这样！你以为你是谁，上帝吗？你怎么知道这就是她临终的时刻？”

And then I was reduced to begging. “Give me a few more days, please. Please put the IV back in….”

然后我就只能苦苦哀求了。“再给我几天时间，求求你了。求求你把输液管重新插上……”

“She doesn’t want it. You have to be strong enough to give your daughter what she needs right now. She needs you to help her, to let her go; that’s the only way you can help her now, to let her go”

“她不想这样。你必须足够坚强，才能给予女儿她现在需要的。她需要你的帮助，放手让她走；这是你现在唯一能帮到她的方法，放手让她走。”

The headache was so bad I thought I might expire before Barbara Ellen did. But I didn’t…. By the following evening I … had recuperated enough to tell my daughter that if she was tired of being sick and wanted to go, I would no longer try to keep her. She held my hand and told me she would wait for me wherever it was that she was going, and she died that morning, in my arms, her sister Marian holding her, too, her father also by her side. 1

头痛得厉害，我感觉自己可能比芭芭拉·艾伦先走一步。但我没有……到了第二天晚上，我……恢复了一些，告诉女儿，如果她不想再生病想走了，我不会再试图留住她。她握着我的手，告诉我无论她要去哪里，她都会等我。那天早上，她就在我的怀里去世了，她的妹妹玛丽安也抱着她，她的父亲也在她身边。

I was the palliative physician in that scene. I well recall Barbara Ellen, huddled in her hospital bed under the window, in the first room on the right of the hall as you entered the ward from the elevator. Slight to begin with, she had been reduced to waif-like size by her terminal cancer. She said very little, and she seemed sad. I had no knowledge of her history, except for the essential details of her disease. She had been diagnosed with inflammatory breast cancer, a type that strikes young women and has a dismally poor prognosis. She had elected to refuse all conventional medical treatment—not an entirely unreasonable decision, considering her diagnosis, but highly unusual. Such decisions always involve more than the bare medical facts, and my sense was that this young woman felt quite isolated—had felt that way all her life. At times I just wanted to cradle and comfort her in my arms, as one would an infant or small child.

在那一幕中，我是负责临终关怀的医生。我至今仍清晰地记得芭芭拉·艾伦蜷缩在病床上，靠着窗户，那是从电梯进入病房后，走廊右侧第一间病房。她原本就体弱多病，如今更是被绝症折磨得瘦骨嶙峋，形如枯槁。她很少说话，看起来很悲伤。我对她的病史一无所知，只知道她患的是什么病。她被诊断出患有炎性乳腺癌，这种癌症多发于年轻女性，预后极差。她选择拒绝所有常规治疗——考虑到她的病情，这并非完全不合理，但却非常罕见。这样的决定总是牵涉到比单纯的医学事实更深层次的原因，我的感觉是，这位年轻的女性感到非常孤独——她一生都感到孤独。有时，我只想把她拥入怀中，像对待婴儿或幼儿一样，温柔地安慰她。

I had talked with Barbara Ellen after morning rounds on the day Betty depicts in her memoir. “How much longer do I have?” she asked.

贝蒂在回忆录中描述的那天，我早上查房后和芭芭拉·艾伦聊了聊。“我还能活多久？”她问。

“Not long. How does it feel to you?”

“没多久了。你感觉怎么样？”

“I’ve had enough. Are you giving me anything to keep me alive?”

“我受够了。你们给我什么活命的办法吗？”

“Only the IV. Without the fluids you would die in a day or two. Would you like us to stop it?”

“只需要输液。如果没有输液，你一两天内就会死。你想让我们停止输液吗？”

“My mother couldn’t handle that.”

“我母亲受不了这件事。”

“I get the feeling you always took care of her in some ways, so it may be difficult for you to do what you want now. But you don’t need to take care of her any more. What would you do if you just took care of yourself?”

“我感觉你一直以来都在某些方面照顾她，所以现在你可能很难做自己想做的事。但你不再需要照顾她了。如果你只照顾自己，你会做什么呢？”

“I would take out the IV.”

“我会拔掉静脉输液管。”

“I respect your mother’s feelings. This is extremely hard on a parent—I can only imagine how unbearably difficult. But you are my patient here, and my primary responsibility is to you. If you wish, I will speak with her.”

“我尊重你母亲的感受。这对父母来说极其艰难——我能想象到那种难以承受的痛苦。但你是我的病人，我的首要职责是照顾你。如果你愿意，我会和她谈谈。”

Recently Betty Krawczyk and I met again to talk about her daughter’s life and death. We had conversed briefly after Barbara Ellen died, when Betty was grieving and attempting to comprehend why her daughter had died so much before her time. I had recounted for her my understanding about the possible connection between a stressful early childhood and an increased risk for the later development of cancer. Soon afterwards, I received in the mail a copy of her first volume of memoirs: Clayoquot: The Sound of My Heart . Inside the cover was this inscription: “Herewith my book. It explains something of my relationship with my daughter who died of breast cancer April 30 in your unit.” Having read that book, I hoped Betty would agree to be interviewed for When the Body Says No . As it turned out, Betty had been thinking of me, having just written the passage quoted above. She was interested in learning more about my perspective and hoped I might help her understand better some of the things Barbara Ellen had said in the last six months of her life.

最近，我和贝蒂·克拉夫奇克再次见面，谈起她女儿的生平。芭芭拉·艾伦去世后，我们曾有过短暂的交谈。当时贝蒂正沉浸在悲痛之中，试图理解女儿为何英年早逝。我曾向她讲述过我对童年早期压力与日后罹患癌症风险增加之间可能存在的联系的理解。不久之后，我收到了她寄来的第一本回忆录：《克拉约科特：我心之声》。扉页上写着：“这是我的书。它解释了我与女儿之间的一些关系，她于4月30日在你们医院因乳腺癌去世。”读过这本书后，我希望贝蒂能接受《当身体说不》的采访。结果，贝蒂似乎也想到了我，因为她刚刚写下了上面引用的那段话。她很想了解我的观点，希望我能帮助她更好地理解芭芭拉·艾伦在生命最后六个月里说过的一些话。

It was no ordinary discussion Betty and I had, but Betty is no ordinary woman. She is well known in British Columbia and beyond for her activism in environmental causes. The title of her first book refers to an internationally renowned rain-forest preserve on the West Coast, Clayoquot Sound, threatened some years ago by logging interests. In September 2001 seventy-three-year-old Betty was incarcerated four and a half months for criminal contempt of court, following another logging protest.

我和贝蒂的谈话非同寻常，贝蒂本人也非同寻常。她在不列颠哥伦比亚省乃至更远的地方都因其在环境保护事业上的积极行动而闻名。她的第一本书的书名就提到了位于西海岸、享誉国际的热带雨林保护区——克拉阔特湾，这片保护区几年前曾受到伐木企业的威胁。2001年9月，73岁的贝蒂因藐视法庭罪被判入狱四个半月，此前她曾参与另一次反对伐木的抗议活动。

Although Clayoquot is mostly about Betty’s experiences as an environmental crusader, she also gives a vivid and honest history of her personal life. With four husbands and eight children, she’s had an eventful life. Now Betty acts as surrogate mother to Barbara Ellen’s son, Julian, who was only two when his mother passed away.

虽然《克拉约科特》主要讲述了贝蒂作为环保主义者的经历，但她也生动而真诚地描绘了自己的个人生活。她有过四段婚姻，育有八个孩子，人生可谓丰富多彩。如今，贝蒂扮演着芭芭拉·艾伦的儿子朱利安的代理母亲的角色，朱利安的母亲去世时，他只有两岁。

Barbara Ellen gave vent to frequent expressions of deep anger at her mother in the final six months before she died. It is that anger Betty was still struggling to understand.

在芭芭拉·艾伦去世前的六个月里，她经常向母亲发泄深深的愤怒。贝蒂至今仍难以理解这种愤怒。

Betty Krawczyk was born in southern Lousiana, which, at that time, she says, was “mostly one big swamp.” “I wasn’t raised to be a protestor,” she writes in Clayoquot . “I was raised a poor, country, southern white woman.”

贝蒂·克拉夫奇克出生于路易斯安那州南部，她说，当时那里“几乎全是沼泽”。她在《克拉约夸特》一书中写道：“我从小就没被培养成抗议者。我是一个贫穷的南方乡村白人女性。”

Memory is so selective, so subjective. At a sibling confab several years ago we were tickled and somewhat amazed to learn that we each, my brother and sister and I, had felt the others to be favored in the family. I know I felt the other two to have been favored. Actually, I still do. My brother was the older, and the only boy, so he got most of the attention. What was left went to my sister because she was the baby and delicate to boot. I was a big, healthy girl who could amuse herself, so nobody took any special notice of me. Which was just fine as far as I was concerned.

记忆是如此的选择性，如此的主观性。几年前的一次兄弟姐妹聚会上，我们惊讶地发现，我和哥哥、妹妹都觉得家里其他人更受宠。我知道我当时觉得他们俩更受宠。事实上，我现在依然这么觉得。哥哥是哥哥，也是家里唯一的男孩，所以他得到了大部分的关注。剩下的关注都给了妹妹，因为她是最小的，而且体弱多病。我是一个又高又健康的女孩，能自己玩，所以没人特别关注我。就我而言，这样挺好的。

You really didn’t want my father to notice you. If he did, you were in trouble. Not that he beat any of us ever, but the threat was always there. We were there to be seen not heard, and seen as little as possible. My mother was different. She was warm and loving. Although I always knew she favored my brother and sister, she was so full of love some of it slopped over on me, too. After I grew up I once confronted my mother with my secret knowledge, and she was hurt and astonished and insisted that if she paid more attention to the other two, it was because they needed her more than I did, that I was always more emotionally independent. 2

你真的不想让我父亲注意到你。如果他注意到了，你就麻烦了。倒不是说他打过我们，但那种威胁一直存在。我们被要求只被看见，不被听见，而且越少被人看见越好。我的母亲则不同。她热情慈爱。虽然我一直知道她更偏爱我的弟弟妹妹，但她满满的爱也流淌到了我身上。长大后，我曾把我知道的秘密告诉母亲，她既伤心又惊讶，坚持说如果她更关注另外两个孩子，那是因为他们比我更需要她，而我一直都比较独立。

Despite this apparent emotional independence, the young Betty suffered “wild nightmares and nervous imaginings in the dark.” She left home early, marrying “the first grown man who came to court who could actually prove he was financially solvent.” In short order, she left her husband, but not before bearing three children. “He was a bit of a compulsive collector of intact hymens. He couldn’t seem to stop after we got married. He finally collected one too many.”

尽管表面上情感独立，年轻的贝蒂却饱受“黑暗中噩梦和神经质幻想”的折磨。她早早离家，嫁给了“第一个到法庭证明自己经济独立的成年男子”。不久后，她离开了丈夫，但在此之前，她已经生下了三个孩子。“他有点儿收集处女膜的癖好。我们结婚后，他似乎也停不下来。最终，他收集的处女膜太多了。”

Three more marriages and five more children followed in the next two decades. Barbara Ellen was the seventh among them, born just before Betty moved to Canada in 1966, “six kids in tow,” and her third marriage on the verge of breaking up. They lived in Kirkland Lake, Ontario. Her husband, a college instructor, was an emotionally distant workaholic who also drank. “I didn’t like John when he drank,” she writes. “He had a tendency to get impossibly self-righteous and accusatory. So I found myself avoiding the same social situations I had originally reached out for. And my depression deepened…. I began to look at John and wonder who he actually was…. I thought that first winter in Kirkland Lake would never end and that spring would never come. Actually, spring never did come…. I think the two most frustrated people in that non-existent spring were me and the baby, Barbara Ellen.”

接下来的二十年里，她又经历了三次婚姻，生了五个孩子。芭芭拉·艾伦是其中的第七个，出生于1966年贝蒂带着六个孩子移居加拿大之前，当时她的第三段婚姻也濒临破裂。他们住在安大略省的柯克兰湖。她的丈夫是一位大学讲师，情感冷漠，是个工作狂，而且还酗酒。“我不喜欢约翰喝酒的样子，”她写道，“他总是变得自以为是，还喜欢指责别人。所以我开始回避那些我原本积极参与的社交场合。我的抑郁症也加重了……我开始审视约翰，想知道他到底是怎样一个人……我以为在柯克兰湖的第一个冬天永远不会结束，春天永远不会到来。事实上，春天真的没有来……我想，在那段没有到来的春天里，最沮丧的两个人就是我和小女儿芭芭拉·艾伦。”

Betty found a way out of her relationship with her husband by falling in love with his department head at the college and relocating with him to British Columbia. It was mostly here that Barbara Ellen grew up, although there were moves back and forth between Eastern and Western Canada, and between the United States and Canada.

贝蒂找到了摆脱与丈夫关系的办法：她爱上了丈夫在大学的系主任，并和他一起搬到了不列颠哥伦比亚省。芭芭拉·艾伦主要在这里长大，尽管她也曾在加拿大东部和西部之间，以及美国和加拿大之间来回搬家。

Betty’s fourth marriage also failed, but over the years she found a truer sense of herself as a person, as a woman and as an activist.

贝蒂的第四段婚姻也失败了，但多年来，她对作为一个人、一个女人和一个活动家有了更真实的认识。

Barbara Ellen was a sensitive child with health problems. At the age of four, she began to have vomiting spells that nobody seemed able to diagnose. These bouts recurred intermittently over the years, and Betty feels now they were related to stresses in her daughter’s life. As a young adult, Barbara became addicted to narcotic painkillers and tranquilizers that she would inject into her body. Right up to the time of her diagnosis with breast cancer, she was fighting her addiction to drugs. With no experience of stability, she was unable to establish an intimate, ongoing relationship with a man: she went from one relationship to another. Julian was born when Barbara Ellen was twenty-five, but when she married shortly afterwards, it was not to her child’s father. “That marriage didn’t last long,” says Betty. “Martin was not able to cope with being married and having a little stepson.”

芭芭拉·艾伦从小体弱多病，性格敏感。四岁时，她开始出现呕吐症状，但似乎没有人能确诊。这些症状多年来断断续续地出现，贝蒂现在觉得这与女儿生活中的压力有关。年轻时，芭芭拉染上了麻醉性止痛药和镇静剂的毒瘾，她会将这些药物注射到体内。直到被诊断出乳腺癌，她仍在与毒瘾作斗争。由于缺乏稳定的生活经验，她无法与任何男性建立亲密、长久的关系：她不断地更换伴侣。朱利安出生时，芭芭拉·艾伦25岁，但不久后她就结婚了，而她的丈夫并非孩子的父亲。“那段婚姻并没有维持多久，”贝蒂说，“马丁无法接受自己已婚，也无法接受自己有个继子。”

Barbara was highly intelligent, sensitive and creative. A dancer, at one point she operated a ballet school for children. She was taking care of Julian and doing some teaching of dance classes in Vancouver when she discovered her cancer.

芭芭拉才华横溢、心思细腻、极富创造力。她曾是一名舞蹈演员，还开办过一所儿童芭蕾舞学校。在温哥华，她一边照顾朱利安，一边教授舞蹈课程，就在那时，她被诊断出患有癌症。

“She told me she had had this mammogram, and they just wanted to do a mastectomy. She wasn’t willing to accept that. Barbara had a keen intellect. She researched all the material on the kind of cancer she had and investigated the treatment outcomes among her age group in the U.S. and Canada. She didn’t like the way it looked. ‘I am not going to go through all that,’ she said. ‘I don’t want to be sick, I don’t want to be mutilated, I don’t want all this chemo stuff. I’m going to treat it holistically and do the best I can with it.’ She asked that John and I support her decision and try not to interfere.”

“她告诉我她做了乳房X光检查，医生只想给她做乳房切除手术。她不愿意接受。芭芭拉思维敏捷。她研究了所有关于她所患癌症的资料，并调查了美国和加拿大同龄患者的治疗结果。她不喜欢手术后的样子。“我不想经历这一切，”她说，“我不想生病，不想毁容，不想接受化疗。我要采用整体疗法，尽我所能地治疗。”她请求我和约翰支持她的决定，尽量不要干涉。

“How was that for you?”

你感觉如何？

“It was horrible. Immediately, I wanted to do something. I tried to pressure her to look at some other options, and then she was just very, very angry and adamant and yelled at me—she’d never yelled at me before. She was angry with me the whole last, I would say, six months of her life. Before, she wouldn’t stay mad; when she was angry with me, she would just say, ‘Okay, Mom, you want to think that, you think that,’ and she’d slam her door or something, but that would be it.”

“太可怕了。我当时就想做点什么。我试图劝她考虑其他选择，但她却非常非常生气，态度也很坚决，冲我大吼大叫——她以前从来没对我吼过。在她生命的最后六个月里，她一直都在生我的气。以前，她不会一直生气；就算生我的气，她也只会说，‘好吧，妈妈，你想这么想就这么想吧，’然后摔门什么的，仅此而已。”

“That’s not exactly an expression of anger—mostly of defeat and frustration.”

“那并不完全是愤怒的表达——更多的是挫败感和沮丧感。”

“She was always hurt by me for some reason, and I don’t know why. I think I was a terrible parent for this child. My personality was hurtful to her.”

“不知为何，她总是对我感到受伤，我也不知道为什么。我觉得我是一个糟糕的父母。我的性格伤害了她。”

“You’re full of tears here. Are you still feeling guilt about it?”

“你现在满脸泪水。你还在为这件事感到内疚吗？”

“Maybe not so much guilt as a feeling that why couldn’t they have given her to someone else who could have dealt with her. She was an extraordinary child in her sensitivity to the world, her understanding of the world, in her gentleness with the world.”

“或许与其说是愧疚，不如说是觉得为什么他们不把她交给其他能照顾她的人。她是个非凡的孩子，对世界充满敏感，理解世界，待人温柔。”

“Gentleness … what was she like as a child?”

“温柔……她小时候是什么样的？”

“She was very precocious. Wherever I took her, people were impressed with her demeanour and level of—I don’t want to say that she acted adult—but at her level of comprehension of the adult world.”

“她非常早熟。无论我带她去哪里，人们都会对她的举止和——我不想说她表现得像个大人——但她对成人世界的理解水平却很高。”

“How about emotionally?”

“情感方面呢？”

“Emotionally? She was a very loving and affectionate child. She was quite gentle and was always very loved by everyone, was always the teacher’s pet. Other kids didn’t seem to resent it, though.”

“情感方面？她是个非常可爱、充满爱心的孩子。她性格温柔，人缘极好，一直是老师的宠儿。不过，其他孩子似乎并不介意。”

“Do you have any sense at all that anybody ever tried to abuse her?”

“你难道一点感觉都没有吗？曾经有人试图虐待她？”

“There was one incident. We had been to Louisiana visiting my mother and sister. My sister had these four boys. One boy was a year older than Barbara and bigger. Barbara would have been about twelve. She didn’t tell me about this. It wasn’t until we got back to California that she told Margaret, her sister. Margaret came and told me that this cousin tried to get on top of Barbara. They were the only two at home. Barbara was very angry about it. I remember asking Margaret, ‘Why didn’t she come tell me?’ and she said, ‘She thought because Doris is your sister that it would cause a big ruckus between you two.’”

“有一次，我们去路易斯安那州看望我母亲和姐姐。我姐姐有四个儿子。其中一个比芭芭拉大一岁，个子也高。当时芭芭拉大概十二岁。她没跟我说过这件事。直到我们回到加州，她才告诉了她妹妹玛格丽特。玛格丽特过来告诉我，那个表弟想对芭芭拉动手动脚。当时家里只有她们俩。芭芭拉为此非常生气。我记得我问玛格丽特：‘她为什么不来告诉我？’玛格丽特说：‘她觉得多丽丝是你姐姐，说了会闹得你们俩不高兴。’”

Betty and I then talked about Barbara’s illness and death. At the time Barbara was diagnosed with cancer, Betty was running in a provincial election for the Green Party. She resigned her candidacy to spend time with her ailing daughter. I asked if she had found that difficult.

之后，我和贝蒂聊起了芭芭拉的病情和去世。芭芭拉被确诊癌症时，贝蒂正在代表绿党参加省议员竞选。为了陪伴生病的女儿，她辞去了候选人资格。我问她，那段时间是否很艰难。

“It wasn’t that hard. My feeling was that we needed each other. But there was something in my personality that Barbara always found irritating. My voice was too loud for her, my actions too flamboyant. I was too much for her more delicate constitution—that’s the only way I can describe it. I’m too loud and too definite in my opinions and too aggressive in my actions. She had the opposite personality of liking to think about things and being quiet and trying to have a more holistic view of other people’s personalities.”

“其实没那么难。我觉得我们彼此需要。但我性格里有些东西总是让芭芭拉觉得烦。我的声音对她来说太大了，我的行为也太张扬了。我太强势了，她体质比较娇弱——我只能这么形容。我说话太大声，观点太固执，做事也太咄咄逼人。她的性格正好相反，她喜欢思考，喜欢安静，也喜欢更全面地看待别人的性格。”

“It sounds like she thought you were more judgmental than she wanted you to be.”

“听起来她觉得你比她希望的更爱评判别人。”

“She always accused me of being judgmental. I stayed awhile and she told me to go. She would always tell me when she was tired of me and she needed to rest because she found me tiring.”

“她总是指责我爱评判别人。我待了一会儿，她就让我走了。她总是会告诉我，她厌倦了我，需要休息，因为她觉得我很累人。”

“This is in the last months?”

“这是最近几个月发生的事情吗？”

“Yes.”

“是的。”

“Why do you think that is? You can’t be tiring. There’s no such thing as a tiring person.”

“你觉得这是为什么呢？你不可能让人感到疲惫。世上根本没有让人感到疲惫的人。”

“My personality would tire her after a while—it was too intense.”

“我的性格过一段时间就会让她感到厌倦——太强烈了。”

“When does one get tired?”

人什么时候才会感到疲倦？

“When you’ve been working. So you think it was work for her to be with me.”

“当你一直在工作的时候。所以你觉得和她在一起对她来说也是一种工作。”

“She had to work too hard around you.”

“在你身边，她不得不工作太辛苦了。”

“Aha …”

“啊哈……”

“Now you’re wondering why I’m saying that. You’d be very unusual to be open to hearing this, but your whole life has been a search for truth. I know and understand that. Look, Barbara came along in your life when there was just no stability at all.”

“现在你肯定想知道我为什么这么说。你不太可能愿意听这些，但你的一生都在追寻真理。我知道，也理解这一点。你看，芭芭拉在你人生最动荡不安的时候出现了。”

“That’s right.”

“这是正确的。”

“You were going through the end stages of your relationship with John when you got pregnant with her, and you felt totally alone. You didn’t feel partnered and you began to realize that while this guy was interesting intellectually, emotionally you were quite alone. Your way of leaving the relationship was to get involved with Wally. Then you make this flight to Western Canada with the kids in tow. What ends up happening is that John gets custody of everybody except Barbara Ellen. She had an awfully huge void to fill in your life all of a sudden, right from the beginning of her life.

“你怀上她的时候，正值你和约翰关系的尾声，你感到无比孤独。你感觉不到伴侣的存在，你开始意识到，虽然约翰在智力上很有魅力，但在情感上，你却非常孤单。你离开这段关系的方式是和沃利在一起。然后你带着孩子们飞往加拿大西部。结果，除了芭芭拉·艾伦，所有孩子的监护权都归约翰所有。芭芭拉·艾伦从出生起，就突然需要填补你生命中一个巨大的空缺。”

“The nature of stress is not always the usual stuff that people think of. It’s not the external stress of war or money loss or somebody dying, it is actually the internal stress of having to adjust oneself to somebody else. Cancer and ALS and MS and rheumatoid arthritis and all these other conditions, it seems to me, happen to people who have a poor sense of themselves as independent persons. On the emotional level, that is—they can be highly accomplished in the arts or intellectually—but on an emotional level they have a poorly differentiated sense of self. They live in reaction to others without ever really sensing who they themselves are.

“压力的本质并非人们通常所想的那样。它并非战争、金钱损失或亲人离世等外部压力，而是不得不适应他人带来的内在压力。在我看来，癌症、肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）、多发性硬化症（MS）、类风湿性关节炎以及其他种种疾病，似乎都发生在那些缺乏独立自我意识的人身上。这种独立自我意识体现在情感层面——他们或许在艺术或智力方面成就斐然——但在情感层面，他们的自我认知却十分模糊。他们活在对他人的反应之中，却从未真正感受到自己的存在。”

“Barbara’s going from one man to the other shows she hadn’t enough of a sense of self to hold on to. As soon as one relationship is over, she had to get into another in order to feel okay about herself. The addictions enter into this as well.

“芭芭拉频繁更换伴侣，说明她缺乏足够的自我认知。一段感情结束后，她必须立刻投入下一段，才能感觉好一些。成瘾问题也与此有关。”

“She comes along in your life when you are particularly emotionally needy and exhausted. I think her precocious intellectual development is what happens to bright and sensitive kids when the emotional environment isn’t able to hold them enough; they develop this very powerful intellect that holds them instead. Hence their intellectual maturity and their ability to relate to adults. People would tell me as a child how mature I was. I always thought I was, because in that mode you can seem highly mature. But then when I look at myself emotionally, I’ve been very immature. I’m fifty-eight now and still trying to grow up.”

“她会在你特别需要情感慰藉、精疲力竭的时候出现在你的生命中。我认为她早熟的智力发展，正是那些聪明敏感的孩子在情感环境无法充分容纳他们时所经历的；他们会发展出强大的智力来支撑自己。因此，他们才拥有了智力上的成熟，以及与成年人相处的能力。小时候，人们总是说我很成熟。我一直都这么认为，因为在那种状态下，你看起来确实很成熟。但当我审视自己的情感时，我发现自己其实非常不成熟。我现在58岁了，却仍在努力成长。”

“This is very interesting.”

“这很有意思。”

“What doesn’t develop in one area will overdevelop in another, if the kid has the brains for it. Barbara develops a huge intellect in order to feel comfortable. I believe that’s because you were not able to give her the emotional sustenance that she needed when she was small.”

“如果孩子有这方面的天赋，那么他在其他方面发展不足的地方就会过度发展。芭芭拉之所以智力超群，是为了寻求慰藉。我认为这是因为你没能在她小时候给予她所需的情感支持。”

“I don’t think so either.”

“我也不这么认为。”

“When the parent can’t put in the work to maintain the relationship, then the child has to. She does so by being a good girl. She does it by being precocious, by being intellectually mature. When she reaches the age of abstract thought, around age thirteen or fourteen, when these connections in the brain actually happen, all of a sudden she becomes your intellectual sounding board. The relationship is based not on her needs but more on yours. With the incident of that boy trying to climb on her, she protects you from her emotional pain by not telling you. She doesn’t let you know about it. She is taking care of you.
