蒂姆说他对自己和别人都非常苛刻——这也是他最终评判自己的另一个原因。“我是个完美主义者，所以我觉得自己缺乏那种与生俱来的同情心。我比较冷漠。十五年来，我从未缺勤过，即便我当时一天要跑十二到十五趟厕所，还经常出血。昨天有个员工请了一天假——他的狗前一天晚上去世了。我当时就想，‘你在说什么？他不来上班是因为他的狗死了？那只是一条狗而已。他为什么不能来上班？’有些同事说，‘你没养过狗吗？你是不是铁石心肠？’我完全无法理解。”

____

Dr. Douglas Drossman is an internationally known gastroenterologist, and a professor of medicine and psychiatry at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. He is an associate editor of Gastroenterology , the official journal of the American Gastroenterology Association. Dr. Drossman has been a leading advocate of seeing intestinal diseases as expressions not only of disturbed physiology but also of stressed lives. He wrote a seminal article on the subject in 1998. “On the basis of clinical reports, on appraisal of the existing research literature, and clinical experience, I believe there is at least indirect evidence that psychosocial factors do affect disease susceptibility and activity. The most likely mechanism for this to occur would be through psychoimmunological pathways.” 5

道格拉斯·德罗斯曼博士是一位国际知名的胃肠病学家，也是北卡罗来纳大学教堂山分校的医学和精神病学教授。他是美国胃肠病学会官方期刊《胃肠病学》的副主编。德罗斯曼博士一直倡导将肠道疾病视为生理紊乱和生活压力共同作用的结果。他于1998年发表了一篇关于此主题的开创性文章。“基于临床报告、对现有研究文献的评估以及临床经验，我认为至少有间接证据表明，社会心理因素确实会影响疾病的易感性和活动性。最可能的机制是通过心理免疫途径。”

The inflammation of IBD is the result of disordered immune activity in the gut. Beyond their functions of digestion and absorption, the intestines are also one of the body’s major barriers to invasion. Whatever is in the gut is simply passing through and still belongs to the external world. Only after penetrating the bowel lining do substances and organisms enter the body proper. Since this protective function of the gut tissue is critical to well-being, it is generously supplied with its own local immune system, one that works in coordination with the body’s general immune defences.

炎症性肠病（IBD）的炎症是肠道免疫活动紊乱的结果。除了消化和吸收功能外，肠道也是人体抵御外来入侵的主要屏障之一。肠道内的物质只是暂时通过，仍然属于外部世界。只有穿透肠壁，物质和微生物才能真正进入人体。由于肠道组织的这种保护功能对健康至关重要，因此它拥有自身完善的局部免疫系统，该系统与人体的整体免疫防御系统协同工作。

Inflammation is an ingenious process invoked by the body to isolate and destroy hostile organisms or noxious particles. It does so by tissue swelling and the influx of a host of immune cells and antibodies. To facilitate its defensive function, the lining, or mucosa, of the bowel is in a “state of perpetually controlled or orchestrated inflammation.” 6 That is its normal state in healthy people.

炎症是人体启动的一种巧妙机制，用于隔离和摧毁有害微生物或颗粒。它通过组织肿胀以及大量免疫细胞和抗体的涌入来实现这一目标。为了发挥其防御功能，肠道内壁（即黏膜）处于一种“持续受控或协调的炎症状态”。 6 这在健康人群中是正常的。

The powerful destructive forces of the immune apparatus must be minutely regulated and kept in such a balance that they are able to carry out their policing duties without harming the delicate body tissues they are charged with defending. Some substances promote inflammation; others inhibit it. If the balance is upset, disease can result. A diminished capacity by the gut to mount an inflammatory response would invite life-threatening infections. On the other hand, an inability to dampen inflammation exposes the gut tissue to self-injury. The central abnormality in inflammatory bowel disease would appear to be just such an imbalance of what one journal article calls the “pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory” molecules in the bowel lining. Emotional influences acting through the nerve and immune pathways of the PNI super-system could tip the balance in favour of inflammation. As Canadian researchers have pointed out, “many, if not all, aspects of gut physiology may be regulated by neuroimmune factors.” 7

免疫系统的强大破坏力必须受到精细的调控，并保持平衡，才能在履行其职责的同时，避免损伤其所保护的脆弱的身体组织。有些物质会促进炎症，而另一些则会抑制炎症。如果这种平衡被打破，就会导致疾病。肠道炎症反应能力的下降会导致危及生命的感染。另一方面，无法抑制炎症则会使肠道组织容易受到自身损伤。炎症性肠病的核心异常似乎正是肠道内壁中“促炎分子和抗炎分子”失衡，正如一篇期刊文章中所描述的那样。情绪因素通过神经和免疫通路影响周围神经系统（PNI）超系统，可能会使这种平衡向炎症倾斜。正如加拿大研究人员所指出的，“肠道生理的许多方面，如果不是全部的话，都可能受到神经免疫因素的调控。”

The nervous system is deeply influenced by emotions. In turn, the nervous system is intimately involved in the regulation of immune responses and of inflammation. Neuropeptides, protein molecules secreted by nerve cells, serve to promote inflammation or to inhibit it. Such molecules are found in heavy concentration in the intestines, in the areas most vulnerable to IBD. They are implicated both in the regulation of local inflammation and in the body’s stress response. For example, a neuropeptide called substance P is a powerful stimulator of inflammation because it induces certain immune cells to release inflammatory chemicals such as histamine and prostaglandins, among many others. In the gut, immune cells are closely associated with nerve cells. Chronically stressful emotional patterns could induce inflammatory disease in the gut, through the mediation of the PNI super-system and the activation of pro-inflammatory molecules by stress.

神经系统深受情绪影响。反过来，神经系统也与免疫反应和炎症的调节密切相关。神经肽是由神经细胞分泌的蛋白质分子，它们既能促进炎症，也能抑制炎症。这类分子在肠道中浓度很高，而肠道正是炎症性肠病（IBD）最易发的区域。它们既参与局部炎症的调节，也参与机体的应激反应。例如，一种名为P物质的神经肽是强效的炎症刺激剂，因为它能诱导某些免疫细胞释放组胺、前列腺素等多种炎症化学物质。在肠道中，免疫细胞与神经细胞紧密相连。长期处于压力状态的情绪模式可能通过神经系统介导和应激激活促炎分子，从而诱发肠道炎症性疾病。

The gut, or intestinal tract, is much more than an organ of digestion. It is a sensory apparatus with a nervous system of its own, intimately connected to the brain’s emotional centres. Everyone intuitively understands the meaning of the phrase “gut-wrenching” as a description of emotionally upsetting events. Many of us can recall experiencing the sore tummy of the anxious child. Gut feelings, pleasant or unpleasant, are part of the body’s normal response to the world—they help us to interpret what is happening around us and inform us whether we are safe or in danger. Nausea and pain or a warm, comforting feeling in the tummy are sensations that orient us to the meaning of events.

肠道，或者说消化道，远不止是一个消化器官。它是一个感觉器官，拥有自身的神经系统，与大脑的情感中枢紧密相连。每个人都能凭直觉理解“令人揪心”这个词的含义，它用来形容令人情绪崩溃的事件。我们很多人都能回忆起焦虑的孩子肚子疼的经历。无论是愉悦的还是不适的“肠胃感觉”，都是身体对外界环境的正常反应——它们帮助我们解读周围发生的事情，并告知我们自身是否安全。恶心、疼痛，或是腹部温暖舒适的感觉，都是引导我们理解事件意义的感官体验。

The gut secretes its own neurotransmitters and is influenced by the body’s general hormonal system. The gut also forms an important part of the body’s barrier against noxious substances and plays a major role in immune defence. Its functioning is inseparable from the psychological processing that each moment gauges and reacts to the stimuli presented to us by the environment. The ability of gut tissue to maintain its integrity is heavily influenced by psychological factors, and its resistance to inflammation and even to malignant change is also vulnerable to emotional stress. A species of New World monkey, the cotton-topped tamarin, develops ulcerative colitis and cancer of the colon when captured and caged. 8 A 1999 Italian study showed that in ulcerative colitis, “long-term perceived stress increases the risk of exacerbation over a period of months to years.” 9

肠道会分泌自身的神经递质，并受人体整体激素系统的影响。肠道也是人体抵御有害物质的重要屏障，在免疫防御中发挥着重要作用。肠道的功能与我们对环境刺激的感知和反应密不可分。肠道组织维持其完整性的能力很大程度上受心理因素的影响，其对炎症甚至恶性病变的抵抗力也容易受到情绪压力的影响。一种新世界猴——棉顶狨猴，在被捕获并关在笼子里时会患上溃疡性结肠炎和结肠癌。1999年的一项意大利研究表明，在溃疡性结肠炎中，“长期感知到的压力会增加数月至数年内病情恶化的风险”。

In 1997 Dr. Noel Hershfield, the Calgary gastroenterologist whose timely letter to the editor sparked my own interest in psychoneuroimmunology some years ago, published an article in the Canadian Journal of Gastroenterology . He pointed out that in clinical trials of medications for inflammatory bowel disease, there have been instances of placebo response in the range of 60 per cent and that in others comparing narcotics with placebo drugs for pain control, the number of patients who obtained the placebo effect was consistent at 55 per cent of the response. The 55 per cent figure has been seen in trials of anti-depressant drugs as well. It has been called “the 55 per cent rule.”

1997年，卡尔加里胃肠病学家诺埃尔·赫什菲尔德博士在《加拿大胃肠病学杂志》上发表了一篇文章。几年前，他给编辑的一封及时来信激发了我对心理神经免疫学的兴趣。赫什菲尔德博士指出，在炎症性肠病药物的临床试验中，安慰剂效应的发生率高达60%；而在比较麻醉药和安慰剂镇痛效果的试验中，出现安慰剂效应的患者比例稳定在55%。抗抑郁药物的试验中也出现了55%的安慰剂效应发生率，因此被称为“55%法则”。

Most people think of placebo as a simple matter of imagination, a case of “mind over matter.” Although induced by thought or emotion, the placebo effect is entirely physiological. It is the activation of neurological and chemical processes in the body that serve to reduce symptoms or to promote healing.

大多数人认为安慰剂效应仅仅是想象的结果，是“精神战胜物质”的体现。尽管安慰剂效应可能由思想或情绪引发，但它本质上是生理性的。它是体内神经和化学过程的激活，从而达到减轻症状或促进康复的目的。

Dr. Hershfield proposes that it could be useful to study what is different about the people who improve on placebos. “What kind of people are they? What kind of environment do they live in? Is there something from their past experience that produces their response? What kind of lives do they lead? Are they content with their existences, upbringings, marriages and relationships with society?” These are questions that few doctors ever ask their patients, either those who recover or those who do poorly. When such questions are posed, the answers are uniformly revealing. Dr. Hershfield’s article concluded with a sensible suggestion, radical though it may seem in today’s medical climate: “Perhaps we should include instruction to our colleagues and fellows in the psychosocial aspects of illness, the psychodynamics of recovery and the biochemistry of healing, and teach them that all ills of humanity cannot be solved by yet another endoscopy, another biopsy and another ‘high tech’ procedure that only confirms but does not heal.” 10

赫什菲尔德博士提出，研究那些服用安慰剂后病情好转的人有何不同之处或许很有意义。“他们是什么样的人？他们生活在什么样的环境中？他们过去的经历中是否有某些因素促成了这种反应？他们过着怎样的生活？他们对自己的生活、成长经历、婚姻以及与社会的关系感到满意吗？” 这些问题很少有医生会问他们的病人，无论是康复的病人还是病情恶化的病人。而当提出这些问题时，得到的答案总是能揭示一些真相。赫什菲尔德博士的文章最后提出了一个合理的建议，尽管在当今的医疗环境下，这个建议可能显得有些激进：“或许我们应该向我们的同事和研究员传授疾病的社会心理因素、康复的心理动力学以及愈合的生物化学原理，并让他们明白，人类的所有疾病都无法通过又一次的内窥镜检查、又一次的活检以及又一次只能确诊却无法治愈的‘高科技’手术来解决。”

A friend of mine, Tibor, suffered an episode of ulcerative colitis—the first and only significant episode he would have—during a time when he was experiencing “a frantic feeling of hopelessness, fear and apprehension.” In his early twenties, shortly after the death of his father, he was unexpectedly confronted with the responsibility of having to support his mother and care for his younger sister. His mother, who was in poor health, had been dismissed from her job and appeared to have little prospect of finding another. “I didn’t know how I might ever have a life of my own,” Tibor recalls. He was rushed to hospital with high fever and bleeding from the colon.

我的朋友蒂博尔患上了溃疡性结肠炎——这是他一生中第一次也是唯一一次严重的发作——当时他正经历着“一种绝望、恐惧和焦虑的疯狂感觉”。二十出头，父亲去世后不久，他突然肩负起赡养母亲和照顾妹妹的重任。他的母亲身体不好，又被解雇了，而且似乎很难再找到工作。“我不知道自己还能不能过上属于自己的生活，”蒂博尔回忆道。他因高烧和结肠出血被紧急送往医院。

“They gave me a steroid. I was in the hospital for three weeks, but as soon as they started the treatment I began to feel better and enjoy the nurses around me. This was before hospital cutbacks when nurses had time for patients. The doctors made all kinds of dire predictions of what can happen in the long term—illness, cancer, whatever. I said, ‘Well, I’m not going to have that happen to me.’ I read up on the subject and saw that there were suggestions that ulcerative colitis was psychologically induced and stress related. I got a book on relaxation techniques. I’d lie down and follow the instructions—you know, just relax your toes, relax your legs, relax your whole body.

“他们给我用了类固醇。我在医院住了三个星期，但治疗一开始我就感觉好多了，也很喜欢周围的护士。那时医院还没裁员，护士们有时间照顾病人。医生们对我的病情长期发展做出了各种可怕的预测——疾病、癌症等等。我说，‘我可不想那样。’我查阅了相关资料，发现有研究表明溃疡性结肠炎是由心理因素和压力引起的。我买了一本关于放松技巧的书。我会躺下来，按照书里的指导去做——你知道，放松脚趾，放松双腿，放松全身。”

“I wasn’t on medication for long, only in the hospital. They were telling me to follow this diet or that. I thought, I’m not going to live my life that way. For whatever it was worth, I decided I was going to take control of this situation. I also decided that I would not let external stresses get to me and consciously did what I could do to minimize stress in my life. In the thirty years since, I have been fortunate to have no more than the occasional minor episode of diarrhea or bleeding. None have required medications or medical care.”

“我服药时间不长，只在医院里服用过。他们让我遵循这个饮食或那个饮食。我想，我不能就这样过日子。不管怎样，我决定要掌控自己的命运。我还决定不让外界压力影响到我，并有意识地尽我所能减少生活中的压力。此后的三十年里，我很幸运，只偶尔出现过轻微的腹泻或出血。这些都不需要药物或医疗护理。”

This is not to suggest that the cure for IBD is to lie down and relax one’s toes. But significant in my friend’s experience was his immediate decision to take charge.

这并非暗示治疗炎症性肠病的办法是躺下来放松脚趾。但我朋友的经历中，关键在于他立即决定主动采取措施。

As Dr. Hershfield implies, not the latest technology or miracle drug but encouraging the patient’s capacity to heal may provide the ultimate answer to inflammatory bowel disease. The 55 per cent solution.

正如赫什菲尔德博士所暗示的那样，并非最新的技术或神奇药物，而是激发患者自身的愈合能力，或许才是治疗炎症性肠病的最终答案。这或许是解决55%问题的办法。

11
11
It’s All in Her Head
一切都在她的脑海里

P ATRICIA’S ANGER SEEMS FRESHLY ROUSED . “I’m furious at the doctors. I’ve been condescended to. I’ve been patronized. I’ve been told to my face that I’m faking. I’ve been told that I have to stop going for second opinions. I’ve been told that I’m not feeling pain.”

帕特里夏的怒火似乎又被重新点燃了。“我恨透了医生们。他们对我颐指气使，轻视我。他们当面说我是装病，还让我别再去寻求第二意见，甚至说我感觉不到疼痛。”

The gallbladder of the salesclerk was removed in 1991, when she was twenty-eight, but she continued to have abdominal pain. “I had what I called phantom gallbladder attacks. I had more of that you’ve-been-pumped-full-of-air pain. It would expand, and then I’d throw up, and then I’d feel better for a bit. I’d go to emergency. They would ignore me or say, ‘You’ve got no gallbladder, so you can’t be having these symptoms.’ Then I started to develop sensitivities to certain foods, and I had diarrhea more often.”

这位售货员28岁时（1991年）做了胆囊切除手术，但腹痛症状依然持续。“我经历过所谓的‘幻觉性胆囊炎’。那种感觉就像被灌满了空气一样，腹部胀痛。然后我会呕吐，之后又会感觉好一些。我去急诊，他们要么不理我，要么说：‘你没有胆囊，所以不可能出现这些症状。’后来，我对某些食物开始过敏，腹泻也越来越频繁。”

After many doctors’ visits and tests Patricia was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Medical terminology calls IBS a functional disorder. Functional refers to a condition in which the symptoms are not explainable by any anatomical, pathological or biochemical abnormality or by infection. Doctors are accustomed to rolling their eyes when faced with a patient who has functional symptoms, since functional is medical code for “all in the head.” There is truth in that. The patient’s experience is, in part, in her brain—but, as we will see, not in the pejorative and dismissive sense that the phrase “all in the head” implies.

经过多次就诊和检查，帕特里夏被确诊为肠易激综合征（IBS）。医学术语称IBS为功能性疾病。功能性指的是症状无法用任何解剖结构、病理或生化异常或感染来解释的疾病。医生们面对有功能性症状的患者时，常常会不屑一顾，因为“功能性”在医学上是“心理作用”的委婉说法。这话不无道理。患者的症状确实部分源于大脑——但正如我们将看到的，这并非“心理作用”这种贬义和轻蔑的说法。

Fiona’s medical history and her experience of emergency wards are remarkably similar to Patricia’s. In 1989, in her early twenties, she also had gallbladder surgery, with no resolution of her abdominal distress.

菲奥娜的病史和急诊经历与帕特里夏惊人地相似。1989年，在她二十出头的时候，她也做了胆囊手术，但腹部不适症状并没有缓解。

“Ever since then, I’ve had these pains. It’s just a mind-boggling, sharp spasm, a pain that they’ve done every test in the book for and have come up with nothing. So they’ve diagnosed this IBS. There are no problems with diarrhea or constipation, just pain. The pain is way up here.”

“从那以后，我就一直有这种疼痛。那是一种难以忍受的剧烈痉挛，医生们做了所有能做的检查，却一无所获。所以他们诊断我得了肠易激综合征。我没有腹泻或便秘的问题，只有疼痛。疼痛的位置很高。”

“That’s not IBS, strictly speaking,” I note.

“严格来说，那不是肠易激综合征，”我说道。

“That’s what I’ve said all along. The diagnosis was made back when they called it spastic colon, and then it’s been called IBS. It was a doctor in Toronto who diagnosed it. I’ve had the stomach scopes, the barium X-ray, and they’ve given me all the medications. They’ve tried me on three or four of the different meds for it. The pills have never done anything for me.

“我一直都是这么说的。当初确诊的时候，他们称之为痉挛性结肠炎，后来改名为肠易激综合征（IBS）。是一位多伦多的医生确诊的。我做过胃镜、钡餐X光检查，他们也给我开了各种各样的药。他们让我试过三四种不同的药。但这些药对我一点用都没有。”

“I’ve gone months without having any of these attacks, and then there may be days where I’ll have them. Sometimes they last two minutes, and other times they are debilitating and last for hours. They are sharp, absolute, spasm-type pains. It takes my breath away—a really intense pain. These days they’re pretty bad. I may have an attack that lasts an hour, but it feels like a year.

“我可能几个月都没发作过，但有时也会突然发作。有时持续两分钟，有时却痛得难以忍受，持续好几个小时。那是剧烈、绝对的痉挛性疼痛，让我喘不过气来——真的非常痛。最近情况很严重。有时发作持续一个小时，但感觉像过了一年。”

“When I was in Toronto, they didn’t know what was wrong with me. They’d put me in hospital and connect me to a Demerol drip, so every time I had an attack I could medicate myself. I had nurses tell me I was just there for the attention and so that I could get more narcotics—that I was hooked on them. My response was ‘Then stop giving it to me. All it does is make me sleep—that’s the only way it helps with the pain.’ I hate the stuff.”

“我在多伦多的时候，他们不知道我到底怎么了。他们把我送进医院，给我输杜冷丁，这样每次发作我都能自己用药。护士们跟我说，我来医院只是为了博取关注，好让我能拿到更多麻醉药——说我对这些药上瘾了。我的回答是：‘那就别给我用了。这药只会让我睡觉——这是它唯一能缓解疼痛的方式。’我恨死这玩意儿了。”

Although abdominal pain is a prominent feature of irritable bowel syndrome, by the current definition of the disorder, pain itself is not sufficient for the diagnosis. A person is considered to have IBS if, in the absence of other pathology, she experiences abdominal pains along with disturbances of bowel function, such as diarrhea or constipation. 1 The symptoms may vary from person to person, or even for the same individual from time to time. Patricia’s disturbed bowel habits, for example, do not follow any single pattern.

虽然腹痛是肠易激综合征的一个显著特征，但根据目前对该疾病的定义，疼痛本身并不足以确诊。如果一个人在排除其他病理的情况下，出现腹痛以及肠道功能紊乱（例如腹泻或便秘），则可诊断为肠易激综合征。症状可能因人而异，甚至同一个人在不同时期也可能出现不同的情况。例如，帕特里夏的排便习惯紊乱就没有固定的模式。

“It swings between constipation and diarrhea. There’s not much in between. I can go days without going to the bathroom, and when I do go, it’s diarrhea. Sometimes it’s several times a day, and sometimes I could be in the bathroom for three hours at once. The only consistent thing is that there is no consistency. It is sometimes explosive, sometimes not.”

“我的便秘和腹泻交替出现，几乎没有中间状态。我可能好几天都不上厕所，就算上厕所也是腹泻。有时候一天要上好几次，有时候一次就能在厕所待上三个小时。唯一不变的就是没有规律。有时候像喷涌而出一样，有时候又很平静。”

Although they are not essential for the diagnosis, there are other symptoms commonly noted. It is not unusual for IBS patients to describe stool that is lumpy or small and pellet-like or, on the other hand, loose and watery. They may find themselves having to strain and feeling they have not completely evacuated their bowels. They frequently describe passing mucus with their stool. A sensation of bloating or abdominal distension is also common.

虽然这些症状并非诊断的必要条件，但其他一些症状也较为常见。肠易激综合征（IBS）患者常常会描述大便呈块状或颗粒状，或者相反，大便稀薄如水。他们可能感到排便费力，并且感觉没有完全排空肠道。他们经常会描述大便中带有黏液。腹胀或腹部膨胀感也很常见。

Irritable bowel syndrome is said to affect up to 17 per cent of the population in the industrialized world and is the most frequent reason for which patients are referred to gastroenterologists. Interestingly, most people with symptoms that would qualify them for the diagnosis do not consult physicians.

据称，发达国家高达17%的人口患有肠易激综合征，这也是患者就诊于肠胃科医生的最常见原因。有趣的是，大多数出现符合诊断标准的症状的人并没有就医。

The medical profession’s reflexive discomfort with uncertainty immensely complicates life for patients like Patricia and Fiona. We expect people to present us with diseases that fit neatly into symptom categories and bear unequivocal pathological findings. As the gastroenterologist Douglas Drossman points out, “Forty years ago, Renee Fox, a medical sociologist, noted that one of the most difficult transitions for medical students is to accept the uncertainty that is intrinsic to medical practice. But the biomedical model creates uncertainty for these common conditions that are not explained by underlying disease.” 2 That uncertainty follows from our innate distrust of the patient’s story when we cannot match it with the hard data of physical examination techniques or scans, X-rays, blood tests, scopes, biopsies or electrodiagnostic tools. In such cases, the complainant finds her symptoms dismissed by doctors. Worse, she may be accused of drug-seeking behaviour, of being neurotic, manipulative, of “just looking for attention.” IBS patients, as well as people with chronic fatigue syndrome and fibromyalgia, often find themselves in that situation.

医学界对不确定性的本能性不安，极大地增加了像帕特里夏和菲奥娜这样的患者的生活难度。我们期望人们所患的疾病能够清晰地归入相应的症状类别，并有明确的病理学发现。正如胃肠病学家道格拉斯·德罗斯曼所指出的：“四十年前，医学社会学家蕾妮·福克斯指出，医学生面临的最艰难的转变之一，就是接受医疗实践中固有的不确定性。但生物医学模式却为那些无法用潜在疾病解释的常见病症制造了不确定性。”这种不确定性源于我们与生俱来的对患者叙述的不信任，因为我们无法将患者的叙述与体格检查、扫描、X光片、血液检查、内窥镜检查、活检或电诊断工具等硬性数据相匹配。在这种情况下，患者的症状往往会被医生忽视。更糟糕的是，她甚至可能被指责为寻求药物、神经质、善于操纵，或者“只是想博取关注”。肠易激综合征患者，以及慢性疲劳综合征和纤维肌痛患者，经常会发现自己处于这种境地。

Magda, a physician herself, knew better than to go the emergency wards with her debilitating abdominal pains. She, too, was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome. “Mostly I had pain and distension. Nobody could find anything wrong with me, so we called it IBS. I had a colonoscopy and everything done. There was just nothing else to find. I guess you could call it a diagnosis of exclusion.

玛格达本身就是一名医生，她很清楚，剧烈的腹痛不该去急诊室。她也被诊断为肠易激综合征。“我主要是腹痛和腹胀。没人能查出我有什么毛病，所以我们就诊断为肠易激综合征。我做了结肠镜检查，各种检查都做了。但就是查不出其他问题。我想你可以称之为排除性诊断。”

“There was hardly a day that I didn’t have a bellyache. Sometimes I was lying on the floor of my office, with heating pads, wondering how I would get through the afternoon and how I would drive myself home. It was extremely severe pain and frequent. I had abdominal pain 80 or 90 per cent of the time. There was not a day that, by mid-afternoon, I didn’t have abdominal pain—for years! I’m sure I would have been in emergency many times, too, with the severity of my pain—it’s just that I stay away from places like that because I know what happens there. I didn’t think anything helpful would happen. I didn’t go, but not because of the lack of severity.”

“几乎每天都会肚子疼。有时候我躺在办公室的地板上，敷着电热毯，想着下午该怎么熬过去，怎么开车回家。疼痛极其剧烈，而且频繁发作。我80%到90%的时间都在腹痛。没有一天，到了下午，我的腹痛就会消失——这种情况持续了好几年！以我当时的疼痛程度，我肯定也去过很多次急诊——只是我尽量避免去那种地方，因为我知道那里会发生什么。我觉得去那里也帮不上什么忙。我没去，并不是因为疼痛不够严重。”

When not seen as the patient’s neurotic imaginings, the pain of IBS—and of undiagnosed abdominal pain in general—has been, until recently, thought to be caused purely by uncoordinated contractions of the intestines. Hence phrases like spastic colon. Now it has been confirmed that dysfunction in these disorders does not lie solely in the gut itself. A key issue is the way that the nervous system senses, evaluates and interprets pain.

如果排除患者的神经质想象，肠易激综合征（IBS）的疼痛——以及一般未确诊的腹痛——直到最近一直被认为完全是由肠道不协调的收缩引起的。因此才有了“痉挛性结肠”之类的说法。现在已经证实，这些疾病的功能障碍并非仅仅在于肠道本身。关键问题在于神经系统感知、评估和解读疼痛的方式。

Several observations have led to this new understanding of abdominal problems. Of particular interest are new findings on electrical and scan studies of the brain. When parts of the intestine are artificially distended, the response pattern in the brains of persons with functional abdominal pain characteristically varies from the brain activity of subjects who have no complaints of pain. 3

多项观察促成了我们对腹部问题的新认识。尤其值得关注的是关于大脑电生理和扫描研究的新发现。当部分肠道被人为扩张时，功能性腹痛患者的大脑反应模式与无疼痛主诉者的大脑活动存在显著差异。

Pain from distension of the colon or other parts of the intestine can also be studied by inserting an endoscope into the bowel and then inflating a balloon attached to the scope. In such studies, the functional patient groups repeatedly exhibit a hypersensitivity to distension. They report that the pain from this procedure is similar to the pain they usually experience. One study compared the effects of balloon inflation in IBS sufferers and controls. “Balloon inflation to 60 ml caused pain in 6 per cent of control subjects and 55 per cent of IBS patients…. Estimated gut wall tension at different volumes was similar in the two groups. However, the incidence of pain in relation to wall tension was increased by nearly ten-fold in the IBS group.” 4

结肠或其他肠道部位扩张引起的疼痛也可以通过将内窥镜插入肠道，然后给连接在内窥镜上的球囊充气来研究。在这些研究中，功能性肠病患者组反复表现出对扩张的过敏反应。他们报告说，这种操作引起的疼痛与他们通常经历的疼痛相似。一项研究比较了球囊充气对肠易激综合征（IBS）患者和对照组的影响。“球囊充气至 60 毫升后，6% 的对照组受试者和 55% 的 IBS 患者出现疼痛……两组在不同容量下的肠壁张力估计值相似。然而，IBS 组与肠壁张力相关的疼痛发生率增加了近十倍。”

Parallel observations have been made elsewhere in the digestive tract, from the esophagus to the small intestine. It appears, then, that in functional abdominal pain, physiological messages from the gut are transmitted by the nervous system and received by the brain in an altered fashion. “There is a new area of investigation for patients with these disorders,” Dr. Drossman writes. “After decades of studying how IBS patients are distinguished from normals with regard to their gastrointestinal physiology, we are beginning to see differences in brain physiology.”

在消化道的其他部位，从食管到小肠，也观察到了类似的现象。由此看来，在功能性腹痛中，来自肠道的生理信息通过神经系统传递到大脑的方式发生了改变。“对于这类疾病患者来说，这是一个新的研究领域，”德罗斯曼博士写道。“经过数十年的研究，我们一直在探索肠易激综合征患者与正常人在胃肠生理方面的区别，现在我们开始发现他们在大脑生理方面也存在差异。”

A type of scan known as positron emission tomography, or PET, measures the activity of brain regions by recording variations in blood flow. When study subjects experience distension of their rectums, a PET scan will indicate which part of the brain registers a response. With rectal distension, or even the anticipation of rectal distension, IBS patients activated the prefrontal cortex, an area not activated in normals. 5

正电子发射断层扫描（PET）是一种通过记录血流变化来测量大脑区域活动的扫描技术。当研究对象出现直肠扩张时，PET扫描会显示大脑的哪个部分产生了反应。在直肠扩张时，甚至在预期直肠扩张时，肠易激综合征（IBS）患者的前额叶皮层会被激活，而正常人通常不会激活该区域。

The prefrontal cortex is where the brain stores emotional memories. It interprets present stimuli, whether physical or psychological, in light of past experiences, which can date as far back as infancy. Activation in this part of the brain means that some event of emotional significance is occurring. In people who have experienced chronic stress, the prefrontal cortex and related structures remain in a state of hypervigilance, on the lookout for danger. Prefrontal activation is not a conscious decision by the individual; rather, it is the result of the automatic triggering of nerve pathways programmed long ago.

前额叶皮层是大脑储存情绪记忆的地方。它会根据过往经验（最早可追溯到婴儿时期）来解读当下的刺激，无论是生理上的还是心理上的。大脑这一区域的激活意味着某种具有重要情绪意义的事件正在发生。对于长期承受压力的人来说，前额叶皮层及其相关结构会持续处于高度警觉状态，时刻警惕危险。前额叶皮层的激活并非个体的意识选择，而是早已预先设定的神经通路自动触发的结果。

In another investigation, the electrical amplitudes of brainwaves evoked by sound stimuli were greater in IBS patients than in controls, again indicating a physiological hypervigilance. 6

另一项研究发现，肠易激综合征（IBS）患者对声音刺激诱发的脑电波振幅高于对照组，这再次表明存在生理性过度警觉。

What accounts for these altered nervous-system responses? The answer emerges when we look not only at human organs but at human lives. There is a high incidence of abuse in the histories of patients with intestinal diseases and especially in those patients with IBS and other functional disorders.

是什么导致了这些神经系统反应的改变？答案在于，我们不仅要关注人体器官，更要关注人类生活。肠道疾病患者，尤其是肠易激综合征（IBS）和其他功能性疾病患者的病史中，虐待史的发生率很高。

In a 1990 study of women patients conducted at the gastroenterology clinic of the North Carolina School of Medicine, 44 per cent of the women reported some type of sexual and/or physical abuse. “Those with abuse history had a four-fold greater risk of pelvic pain, two to three times more non-abdominal symptoms (e.g., headaches, backaches, fatigue), as well as more lifetime surgeries.” 7 In a more recent investigation at the same centre, fully two-thirds of the women interviewed had experienced abuse of a physical or sexual nature, or both. Again, abused patients were more likely to undergo various surgeries, such as gallbladder operations, hysterectomies, and laparotomies. They also had “more pain, non-gastrointestinal somatic symptoms, bed disability days, psychological distress, and functional disability compared to those without sexual abuse.” 8

1990 年，北卡罗来纳州医学院胃肠病诊所对女性患者进行了一项研究，结果显示，44% 的女性报告曾遭受某种形式的性虐待和/或身体虐待。“有虐待史的女性患盆腔疼痛的风险是无虐待史者的四倍，出现非腹部症状（例如头痛、背痛、疲劳）的风险是无虐待史者的两到三倍，并且一生中接受手术的次数也更多。” 7 在同一中心最近的一项调查中，接受采访的女性中有三分之二曾遭受过身体虐待、性虐待或两者兼有。同样，遭受虐待的患者更有可能接受各种手术，例如胆囊切除术、子宫切除术和剖腹探查术。与未遭受性虐待的女性相比，她们还“疼痛更剧烈，非胃肠道躯体症状更多，卧床不起的时间更长，心理压力更大，功能障碍也更严重。” 8

It is self-evident that direct physical trauma—a severe brain contusion or the cutting or bruising of a nerve—could physiologically disrupt the nervous system. But how does psychological trauma exert its effect on the perception of pain?

显而易见，直接的身体创伤——例如严重的脑挫伤或神经的切割或损伤——会从生理上扰乱神经系统。但是，心理创伤又是如何影响疼痛感知的呢？

The nervous system of the gut contains about one hundred million nerve cells—we have as many in the small intestine alone as there are in our entire spine! 9 These nerves do more than coordinate the digestion and absorption of food and the elimination of waste—they also form part of our sensory apparatus. The gut responds to emotional stimuli by muscle contractions, blood flow changes and the secretion of a multitude of biologically active substances. Such brain-gut integration is essential for survival. Large volumes of blood, for example, may need to be diverted from the intestines to the heart and to the muscles of the limbs at a moment’s notice.

肠道的神经系统包含约一亿个神经细胞——仅小肠中的神经细胞数量就相当于我们整个脊柱中的神经细胞数量！这些神经不仅协调食物的消化吸收和废物的排出，它们也是我们感觉器官的一部分。肠道通过肌肉收缩、血流变化以及分泌多种生物活性物质来响应情绪刺激。这种脑-肠整合对生存至关重要。例如，在紧急情况下，大量的血液可能需要立即从肠道转移到心脏和四肢肌肉。

In turn, the gut is abundantly supplied with sensory nerves that carry information to the brain. Quite to the contrary of what was believed until recently, nerve fibres ascending from the intestines to the brain greatly outnumber ones descending from brain to gut. 10

反过来，肠道也分布着丰富的感觉神经，这些神经将信息传递到大脑。与最近人们的认知截然相反，从肠道上行到大脑的神经纤维数量远远超过从大脑下行到肠道的神经纤维数量。

The brain relays to the gut data from sensory organs such as the eyes, the skin or the ears—or more correctly, relayed to the gut is the interpretation of such data by the brain’s emotional centres. The resulting physiological events in the gut then reinforce that emotional interpretation. The signals sent back to the brain give rise to gut feelings that we can apprehend consciously. If we lose touch with gut feelings, the world becomes less safe.

大脑将来自眼睛、皮肤或耳朵等感觉器官的信息传递给肠道——更准确地说，传递给肠道的是大脑情感中枢对这些信息的解读。肠道由此产生的生理反应会强化这种情感解读。反馈到大脑的信号会产生我们能够有意识地感知到的直觉。如果我们失去了与直觉的联系，世界就会变得不再安全。

Obviously, life would not be livable if we felt every micro-event in our bodies. Digestion, breathing, blood flow to organs or limbs and myriad other functions must take place without intruding on consciousness. There has to be a threshold below which the brain does not register sensation, below which stimuli are accepted as unremarkable but above which the brain will be alerted to potential danger from within or without. There needs to be, in other words, a well-calibrated thermostat for pain and other sensations.

显然，如果我们能感受到身体里每一个细微的变化，生活将无法维系。消化、呼吸、器官或四肢的血液循环以及其他无数生理功能都必须在不干扰意识的情况下进行。必须存在一个阈值，低于这个阈值，大脑不会感知任何感觉，刺激会被视为无关紧要；而高于这个阈值，大脑就会对来自体内或体外的潜在危险发出警报。换句话说，我们需要一个精准校准的疼痛和其他感觉的“恒温器”。

When there are too many “gut-wrenching” experiences, the neurological apparatus can become oversensitized. Thus, in the spinal cord the conduction of pain from gut to brain is adjusted as a result of psychological trauma. The nerves involved are set off by weaker stimuli. The greater the trauma, the lower becomes the sensory threshold. A normal amount of gas in the intestinal lumen and a normal level of tension in the intestinal wall will trigger pain in the sensitized person.

当经历过多“撕心裂肺”的痛苦体验时，神经系统可能会变得过度敏感。因此，由于心理创伤，脊髓中从肠道到大脑的疼痛传导会发生改变。相关神经更容易被较弱的刺激触发。创伤越大，感觉阈值就越低。即使是肠腔内正常的气体量和肠壁正常的张力，也会在过度敏感的人身上引发疼痛。

At the same time, the prefrontal areas of the cortex will be in a heightened state of vigilance, responding with distress to normal physiological processes. Along with increased pain, IBS patients report higher levels of anxiety, arousal and fatigue during rectal distension than do healthy people. During emotional stress, activity of the cortical regions amplifies the perception of distress.

与此同时，大脑皮层前额叶区域会处于高度警觉状态，对正常的生理过程产生应激反应。除了疼痛加剧外，肠易激综合征患者在直肠扩张期间的焦虑、兴奋和疲劳程度也高于健康人群。在情绪压力下，大脑皮层区域的活动会放大对痛苦的感知。

Dr. Lin Chang is associate professor at the UCLA Medical School and co-director of the UCLA/CURE Neuroenteric Disease Program. He has summarized the current understanding of irritable bowel syndrome this way: “Both external and internal stressors contribute to the development of IBS. External stressors include abuse during childhood and other pathological stresses, which alter stress responsiveness and make a predisposed individual more vulnerable to developing IBS. Later in life, infections, surgery, antibiotics and psychosocial stressors can all contribute to IBS onset and exacerbation.” 11

林昌博士是加州大学洛杉矶分校医学院副教授，也是加州大学洛杉矶分校/CURE神经肠病项目的联合主任。他这样总结了目前对肠易激综合征的认识：“外部和内部压力因素都会导致肠易激综合征的发生。外部压力因素包括童年时期的虐待和其他病理性压力，这些因素会改变个体的压力反应，使易感个体更容易患上肠易激综合征。成年后，感染、手术、抗生素和心理社会压力因素都可能导致肠易激综合征的发生和加重。”

Stress can definitely induce contractions of the intestines. Women who have been sexually abused, for example, are prone to constipation when the muscles in their pelvic floor are chronically tight, incapable of relaxing with defecation. Alternatively, as people who have been terribly frightened have experienced, stress can set off uncontrollable movements in the colon. That was graphically illustrated in a young doctor-to-be who became an unwitting guinea pig in an experiment: “The investigators produced an elaborate hoax by suggesting to a fourth-year medical student undergoing a voluntary sigmoidoscopic examination that they were seeing a cancer. This led to increased contractility or ‘spasm’ of the bowel, which persisted until the hoax was explained. These type of studies confirmed that stress affects colonic function in normal persons and patients.” 12

压力确实会诱发肠道收缩。例如，遭受过性虐待的女性容易便秘，因为她们的盆底肌肉长期处于紧张状态，无法在排便时放松。此外，正如那些经历过极度恐惧的人所体验到的那样，压力会引发结肠不受控制的运动。一位年轻的准医生在不知情的情况下成为了实验对象，生动地说明了这一点：“研究人员精心策划了一个骗局，他们告诉一位正在接受自愿乙状结肠镜检查的四年级医学生，他们发现他患有癌症。这导致肠道收缩增强或‘痉挛’，这种痉挛一直持续到骗局被解释清楚为止。这类研究证实，压力会影响正常人和患者的结肠功能。”

What has been discovered about IBS applies to other diseases of the gut. Patricia, in addition to her IBS, suffers heartburn that has seemed to defy medical explanation. She speaks of it with bitterness. “I have this mysterious gastrointestinal problem that has never been diagnosed. I get acid from eating things that are completely bland. I’ve had to cut out anything with any flavour from my diet.

关于肠易激综合征（IBS）的研究成果也适用于其他肠道疾病。帕特里夏除了患有IBS之外，还饱受胃灼热的折磨，这种症状似乎至今无法用医学解释。她对此感到愤愤不平。“我患有这种神秘的胃肠道疾病，一直没有确诊。即使吃一些味道很淡的食物，我也会胃酸过多。我不得不从饮食中剔除所有有味道的食物。”

“I keep having tests, and they keep telling me I’m fine … or, I should say, one test did show a tiny bit of upset, but they tell me it’s totally out of proportion to what I actually feel. They put that thing up your nose and down into your esophagus, and they measure the amount of acid. There was, they said, a tiny bit of acid, but not enough to cause the degree of pain I’m having.

“我一直在做检查，他们总是告诉我我没事……或者应该说，有一次检查确实显示我有点胃酸分泌，但他们说这和我实际的感受完全不成比例。他们会把那个东西从我的鼻孔伸到食道，测量胃酸的含量。他们说，确实有一点点胃酸，但不足以引起我现在这种程度的疼痛。”

“I’ve been on Pantoloc for about three or four years. It’s supposed to wipe out acid completely, and I was only supposed to take it for six weeks. I also take Diovol or Gaviscon every day. I still have symptoms of acid, but they can’t find anything.”

“我服用潘妥洛克（Pantoloc）大概三四年了。它本应该彻底消除胃酸，而我原本只需要服用六周。我还每天服用代沃（Diovol）或盖胃平（Gaviscon）。我仍然有胃酸过多的症状，但他们查不出任何问题。”

The medical name for the distressing chronic experience of stomach acid flowing upward into the esophagus is gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Researchers in 1992 studied the relationship of reflux symptoms to stress in subjects diagnosed with GERD. While the perception of reflux-associated heartburn by these patients was markedly increased during the stressful stimuli, the objective measures of acid levels were unchanged from one stimulus to another. Stress, in other words, lowered the pain threshold. 13

胃酸反流至食管的慢性不适症状的医学名称是胃食管反流病（GERD）。1992年，研究人员对GERD患者的反流症状与压力之间的关系进行了研究。结果发现，虽然这些患者在压力刺激下对反流引起的烧心感明显增强，但客观测量的胃酸水平在不同刺激下却没有变化。换句话说，压力降低了疼痛阈值。

An intestinal specialist unfamiliar with the neurophysiology or psychology of pain who looked at Patricia’s lower esophagus through an endoscope could, in good conscience, tell her that the acid reflux he observed was inadequate to explain the degree of her pain. And Patricia, in equally good conscience, would be incensed by what she perceived as the callous dismissal of a symptom that is a source of intense daily discomfort in her life.

一位对疼痛的神经生理学或心理学一无所知的肠胃专科医生，如果通过内窥镜观察帕特里夏的下食管，完全可以理直气壮地告诉她，他观察到的胃酸反流不足以解释她所承受的疼痛程度。而帕特里夏同样会因为这种在她看来是对她日常生活中造成巨大痛苦的症状的冷漠忽视而感到愤怒。

This is not to say that people with GERD do not experience more frequent reflux than other people. They probably do, and, once more, it is a brain-gut problem. Investigators comparing healthy controls with reflux patients found that the resting pressure of the esophageal sphincter was more frequently low in the GERD subjects. The decreased efficiency of the sphincter muscles permitted more episodes of reflux. 14

这并非意味着胃食管反流病（GERD）患者的反流频率不高于其他人。事实上，他们的反流频率可能更高，而且，这再次表明，这是一个脑-肠轴问题。研究人员比较了健康对照组和反流患者，发现GERD患者的食管下括约肌静息压力较低的情况更为常见。括约肌功能下降导致反流发作次数增多。

How can the mind and the brain contribute to reflux? It happens by means of the vagus nerve, which is responsible for the tone of the muscles of the lower esophageal sphincter. In turn, the activity of the vagus is influenced by the hypothalamus. The hypothalamus, as we have seen, receives input from the emotional centres in the cortex that are susceptible to stress. Thus, in GERD, a lower pain threshold is combined with excessive relaxation of the sphincter—both phenomena that can be related to stress.

心理和大脑如何影响反流？这主要通过迷走神经实现，迷走神经负责调节食管下括约肌的张力。而迷走神经的活动又受到下丘脑的影响。正如我们所见，下丘脑接收来自大脑皮层情绪中枢的输入，这些中枢对压力非常敏感。因此，在胃食管反流病（GERD）中，疼痛阈值降低与括约肌过度松弛同时出现——这两种现象都可能与压力有关。

The three women interviewed for this chapter described similar pain experiences, though it is only Patricia whose constellation of symptoms meet the full diagnostic criteria for IBS. Unlike the majority of patients in the North Carolina studies, none of these women suffered sexual or physical abuse either as children or as adults. How, then, can we explain their lowered pain thresholds?

本章采访的三位女性描述了类似的疼痛经历，但只有帕特里夏的症状完全符合肠易激综合征（IBS）的诊断标准。与北卡罗来纳州研究中的大多数患者不同，这三位女性在童年或成年时期都没有遭受过性虐待或身体虐待。那么，我们该如何解释她们较低的疼痛阈值呢？

The downward calibration of the nervous system’s pain “thermostat” does not require abuse; chronic emotional stress is sufficient to diminish the pain threshold and to induce hypervigilance in the brain. While abuse would be a major source of such stress, there are other potential stresses on the developing child that are subtle, less visible, but harmful nonetheless. Such strains are present in many families, with parents who love their children and would be horrified by any thought of hurting them. Experiences that affect the physiology of pain perception and of intestinal functioning may happen to children who were not abused in any sense of that word and who even felt loved and protected.

神经系统疼痛“恒温器”的下调并不一定需要虐待；长期的情绪压力就足以降低疼痛阈值，并诱发大脑过度警觉。虽然虐待是这种压力的主要来源，但对发育中的儿童而言，还有其他一些潜在的压力，这些压力较为隐蔽，不易察觉，但同样有害。许多家庭都存在这样的压力，即使父母深爱自己的孩子，任何伤害他们的想法都会让他们感到恐惧。即使没有遭受任何意义上的虐待，甚至感受到爱与保护的孩子，也可能经历一些影响疼痛感知和肠道功能的生理过程。

The immediate stressors for Magda’s severe abdominal pains were related to her job. At the time she was working in a New York hospital. The director of her laboratory had recently resigned, and Magda was not on good terms with his replacement. “The new boss had it in for me from the beginning. In retrospect, I think she was looking for ways to get rid of me from the day she arrived. It was an extremely unpleasant, tense, miserable situation where I loved my work but I hated the environment.

导致玛格达剧烈腹痛的直接压力源与她的工作有关。当时她在纽约一家医院工作。她所在的实验室主任最近辞职了，而玛格达与他的继任者关系并不好。“新老板从一开始就对我怀有敌意。现在回想起来，我觉得她从上任那天起就一直在想方设法把我赶走。那段日子极其难熬，气氛紧张，令人痛苦不堪，我热爱我的工作，但我讨厌那里的工作环境。”

“I worked incredible hours. I was in at seven in the morning. I usually left on time at four, on principle, unless there was some kind of meeting, which happened quite often. I never stopped for lunch. I never took a break. I took work home; I’d work on weekends. I never added it up, but a lot of hours non-stop with tremendous pressure and dirty, dirty politics and a terrible fear—there were no jobs to go to in my field, which was a dying specialty. I never wanted to do general practice, and I didn’t want to go back and do another residency.

“我工作时间长得惊人。早上七点就到，原则上四点准时下班，除非有会议，这种情况经常发生。我从不吃午饭，也从不休息。我把工作带回家，周末也加班。我从没算过具体工作时间，但肯定连续工作了很长时间，承受着巨大的压力，还要面对肮脏的政治斗争和深深的恐惧——我的专业领域正在走向衰落，根本没有工作机会。我从来没想过要做全科医生，也不想再回去做住院医师了。”

“Even with all the pain, I appeared at seven on Monday morning and never dropped the ball—ever. I was never sick. I wasn’t going to give them a way to get rid of me. They were never going to find anything wrong. I didn’t know what I was going to do with my life. I desperately wanted to leave, but I didn’t know what I was going to do.”

“即便疼痛难忍，我周一早上七点还是准时到岗，从未懈怠过。我根本没生病。我不会给他们任何解雇我的机会。他们也永远找不到任何毛病。我不知道自己的人生该何去何从。我迫切地想要离开，但我不知道自己该何去何从。”

Magda was born in an East European refugee camp after the war. As the daughter of Holocaust survivors from Poland, she became secondarily traumatized by their experience. She has always carried a heavy burden of guilt and responsibility for the sufferings of her parents and for difficulties they continued to face. Her decision to enter the medical field did not arise from her own inclinations. It was motivated by her perception of the needs and expectations of her parents and by her concern to ease their anxieties for her future security.

玛格达出生于战后东欧的一个难民营。作为波兰大屠杀幸存者的女儿，她深受父母经历的创伤。她始终背负着沉重的愧疚和责任感，为父母的苦难和他们持续面临的困境感到愧疚。她选择从医并非出于个人意愿，而是出于对父母需求和期望的体察，以及希望减轻他们对她未来生活的担忧。

“If you look at my natural skills, I’m very good at languages, and I’m very good at explaining things. I would never have gone into medicine if I had been free to choose. In fact, I hated a lot about medicine, but I had to deny it to myself.

“如果你看看我的天赋，你会发现我非常擅长语言，也很擅长解释事情。如果让我自由选择，我绝对不会选择学医。事实上，我非常讨厌医学的很多方面，但我不得不压抑这种感觉。”

“I hated much of the course material. I came within a millimetre of failing anatomy. It was an absolute nightmare. I couldn’t do calculus. I couldn’t do physics. I don’t have that kind of mind. I was never good at clinical work. I don’t know if I ever heard a diastolic murmur in my life! I just don’t have that kind of skill. I don’t think I ever felt a spleen—I just pretended. Those were just not things I was good at or inclined to do.

“我讨厌大部分课程内容。解剖学我差点挂科，简直是噩梦。微积分我学不会，物理也学不会，我没有那种思维方式。临床工作我也一直不擅长。我甚至不确定自己这辈子有没有听过舒张期杂音！我就是没有那种技能。我好像从来没摸过脾脏——我只是假装摸到了。这些事情我既不擅长，也不想做。”

“I thought that being a doctor was what I wanted. My parents never said I should I do it, or that I shouldn’t do something else. They just mentioned enough times that it was so good to be able to help other people, and how even the Nazis needed the doctors.”

“我一直以为当医生是我想要的。我的父母从来没说过我应该当医生，或者不应该做别的。他们只是反复强调，能够帮助别人是多么美好，甚至连纳粹都需要医生。”

“Yes, I used to hear that too. And the security that you always carry your knowledge with you in a bag.”

“是的，我也经常听到这种说法。还有一种安全感，就是你总是能把知识装在包里随身携带。”

“That’s right, and nobody can take that away. No matter what kind of times, no matter what happens, doctors are always needed. You can be your own boss and how nice that is. My parents brainwashed me from a very young age.

没错，这一点谁也夺不走。无论时代如何变迁，无论发生什么，医生永远都是不可或缺的。你可以自己当老板，这感觉真好。我父母从小就给我灌输这种思想。

“Then I became a laboratory researcher and I wasn’t a ‘regular’ doctor the way my parents imagined. My mother never really understood what I did and never really was satisfied. What I do is kind of second rate. I don’t put the stethoscope on the patient and I don’t write prescriptions, and I don’t do all those things real doctors do. I just look at specimens and slides. She doesn’t say it to my face, but to some extent she is always disappointed.”

“后来我成了一名实验室研究员，不像我父母想象的那样是个‘正规’医生。我母亲始终不太理解我的工作，也一直不太满意。我的工作算是二流的。我不给病人听诊，也不开处方，不做那些真正医生会做的事情。我只是看看标本和玻片。她虽然不当面说，但某种程度上，她总是很失望。”

As she realized that conventional medical treatment had little to offer her, Magda began psychotherapy. Repressed since childhood, her deep anger toward her parents began to emerge. “I was short-circuiting my visceral experience of anger—at my dad because he yelled and screamed and frightened me so much as a child.

当她意识到传统医学治疗对她帮助不大时，玛格达开始接受心理治疗。她从小就对父母怀有深深的愤怒，这种愤怒开始浮现。“我一直在压抑自己内心深处的愤怒——我对父亲的愤怒，因为他小时候总是对我大吼大叫，吓唬我。”

“The much bigger problem was my relationship with my mother. I thought it was wonderful and we were best buddies—she was my friend and my supporter and ally and the one who listened to me for hours when I came home from school, and the one that I felt close to and understood by and all the rest. It took many, many sessions to uncover the fact that this was actually a very poor-quality relationship. With all her protection of me, she undermined me. She left me feeling quite inept socially and within myself, and she didn’t help me grow up and become my own person. She kept me—with good intentions—very immature.

“更大的问题在于我和母亲的关系。我原以为我们的关系很美好，我们是最好的朋友——她是我的朋友、支持者和盟友，放学回家后她会耐心倾听我几个小时，让我感到亲近和理解，等等等等。我花了很长时间才意识到，这其实是一段非常糟糕的关系。她虽然保护我，却也在暗中削弱我。她让我觉得自己社交能力很差，对自己也很不自信，她没有帮助我成长，没有让我成为一个独立的人。她出于好意，却让我一直保持着不成熟的状态。”

“Other things too—she told me stories of the Holocaust. Other kids were told fairy tales, and I was told stories of the Holocaust … many inappropriate things.”

“还有其他一些事——她给我讲了关于大屠杀的故事。其他孩子听的是童话故事，而我却听的是关于大屠杀的故事……很多不恰当的事情。”

“Do you feel it was inappropriate for you to find out about that?”

“你觉得你得知这件事是否不合适？”

“It was inappropriate at age three and four, when she started telling me. And I don’t know what age it was, but I cannot remember a time when I didn’t hear the accounts of how the whole family nearly got killed because of me when we crossed the border to escape Poland—about how I cried with everybody except with my mother, but I was heavy and she tripped and fell and dropped me in the river, and in order to save me from drowning, they almost all got shot yelling for help. Then she dislocated her shoulder and it’s never been right since.

“我三四岁的时候，她就开始跟我讲这些，当时觉得很不合适。我不记得她具体几岁了，但我总记得她讲过我们一家人为了逃离波兰越境差点因为我丧命的故事——我跟除了妈妈以外的所有人都哭了，因为我太重了，她绊倒了，把我掉进了河里，为了救我，他们几乎都被枪击中，大声呼救。然后她的肩膀脱臼了，从那以后就一直没好过。”

“My parents never said life would have been easier without a child. They wanted a child—they loved me. But I still took on this sense that I was the problem.”

“我的父母从未说过如果没有孩子生活会更容易。他们想要个孩子——他们爱我。但我仍然觉得问题出在我身上。”

Given the trauma her parents had endured and the circumstances surrounding her developing years, Magda’s choice to ignore her own inclinations was almost inevitable. That choice also left her perilously vulnerable to stress. Believing herself to be trapped in a job where she felt rejected by her new laboratory chief was a natural trigger for the excruciating abdominal pains she experienced. In this situation, she could no more assert herself than she could have as a child in her family home. The origin of her pain, as she came to realize, was connected with her unconscious repression of anger.

鉴于父母遭受的创伤以及她成长过程中所处的环境，玛格达选择忽视自己的意愿几乎是不可避免的。这种选择也使她极易受到压力的影响。她觉得自己被困在一份工作中，新来的实验室主管对她不屑一顾，这自然而然地引发了她剧烈的腹痛。在这种情况下，她就像小时候在家里一样，无法表达自己的意愿。后来她意识到，疼痛的根源在于她无意识地压抑了愤怒。

We have noted that gut feelings are an important part of the body’s sensory apparatus, helping us to evaluate the environment and assess whether a situation is safe. Gut feelings magnify perceptions that the emotional centres of the brain find important and relay through the hypothalamus. Pain in the gut is one signal the body uses to send messages that are difficult for us to ignore. Thus, pain is also a mode of perception . Physiologically, the pain pathways channel information that we have blocked from reaching us by more direct routes. Pain is a powerful secondary mode of perception to alert us when our primary modes have shut down. It provides us with data that we ignore at our peril.

我们已经注意到，直觉是人体感觉系统的重要组成部分，它帮助我们评估环境，判断某种情况是否安全。直觉会放大大脑情绪中枢认为重要的感知，并通过下丘脑传递这些信息。肠胃疼痛是身体用来传递难以忽视的信息的一种信号。因此，疼痛也是一种感知方式。从生理学角度来看，疼痛通路传递着我们无法通过更直接途径获取的信息。疼痛是一种强大的辅助感知方式，它在我们主要的感知方式失效时发出警报。它为我们提供的信息，若我们忽视，后果不堪设想。

Fiona, whose abdominal pains were ascribed first to a “spastic colon” and finally to IBS, had a childhood less dramatically charged than Magda’s. However, there is a strong emotional resonance in her chronic fear that she was not accepted for who she was.

菲奥娜的腹痛最初被诊断为“痉挛性结肠”，最终确诊为肠易激综合征，她的童年经历远不如玛格达那样跌宕起伏。然而，她内心深处始终存在的恐惧——害怕自己不被他人接纳——却能引起强烈的共鸣。

“I honestly believe now that I’m an adult and I know my dad as an adult that he never intentionally judged me for anything I did, but he was always critiquing and evaluating. I said to a girlfriend of mine in Calgary when I was seventeen that I haven’t even had a real job yet and I already felt like my resumé didn’t measure up to my sister’s and brother’s. With Dad it always feels like you’re building a resumé instead of just doing what you like to do.”

“我现在长大成人，也以成年人的视角了解了我的父亲，我真心相信他从未故意评判过我做的任何事，但他总是会批评和评价我。我十七岁的时候在卡尔加里跟一个女朋友说，我甚至还没正式工作过，就已经觉得自己的履历比不上我的哥哥姐姐。跟爸爸在一起，总感觉你是在打造一份履历，而不是在做自己喜欢的事。”

“As a child, did you ever tell your parents when you felt bad?” I inquire.

我问道：“你小时候心情不好的时候，有没有告诉过父母？”

“Physically, yes. Never emotionally. I’ve never been good about talking about that. I don’t know why. I think it’s just too personal and private. I’m better at it now. I would never have talked to you five years ago.”

“生理上，是的。但情感上，从来没有。我一直不擅长谈论这个。我不知道为什么。我想这太私人、太个人化了。我现在好多了。五年前，我绝对不会跟你谈这个。”

At the time of our interview, the immediate stresses in Fiona’s life stemmed from her marriage. She had been in the relationship eight years and there were two children. “My husband suffers from depression and panic attacks. He gets these really anxious moments—he’s been like that as long as I’ve known him. He’s a great guy and I love him dearly. He’s a kind-hearted person, but it has been so exhausting to look after him. I’ve been his mother. I have three children—a thirty-nine-year-old, a six-year-old and a two-year-old.”

在我们采访时，菲奥娜生活中最直接的压力来自她的婚姻。她和丈夫已经结婚八年，育有两个孩子。“我丈夫患有抑郁症和恐慌症。他经常会感到非常焦虑——我认识他这么久以来，他一直都是这样。他是个很棒的人，我非常爱他。他心地善良，但照顾他真的让我筋疲力尽。我一直像他妈妈一样照顾他。我有三个孩子——一个39岁，一个6岁，还有一个2岁。”

“These are problems you are aware of. Is it possible that the pains you get reflect something else you haven’t been paying attention to? Rather than seeing the pains as a problem, perhaps they really are gut feelings that are telling you something. When you don’t pay attention to emotional signals, your body says, ‘Okay, here are some physical signals for you.’ If you don’t pay attention to them either, you really are in deep trouble.”

“这些都是你意识到的问题。你感受到的疼痛是否可能反映了你一直忽略的其他问题？与其把疼痛看作问题，或许它们真的是你的直觉在告诉你一些事情。当你忽视情绪信号时，你的身体会发出信号：‘好了，这里有一些生理信号。’如果你仍然忽视这些信号，那你就真的麻烦大了。”

A week after that conversation, Fiona called me back. Her husband, she revealed, had a serious drug addiction problem that she had been ignoring for a long time. She had suppressed her anxiety and anger, wanting to hold on to a childlike hope that he would quit. In consequence of our interview, she began to rethink her situation.

那次谈话一周后，菲奥娜给我回了电话。她透露，她的丈夫有严重的毒瘾问题，而她长期以来一直对此视而不见。她压抑着自己的焦虑和愤怒，仍然抱有孩童般的希望，盼望着他能戒掉毒瘾。但这次谈话之后，她开始重新审视自己的处境。

Patricia, who suffered from irritable bowel syndrome and esophageal reflux, had the most emotionally difficult childhood of the three women introduced in this chapter. She grew up with a perception not only of being unacceptable as she was but of being unwanted in the first place.

帕特里夏患有肠易激综合征和食管反流，是本章介绍的三位女性中童年情感最为艰难的一位。她从小就觉得自己不仅不被接纳，而且从一开始就不被需要。

“I know I wasn’t wanted. I’m not sure when I first realized it, whether as a teenager or as an adult. I’ve thought about things that my mom has said to me, and I realized the signs were there since I was a child. I didn’t recognize them then. I just knew I felt uncomfortable. She always said, ‘You know, I don’t think you belong in this family. I think they gave us the wrong baby.’ And she’d say it with a smile on her face. But, of course, people often pretend to joke when they say something serious.”

我知道我不被家人期待。我不确定自己是什么时候第一次意识到这一点的，是在青少年时期还是成年之后。我回想了妈妈曾经对我说过的话，意识到其实从小我就感觉到了。当时我并没有意识到，只觉得很不自在。她总是说：“你知道吗，我觉得你不属于这个家。我觉得他们给我们生错了孩子。”说这话的时候，她脸上总是带着笑容。当然，人们常常会在说一些严肃的事情时，假装开玩笑。

Irritable bowel patients are more likely than others to have symptoms elsewhere in the body. Susceptibility to pain—migraines, for example—is a problem many IBS patients are prone to, a fact we can readily understand if we grasp the concept of nervous-system sensitization by stressful experience. Heightened perception of pain can be generalized, as Patricia’s medical history illustrates. In addition to IBS and esophageal reflux, Patricia suffers from other conditions, including interstitial cystitis and fibromyalgia.

肠易激综合征（IBS）患者比其他人更容易出现身体其他部位的症状。例如，许多IBS患者容易出现疼痛敏感性，比如偏头痛。如果我们理解压力经历导致的神经系统敏感化这一概念，就能很容易地理解这一点。正如帕特里夏的病史所示，疼痛感知增强可能会扩散到全身。除了IBS和食管反流外，帕特里夏还患有其他疾病，包括间质性膀胱炎和纤维肌痛。

In the North Carolina study that found a majority of women with IBS to have suffered abuse, it was also learned that in only 17 per cent of the abuse cases was the patient’s physician aware of the traumatic history. The practical exclusion of people’s life histories from the medical approach to illness deprives doctors of powerful healing tools. It also leaves them vulnerable to grasping at the latest pharmacological miracle. A case in point is the sobering example of a recent “wonder drug” for irritable bowel syndrome.

北卡罗来纳州的一项研究发现，大多数患有肠易激综合征（IBS）的女性都曾遭受虐待，但研究还发现，在仅有17%的虐待案例中，患者的医生了解其创伤史。在疾病的医疗过程中，人们的生活史实际上被排除在外，这剥夺了医生强大的治疗手段，也使他们更容易盲目追求最新的药物奇迹。最近一种治疗肠易激综合征的“神奇药物”就是一个令人警醒的例子。

On October 24, 2000, The Medical Post , a weekly publication read by many Canadian physicians, carried an enthusiastic headline: “New Drug Relieves IBS Symptoms in Women.” The article reported that a new medication, alosetron, “has been proven in clinical trials to be safe and well-tolerated, and to rapidly and significantly relieve pain and bowel function in patients with IBS, particularly in women with diarrhea-prominent IBS.” A leading Canadian authority was quoted endorsing the drug and hoping for others like it to follow: “Physicians are going to potentially have therapies for IBS that are useful…. IBS patients have a sense of frustration that we really don’t understand what is causing the symptoms. Some of the patients don’t get a lot of relief.”

2000年10月24日，加拿大医生常读的周刊《医学邮报》（The Medical Post）刊登了一篇标题振奋人心的文章：“新药缓解女性肠易激综合征症状”。文章报道称，一种名为阿洛司琼（alosetron）的新药“在临床试验中已被证实安全且耐受性良好，能够迅速显著地缓解肠易激综合征患者的疼痛和肠道功能，尤其对腹泻型肠易激综合征的女性患者效果显著”。文章援引一位加拿大权威人士的话，对该药表示支持，并希望未来能有更多类似的药物问世：“医生们或许将拥有一些有效的肠易激综合征治疗方法……肠易激综合征患者常常感到沮丧，因为我们并不真正了解导致这些症状的原因。有些患者服用后症状并没有得到显著缓解。”

Another expert, the head of the department of medicine at a Canadian university, echoed that positive assessment of the newly available medication: “It’s a very exciting breakthrough…. There is nothing else for them out there. None of the other drugs work. This is it.”

另一位专家，加拿大某大学医学院系主任，也对这种新药给予了积极评价：“这是一个非常令人振奋的突破……目前市面上没有其他药物可以治疗他们。其他药物都无效。就是它了。”

Four months earlier, The Medical Letter , a respected weekly bulletin on medications, had already reported that there was no evidence alosetron offered any advantages over standard treatment. For those patients who did experience improvement with the medication, the benefits disappeared after one week of stopping the drug. The Medical Letter also noted that some women taking it had developed ischemic colitis, a potentially catastrophic condition in which bowel tissue is damaged by a lack of oxygen caused by the constriction of blood supply.

四个月前，权威的药物周刊《医学通讯》（The Medical Letter）就已报道，没有证据表明阿洛司琼比标准疗法有任何优势。对于那些服用该药后病情有所改善的患者，停药一周后疗效便消失。《医学通讯》还指出，一些服用该药的女性出现了缺血性结肠炎，这是一种潜在的灾难性疾病，由于血液供应受阻导致缺氧，从而损伤肠道组织。

In the United States, too, alosetron had been greeted with much fanfare. It was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in February 2000. At the end of November, only a month after the publication of the enthusiastic article in The Medical Post , the FDA forced the manufacturer to withdraw the drug. More women had been hospitalized with ischemic colitis, several of whom required surgery. It was reported that in at least one case the patient’s entire colon had to be removed. There were also reports of deaths.

在美国，阿洛司琼也曾备受瞩目。它于2000年2月获得美国食品药品监督管理局（FDA）的批准。然而，就在《医学邮报》发表那篇热情洋溢的文章一个月后，11月底，FDA就勒令生产商撤回了该药物。更多女性因缺血性结肠炎住院，其中几人需要手术。据报道，至少有一例患者的整个结肠都被切除。此外，还有死亡病例的报道。

If medications are prescribed in a chronic condition like IBS, they usually have to be taken for months or years. It is always risky to commit to a new drug whose long-term safety cannot have been demonstrated by the time it first appears on pharmacy shelves. Doctors and patients do not have to reach for the pharmacopia when the impact of psychological factors on a disease has so abundantly been demonstrated. There is encouraging research evidence that even minimal psychological intervention can be of benefit: “In one controlled study of cognitive-behavioural treatment for patients with irritable bowel syndrome, eight 2-hour group treatment sessions over a 3-month period led to an increase in the number of effective cognitive and behavioural strategies and concurrent reduction in abdominal complaints. Furthermore, improvement continued at 2-year follow-up examinations.” 15

如果像肠易激综合征 (IBS) 这样的慢性疾病需要药物治疗，通常需要服用数月甚至数年。在药物首次上市时，其长期安全性尚未得到证实，因此贸然使用新药总是存在风险。然而，当心理因素对疾病的影响已被充分证实时，医生和患者就不必求助于各种药物了。令人鼓舞的研究证据表明，即使是最小程度的心理干预也能带来益处：“在一项针对肠易激综合征患者的认知行为治疗对照研究中，为期三个月的八次、每次两小时的小组治疗，显著增加了患者有效认知和行为策略的数量，并同时减轻了腹部不适症状。此外，在两年的随访检查中，患者的病情持续改善。”

Magda, the New York physician, has dealt with her debilitating abdominal pains by working out her repressed rage through psychotherapy. She has also entered a profession more suited to her inclinations and personality. “Being in pain 80 per cent of the time disappeared a long time ago,” she says. “In the past two or three months, there has been even further improvement. Recently I cleaned out the fridge in my office, where I have a bottle of Bentylol [a medication to relieve spasms of the intestines]. I honestly can’t remember when I took the last one. It would be quite a few months ago.”

纽约医生玛格达通过心理治疗来释放压抑的愤怒，从而缓解了她严重的腹痛。她也选择了一份更适合自己兴趣和性格的职业。“很久以前，我80%的时间都在疼痛中度过，”她说。“最近两三个月，情况又有了进一步的改善。前几天我清理了办公室的冰箱，里面放着一瓶苯妥英钠（一种缓解肠痉挛的药物）。说实话，我已经记不清上次服用是什么时候了，应该好几个月前了。”

Fiona decided to take the warnings of her abdominal pain to heart. She left her husband when it became clear that he was unwilling to give up his drug addiction. With her two children, she has moved to a new town and filed for divorce. She is no longer experiencing pain.

菲奥娜决定重视腹痛的警告。当她意识到丈夫不愿戒毒时，她离开了他。她带着两个孩子搬到了另一个城镇，并提出了离婚申请。现在，她已经不再感到疼痛了。

12
12
I Shall Die First from the Top
我将第一个死去

A LZHEIMER’S DISEASE IS BECOMING the baby boomers’ nightmare. Affluence and advanced medical care will ensure that the cohort now entering ripe middle age will live longer than any comparable group in history—and will see more of its members slide into dementia than any previous generation. The number of elderly Canadians is predicted to increase by 50 per cent in the next half century. About 100,000 people die of Alzheimer’s annually in the United States, where in 1999 there were estimated to be four million people with the disease. That latter statistic is expected to reach fifteen million in 2050, if present trends continue.

阿尔茨海默病正成为婴儿潮一代的噩梦。富裕的生活和先进的医疗技术将确保如今步入中年的这一代人比历史上任何同等年龄段的人群都更加长寿，但同时也意味着，他们当中患上痴呆症的人数将超过以往任何一代。预计未来半个世纪，加拿大老年人口数量将增长50%。在美国，每年约有10万人死于阿尔茨海默病，1999年美国估计有400万人患有此病。如果目前的趋势持续下去，预计到2050年，这一数字将达到1500万。

Conditions that lead people to be demented—literally, “out of mind”—become more common as we get older. Three per cent of seventy-year-olds suffer from Alzheimer’s or some other form of dementia; by age seventy-seven, the figure rises to 13 per cent. The financial costs are enormous, as is the physical and emotional burden on caregivers. And how can those of sound mind imagine the suffering experienced by someone who helplessly witnesses his memory, his intellect, his very self dissolve into infantile chaos? Gradually comes the loss of control over emotional expression, speech and bodily functions until, if the disease runs its natural course, immobility and death follow.

随着年龄增长，导致痴呆症（字面意思是“失去理智”）的疾病也变得越来越普遍。70岁的老人中，有3%患有阿尔茨海默病或其他形式的痴呆症；到了77岁，这一比例上升到13%。这不仅造成了巨大的经济负担，也给照护者带来了沉重的身心压力。而那些头脑清醒的人又该如何想象，眼睁睁看着自己的记忆、智力乃至自我意识逐渐消融，最终陷入孩童般的混乱状态，是何等的痛苦？患者会逐渐失去对情绪表达、语言和身体机能的控制，最终，如果病情顺其自然发展，就会走向瘫痪和死亡。

“This is the worst thing that can happen to a thinking person,” a person with Alzhemier’s said. “You can feel yourself, your whole inside and outside, break down.” The patient was talking to David Shenk, author of The Forgetting , an illuminating book on the history of Alzheimer’s disease.

“这对一个有思考能力的人来说是最糟糕的事情，”一位阿尔茨海默病患者说道，“你会感觉自己，你的整个身心，都在崩溃。”这位患者当时正在与大卫·申克交谈，申克是《遗忘》一书的作者，这本书深入浅出地讲述了阿尔茨海默病的历史。

Shenk also quotes Jonathan Swift. The seventeenth-century Irish writer, satirist and wit was an intellectual giant reduced in his last years to being a mental Lilliputian, his memory failing, his thoughts disordered. “I neither read nor write, nor remember nor converse,” Swift lamented in a letter composed during the early phases of his dementia. In another, he said that he could “hardly write 10 lines without blunders, as you will see by the numbers of scratchings and blots before this letter is done. Into the bargain, I have not one rag of memory.”

申克还引用了乔纳森·斯威夫特的话。这位十七世纪的爱尔兰作家、讽刺作家和妙语连珠的智者，晚年却如同精神上的侏儒，记忆力衰退，思维混乱。“我既不读书，也不写作，既不记得，也不说话，”斯威夫特在痴呆症早期写的一封信中哀叹道。在另一封信中，他写道：“我几乎写不出十行字，错误百出，正如你在这封信完成之前看到的那些涂改和污渍。更糟糕的是，我的记忆力也荡然无存。”

One of the first structures to deteriorate in Alzheimer’s is the hippocampus, a centre of grey matter in the temporal lobe of the brain, located on either side next to the ears. The hippocampus is active in memory formation and has an important function in stress regulation. It is well known that chronically high levels of the stress hormone cortisol can shrink the hippocampus.

阿尔茨海默病最先出现退化的结构之一是海马体，它是大脑颞叶中位于耳旁两侧的灰质中心。海马体在记忆形成中发挥着重要作用，并在压力调节中扮演着关键角色。众所周知，长期高水平的压力激素皮质醇会导致海马体萎缩。

Could early life experience, emotional repression and lifelong stress predispose to Alzheimer’s? Scientific research indicates so, as does a close look at the lives of people with Alzheimer’s—whether common folk or the famous, like Swift or the former U.S. president Ronald Reagan. An interesting clue that early relationships may be crucial in the later development of dementia comes from animal experimentation. Rats who receive gentle handling in infancy suffer virtually no loss of hippocampal cells in advanced age. 1 Their capacity to remember remains intact. By comparison, non-handled rats are more likely to suffer shrinkage of the hippocampus and also exhibit greater memory impairment in old age.

早期生活经历、情感压抑和终生压力是否会增加患阿尔茨海默病的风险？科学研究表明确实如此，仔细观察阿尔茨海默病患者的生活也印证了这一点——无论是普通人还是像泰勒·斯威夫特或美国前总统罗纳德·里根这样的名人。动物实验提供了一个有趣的线索，表明早期人际关系可能对日后痴呆症的发展至关重要。幼年时期受到温柔对待的大鼠，在老年时期几乎没有海马细胞的损失，它们的记忆能力也保持完好。相比之下，未受过温柔对待的大鼠更容易出现海马萎缩，并且在老年时期表现出更严重的记忆障碍。

In humans, the widely reported Nun Study found that low linguistic ability in early life had a strong association with dementia and premature death in late life. The retrospective research examined the handwritten autobiographies of a group of young postulants (candidate nuns), completed during their first year in the convent. Their mean age at the time of writing was twenty-three. More than six decades later, researchers asked to see the autobiographical statements each had made, and in addition, these now aged nuns were examined for mental health and acuity. As part of the study, each nun was asked and gave permission for an autopsy to be performed after her death. It turned out that those who had expressed a paucity of ideas and had used less vivid language in their youthful memoirs were proportionately more likely to have developed clinical Alzheimer’s as they grew older, along with the characteristic pathological findings in the brain. 2

在人类中，一项广为人知的“修女研究”发现，早年语言能力低下与晚年患痴呆症和过早死亡密切相关。这项回顾性研究考察了一群年轻见习修女（准修女）在修道院第一年完成的手写自传。她们撰写自传时的平均年龄为23岁。六十多年后，研究人员要求查看每位修女当年的自传，并对这些如今已年迈的修女进行了精神健康和认知能力的检查。作为研究的一部分，每位修女都被询问并同意在去世后进行尸检。结果发现，那些在年轻时撰写的回忆录中表达内容匮乏、语言不够生动的修女，随着年龄增长，患上临床阿尔茨海默病以及出现典型脑部病理改变的概率更高。

Richness or poverty of language is determined by many factors, but dominant among them is the quality of early emotional relationships. The author of the world classic Gulliver’s Travels hardly appears to have been deprived of linguistic capacity. On a closer look, Jonathan Swift’s life and writing both manifest a poverty of felt emotional experience and of direct emotional expression. His phenomenal powers were largely confined to intellectual ideas and to an acerbic wit so dry that his humour often escaped less sophisticated readers. As we saw with Gilda Radner, wit can be a coping style that blocks conscious emotional pain, camouflages anger and provides a means of gaining acceptance by others.

语言的丰富或贫乏取决于诸多因素，但其中最主要的是早期情感关系的质量。世界经典《格列佛游记》的作者似乎并不缺乏语言天赋。仔细观察，乔纳森·斯威夫特的生活和作品都体现出他情感体验的匮乏以及直接情感表达的不足。他惊人的才华主要体现在理性的思考和尖刻的幽默上，这种幽默如此冷峻，以至于一些见识浅薄的读者往往难以领会。正如我们在吉尔达·拉德纳的例子中看到的，机智可以成为一种应对方式，它能屏蔽意识层面的情感痛苦，掩盖愤怒，并提供一种获得他人认可的途径。

We can infer the intensely negative emotions agitating Swift, particularly his rage toward women, from the passive-aggressive style of his irreverent satire and from some crudely descriptive passages in his narratives. Swift conjures one of the most physically revolting experiences to befall Gulliver when he has him encounter a female breast in Brobdingnag, the land of giants. In this scene Gulliver observes a wet nurse suckling an infant. “I must confess no Object ever disgusted me so much as the sight of her monstrous Breast, which I cannot tell what to compare with…. It stood prominent six Foot, and could not be less than sixteen in Circumference. The Nipple was about half the Bigness of my Head, and the Hue both of that and the Dug so varified with Spots, Pimples and Freckles, that nothing could appear more nauseous.”

我们可以从斯威夫特不敬的讽刺作品中那种被动攻击式的风格，以及他叙事中一些粗俗的描写段落中，推断出他内心强烈的负面情绪，尤其是他对女性的愤怒。在巨人国布罗卜丁奈格，斯威夫特让格列佛目睹了女性乳房，这无疑是他人生中最令人作呕的经历之一。在这一幕中，格列佛看到一位奶妈正在哺乳婴儿。“我必须承认，没有任何事物比她那巨大的乳房更令我反感，我简直无法用语言来形容……它足足有六英尺高，周长至少有十六英寸。乳头大约有我脑袋的一半大，乳头和乳房上都布满了斑点、粉刺和雀斑，真是令人作呕。”

We understand this disturbing account on a deeper level when we learn that Swift suffered a grievous emotional hurt in infancy, one that he later attributed to his nurse. Swift’s father, also named Jonathan, died seven months before his first and only son’s birth. When only a year old, Jonathan was separated from his mother, Abigaile. He was not to see her for years. In an autobiographical fragment, Swift claims that the nurse abducted him, but to some biographers that sounds like “a comforting fable.” More likely he was abandoned, since, after a brief reunion, his mother left him once more.

当我们了解到斯威夫特幼年时期遭受过严重的精神创伤，而他后来将这种创伤归咎于他的保姆时，我们对这段令人不安的叙述有了更深层次的理解。斯威夫特的父亲也叫乔纳森，在他唯一的儿子出生前七个月去世。乔纳森一岁时就与母亲阿比盖尔分离，此后多年都未能再见到她。在一段自传片段中，斯威夫特声称是保姆绑架了他，但一些传记作家认为这听起来更像是“一个令人安慰的寓言”。更有可能的是，他是被遗弃的，因为在短暂的重聚之后，他的母亲再次离开了他。

Gulliver’s encounter with that monstrous breast no doubt represents an intrinsic emotional memory. Here we are faced with the infant Jonathan’s despair and anger at the sudden absence of his mother, who—in the infant’s preverbal perception—was unaccountably replaced by the detestable nurse and her abhorrent dug.

格列佛与那骇人的乳房的遭遇无疑代表着一种内在的情感记忆。在这里，我们看到的是幼小的乔纳森因母亲的突然离去而产生的绝望和愤怒——在婴儿尚不具备语言能力的认知中，母亲莫名其妙地被令人厌恶的奶妈和她那可憎的狗所取代。

Jonathan was twenty years old before he met his mother again; it was a meeting he initiated. In a manner often seen in the emotionally repressed, he idealized his mother’s memory despite that minimal relationship. In the eulogy he wrote for her, he said, “If the way to Heaven be through piety, truth, justice, and charity, she is there.”

乔纳森二十岁才再次见到母亲，而且是他主动提出的。尽管与母亲关系疏远，他仍然像许多情感压抑的人那样，将母亲理想化。在他为母亲写的悼词中，他写道：“如果通往天堂的道路是虔诚、真理、正义和仁爱，那么她就在那里。”

Swift’s long-repressed anger toward his mother would erupt later not only in misogynistic writings but also in his relationships with women. Toward them he would display a “cold, inexpressive anger,” or even physical violence. Sexually he was repressed. A recent biographer, Victoria Glendinning, writes, “With women who were closer to him, the permafrost of the emotions was maintained. A thaw cannot be risked. No one must have power over him—the power to melt self-possession, the power to hurt…. The only possible emotional outlets are limited, unthreatening ones with powerless and submissive women.” 3

斯威夫特长期压抑着对母亲的愤怒，后来不仅在他厌女的作品中爆发，也体现在他与女性的关系中。他对她们表现出“冷漠、不露声色的愤怒”，甚至诉诸暴力。他的性欲也十分压抑。近期的传记作家维多利亚·格伦丁宁写道：“对于与他关系亲近的女性，他始终保持着情感的冰封状态。他不能冒险让情感融化。任何人都不能掌控他——不能让他失去自控力，不能让他受到伤害……他唯一可能的情感宣泄途径，是与那些无权无势、顺从的女性建立的有限的、无威胁的关系。”

Swift’s lifelong abhorrence of intimacy and his underlying fear of emotional contact or vulnerability are the defensive responses of a child deprived of emotional nurturing, a child who had to learn quickly to fend for himself. “There was, it seems, no one adult who particularly cared for Jonathan, or for whom he particularly cared.”

斯威夫特终其一生都厌恶亲密关系，他内心深处也害怕情感接触或脆弱，这都是一个缺乏情感滋养的孩子的防御性反应，一个不得不迅速学会自力更生的孩子。“似乎没有哪个成年人特别关心乔纳森，他也没有特别关心过谁。”

In some highly sensitive individuals there may arise an uncanny prescience of deeply hidden processes at work in the body/mind. We have noted this before, with the cellist Jacqueline du Pré and the dancer Joanne who died of ALS. Thirteen years before his death, while still in good health, Swift predicted his dementia. He wrote in Verses on the Death of Dr. Swift:

在一些高度敏感的人身上，可能会出现一种不可思议的预知能力，能够察觉到身心深处正在发生的种种变化。我们之前就注意到过这种情况，比如大提琴家杰奎琳·杜普蕾和因渐冻症去世的舞蹈家乔安妮。斯威夫特在去世前十三年，身体还很健康的时候，就预言了自己会患上痴呆症。他在《悼念斯威夫特博士》一诗中写道：

Poor gentleman, he droops apace,
可怜的先生，他日渐衰弱，
You plainly find it in his face:
你从他的脸上就能清楚地看到：
That old vertigo in his head,
他头上的老毛病，
Will never leave him, till he’s dead:
将伴随他一生：
Besides, his memory decays,
此外，他的记忆力也在衰退，
He recollects not what he says;
他记不起自己说过的话；
He cannot call his friends to mind;
他想不起自己的朋友；
Forgets the place where he last dined….
忘记了自己上次在哪里用餐……

He expressed the same premonition on a walk with a friend, seeing a decaying tree: “I shall be like that tree; I shall die first at the top.”

在与朋友散步时，他看到一棵枯树，表达了同样的预感：“我将像那棵树一样；我将在顶端最先死去。”

Swift died at age sixty-seven, in his time a fairly advanced age. His last years were an inexorable descent into dementia. Even toward the end, he was capable of uttering poignant wisdom—if only unconsciously, by rote. Glendinning writes: “One day during the sad last months—it was Sunday, 17 March 1744—sitting in his chair, he put out his hand to snatch at a knife lying on the table. Anne Ridgeway moved it out of his reach. He shrugged his shoulders, and rocked himself, and said, ‘I am what I am.’ He repeated the words, ‘I am what I am. I am what I am.’”

斯威夫特享年六十七岁，在当时算是高龄。他晚年逐渐陷入痴呆。即便到了生命的尽头，他依然能够说出一些意味深长的智慧之语——尽管只是无意识地、机械地重复。格伦丁宁写道：“在他生命最后几个月的某一天——那是1744年3月17日，星期日——他坐在椅子上，伸手去抓桌上的一把刀。安妮·里奇韦把刀移开了。他耸了耸肩，摇了摇身一摇，说道：‘我就是我。’他重复着这句话：‘我就是我。我就是我。’”

From diagnosis to death, life expectancy in Alzheimer’s averages eight years, regardless of the age when the disease first strikes. In rare instances, that may be as early as the sixth decade. Such was the case of Frau Auguste D., a fifty-one-year-old woman admitted to a Frankfurt psychiatric hospital in 1901 with a history of unexplainable behavioural quirks, emotional outbursts and memory lapses. Her course of irreversible mental and physical debility culminated in her death four years later. There was no known diagnosis, but posthumously, Frau D.’s condition came to bear the name of her psychiatrist, the brilliant Alois Alzheimer.

从确诊到死亡，阿尔茨海默病患者的平均预期寿命为八年，与发病年龄无关。极少数情况下，患者甚至可能在六十岁左右就发病。奥古斯特·D女士就是如此。1901年，这位五十一岁的女性因无法解释的行为怪癖、情绪爆发和记忆力衰退被送入法兰克福一家精神病院。四年后，她不可逆转的身心衰弱最终导致去世。当时并未确诊，但D女士的病情后来被命名为阿尔茨海默病，以纪念她的精神科医生——杰出的阿洛伊斯·阿尔茨海默。

Although Frau D.’s deterioration mimicked senile dementia, which was previously thought to be a normal, if unfortunate, consequence of aging, his patient’s relatively young age suggested to Alzheimer that she had a yet-unidentified disease process. The new laboratory techniques of the time made possible a post-mortem examination of Frau D.’s brain, yielding what are now recognized as the hallmarks of the diagnosis: pathological changes in brain tissue specific to this disease. Normal nerve fibres are obliterated, replaced by tangles of strange strands called fibrils and by plaques, which David Shenk describes as “crusty brown lumps … a hodgepodge of granules and short, crooked threads, as if they were sticky magnets for microscopic trash.” 4

尽管D女士的病情恶化与老年痴呆症相似（老年痴呆症此前被认为是衰老的正常结果，尽管令人遗憾），但她相对年轻的年龄让阿尔茨海默医生怀疑她患有一种尚未被发现的疾病。当时的新型实验室技术使得对D女士的大脑进行尸检成为可能，并发现了如今被认为是该疾病诊断标志的特征：脑组织中特有的病理变化。正常的神经纤维消失，取而代之的是被称为原纤维的奇怪丝状物和斑块。大卫·申克将这些斑块描述为“棕色的硬块……由颗粒和短而弯曲的丝状物混合而成，就像是吸引微小垃圾的粘性磁铁。”

Following on Alzheimer’s pioneering work, we now know dementia is not an inexorable part of getting older but always represents disease. Various theories have been floated to explain the cause of Alzheimer’s, but so far none of them have been convincing. Some years ago, the finding that the Alzheimer’s-affected brain contains higher than normal levels of aluminum prompted many people to discard their aluminum utensils in the hope of warding off the disease. Only later was it recognized that the presence of this metal in the brain was a consequence of the degenerative process, not the cause of it. Even more intriguing, tangles and plaques have been found in the brains of people who, during life, exhibited no signs at all of suffering from Alzheimer’s. (Recall that we have seen analogous findings of cancer cells in the breasts of women who had no clinical malignancy, or in the prostates of men dying in healthy old age.) A most telling example came in the recently concluded study of nuns and Alzheimer’s disease. “Sister Mary, the gold standard for the Nun Study, was a remarkable woman who had high cognitive test scores before her death at 101 years of age. What is more remarkable is that she maintained this high status despite having abundant neurofibrillary tangles and senile plaques, the classic lesions of Alzheimer’s disease.” 5

继阿尔茨海默病先驱的研究之后，我们现在知道，痴呆症并非衰老的必然组成部分，而始终代表着一种疾病。人们提出了各种理论来解释阿尔茨海默病的病因，但迄今为止，没有一种理论能够令人信服。几年前，人们发现阿尔茨海默病患者的大脑中铝含量高于正常水平，这促使许多人丢弃铝制餐具，希望以此预防该疾病。但后来人们才认识到，大脑中铝的存在是退行性过程的结果，而非病因。更令人费解的是，人们在生前完全没有表现出任何阿尔茨海默病症状的人的大脑中也发现了神经纤维缠结和斑块。 （回想一下，我们曾在一些没有临床恶性肿瘤的女性乳房中，或在一些健康老年去世的男性前列腺中，发现过类似的癌细胞。）最近完成的一项关于修女与阿尔茨海默病的研究就是一个最能说明问题的例子。“玛丽修女是修女研究的黄金标准，她是一位杰出的女性，在101岁去世前，认知测试得分很高。更令人惊讶的是，尽管她体内有大量的神经原纤维缠结和老年斑——阿尔茨海默病的典型病变——她仍然保持着如此高的认知水平。”

An international scientific consensus is steadily gaining ground that points to Alzheimer’s as one of the diseases on the spectrum of autoimmune conditions, along with multiple sclerosis, asthma, rheumatoid arthritis, ulcerative colitis and many others. Again, these are the diseases in which the body’s immune system turns against the self. In autoimmune illness, there is blurring between what is self and non-self—- foreign matter to be attacked.

国际科学界正逐渐达成共识，认为阿尔茨海默病与多发性硬化症、哮喘、类风湿性关节炎、溃疡性结肠炎等多种疾病一样，都属于自身免疫性疾病。这些疾病的共同特征是人体免疫系统攻击自身组织。在自身免疫性疾病中，自身与非自身（即需要攻击的外来物质）之间的界限变得模糊不清。

“Autoimmune aggression” is how Russian researchers recently characterized the pathological process in Alzheimer’s. 6 Canadian physicians have found a higher incidence of other autoimmune illnesses in the families of Alzheimer’s patients, suggesting a common predisposition. 7 The inflammation of brain tissue in Alzheimer’s—called inflamm-aging by a group of Italian scientists—has been successfully slowed by the same anti-inflammatory drugs employed in the treatment of arthritis. Spanish invesigators have found immune-system components, including specialized immune cells and chemicals, in the brain tissue of affected patients. 8 Scientists have identified unique anti-brain antibodies manufactured by the confused immune system. According to Austrian researchers, “There is little doubt that the immune system plays a role in the neurodegenerative process in Alzheimer’s disease.” 9

俄罗斯研究人员最近将阿尔茨海默病的病理过程描述为“自身免疫攻击”。加拿大医生发现，阿尔茨海默病患者的家族中其他自身免疫性疾病的发病率较高，这表明存在共同的易感因素。意大利一组科学家将阿尔茨海默病脑组织的炎症称为“炎症衰老”，而用于治疗关节炎的抗炎药物已成功减缓了这种炎症。西班牙研究人员在受影响患者的脑组织中发现了免疫系统成分，包括特化的免疫细胞和化学物质。科学家们已经鉴定出由紊乱的免疫系统产生的独特抗脑抗体。奥地利研究人员表示：“毫无疑问，免疫系统在阿尔茨海默病的神经退行性过程中发挥着作用。”

The autoimmune diseases all entail imbalances in the body’s physiological stress-regulation system, in particular the hormonal cascade set off by the hypothalamus. This surge of hormones culminates in the release of cortisol and adrenalin by the adrenal glands. Many studies have shown dysregulated physiological stress responses in Alzheimer’s, including abnormal production of hypothalamic and pituitary hormones and cortisol. In human beings with Alzheimer’s and in animal models of dementia, there is excessive production of cortisol, which is paralleled by the degree of damage to the hippocampus.

所有自身免疫性疾病都会导致人体生理应激调节系统失衡，尤其是下丘脑启动的激素级联反应。这种激素激增最终会导致肾上腺释放皮质醇和肾上腺素。许多研究表明，阿尔茨海默病患者存在生理应激反应失调，包括下丘脑和垂体激素以及皮质醇的异常分泌。在阿尔茨海默病患者和痴呆症动物模型中，皮质醇分泌过多，且其程度与海马体的损伤程度呈正相关。

Dr. Cai Song is an internationally known researcher at the University of British Columbia and co-author of a recent textbook, Fundamentals of Psychoneuroimmunology . “I am convinced that Alzheimer’s is an autoimmune disease,” says Dr. Song. “It is probably triggered by chronic stress acting on an aging immune system.”

蔡松博士是英属哥伦比亚大学一位国际知名的研究员，也是近期出版的教科书《精神神经免疫学基础》的合著者。“我确信阿尔茨海默病是一种自身免疫性疾病，”宋博士说，“它很可能是由慢性压力作用于衰老的免疫系统而引发的。”

The emotional centres in the brain profoundly influence the neurological and hormonal processes of the stress response, as we have seen. The repression of negative emotion—for example, the unconscious grief, anger and loathing Jonathan Swift experienced as a result of early deprivation—is a chronic and significant source of damaging stress. Researchers at the Ohio State University have suggested that in Alzheimer’s, as in the other autoimmune conditions, negative emotions provide a major risk factor for the eventual onset of disease. 10

正如我们所见，大脑中的情绪中枢对压力反应的神经和激素过程有着深远的影响。压抑负面情绪——例如，乔纳森·斯威夫特因早年匮乏而产生的无意识的悲伤、愤怒和憎恨——是造成慢性且严重的压力来源。俄亥俄州立大学的研究人员指出，在阿尔茨海默病以及其他自身免疫性疾病中，负面情绪是最终发病的重要风险因素。

The world’s most famous Alzheimer’s sufferer is Ronald Reagan. When Reagan was first diagnosed at the age of eighty-three, six years after the end of his second presidential term, he wrote poignantly in his farewell message to the American people, “I now begin the journey that will lead me into the sunset of my life.” It has been a long, sad decline.

世界上最著名的阿尔茨海默病患者是罗纳德·里根。里根在83岁高龄被确诊患有此病，当时距离他第二个总统任期结束已有六年。他在致美国人民的告别信中动情地写道：“我即将踏上人生暮年的旅程。” 这是一段漫长而令人悲伤的衰落过程。

Like Swift, Reagan suffered trauma early on. His father, Jack, was an alcoholic. “At four, he could hardly comprehend that his father had been arrested for public drunkenness,” avers Edmund Morris in his unorthodox biography, Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan . “Dutch, a dreamy, mild-mannered boy, remained oblivious to the high cost of alcoholism. He did not understand why he and Neil [his brother], on baseball afternoons, were festooned around the neck with sacks of freshly-popped corn and told to ‘go sell it down in the amusement park.’” 11

和斯威夫特一样，里根早年也遭受过创伤。他的父亲杰克是个酒鬼。“四岁时，他几乎无法理解父亲因醉酒闹事而被捕，”埃德蒙·莫里斯在他那部非传统的传记《荷兰人：罗纳德·里根回忆录》中写道。“荷兰人是个爱幻想、性格温和的男孩，对酗酒的代价浑然不觉。他不明白为什么他和尼尔（他的弟弟）在棒球比赛的下午，脖子上会被挂满一袋袋新鲜爆米花，然后被告知‘去游乐园卖’。”

Morris, a perceptive biographer, was wrong this time—or only partially right. While a young child may not be cognitively aware of family disgrace, emotionally he is absorbing all the negative psychic vibrations of the stressed family system. An emotional shutdown, a tuning-out of reality, is his brain’s most readily available defence. In consequence, the Great Communicator could speak the language of sentiment but not that of genuine emotion. “Really, there are no words” became Reagan’s mantra, “his standard cliché to express emotion required of him,” writes Morris.

莫里斯是一位洞察力敏锐的传记作家，但这一次他错了——或者说只对了一部分。虽然年幼的孩子在认知上可能意识不到家庭的耻辱，但在情感上，他却会吸收整个紧张家庭系统带来的所有负面心理影响。情感封闭，即对现实的麻木，是他大脑最容易启动的防御机制。因此，这位伟大的沟通者能够说一些煽情的语言，却无法表达真正的情感。“真的，无言以对”成了里根的口头禅，“成了他表达情感时常用的陈词滥调，”莫里斯写道。

If the shutting-down of emotion occurs early enough, during the critical phases of brain development, the capacity to recognize reality may become permanently impaired.
