Hans Selye, the founder of stress research, developed the concept of adaptation energy . “It is as though we had hidden reserves of adaptability, or adaptation energy, throughout the body…. Only when all of our adaptability is used up will irreversible, general exhaustion and death follow.” 7 Aging, of course, is the normal process through which the reserves of adaptation energy become depleted. But physiologically stress ages us as well—as the language recognizes when people speak of “having aged overnight.” Throughout her lifetime, much of Caitlin’s adaptation energy had been diverted away from self-nurturing toward taking care of others. Her function had been determined by family dynamics during her childhood. By the time her illness struck, she had run out of energy.

压力研究的创始人汉斯·塞利提出了适应能量的概念。“就好像我们全身都隐藏着适应能力或适应能量的储备……只有当我们所有的适应能力都耗尽时，才会出现不可逆转的、普遍的衰竭和死亡。”当然，衰老是适应能量储备逐渐耗尽的正常过程。但从生理角度来看，压力也会加速我们的衰老——正如人们常说的“一夜之间老了”。凯特琳一生中，她的大部分适应能量都从自我滋养转移到了照顾他人。她的功能在她童年时期就受到家庭关系的影响。当她生病时，她已经精疲力竭了。

Central to any understanding of stress, health and disease is the concept of adaptiveness . Adaptiveness is the capacity to respond to external stressors without rigidity, with flexibility and creativity, without excessive anxiety and without being overwhelmed by emotion. People who are not adaptive may seem to function well as long as nothing is disturbing them, but they will react with various levels of frustration and helplessness when confronted by loss or by difficulty. They will blame themselves or blame others. A person’s adaptiveness depends very much on the degree of differentiation and adaptiveness of previous generations in his family and also on what external stressors may have acted on the family. The Great Depression, for example, was a difficult time for millions of people. The multigenerational history of particular families enabled some to adapt and cope, while other families, facing the same economic scarcities, were psychologically devastated.

理解压力、健康和疾病的核心在于适应性这一概念。适应性是指个体能够灵活、创造性地应对外部压力，避免过度焦虑和情绪失控。缺乏适应性的人，只要没有外界干扰，表面上看起来似乎一切正常；但一旦遭遇损失或困境，他们就会表现出不同程度的沮丧和无助。他们会自责或责怪他人。一个人的适应性很大程度上取决于其家族前几代人的分化程度和适应能力，以及该家族所经历的外部压力。例如，大萧条时期对数百万人来说是一段艰难的时期。某些家族凭借其多代传承的经验得以适应和应对，而另一些面临同样经济困境的家族则遭受了严重的心理创伤。

“Highly adaptive people and families, on the average, have fewer physical illnesses, and those illnesses that do occur tend to be mild to moderate in severity,” writes Dr. Michael Kerr.

“平均而言，适应能力强的人和家庭患的身体疾病较少，而且即使患病，病情也往往较轻或中等，”迈克尔·克尔博士写道。

Since one important variable in the development of physical illness is the degree of adaptiveness of an individual, and since the degree of adaptiveness is determined by the multigenerational emotional process, physical illness, like emotional illness, is a symptom of a relationship process that extends beyond the boundaries of the individual “patient.” Physical illness, in other words, is a disorder of the family emotional system [which includes] present and past generations. 8

由于个体的适应程度是身体疾病发展的一个重要变量，而适应程度又取决于多代情感过程，因此，身体疾病与情绪疾病一样，都是超越个体“患者”界限的关系过程的症状。换言之，身体疾病是家庭情感系统（包括当代和过去几代人）的一种紊乱。

Children who become their parents’ caregivers are prepared for a lifetime of repression. And these roles children are assigned have to do with the parents’ own unmet childhood needs—and so on down the generations. “Children do not need to be beaten to be compromised,” researchers at McGill University have pointed out. 9 Inappropriate symbiosis between parent and child is the source of much pathology.

那些成为父母照顾者的孩子，注定要承受终生的压抑。而这些被赋予的角色，与父母自身童年时期未被满足的需求息息相关——这种模式代代相传。“孩子不需要挨打就会变得脆弱，”麦吉尔大学的研究人员指出。父母与子女之间不恰当的共生关系是许多病态心理的根源。

The child’s habitual adaptive responses to the family system give rise to the traits that, with time, become identified with her “personality.” We have noted that personality does not cause disease—stress does. If we may speak of a disease-prone personality, it is only in the sense that certain traits—in particular, the repression of anger—increase the amount of stress in an individual’s life. Now we see that concepts such as “the rheumatoid personality” or “the cancer personality” are misleading for yet another reason: they assume that an individual person is an isolated entity, not recognizing that he is situated in and shaped by a multigenerational family system. As Dr. Kerr suggests, it is much more illuminating to think of, say, a cancer position than a cancer personality. “The concept of a cancer personality, although certainly having some validity, is based in individual theories of human functioning. The concept of a cancer position is based in a systems theory of human functioning. In a family system the functioning of each person is influenced and regulated by the functioning of every other person.” 10

儿童对家庭系统的习惯性适应性反应会形成一些特征，这些特征随着时间的推移，最终与她的“人格”联系起来。我们已经注意到，人格本身并不会导致疾病——压力才会。如果我们要谈论易患疾病的人格，那也仅仅是指某些特征——特别是压抑愤怒——会增加个体生活中的压力。现在我们看到，“类风湿性人格”或“癌症人格”之类的概念之所以具有误导性，还有另一个原因：它们假定个体是一个孤立的实体，而没有意识到个体身处并受制于一个多代家庭系统。正如克尔博士所建议的，与其思考癌症人格，不如思考癌症的立场，这样会更有启发性。 “巨蟹座人格的概念虽然确实有一定道理，但它是基于个体的人类功能理论。而巨蟹座位置的概念则是基于系统性的人类功能理论。在家庭系统中，每个人的功能都受到其他每个人的功能的影响和调节。”

If individuals are part of a multigenerational family system, families and individuals are also parts of a much larger whole: the culture and society in which they live. The functioning of human beings can no more be isolated from the larger social context than can that of a bee in a hive. It is not enough, therefore, to stop at the family system as if it determined the health of its members without regard to the social, economic and cultural forces that shape family life.

如果说个人是多代家庭系统的一部分，那么家庭和个人也是更大整体的一部分：他们所生活的文化和社会。人类的生存和发展离不开更大的社会环境，正如蜜蜂离不开蜂巢一样。因此，仅仅关注家庭系统本身，仿佛它决定了家庭成员的健康，而忽略塑造家庭生活的社会、经济和文化力量，是远远不够的。

Cancer and the autoimmune diseases of various sorts are, by and large, diseases of civilization. While industrialized society organized along the capitalist model has solved many problems for many of its members—such as housing, food supply and sanitation—it has also created numerous new pressures even for those who do not need to struggle for the basics of existence. We have come to take these stresses for granted as inevitable consequences of human life, as if human life existed in an abstract form separable from the human beings who live it. When we look at people who only recently have come to experience urban civilization, we can see more clearly that the benefits of “progress” exact hidden costs in terms of physiological balance, to say nothing of emotional and spiritual satisfaction. Hans Selye wrote, “Apparently in a Zulu population, the stress of urbanization increased the incidence of hypertension, predisposing people to heart accidents. In Bedouins and other nomadic Arabs, ulcerative colitis has been noted after settlement in Kuwait City, presumably as a consequence of urbanization.” 11

癌症和各种自身免疫性疾病，总体而言，都是文明病。虽然以资本主义模式组织的工业化社会为许多成员解决了住房、食品供应和卫生等诸多问题，但也给那些无需为基本生存而挣扎的人们带来了诸多新的压力。我们逐渐将这些压力视为人类生活不可避免的后果，仿佛人类生活以一种抽象的形式存在，与生活在其中的人类个体分离。当我们观察那些近期才开始体验城市文明的人们时，我们就能更清楚地看到，“进步”带来的好处背后隐藏着生理平衡方面的代价，更不用说情感和精神上的满足感了。汉斯·塞利写道：“显然，在祖鲁族人群中，城市化的压力增加了高血压的发病率，使人们更容易发生心脏意外。在贝都因人和其他阿拉伯游牧民族中，人们注意到在科威特城定居后溃疡性结肠炎的发病率有所上升，这很可能是城市化的结果。”

The main effect of recent trends on the family under the prevailing socio-economic system, accelerated by the current drive to “globalization,” has been to undermine the family structure and to tear asunder the connections that used to provide human beings with a sense of meaning and belonging. Children spend less time around nurturing adults than ever before during the course of human evolution. The nexus previously based in extended family, village, community and neighbourhood has been replaced by institutions such as daycare and school, where children are more oriented to their peers than to reliable parents or parent substitutes. Even the nuclear family, supposedly the basic unit of the social structure, is under intolerable pressure. In many families now, both parents are having to work to assure the basic necessities one salary could secure a few decades ago. “[The] separation of infants from their mothers and all other types of relocation which leave few possibilities for interpersonal contact are very common forms of sensory deprivation; they may become major factors in disease,” wrote the prescient Hans Selye.

在当前的社会经济体系下，受“全球化”浪潮的加速推动，近期趋势对家庭的主要影响是削弱了家庭结构，并撕裂了曾经赋予人类意义感和归属感的纽带。在人类进化史上，儿童与悉心照料的成年人相处的时间比以往任何时候都少。过去以大家庭、村庄、社区和邻里为基础的纽带已被托儿所和学校等机构所取代，在这些机构中，儿童更倾向于与同伴而非可靠的父母或监护人相处。即使是作为社会结构基本单元的核心家庭，也面临着难以承受的压力。如今，许多家庭的父母双方都必须工作，才能维持几十年前一份工资就能满足的基本生活需求。“婴儿与母亲分离以及所有其他导致人际交往机会减少的搬迁，都是非常常见的感官剥夺形式；它们可能成为疾病的主要诱因，”富有远见的汉斯·塞利写道。

In Tuesdays with Morrie , Mitch Albom reports that Morrie Schwartz, his former professor terminally ill with ALS, “was intent on proving that the word ‘dying’ was not synonymous with ‘useless.’” The immediate question is why one would have a need to prove this. No human being is “useless,” whether the helpless infant or the helpless ill or dying adult. The point is not to prove that dying people can be useful but to reject the spurious concept that people need to be useful in order to be valued. Morrie learned at a young age that his “value” depended on his ability to serve the needs of others. That same message, taken to heart by many people early in life, is heavily reinforced by the prevailing ethic in our society. All too frequently, people are given the sense that they are valued only for their utilitarian contribution and are expendable if they lose their economic worth.

在《相约星期二》一书中，米奇·阿尔博姆写道，他以前的教授莫里·施瓦茨身患渐冻症，已是绝症患者，“他一心想证明‘垂死’并不等同于‘无用’”。人们不禁要问，为什么需要证明这一点？无论是无助的婴儿，还是无助的病人或垂死的成年人，没有人是“无用的”。重点不在于证明垂死之人也能有用，而在于驳斥“人必须有用才能被认可”这种谬论。莫里从小就明白，他的“价值”取决于他服务他人的能力。许多人在人生早期就接受了这种观念，而这种观念又被我们社会盛行的伦理观念所强化。人们常常被灌输一种感觉：他们的价值仅仅在于他们的功利性贡献，一旦失去经济价值，他们就成了可有可无的牺牲品。

The separation of mind and body that informs medical practice is also the dominant ideology in our culture. We do not often think of socio-economic structures and practices as determinants of illness or well-being. They are not usually “part of the equation.” Yet the scientific data is beyond dispute: socio-economic relationships have a profound influence on health. For example, although the media and the medical profession—inspired by pharmaceutical research—tirelessly promote the idea that next to hypertension and smoking, high cholesterol poses the greatest risk for heart disease, the evidence is that job strain is more important than all the other risk factors combined. Further, stress in general and job strain in particular are significant contributors both to high blood pressure and to elevated cholesterol levels.

医学实践中奉行的身心分离观念，也正是我们文化中的主流意识形态。我们通常不会将社会经济结构和实践视为疾病或健康的决定因素。它们通常不被纳入考量。然而，科学数据无可辩驳地表明：社会经济关系对健康有着深远的影响。例如，尽管媒体和医学界——受药物研究的启发——不遗余力地宣传高胆固醇是除高血压和吸烟之外，心脏病的最大风险因素，但证据表明，工作压力比所有其他风险因素加起来都更为重要。此外，压力，尤其是工作压力，是导致高血压和高胆固醇的重要因素。

Economic relationships influence health because, most obviously, people with higher incomes are better able to afford healthier diets, living and working conditions and stress-reducing pursuits. Dennis Raphael, associate professor at the School of Health Policy and Management at York University in Toronto has recently published a study of the societal influences on heart disease in Canada and elsewhere. His conclusion: “One of the most important life conditions that determine whether individuals stay healthy or become ill is their income. In addition, the overall health of North American society may be more determined by the distribution of income among its members rather than the overall wealth of the society…. Many studies find that socioeconomic circumstances, rather than medical and lifestyle risk factors, are the main causes of cardiovascular disease, and that conditions during early life are especially important.” 12

经济关系影响健康，最显而易见的是，收入较高的人更有能力负担更健康的饮食、生活和工作条件以及减压方式。多伦多约克大学健康政策与管理学院副教授丹尼斯·拉斐尔（Dennis Raphael）近期发表了一项关于社会因素对加拿大及其他地区心脏病影响的研究。他的结论是：“决定个人健康与否的最重要生活条件之一是收入。此外，北美社会的整体健康状况可能更多地取决于其成员之间的收入分配，而非社会的整体财富……许多研究发现，社会经济环境而非医疗和生活方式风险因素才是心血管疾病的主要原因，而早期生活环境尤为重要。”

The element of control is the less obvious but equally important aspect of social and job status as a health factor. Since stress escalates as the sense of control diminishes, people who exercise greater control over their work and lives enjoy better health. This principle was demonstrated in the British Whitehall study showing that second-tier civil servants were at greater risk for heart disease than their superiors, despite nearly comparable incomes. 13

控制感是社会和职业地位作为健康因素中一个不太明显但同样重要的方面。由于压力会随着控制感的降低而加剧，因此对工作和生活拥有更大控制权的人往往更健康。英国白厅的一项研究证实了这一原则，该研究表明，尽管收入几乎相当，但二线公务员患心脏病的风险却高于他们的上级。

Recognizing the multigenerational template for behaviour and for illness, and recognizing, too, the social influences that shape families and human lives, we dispense with the unhelpful and unscientific attitude of blame. Discarding blame leaves us free to move toward the necessary adoption of responsibility, a matter to be taken up when we come in the final chapters to consider healing.

认识到行为和疾病的多代遗传模式，以及塑造家庭和人生的社会影响，我们就摒弃了无益且不科学的指责态度。摒弃指责，我们才能自由地承担起必要的责任，而这需要在最后探讨疗愈时再行讨论。

17
17
The Biology of Belief
信念的生物学

T HE SCIENTIFIC INSIGHTS OF Bruce Lipton, a molecular biologist formerly at Stanford University in California, have profound implications for the understanding of illness, health and healing. In his public talks, as in personal interviews, he likes to throw his audience a scientific curve ball in the form of a question: “What is the brain of the individual cell?” The typical answer he receives, as he did from this interviewer, is: “The nucleus, of course.”

曾任加州斯坦福大学分子生物学家的布鲁斯·利普顿的科学见解，对我们理解疾病、健康和康复具有深远意义。无论是在公开演讲还是私人访谈中，他都喜欢抛出一个科学难题，比如：“单个细胞的大脑是什么？”他得到的典型答案，就像这次采访一样，是：“当然是细胞核。”

Of course, the nucleus is not the brain of the cell. The brain is our organ of decision making, and it is the brain that acts as our interface with the environment. In the life of the individual cell, not the nucleus but the cell membrane fulfills the functions analogous to the activities of the brain.

当然，细胞核并非细胞的大脑。大脑是我们做出决策的器官，也是我们与环境交互的界面。在单个细胞的生命活动中，并非细胞核，而是细胞膜发挥着类似于大脑的功能。

In human embryological development, both the nervous system and the skin stem from the same tissue, the ectoderm . Individual cells use their membrane as both skin and nervous system. Like the skin, the membrane surrounds and protects the internal milieu of the cell. At the same time, it has on its surface the millions of molecular receptors that act as the cell’s sensory organs: they “see” and “hear” and “feel” and—like the brain—interpret the messages arriving from the cell’s external milieu. It also facilitates the exchange of substances and messages with the environment. The cell’s “decision making” also takes place in the membrane and not in the nucleus, where the cell’s genetic material is located.

在人类胚胎发育过程中，神经系统和皮肤都起源于同一组织——外胚层。单个细胞利用其细胞膜同时作为皮肤和神经系统。如同皮肤一样，细胞膜包裹并保护着细胞的内部环境。同时，细胞膜表面分布着数百万个分子受体，它们如同细胞的感觉器官：能够“看”、“听”和“感觉”，并像大脑一样，解读来自细胞外部环境的信息。细胞膜还促进细胞与环境之间的物质和信息交换。此外，细胞的“决策”也发生在细胞膜上，而不是细胞核内——细胞核内储存着细胞的遗传物质。

As soon as we understand this fundamental biological reality, we are able to see past the popular assumption that genes are all-decisive in human behaviour and health. People may be forgiven for that misbelief. Expressions of near-religious awe from some scientists and politicians and prophecies of dramatic medical advances greeted announcements in 2000 that researchers were close to deciphering the human genome, the genetic blueprint for the human body. “Today we are learning the language in which God created life,” then president Bill Clinton said at the White House ceremony marking the truce between two groups of scientists racing to complete the genome. “I truly feel this is going to revolutionize medicine because we are going to understand not only what causes disease but what prevents disease,” enthused Dr. Stephen Warren, a U.S. medical geneticist and editor of The American Journal of Human Genetics .

一旦我们理解了这一基本的生物学事实，就能摒弃那种认为基因决定人类行为和健康的普遍误解。人们的这种误解或许情有可原。2000年，当研究人员宣布即将破译人类基因组（人体遗传蓝图）时，一些科学家和政治家表现出近乎宗教般的敬畏，并预言医学将取得重大突破。“今天，我们正在学习上帝创造生命的语言，”时任总统比尔·克林顿在白宫举行的仪式上说道，该仪式标志着两组科学家在基因组破译竞赛中达成停战协议。“我真心认为这将彻底改变医学，因为我们不仅会了解疾病的病因，还会了解疾病的预防方法，”美国医学遗传学家、《美国人类遗传学杂志》主编斯蒂芬·沃伦博士兴奋地说道。

The actual results of the genome project are bound to be disappointing. Although the scientific information uncovered is important for its own sake, very little can be expected from the genome program that will lead to broad health benefits in the near future, if ever.

基因组计划的实际结果注定令人失望。尽管所揭示的科学信息本身具有重要意义，但人们几乎无法指望基因组计划在近期内，甚至可能永远无法带来广泛的健康益处。

First, there are many technical problems still to be solved. Our current state of knowledge about the genetic makeup of human beings may be likened to using a copy of The Concise Oxford English Dictionary as “the model” from which the plays of William Shakespeare or the novels of Charles Dickens were created. “All” that remains to duplicate their work now is to find the prepositions, grammatical rules and phonetic indications, then to figure out how the two authors arrived at their storylines, dialogues and sublime literary devices. “The genome is the biological programming,” one of the more thoughtful science reporters wrote, “but evolution has neglected to provide even the punctuation to show where genes stop and start, let alone any helpful notes as to what each gene is meant to do.”

首先，还有许多技术难题亟待解决。我们目前对人类基因构成的了解，就好比用《简明牛津英语词典》作为“模板”来创作莎士比亚的戏剧或狄更斯的小说。“现在”要复制他们的作品，剩下的工作就是找到介词、语法规则和语音提示，然后弄清楚这两位作者是如何构思出他们的故事情节、对话和精妙的文学手法的。“基因组是生物程序，”一位颇具洞察力的科学记者写道，“但进化甚至连标点符号都没有提供，更遑论标点每个基因的功能了。”

Second, contrary to the genetic fundamentalism that currently informs medical thinking and public awareness, genes alone cannot possibly account for the complex psychological characteristics, the behaviours, health or illness of human beings. Genes are merely codes. They act as a set of rules and as a biological template for the synthesis of the proteins that give each particular cell its characteristic structure and functions. They are, as it were, alive and dynamic architectural and mechanical plans. Whether the plan becomes realized depends on far more than the gene itself. Genes exist and function in the context of living organisms. The activities of cells are defined not simply by the genes in their nuclei but by the requirements of the entire organism—and by the interaction of that organism with the environment in which it must survive. Genes are turned on or off by the environment . For this reason, the greatest influences on human development, health and behaviour are those of the nurturing environment.

其次，与目前主导医学思维和公众意识的基因原教旨主义相反，基因本身根本无法解释人类复杂的心理特征、行为、健康或疾病。基因仅仅是编码。它们作为一套规则，以及合成蛋白质的生物模板，赋予每个特定细胞独特的结构和功能。它们就像是鲜活的、动态的建筑和机械蓝图。蓝图能否实现，远不止取决于基因本身。基因存在于生物体中并发挥作用。细胞的活动并非仅仅由细胞核中的基因决定，而是由整个生物体的需求以及生物体与其生存环境的相互作用所决定。基因的开启或关闭都取决于环境。因此，对人类发展、健康和行为影响最大的因素是养育环境。

Hardly anyone who raises plants or animals would ever dispute the primary role of early care in shaping how genetic endowment and potential will unfold. For reasons that have little to do with science, many people have difficulty grasping the same concept when it comes to the development of human beings. This paralysis of thought is all the more ironic, since of all animal species it is the human whose long-term functioning is most profoundly regulated by the early environment.

几乎所有种植或饲养植物的人都不会否认早期养育在塑造遗传禀赋和潜能发展方面起着至关重要的作用。然而，由于一些与科学关系不大的原因，许多人在谈到人类发展时却难以理解同样的道理。这种思维上的障碍尤其具有讽刺意味，因为在所有动物物种中，人类的长期发展恰恰最深刻地受到早期环境的影响。

Given the paucity of evidence for any decisive role of genetic factors in most questions of illness and health, why all the hoopla about the genome project? Why the pervasive genetic fundamentalism?

鉴于缺乏证据表明遗传因素在大多数疾病和健康问题中起决定性作用，为什么基因组计划会引起如此大的轰动？为什么会出现如此普遍的遗传原教旨主义？

We are social beings, and science, like all disciplines, has its ideological and political dimensions. As Hans Selye pointed out, the unacknowledged assumptions of the scientist will often limit and define what will be discovered. Settling for the view that illnesses, mental or physical, are primarily genetic allows us to avoid disturbing questions about the nature of the society in which we live. If “science” enables us to ignore poverty or man-made toxins or a frenetic and stressful social culture as contributors to disease, we can look only to simple answers: pharmacological and biological. Such an approach helps to justify and preserve prevailing social values and structures. It may also be profitable. The value of shares in Celera, the private company participating in the genome project, went up 1,400 per cent between 1999 and 2000.

我们是社会性动物，而科学，如同所有学科一样，也具有意识形态和政治维度。正如汉斯·塞利所指出的，科学家未加承认的假设往往会限制甚至定义他们的发现。如果仅仅满足于认为疾病（无论是精神上的还是生理上的）主要由基因造成，我们就能回避那些令人不安的问题，例如我们所处社会的本质。如果“科学”使我们能够忽视贫困、人为毒素或紧张而焦虑的社会文化等因素对疾病的影响，那么我们就只能寻求简单的答案：药理学和生物学。这种方法有助于维护和巩固现有的社会价值观和结构，而且可能有利可图。参与基因组计划的私营公司塞莱拉（Celera）的股价在1999年至2000年间上涨了1400%。

The genome hype is not only poor science, it is also suspect as theology. In the Book of Genesis creation story, God fashions the universe first, then nature, and only afterwards does He shape humankind from the substance of the earth. He knew, even if Bill Clinton did not, that from their very earliest beginnings humans could never be understood apart from their environment.

基因组炒作不仅缺乏科学依据，其神学观点也令人怀疑。在《创世记》的创世故事中，上帝先创造了宇宙，然后是自然，最后才用大地的物质塑造了人类。祂知道（即便比尔·克林顿可能不这么认为），从人类诞生之初，就无法脱离环境而理解人类。

The milieu of the human organism is the physical and psychoemotional environment that shapes our development and affects our interactions with the world throughout the lifetime. The milieu of the individual cell is the cell’s immediate surroundings, from which it receives messenger substances that originate in nearby cells, in nerve endings controlled from afar and in distant organs that secrete chemicals into the circulatory system. The information substances attach to receptors on the cell surface. Then, in the cell membrane—depending on how receptive the cell is at that moment —effector substances are produced that go to the nucleus, instructing the genes to synthesize particular proteins to carry out specific functions. These receptor-effector protein complexes—called perception proteins —Bruce Lipton explains, act as the “switches” that integrate the function of the cell with its environment:

人体环境是指塑造我们发育并影响我们一生与世界互动的生理和心理情感环境。单个细胞的环境是指细胞的直接周围环境，细胞从中接收来自邻近细胞、远程控制的神经末梢以及分泌化学物质进入循环系统的远端器官的信使物质。这些信使物质与细胞表面的受体结合。然后，在细胞膜上——取决于细胞当时的感受性——会产生效应物质，这些效应物质进入细胞核，指示基因合成特定的蛋白质以执行特定的功能。布鲁斯·利普顿解释说，这些受体-效应蛋白复合物——被称为感知蛋白——就像“开关”一样，将细胞的功能与其环境整合起来：

Although perception proteins are manufactured through molecular genetic mechanisms, activation of the perception process is “controlled” or initiated by environmental signals…. The controlling influence of the environment is underscored in recent studies on stem cells. * Stem cells do not control their own fate. The differentiation of stem cells is based upon the environment the cell finds itself in. For example, three different tissue culture environments can be created. If a stem cell is placed in culture number one, it may become a bone cell. If the same stem cell was put into culture two, it will become a nerve cell, or if placed into culture dish number three, the cell matures as a liver cell. The cell’s fate is “controlled” by its interaction with the environment and not by a self-contained genetic program. 1

尽管感知蛋白是通过分子遗传机制产生的，但感知过程的激活却受到环境信号的“控制”或启动……近期对干细胞的研究强调了环境的控制作用。干细胞无法控制自身的命运。干细胞的分化取决于其所处的环境。例如，可以构建三种不同的组织培养环境。如果将干细胞置于培养皿一中，它可能会分化成骨细胞；如果将同一干细胞置于培养皿二中，它会分化成神经细胞；如果置于培养皿三中，它会成熟为肝细胞。细胞的命运是由其与环境的相互作用“控制”的，而不是由其自身独立的遗传程序控制的。

A key point in Dr. Lipton’s astute explanation of biological activity is that at any one time, cells—like the entire human organism—can be either in defensive mode or growth mode but not both. Our perceptions of the environment are stored in cellular memory. When early environmental influences are chronically stressful, the developing nervous system and the other organs of the PNI super-system repeatedly receive the electric, hormonal and chemical message that the world is unsafe or even hostile. Those perceptions are programmed in our cells on the molecular level . Early experiences condition the body’s stance toward the world and determine the person’s unconscious beliefs about herself in relationship to the world. Dr. Lipton calls that proces s the biology of belief . Fortunately, human experience and the ever-unfolding potential of human beings ensure that the biology of belief, though deeply physiologically ingrained, is not irreversible.

利普顿博士对生物活动的精辟解释的关键在于，细胞——如同整个人体——在任何时刻都只能处于防御模式或生长模式，而不能同时处于两者。我们对环境的感知储存在细胞记忆中。当早期环境影响长期处于压力之下时，发育中的神经系统和PNI超系统的其他器官会反复接收到来自电信号、激素信号和化学物质的信号，表明世界是不安全的，甚至是充满敌意的。这些感知在分子水平上被写入我们的细胞。早期经历塑造了身体对世界的认知，并决定了个体关于自身与世界关系的无意识信念。利普顿博士将这一过程称为“信念的生物学”。幸运的是，人类的经验和人类不断展现的潜能确保了“信念的生物学”虽然根深蒂固，但并非不可逆转。

We have seen that stress is the result of an interaction between a stressor and a processing system . That processing apparatus is the human nervous system, operating under the influence of the brain’s emotional centres. The biology of belief inculcated in that processing apparatus early in life crucially influences our stress responses throughout our lives. Do we recognize stressors? Do we magnify or minimize potential threats to our well-being? Do we perceive ourselves as alone? As helpless? As never needing help? As never deserving help? As being loved? As having to work to deserve love? As hopelessly unlovable? These are unconscious beliefs, embedded at the cellular level. They “control” our behaviours no matter what we may think on the conscious level. They keep us in shut-down defensive modes or allow us to open to growth and to health. We look now at some of these viscerally held perceptions more closely.

我们已经看到，压力是压力源与处理系统相互作用的结果。这个处理系统就是人类的神经系统，它受大脑情绪中枢的影响。生命早期灌输到这个处理系统中的信念，对我们一生的压力反应有着至关重要的影响。我们是否能识别压力源？我们会放大还是缩小对自身福祉的潜在威胁？我们是否觉得自己孤独无助？永远不需要帮助？永远不值得帮助？被爱？需要努力才能赢得爱？还是无可救药地不值得被爱？这些都是潜意识的信念，根植于细胞层面。无论我们在意识层面如何思考，它们都在“控制”着我们的行为。它们使我们处于封闭的防御状态，或者让我们敞开心扉，走向成长和健康。现在，我们将更仔细地审视其中一些根深蒂固的认知。

1. I have to be strong

1. 我必须坚强

As an artist and avid reader, Iris is highly intellectual. About ten years ago, at the age of forty-two, she was diagnosed with SLE (lupus). Iris grew up in Europe, immigrating with her family to the United States in her early twenties. Her father was tyrannical and unpredictable, and her mother, she reports, “did not exist separately from my father.”

作为一名艺术家和博览群书的读者，艾瑞斯才思敏捷。大约十年前，42岁的她被诊断出患有系统性红斑狼疮（SLE）。艾瑞斯在欧洲长大，二十出头时随家人移民到美国。她的父亲专横跋扈、喜怒无常，而她的母亲，据她描述，“与父亲形影不离”。

“I’ve thought about this theory of the body saying no when your mind can’t,” Iris says. “I’ve heard it before, and I have agreed with the principle before. I just don’t like thinking of it in terms of me.”

“我思考过这种说法，即当大脑无法做出反应时，身体会做出反应，”艾瑞斯说。“我以前听过这种说法，也认同其中的原理。我只是不喜欢把它应用到我自己身上。”

“Why not?” I ask her.

“为什么不行呢？”我问她。

“It means you aren’t strong enough … you’re not capable of doing whatever it was to be strong enough.” These words brought to mind an ovarian cancer patient who disliked my theory because, she said, it made her look like a “wimp.”

“这意味着你不够坚强……你没有能力去做任何能让你变得足够坚强的事情。” 这句话让我想起一位卵巢癌患者，她不喜欢我的理论，因为她说，这让她看起来像个“懦夫”。

“What if one truly isn’t ‘strong enough’?” I say. “If I tried to lift a ten-thousand-pound weight and somebody said, ‘You’re not strong enough for that,’ I’d agree.”

“如果一个人真的‘力气不够’呢？”我问。“如果我尝试举起一万磅重的物体，有人说，‘你力气不够’，我会同意。”

“Under those circumstances, I’d say, ‘What are you, an idiot?’”

“在这种情况下，我会说，‘你是白痴吗？’”

“That’s the whole point. Sometimes the problem is not that we lack strength but that the demands we make on ourselves are impossible. So what’s wrong with not being strong enough?”

“关键就在这里。有时候问题不在于我们缺乏力量，而在于我们对自己提出的要求是不切实际的。那么，不够强大又有什么错呢？”

The core belief in having to be strong enough, characteristic of many people who develop chronic illness, is a defence. The child who perceives that her parents cannot support her emotionally had better develop an attitude of “I can handle everything myself.” Otherwise, she may feel rejected. One way not to feel rejected is never to ask for help, never to admit “weakness”—to believe that I am strong enough to withstand all my vicissitudes alone.

许多慢性病患者都有一种根深蒂固的信念，那就是必须足够坚强，这是一种自我保护机制。如果孩子觉得父母无法在情感上支持自己，她最好培养一种“我可以自己处理一切”的态度。否则，她可能会感到被抛弃。避免这种感觉的方法之一就是永远不寻求帮助，永远不承认自己的“软弱”——坚信自己足够强大，可以独自承受所有的苦难。

Iris quickly conceded that when her friends call her with their problems, she does not judge them or accuse them of being weak. They are comfortable relying on her and see her as empathic and supportive. It was clear that her double standard—higher expectations of herself than of others—had nothing to do with strength . It had to do with a lack of power , as experienced by the child. A child can be stronger than he should have to be, because he doesn’t have power.

艾瑞斯很快承认，当朋友们打电话向她倾诉烦恼时，她不会评判他们，也不会指责他们软弱。朋友们可以放心地依靠她，并认为她富有同情心，乐于助人。很明显，她的双重标准——对自己要求高于对别人的要求——与坚强无关，而是源于孩子所经历的无力感。孩子可能会表现得比他应该有的坚强，因为他缺乏力量。

2. It’s not right for me to be angry

2. 我不应该生气

Shizuko is forty-nine, the mother of two grown children. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis at twenty-one, shortly after arriving in Canada as a foreign student. Her birth mother died when she was four, after which her father married her aunt, her mother’s sister. “My stepmother liked business more than she liked children,” she says. Her father indulged all her material needs and desires but he was most often away from home.

静子今年四十九岁，是两个成年孩子的母亲。她二十一岁时被诊断出患有类风湿性关节炎，当时她刚以留学生的身份来到加拿大不久。她的生母在她四岁时去世，之后她的父亲娶了她的姨妈，也就是她母亲的妹妹。“我的继母更喜欢生意而不是孩子，”她说。她的父亲满足了她所有的物质需求和愿望，但他经常不在家。

Shizuko divorced her emotionally distant husband five years ago. “My marriage was terrible. When I was living with my husband, I was tired all the time, raising the kids. [Fatigue is a common symptom in the rheumatic diseases.] Before 3:00 p.m. I would lie on the couch, and my husband always complained, ‘You did nothing, nothing.’ He said I was using him to be a free meal ticket.”

静子五年前与情感疏离的丈夫离婚了。“我的婚姻糟透了。和丈夫一起生活时，我总是很累，要照顾孩子。[疲劳是风湿病的常见症状。]下午三点前，我就会躺在沙发上，丈夫总是抱怨：‘你什么都不做，什么都不做。’他说我把他当成白吃白喝的工具。”

“Did you ever feel angry?”

你有没有感到过愤怒？

“Yes, I was angry at him all the time.”

“是的，我一直都很生他的气。”

“Did you express the anger?”

你表达过愤怒吗？

“No … The way my stepmother raised me, I think I am not supposed to be angry.”

“不……继母那样教育我，我觉得我不应该生气。”

3. If I’m angry, I will not be lovable.

3. 如果我生气了，我就不讨人喜欢了。

Alan, with cancer of the esophagus, has been unhappy in his marriage. The reader may recall his perception that his wife was unable to be “romantic, intimate and all the things that I need.”

患有食道癌的艾伦婚姻并不幸福。读者或许还记得，他认为妻子无法做到“浪漫、亲密，以及满足我的一切需求”。

“How would you express your dissatisfaction? Do you ever get angry about it? Do you ever feel angry about it?”

“你会如何表达你的不满？你会为此生气吗？你会为此感到愤怒吗？”

“It’s hard to relate because now I get angry all the time. We talk about it a lot more now.”

“很难感同身受，因为我现在总是很容易生气。我们现在也经常谈论这件事。”

“What happened to the anger before you were diagnosed with cancer?”

“在你被诊断出癌症之前，你的愤怒都到哪里去了？”

“I don’t know. I see what you’re getting at, and it’s probably true.”

“我不知道。我明白你的意思，而且很可能是真的。”

“Where did you learn to repress anger?”

“你是从哪里学会压抑愤怒的？”

“That’s a good one—I don’t think I’ve analyzed this quite enough. I think it comes from a desire to be liked. If you’re angry, people don’t like you.”

“这个问题问得好——我觉得我还没有对此进行充分的分析。我认为这源于渴望被人喜欢。如果你生气，人们就不会喜欢你。”

4. I’m responsible for the whole world

4. 我对整个世界负有责任

Leslie, a fifty-five-year-old social worker, also attributes his illness—in his case, ulcerative colitis—to the stresses of a relationship. “It began during my first marriage. There was a lot of stress, and that’s when it was the worst. It hasn’t been bad in a long time. Now I sometimes have some bleeding, but it is very limited.

55岁的社工莱斯利也将自己的疾病——溃疡性结肠炎——归咎于恋爱关系带来的压力。“我的病是从第一次婚姻期间开始的。当时压力很大，病情也最严重。现在很久以来病情都不算严重了。偶尔会出血，但量很少。”

“My relationship with my first wife was always up and down. I think she didn’t want to be involved. It was never a partnership. I had to think for her. It got real crazy making, because I would have to think about what we could do together. She would never tell me what she wanted to do. I would have to come up with a movie that I thought we both would like, one we both could go, and be happy with.”

“我和前妻的关系总是时好时坏。我觉得她并不想参与其中。我们之间从来没有真正的伙伴关系。我得替她做决定。这真的让人很抓狂，因为我得想办法让我们一起做什么。她从来不告诉我她想做什么。我得想出一部我们俩都会喜欢的电影，一部我们俩都能去看，并且都满意的电影。”

“Didn’t it upset you to play that role?”

“扮演那个角色难道不让你感到难过吗？”

“For sure.”

“一定。”

“What did you do with that anger?”

你如何处理了那份愤怒？

“Swallowed it—no question. I couldn’t fight because then she would say, ‘ You see, this is a bad marriage.’ Conflict with her was considered an indicator that the relationship was bad.

“我默默忍受了——毫无疑问。我无法反抗，因为那样她就会说，‘你看，这是一段糟糕的婚姻。’和她发生冲突就被认为是婚姻关系破裂的标志。”

“I had to be very, very careful. When I started going out with Eva, who is now my wife, and we would have a fight, I would start smiling. I told her I was enjoying that we could actually fight and be different, and she was not going to go away. I definitely had fears of people leaving, of abandonment.”

“我必须非常非常小心。当我开始和伊娃（现在是我的妻子）交往时，我们吵架，我会笑着告诉她，我很享受我们能够争吵，能够展现真实的自己，而且她不会离开我。我当然害怕被抛弃，害怕被抛弃。”

It took Leslie several months after the initial onset of his symptoms to seek medical help. “I wasn’t ready to accept my vulnerability in having problems. It had a lot to do with my perfectionism, wanting to be perfectly all right, to have nothing wrong with me.”

莱斯利在出现症状几个月后才寻求医疗帮助。“我还没准备好接受自己身体有问题的事实。这很大程度上与我的完美主义有关，我希望自己一切都好，没有任何毛病。”

When Leslie was nine years old, his father died suddenly of a heart attack, and two years later he witnessed the sudden death of his brother from a brain aneurysm. “After that, I had an obsessive ritual every night, a routine to make sure people would not die. ‘Don’t die, don’t die … ’ It was my way of controlling people not dying in my life.

莱斯利九岁时，他的父亲因心脏病突发去世；两年后，他又亲眼目睹哥哥因脑动脉瘤破裂猝然离世。“从那以后，我每晚都会进行一种强迫性的仪式，一种确保身边的人不会死去的习惯。‘别死，别死……’这是我控制身边人不死的方式。”

“One day, I was talking with my psychiatrist. I said, ‘I gave up that ritual and I don’t know where it went.’ It was like an ‘aha’ experience—all of a sudden it came to me: ‘I know where it went. I became a social worker, and now I’m trying to save the world!’

“有一天，我和我的精神科医生聊天。我说：‘我放弃了那个仪式，但我不知道它去了哪里。’那一刻就像醍醐灌顶——我突然明白了：‘我知道它去了哪里。我成了一名社会工作者，现在我正在努力拯救世界！’”

“It caused me a lot of stress when I was trying to save the world and wasn’t succeeding. I was on stress leave two or three years ago. I finally recognized that I can’t save the world. I even have a mantra that the psychiatrist and I came up with: ‘I should be a guide, not a God.’ It works for me.”

“当我试图拯救世界却失败时，我压力很大。两三年前，我甚至因为压力过大而休了假。我最终意识到我拯救不了世界。我和我的精神科医生还一起想出了一句座右铭：‘我应该做个向导，而不是上帝。’这对我来说很有效。”

“So you thought this entire unholy mess of a world out there was your fault?”

“所以你认为外面这个混乱不堪的世界都是你的错？”

“At one point I believed that whether or not it was my fault, I was going to be the one to fix it.”

“我一度认为，不管是不是我的错，我都要亲自去解决问题。”

“How did that manifest itself in your work?”

“这在你的作品中是如何体现的？”

“Well, if my parents, I mean clients, were not doing well, I felt I didn’t have enough knowledge. I needed to know more and have better skills. I needed to find the right solution, work harder, read more, go to workshops.”

“嗯，如果我的客户（我是说我的父母）情况不好，我就觉得自己的知识不够。我需要了解更多，掌握更好的技能。我需要找到正确的解决方案，更加努力工作，阅读更多书籍，参加研讨会。”

One did not have to search far for the meaning of Leslie’s Freudian substitution of parents for clients . Not only did he become his mother’s chief companion and solace after the deaths of his father and older brother, but it also turns out that he had been in that role from birth.

莱斯利用父母代替客户这种弗洛伊德式的心理治疗方式，其意义并不难理解。在他父亲和哥哥去世后，他不仅成了母亲最主要的陪伴者和慰藉，而且事实证明，他从出生起就扮演着这样的角色。

“My mom did want me to be happy. She was always concerned that I should be happy. That was something that I was always trying to do. I tried to be happy in my childhood. I didn’t know what depression was; I didn’t even know what sad feelings were.

“我妈妈确实希望我快乐。她总是很关心我是否快乐。这也是我一直努力做到的。我小时候就努力让自己快乐。我不知道什么是抑郁症；我甚至不知道什么是悲伤。”

“My mom used say I was such a good-natured child, which my brother wasn’t. I was such a good-natured baby that she could wake me up in the middle of the night, play with me for a while and put me back, and I’d go back to sleep.”

“我妈妈以前常说我是个性格很乖的孩子，而我哥哥则不是。我小时候性格特别好，她半夜把我叫醒，陪我玩一会儿，再把我放回床上，我就能继续睡。”

“Why on earth would she do that?”

“她到底为什么要这么做？”

“I guess she was lonely or needing some attention.”

“我猜她可能是感到孤独，或者需要一些关注。”

“So you had to work … from infancy.”

所以你必须从婴儿时期就开始工作。

“My mom’s marriage with my father was terrible. They’d fight—it was bad before he died. It was my job to make her happy.”

“我妈妈和我爸爸的婚姻很糟糕。他们经常吵架——在他去世前情况就很糟。我的责任就是让她开心。”

5. I can handle anything

5. 我能应付任何事

Don, a fifty-five-year-old civil servant, had part of his colon removed for bowel cancer. Among his chronic stresses has been his compulsion to be hyperconscientious in his professional life. “Workload issues can make me angry,” he says. “I don’t know if anger is the right word, just frustrated . Not being able to handle just how much work I had on my desk at the time.”

唐是一位55岁的公务员，因肠癌切除了部分结肠。他长期承受的压力之一是工作中过度认真负责的倾向。“工作量问题会让我生气，”他说，“我不知道用‘生气’这个词是否恰当，只是感到沮丧。当时我手头的工作实在太多，根本无法应付。”

“What did you do about it?”

你对此采取了什么措施？

“I tensed up and calmed down by going for a walk, then came back and plunged back into the work and got it done.”

“我紧张起来，出去散步放松了一下，然后回来继续工作，把工作完成了。”

“What about going to whoever is assigning the work and pointing out that it is too much for any one person to handle?”

“为什么不去找布置任务的人，指出这项工作对任何一个人来说都太繁重了呢？”

“Never done that. I can handle anything, that’s why. My determination was to be the one in the branch who handled the most files, in the best way.”

“我从没做过那种事。我能应付任何事，所以才这样。我的目标是成为分行里处理文件最多、处理方式最好的人。”

“Why?”

“为什么？”

“For a couple of reasons. One, competitive instincts. Two, I’m getting paid well, therefore I should do the best job. The approach I always took was, you give me the work and I’ll do it. If you give me more work, I’ll do more, and if you give me less work, I’ll do less work.”

“原因有二。第一，我的竞争本能。第二，我薪水高，所以理应做到最好。我一直以来的做法是，你给我工作，我就做。工作越多，我做得越多；工作越少，我做得越少。”

“And when they cut back on staff and fewer people have to do the same amount of work?”

“当他们裁员，让更少的人完成同样的工作量时，情况又会如何呢？”

“I’d do more. In fact, what I’d often do is go to other people who were complaining about their workload and take work from them. There would always be a level of guilt that I could have done a better job on this or that file. There was always a little more I could do.

“我会做得更多。事实上，我经常会去找那些抱怨工作量大的人，从他们那里接手工作。我总是会感到内疚，觉得我本可以把这个或那个文件做得更好。总觉得我还能做得更多。”

“I prided myself in presenting this image that I could do more than anyone else, in less time than anyone else.”

“我一直引以为豪的是，我能展现出比任何人都能做得更多、用时更短的形象。”

“Any connections in that to your childhood?”

“这和你的童年有什么联系吗？”

“Part of that was my mother. If I brought home a report card with three A’s and three B’s, it would be, ‘Why not six A’s?’ Nothing I ever did was good enough. She always automatically assumed that I would become a professional of some sort. It was a big disappointment to my mother that I began my working life as a construction labourer.”

“一部分原因是我母亲。如果我带回家一张成绩单，上面有三个A和三个B，她就会问：‘为什么不是六个A？’无论我做什么，她都觉得不够好。她总是理所当然地认为我会成为某种专业人士。我职业生涯的开始是做建筑工人，这让我母亲非常失望。”

6. I’m not wanted—I’m not lovable

6. 我不被需要——我不讨人喜欢。

Gilda Radner had a lifelong perception of not being wanted. An indication of the depth of Gilda’s psychic despair came in some notes her husband, Gene Wilder, found after her death. In one, titled “Right-Hand Questions—Left-Hand Answers,” the questions were written out in Gilda’s right hand, the answers with the left. The technique and the title are especially significant: it is the right side of our brain, the holistic and emotional side, that controls the left hand. One right-hand question asks: “Is cancer your mother inside you?” The left-hand answer: “She doesn’t want me to exist [her italics].”

吉尔达·拉德纳终其一生都觉得自己不被需要。她去世后，丈夫吉恩·怀尔德发现了一些笔记，从中可以看出吉尔达内心深处的绝望。其中一份笔记题为“右手提问，左手回答”，问题用吉尔达的右手写出，答案则用左手写出。这种写法和标题都意义非凡：我们大脑的右半球，也就是负责整体和情感的那部分，控制着左手。其中一个右手提问是：“癌症是你母亲的后裔吗？”左手的回答是：“她不想让我存在[她用斜体字写]。”

7. I don’t exist unless I do something.
I must justify my existence

7. 我不做事就不存在。我必须证明我的存在是有意义的。

Joyce, the university professor with asthma, talked about her terrifying sense of emptiness when she was not busy doing something. I asked her what she meant by that.

患有哮喘的大学教授乔伊斯谈到，当她无所事事时，会感到一种可怕的空虚感。我问她这是什么意思。

“The emptiness is about this terror that if I don’t fulfill things, demands, I won’t really exist. As a child I was not part of the whole equation. All the tensions that were happening with my father and mother, and my father and brother, I was not part of. I was eight years younger, the daughter; I was the perfect little girl. All these things were going on. The feeling was that you don’t exist unless you do something in the world.”

“这种空虚感源于一种恐惧：如果我不去满足某些要求，我就无法真正存在。小时候，我并不属于这个整体。父母之间、父亲和哥哥之间所有的矛盾，我都置身事外。我比他们小八岁，是女儿；我是个完美的小女孩。所有这些事情都在发生。那种感觉就像，除非你在世上有所作为，否则你就不存在。”

8. I have to be very ill to deserve being taken care of

8. 我得病得很重才配得上被照顾。

Angela was diagnosed two years ago with cancer of the uterus, at age forty-five. Prior to that, she had struggled with alcoholism, anorexia-bulimia, depression, and fibromyalgia. At one point she underwent intestinal bypass surgery for weight loss. She lost 150 pounds within a year but soon gained it back, since neither her stress levels nor her eating habits had changed. I interviewed Angela at Hope House, a counselling and support centre in Vancouver for people with malignancy and other types of chronic disease.

安吉拉两年前被诊断出患有子宫癌，当时她45岁。在此之前，她曾饱受酗酒、厌食症/暴食症、抑郁症和纤维肌痛的折磨。她一度为了减肥接受了肠道旁路手术，一年内减掉了150磅（约68公斤），但很快又反弹了，因为她的压力水平和饮食习惯都没有改变。我在温哥华的希望之家采访了安吉拉，希望之家是一家为恶性肿瘤和其他慢性病患者提供咨询和支持的中心。

“I feel like the cancer was a gift to me, because it got me out of Revenue Canada. I was an auditor for the past twelve years and I hated the job. Ever since childhood I’ve been unable not to take it personally when there is confrontation and conflict. People get upset when they are audited, and they project all their hate of government and taxes onto you. And I took it on.”

“我觉得癌症对我来说反而是一份礼物，因为它让我离开了加拿大税务局。过去十二年我一直做审计员，我讨厌这份工作。从小到大，遇到冲突和矛盾，我总是忍不住往心里去。人们被审计时会很生气，他们会把对政府和税收的所有不满都投射到你身上。而我却把这些都承受了。”

“Why did it take cancer to get you out of a job that you hated and was bad for you?”

“为什么非得患上癌症才能让你摆脱一份你讨厌且对你有害的工作呢？”

“I was depressed most of the time, and I felt like I had no choice. I’ve been working since I was seventeen. I knew that in other types of jobs, it would not be accepted to be sick so much. I was sick a lot. In the government, you’re like a cog in the wheel. There are a hundred other people who do the same kind of thing that you do, so that if your work doesn’t get done, they can shunt it off on someone else. That’s the reason that I stayed there, out of fear.”

“我大部分时间都很沮丧，感觉自己别无选择。我从十七岁就开始工作了。我知道在其他类型的工作中，经常生病是不被允许的。我的确经常生病。在政府部门，你就像机器上的一个齿轮。还有上百人做着和你一样的工作，所以如果你的工作没完成，他们可以把活儿推给别人。这就是我出于恐惧而留在那里的原因。”

“How did the cancer get you out of there?”

“癌症是怎么把你从那种境地中解救出来的？”

“After the cancer diagnosis, I began coming to Hope House and talking with the counsellors here. I was encouraged to take a look at my feelings and my life. I found out I’ve been trying to fit into something that I’m not really truly meant to be in.”

“确诊癌症后，我开始来希望之家，和这里的咨询师交谈。他们鼓励我审视自己的感受和生活。我发现我一直试图融入一个我并不真正适合的地方。”

“Did they tell you the title of my book?”

“他们有没有告诉你我的书名？”

“Well, my body said no. I had major bleeding actually for two years, and they kept testing. They did two biopsies—on the second one they found cancer cells.

“嗯，我的身体不这么认为。实际上，我出血不止两年，他们也一直在做检查。他们做了两次活检——第二次活检发现了癌细胞。”

“When the doctor said the word cancer to me, my intuition, in a split millisecond, said Revenue Canada. It was pretty obvious to me. I’ve been having that message for the past twelve years, and I’ve been ignoring it.”

“当医生跟我说起癌症这个词时，我的直觉瞬间就告诉我：加拿大税务局。这对我来说显而易见。过去十二年来，我一直有这种感觉，但我一直置之不理。”

“That’s what I’m asking. Why did it take the cancer for you to do that?”

“我问的也是这个。为什么非得得癌症你才这么做？”

“Because it was something real . I’ve got this whole thing in my head that mood disorders are not enough. Bulimia is not enough. Everybody looks at disorders of the mind as, well, there’s nothing wrong with you. There’s a lot of judgment around.”

“因为这是真实存在的。我一直觉得，仅仅是情绪障碍还不够，仅仅是暴食症也不够。每个人都觉得精神疾病没什么大不了的，你又没病。周围充满了评判。”

“But there’s a brain in there; it’s a physical organ. Mood disorder is just as physiological as uterine cancer is.”

“但子宫里有大脑，它是一个生理器官。情绪障碍和子宫癌一样，都是生理疾病。”

“I agree with you. But that was my own judgment of it, because I believed what I had been conditioned to believe by my family and by society.

“我同意你的看法。但这只是我个人的判断，因为我相信我的家庭和社会从小灌输给我的观念。”

“Just the fact that I was depressed and that the job was making me sick was not enough, in my mind. I was so concerned about what other people would think—most important, my family.”

“在我看来，仅仅是我感到抑郁，工作让我生病，这还不够。我太在意别人的看法了——最重要的是，我的家人。”

The support system Angela has found since being diagnosed with cancer has enabled her to face her issues. “I have felt a safety I have never felt before,” she says, “especially when I was going through all that stuff about detaching from Revenue Canada. And I’ve had a lot of encouragement to do things, loving things for myself, to do the things I have a passion for.”

自从被诊断出癌症以来，安吉拉找到的支持系统让她能够面对自己的问题。“我感受到了一种前所未有的安全感，”她说，“尤其是在我经历从加拿大税务局离职的那些事情时。而且，我得到了很多鼓励，去做一些让自己快乐的事情，去做我真正热爱的事情。”

Although with human beings anything is possible, it would be hard to accept that Gilda’s mother, Henrietta, truly did not want her daughter to exist, or that Leslie’s mother ever consciously wished to make her son responsible for her happiness, or that Alan’s parents wished to convey to him that he is only lovable when he is not angry. Most parents feel unconditional love for their children, and that is what they hope to get across to them. That is important to know, but it is not what matters. What matters are the child’s unconscious perceptions, based on his innermost interpretations of his interactions with the world. Those interpretations, embedded at the cellular level, constitute the biology of belief that governs so much of what we feel, what we do and how we react to events.

虽然对人类而言一切皆有可能，但我们很难接受吉尔达的母亲亨丽埃塔真的不希望女儿存在，或者莱斯利的母亲曾有意让儿子为她的幸福负责，又或者艾伦的父母想让他明白，只有不生气的时候才值得被爱。大多数父母都对自己的孩子怀有无条件的爱，而这正是他们希望传递给孩子的。了解这一点固然重要，但这并非关键所在。关键在于孩子基于自身与世界互动的内在解读而形成的无意识感知。这些解读根植于细胞层面，构成了我们信念的生物学基础，支配着我们的大部分感受、行为以及对事件的反应。

A major contributor to the genesis of many diseases—all the examples we have looked at—is an overload of stress induced by unconscious beliefs. If we would heal, it is essential to begin the painfully incremental task of reversing the biology of belief we adopted very early in life. Whatatever external treatment is administered, the healing agent lies within. The internal milieu must be changed. To find health, and to know it fully, necessitates a quest, a journey to the centre of our own biology of belief. That means rethinking and recognizing—re-cognizing: literally, to “know again”—our lives.

许多疾病——我们所探讨的所有例子——其主要成因之一，是无意识信念造成的压力过大。如果我们想要康复，就必须开始一项痛苦而循序渐进的任务：逆转我们很小的时候就形成的信念体系。无论采取何种外部治疗，治愈的源泉都蕴藏在我们内心深处。我们必须改变内在环境。要获得健康，并充分了解健康，就需要一场探索，一段通往我们自身信念体系核心的旅程。这意味着重新思考和认识——重新认识：字面意义上的“再次认识”——我们的人生。

Whichever modality of treatment people choose—conventional medicine with or without complementary healing; alternative approaches like energy medicine or various mind-body techniques; ancient Eastern practices like Ayurvedic medicine or yoga or Chinese acupuncture; the universal practice of meditation techniques; psychotherapy; nutritional healing—the key to healing is the individual’s active, free and informed choice. There are many different ways to find that innate human capacity for freedom, outlined in many teachings, books and other sources. Liberation from oppressive and stressful external circumstances is essential, but that is only possible if we first liberate ourselves from the tyranny of our ingrained biology of belief.

无论人们选择何种治疗方式——无论是传统医学（无论是否结合辅助疗法）；还是替代疗法，例如能量医学或各种身心疗法；亦或是古老的东方疗法，如阿育吠陀医学、瑜伽或中医针灸；以及普遍适用的冥想技巧、心理疗法或营养疗法——治愈的关键在于个人积极、自由且知情的选择。许多教义、书籍和其他资料都阐述了如何发掘人类与生俱来的自由能力。摆脱压迫和压力重重的外部环境至关重要，但这只有在我们首先摆脱根深蒂固的生物本能信念的束缚之后才有可能实现。

* Stem cells are multipotential embryonic cells that have not yet specialized into particular tissue types .

干细胞是具有多能性的胚胎细胞，尚未分化成特定的组织类型。

18
The Power of Negative Thinking

18 消极思考的力量

T HE V ANCOUVER ONCOLOGIST Karen Gelmon does not favour the war metaphors often applied to cancer. “The idea is that with enough might you can control, with enough might you can expel,” she says. “It suggests that it’s all a battle. I don’t think that’s a helpful way of looking at it. First, it’s not valid physiologically. Second, I don’t think it’s healthy psychologically.

温哥华肿瘤学家凯伦·格尔蒙并不赞同人们常用战争来比喻癌症。“这种说法认为，只要有足够的力量就能控制癌症，只要有足够的力量就能消灭癌症，”她说。“这暗示着一切都是一场战斗。我认为这种看待癌症的方式并无益处。首先，从生理学角度来看，这种说法并不成立。其次，我认为这对心理健康也不利。”

“What happens with our body is a matter of flow—there is input and there is output, and you can’t control every aspect of it. We need to understand that flow, know there are things you can influence and things you can’t. It’s not a battle, it’s a push-pull phenomenon of finding balance and harmony, of kneading the conflicting forces all into one dough.”

“我们身体的运作是一个流动的过程——有输入也有输出，你无法控制其中的方方面面。我们需要理解这种流动，明白有些事情你可以影响，有些事情你无法影响。这不是一场战斗，而是一个推拉的过程，目的是找到平衡与和谐，将相互冲突的力量揉捏成一个整体。”

What we might call the military theory of disease sees illness as a hostile force, something foreign that the organism must battle and defeat. Such a view leaves an important question unanswered, even in the treatment of acute infections where we are able to identify the micro-organisms invading the body and to kill them with antibiotics: why will the same bacterium or virus spare one person but fell another? An organism such as streptococcus, responsible for the so-called flesh-eating disease, lives in many people but triggers illness in only a few. Or it may be present in an individual at one time without leading to problems but mount a lethal attack at another time in the person’s life. What accounts for the difference?

我们或许可以称之为疾病的“军事理论”，它将疾病视为一种敌对力量，一种外来物，机体必须与之斗争并战胜它。这种观点遗留了一个重要问题，即使在治疗急性感染时，我们能够识别入侵人体的微生物并用抗生素将其杀死，这个问题依然存在：为什么同样的细菌或病毒对某些人无害，却对另一些人致命？例如，导致所谓“食肉菌感染”的链球菌，虽然存在于许多人体内，但只会在少数人身上引发疾病。或者，它可能在某个时期存在于个体体内而不引起任何问题，但在该人生命中的另一个时期却会发起致命攻击。造成这种差异的原因是什么？

The nineteenth century saw a heated debate on this subject, conducted for decades between two outstanding figures in the history of medicine, the pioneer microbiologist Louis Pasteur and the physiologist Claude Barnard. Pasteur insisted that the virulence of the microbe decided the course of illness, Barnard that the vulnerability of the host body was most responsible. On his deathbed Pasteur recanted. “Barnard avait raison,” he said. “Legerm n’est rien, c’est la terrain qui est tout.” [Barnard was right. The microbe is nothing, the ground (i.e., the host body) is everything.]

十九世纪，医学史上两位杰出人物——微生物学先驱路易·巴斯德和生理学家克劳德·巴纳德——就此展开了长达数十年的激烈辩论。巴斯德坚持认为微生物的毒性决定了疾病的进程，而巴纳德则认为宿主的脆弱性才是主要原因。临终前，巴斯德改变了自己的观点。“巴纳德是对的，”他说，“微生物算不了什么，关键在于宿主。”

The dying Pasteur may have swung too far in the opposite direction, but perhaps he had an eye toward the future. Since his days, and especially with the coming of the antibiotic era in the mid-twentieth century, we have all but forgotten that the terrain for illness is a particular human being at a particular time of his life history. “Why does this patient have this disease now?” George Engel, a researcher of mind-body unity in medicine asked in 1977. 1 To all intents and purposes, modern medical practice has adopted a simplistic “cause-and-effect” perspective. When no obvious external agent is found—as is the case with most serious illnesses—it throws up its hands and declares the cause unknown. “Of unknown etiology” may be the most common phrase in textbooks of internal medicine.

垂死的巴斯德或许走向了另一个极端，但他或许也预见到了未来。自他之后，尤其是在20世纪中期抗生素时代到来之后，我们几乎忘记了疾病的根源在于特定个体在其生命历程中的特定时期。“为什么这个病人现在会得这种病？”医学身心统一研究者乔治·恩格尔在1977年提出了这个问题。现代医学实践实际上采用了一种过于简单的“因果”视角。当找不到明显的外部因素时——大多数严重疾病都是如此——医学便束手无策，宣布病因不明。“病因不明”可能是内科教科书中最常见的短语。

While scientific humility is welcome, a cause-and-effect model of disease is itself a source of misperception. It cannot portray the ways that health is transmuted into illness or how illness may be turned toward health. Sufi tradition tells the famous story of the twelfth-century fool and sage, the mullah Nasruddin, on his hands and knees searching under a street light. “What are you looking for?” his neighbours ask. “My key,” he replies. The neighbours all join in the search, carefully and systematically perusing every inch of ground in the vicinity of the lamp. No one finds the key. “Wait, Nasruddin,” someone finally says, “just where did you lose this key?” “In my house.” “Then why are you looking out here?” “Because, of course, I can see better here, under the light.” It may be easier (and financially more rewarding) to research isolated causes such as microbes and genes, but as long as we ignore a broader perspective, diseases will always be of unknown etiology. A search outside where the light shines will not yield us the key to health; we have to look inside, where it is dark and murky.

科学的谦逊固然可贵，但疾病的因果模型本身就是一种误解。它无法展现健康如何转化为疾病，也无法解释疾病如何转化为健康。苏菲派传统中流传着一个著名的故事：十二世纪的愚人兼智者纳斯鲁丁（Nasruddin）跪在路灯下寻找钥匙。“你在找什么？”邻居们问。“我的钥匙。”他回答。邻居们纷纷加入寻找，仔细而有条不紊地搜遍了路灯周围的每一寸土地。然而，谁也没有找到钥匙。“等等，纳斯鲁丁，”终于有人问道，“你到底把钥匙丢在哪儿了？”“在我家。”“那你为什么还要在这里找？”“因为，当然，在灯光下我看得更清楚。”研究微生物和基因等孤立的病因或许更容易（也更有利可图），但只要我们忽略更广阔的视角，疾病的病因就永远无法确定。向外寻求光明并不能找到健康的秘诀；我们必须向内探寻，那里黑暗而浑浊。

No disease has a single cause. Even where significant risks can be identified—such as biological heredity in some autoimmune diseases or smoking in lung cancer—these vulnerabilities do not exist in isolation. Personality also does not by itself cause disease: one does not get cancer simply from repressing anger or ALS just from being too nice. A systems model recognizes that many processes and factors work together in the formation of disease or in the creation of health. We have demonstrated in this book a biopsychosocial model of medicine. According to the biopsychosocial view, individual biology reflects the history of a human organism in lifelong interaction with an environment, a perpetual interchange of energy in which psychological and social factors are as vital as physical ones. As Dr. Gelmon suggests, healing is a phenomenon of finding balance and harmony.

没有一种疾病是由单一原因造成的。即使可以识别出显著的风险因素——例如某些自身免疫性疾病的生物遗传或肺癌的吸烟——这些风险因素也并非孤立存在。人格本身也不会导致疾病：一个人不会仅仅因为压抑愤怒而患上癌症，也不会仅仅因为过于和善而患上肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）。系统模型认为，疾病的形成或健康的创造是多种过程和因素共同作用的结果。本书阐述了一种生物心理社会医学模型。根据生物心理社会观点，个体生物学反映了人类有机体终生与环境互动的历史，这是一种持续的能量交换，其中心理和社会因素与生理因素同样重要。正如盖尔蒙博士所言，治愈是一种寻求平衡与和谐的过程。

We cannot remind ourselves too often that the word healing derives from an ancient origin, meaning “whole”—hence our equation of wholesome and healthy. To heal is to become whole. But how can we be more whole than we already are? Or how is it that we could ever be less than whole?

我们必须时常提醒自己，“疗愈”一词源于古老的词根，意为“完整”——因此我们才将完整与健康划上等号。疗愈即是变得完整。但我们如何才能比现在更完整呢？或者说，我们又怎会不完整呢？

That which is complete may become deficient in two possible ways: something could be subtracted from it, or its internal harmony could be so perturbed that the parts that worked together no longer do so. As we have seen, stress is a disturbance of the body’s internal balance in response to perceived threat, including the threat of some essential need being denied. Physical hunger may be one such deprivation, but in our society the threat is most often psychic, such as the withdrawal of emotional nourishment or the disruption of psychological harmony.

完整的事物可能会以两种方式变得不完整：一是某些部分被缺失，二是其内部的和谐被破坏，导致原本协同运作的部分不再有效。正如我们所见，压力是身体对感知到的威胁（包括某些基本需求被剥夺的威胁）而导致的内部平衡紊乱。生理上的饥饿或许就是一种剥夺，但在我们的社会中，这种威胁往往是心理上的，例如情感滋养的缺失或心理和谐的破坏。

“I cannot understand why I have cancer,” one woman with ovarian cancer said. “I’ve led a healthy life, eaten well, exercised regularly. I’ve always taken good care of myself. If anyone should be a picture of health, it’s me.” The area she overlooked was invisible to her: the stress connected with emotional repression. Her conscientious (and conscious) best efforts to look after herself properly could not extend to an arena she did not know existed. That is why knowledge and insight have the power to transform, and why insight is more helpful to people than advice. If we gain the ability to look into ourselves with honesty, compassion and with unclouded vision, we can identify the ways we need to take care of ourselves. We can see the areas of the self formerly hidden in the dark.

“我无法理解我为什么会得癌症，”一位卵巢癌患者说道，“我一直过着健康的生活，饮食均衡，坚持规律运动。我一直以来都非常注重保养自己。如果说谁最能代表健康，那非我莫属。” 她忽略的那个领域对她而言是隐形的：那就是与情绪压抑相关的压力。她尽心尽力地照顾自己，却无法触及她从未意识到的领域。正因如此，知识和洞察力才拥有改变的力量，也正因如此，洞察力比建议更能帮助人们。如果我们能够以诚实、慈悲和清晰的视角审视自己，就能找到需要照顾自己的方式。我们就能看清那些曾经隐藏在黑暗中的自我角落。

The potential for wholeness, for health, resides in all of us, as does the potential for illness and disharmony. Disease is disharmony. More accurately, it is an expression of an internal disharmony. If illness is seen as foreign and external, we may end up waging war against ourselves.

我们每个人都拥有获得完整和健康的潜能，同时也拥有患病和失衡的潜能。疾病即失衡，更准确地说，它是内在失衡的一种表现。如果我们把疾病视为外在的、异己的，最终可能会与自身交战。

The first step in retracing our way to health is to abandon our attachment to what is called positive thinking. Too many times in the course of palliative care work I sat with dejected people who expressed their bewilderment at having developed cancer. “I have always been a positive thinker,” one man in his late forties told me. “I have never given in to pessimistic thoughts. Why should I get cancer?”

重获健康的第一步，就是放弃对所谓“积极思考”的执着。在临终关怀工作中，我无数次遇到沮丧的病人，他们对罹患癌症感到困惑不解。“我一直是个积极思考的人，”一位年近五十的男士告诉我，“我从不屈服于悲观的想法。我为什么会得癌症呢？”

As an antidote to terminal optimism, I have recommended the power of negative thinking. “Tongue in cheek, of course,” I quickly add. “What I really believe in is the power of thinking.” As soon as we qualify the word thinking with the adjective positive , we exclude those parts of reality that strike us as “negative.” That is how most people who espouse positive thinking seem to operate. Genuine positive thinking begins by including all our reality. It is guided by the confidence that we can trust ourselves to face the full truth, whatever that full truth may turn out to be.

为了对抗盲目乐观，我曾推荐过“消极思考”的力量。“当然，这只是玩笑，”我赶紧补充道，“我真正相信的是思考的力量。”一旦我们用“积极”这个形容词来限定“思考”这个词，我们就排除了那些我们认为是“消极”的现实部分。这似乎就是大多数鼓吹积极思考的人的运作方式。真正的积极思考始于包容我们所有的现实。它源于这样一种信念：我们能够相信自己，去面对全部的真相，无论那真相最终是什么。

As Dr. Michael Kerr points out, compulsive optimism is one of the ways we bind our anxiety to avoid confronting it. That form of positive thinking is the coping mechanism of the hurt child. The adult who remains hurt without being aware of it makes this residual defence of the child into a life principle.

正如迈克尔·克尔博士所指出的，强迫性乐观是我们逃避焦虑的一种方式。这种积极思考方式是受伤孩童的应对机制。成年人如果仍然受到伤害却不自知，就会将这种孩童时期遗留的防御机制转化为人生信条。

The onset of symptoms or the diagnosis of a disease should prompt a two-pronged inquiry: what is this illness saying about the past and present, and what will help in the future? Many approaches focus only on the second half of that healing dyad without considering fully what led to the manifestation of illness in the first place. Such “positive” methods fill the bookshelves and the airwaves.

症状出现或疾病确诊后，应进行双重探究：这种疾病反映了过去和现在的哪些问题？未来又该如何应对？许多疗法只关注治疗的后半部分，而没有充分考虑疾病最初是如何产生的。这类“积极疗法”充斥着书架和广播电视。

In order to heal, it is essential to gather the strength to think negatively. Negative thinking is not a doleful, pessimistic view that masquerades as “realism.” Rather, it is a willingness to consider what is not working. What is not in balance? What have I ignored? What is my body saying no to? Without these questions, the stresses responsible for our lack of balance will remain hidden.

为了疗愈，至关重要的是要鼓起勇气进行负面思考。负面思考并非伪装成“现实主义”的悲观消极观点，而是一种愿意去思考哪些方面出了问题。哪些方面失衡了？我忽略了什么？我的身体在拒绝什么？如果没有这些问题，导致我们身心失衡的压力源将始终隐藏在表面之下。

Even more fundamentally, not posing those questions is itself a source of stress . First, “positive thinking” is based on an unconscious belief that we are not strong enough to handle reality. Allowing this fear to dominate engenders a state of childhood apprehension. Whether or not the apprehension is conscious, it is a state of stress. Second, lack of essential information about ourselves and our situation is one of the major sources of stress and one of the potent activators of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) stress response. Third, stress wanes as independent, autonomous control increases.

更根本的是，不去提出这些问题本身就是一种压力来源。首先，“积极思考”基于一种潜意识的信念，即我们没有足够的力量去应对现实。任由这种恐惧占据主导地位，会引发一种童年时期的焦虑状态。无论这种焦虑是否出于意识，它都是一种压力状态。其次，缺乏关于自身和所处境况的关键信息是压力的主要来源之一，也是下丘脑-垂体-肾上腺（HPA）应激反应的强效激活因素之一。第三，随着独立自主能力的增强，压力会逐渐减轻。

One cannot be autonomous as long as one is driven by relationship dynamics, by guilt or attachment needs, by hunger for success, by the fear of the boss or by the fear of boredom. The reason is simple: autonomy is impossible as long as one is driven by anything . Like a leaf blown by the wind, the driven person is controlled by forces more powerful than he is. His autonomous will is not engaged, even if he believes that he has “chosen” his stressed lifestyle and even if he enjoys his activities. The choices he makes are attached to invisible strings. He is still unable to say no, even if it is only to his own drivenness. When he finally wakes up, he shakes his head, Pinocchio-like, and says, “How foolish I was when I was a puppet.”

只要一个人受制于人际关系、内疚或依恋需求、对成功的渴望、对老板的恐惧或对无聊的恐惧，他就无法真正自主。原因很简单：只要受到任何事物的驱使，自主就无从谈起。就像被风吹落的树叶，被驱使的人会被比他自身更强大的力量所控制。即使他认为自己“选择”了这种充满压力的生活方式，即使他乐在其中，他的自主意志也无法发挥作用。他所做的选择仿佛被无形的绳索束缚着。他仍然无法说“不”，即使只是拒绝自己的驱使。当他最终醒悟过来时，他会像匹诺曹一样摇摇头，说道：“我以前做木偶的时候真是太傻了。”

Joyce, the university lecturer with asthma, finds it impossible to say no. Her lungs say it for her. Joyce’s fear of the no is not a fear of others but of an emptiness she feels when she is not pushing herself. “The emptiness,” she says, “is about this terror that if I don’t fulfill demands, I won’t really exist.” If she invoked her power of negative thinking, she could accept that fearsome void within herself. She would explore the experience of the void rather than attempt to fill it with positive deeds.

患有哮喘的大学讲师乔伊斯发现自己根本无法说“不”。她的肺替她说了“不”。乔伊斯害怕被拒绝，并非害怕别人，而是害怕当她不努力奋斗时，内心会感到一种空虚。“这种空虚，”她说，“源于一种恐惧：如果我不满足别人的要求，我就仿佛不存在了。”如果她能运用消极思维，或许就能接受内心那可怕的空虚。她会去探索这种空虚的体验，而不是试图用积极的行动去填补它。

Michelle, diagnosed with breast cancer at age thirty-nine, used to seek relief in her lifelong habit of daydreaming. “No wonder I lived in a fantasy world,” she said as she recalled her childhood unhappiness. “It’s safer. You make up your own rules, and you can make it protective and as happy as you want it to be. The outside world is completely different.”

米歇尔39岁时被诊断出患有乳腺癌，她过去常常沉迷于白日梦来寻求慰藉。“难怪我活在幻想世界里，”她回忆起童年的不幸时说道，“那里更安全。你可以自己制定规则，让它充满保护，让你感到快乐。外面的世界完全是另一番景象。”

One study conducted over nearly two years found that breast cancer patients with a propensity to engage in pleasant daydreams had a poorer prognosis than their more reality-based counterparts. So did women who reported fewer negative feelings. 2

一项历时近两年的研究发现，喜欢做白日梦的乳腺癌患者预后比那些更注重现实的患者差。负面情绪较少的女性预后也较差。

According to another report on women with recurrent breast cancer, “Patients who reported little in the way of [psychological] stress … and who were rated by others as ‘well adjusted,’ were more likely to be dead at the one year follow-up.” 3

另一份关于复发性乳腺癌女性患者的报告指出，“那些报告心理压力较小……且被他人评价为‘适应良好’的患者，在一年随访时死亡的可能性更高。”

The repeated finding that people with happier, less troubled thought patterns can suffer more illness seems to defy common sense. The general belief is that positive emotions must be conducive to good health. While it is true that genuine joy and satisfaction enhance physical well-being, “positive” states of mind generated to tune out psychic discomfort lower resistance to illness.

反复发现，拥有更快乐、更少烦恼的思维模式的人反而更容易生病，这似乎有悖常理。人们普遍认为，积极的情绪必然有益于健康。虽然真正的快乐和满足感确实能提升身体健康，但为了消除心理不适而人为营造的“积极”心态反而会降低人体对疾病的抵抗力。

The brain governs and integrates the activities of all organs and systems of the body, simultaneously coordinating our interactions with the environment. This regulating function depends on the clear recognition of negative influences, danger signals and signs of internal distress. In children whose environment chronically conveys mixed messages, an impairment occurs in the developing apparatus of the brain. The brain’s capacity to evaluate the environment is diminished, including its ability to distinguish what is nourishing from what is toxic. People wounded in this way, as Michelle was during her childhood, are more likely to make decisions that lead to further stress. The more they tune out their anxiety via “positive thoughts,” denial or daydreaming, the longer that stress will act on them and the more damaging it will be. When one lacks the capacity to feel heat, the risk of being burned increases.

大脑统筹协调身体所有器官和系统的活动，同时协调我们与环境的互动。这种调节功能依赖于对负面影响、危险信号和内在痛苦迹象的清晰识别。如果儿童长期处于充满矛盾信息的环境中，其大脑发育机制就会受损。大脑评估环境的能力会下降，包括区分有益和有害事物的能力。像米歇尔这样童年时期遭受过此类伤害的人，更容易做出导致进一步压力的决定。他们越是通过“积极思考”、否认或白日梦来麻痹焦虑，压力就会持续作用于他们，造成的损害也就越大。当一个人缺乏感知温度的能力时，被烫伤的风险就会增加。

Inevitably, negative thinking of the honest sort will lead into areas of pain and conflict we have shunned. It cannot be otherwise. The overwhelming need of the child to avoid pain and conflict is responsible for the personality trait or coping style that later predisposes the adult to disease.

不可避免地，真诚的负面思考会将我们引向我们一直回避的痛苦和冲突领域。这是必然的。孩子极力逃避痛苦和冲突的需求，造就了他们日后易患疾病的性格特征或应对方式。

Natalie, with multiple sclerosis, put up with her alcoholic and emotionally abusive husband. She faithfully nursed him through his convalescence from two cancer operations and tolerated his petulant demands. He betrayed her, but even years after his death she cannot say no to other people’s expectations. “Five years down the road and I still have not learned that I have to pace myself. My body says no to me frequently and I just keep going. I just don’t learn.” Natalie’s explanation? “The nurse in me won’t allow me to stop.” That is the story she tells herself, as if there really existed a powerful “nurse” within her that controlled her behaviour. When Natalie does not say no, she is likely to find herself feeling stressed and suffer a flare-up of her MS. But to free herself from such stress she would have to accept the painful reality that only her own choices, based on childhood perceptions, render her incapable of asserting her needs.

患有多发性硬化症的娜塔莉忍受着酗酒且情感虐待的丈夫。她悉心照料他，陪伴他度过了两次癌症手术后的康复期，也容忍了他任性的要求。他背叛了她，但即使在他去世多年后，她仍然无法拒绝他人的期望。“五年过去了，我仍然没有学会放慢脚步。我的身体经常发出警告，但我却继续坚持。我就是学不会。”娜塔莉的解释是：“我内心深处的护士本能不允许我停下来。”她这样告诉自己，仿佛她体内真的存在一个强大的“护士”，控制着她的行为。当娜塔莉不去拒绝别人时，她很可能会感到压力倍增，多发性硬化症也会复发。但要想摆脱这种压力，她必须接受一个痛苦的现实：正是她基于童年认知做出的选择，才使她无法表达自己的需求。

Many people are blocked from self-knowledge and personal growth by the myth they feel compelled to hold on to, of having had a “happy childhood.” A little negative thinking would empower them to see through the self-delusion that helps keep them stuck in self-harming behavioural patterns.

许多人因为执着于“拥有幸福童年”的迷思而阻碍了自我认知和个人成长。稍微反思一下，就能让他们看穿这种自欺欺人的假象，从而摆脱自我伤害的行为模式。

Jean, a thirty-five-year-old legal secretary, was diagnosed at age twenty-four with multiple sclerosis, having suffered weakness, dizziness, fatigue, bladder problems and, finally, a temporary loss of vision. She spent nearly a year in medical institutions, at an acute-care hospital and then at a rehabilitation facility. The few recurrences since then have been much milder.

35岁的法律秘书珍妮在24岁时被诊断出患有多发性硬化症，她曾出现虚弱、头晕、疲劳、膀胱问题，最终还出现了暂时性失明。她在医疗机构住了将近一年，先是在一家急症医院，然后转到康复中心。此后几次复发症状都比较轻微。

Jean was married at nineteen. Her first husband was an older man, controlling and abusive. “Mostly emotional, verbal, but at the end physical. He hit me. That’s when I left. He used to tape my phone conversations with my friends. I was working two jobs—playing music at night, daycare during the days. I handed over my paycheque. I didn’t like working in his band. Too much travelling. I was lonely.

珍十九岁就结婚了。她的第一任丈夫年纪比她大，控制欲强，而且虐待她。“主要是精神上的和言语上的虐待，但最后也发展到了肢体暴力。他打我。所以我离开了。他以前会录下我和朋友的电话。我当时打两份工——晚上演奏音乐，白天在托儿所工作。我把工资都交给了他。我不喜欢在他的乐队里工作。到处奔波太累了。我感到很孤独。”

“I also had an eating disorder much of my life. When I went into hospital I weighted eighty-nine pounds, and I’m five foot six. I was anorexic. I left my husband one day and ended up in hospital the next.”

“我一生中大部分时间都患有饮食失调症。我入院时体重只有89磅，而我身高5英尺6英寸。我患有厌食症。有一天我离开了丈夫，第二天就进了医院。”

“Your putting up for five years with an abusive older man could not have been accidental. I believe it says a lot about your family of origin.”

“你忍受一个虐待你的年长男人五年之久，这绝非偶然。我认为这反映了你原生家庭的很多问题。”

“I could not disagree more. My family was the furthest thing from abusive you could possibly get. I have an incredibly supportive family. I have two brothers and a sister and parents who have been happily married for forty-five years. I was never treated with anything except care and love and tenderness.”

“我完全不同意这种说法。我的家庭与虐待完全不沾边。我的家人非常支持我。我有两个兄弟和一个姐妹，父母已经幸福地结婚四十五年了。我从小到大都感受到的是关爱、呵护和温柔。”

“I didn’t use the word abusive about your family. I said your story tells me a lot about your family of origin.”

“我没有用‘虐待’这个词来形容你的家庭。我说的是，你的故事让我对你的原生家庭有了很多了解。”

“Oh! [long pause] I don’t know. What does it tell you?”

“哦！（长久的停顿）我不知道。它告诉你什么呢？”

“Let me ask you first of all if you were ever sexually abused as a child.”

“首先我想问你，你小时候是否遭受过性虐待？”

“No, or … there was an episode of inappropriate touching when I was about eleven or so, by a fellow who worked with my dad somehow. We had a camp-out with people. I told my parents. I didn’t tell them at the time, I told them years later .

“不，或者说……我大概十一岁左右的时候，被一个跟我爸爸有某种关联的人不恰当地碰过。当时我们和一些人一起露营。我告诉了我父母。我当时没告诉他们，是几年后才告诉他们的。”

“We were at a campfire, and I had shorts on. He was telling me what a pretty girl I was, and I was flattered. He was running his hand up the inside of my leg. I think the whole thing went on for about half an hour, but when he started touching me, that’s when I made excuses and left. And I knew that I was upset about it.

“当时我们在篝火旁，我穿着短裤。他夸我漂亮，我挺高兴的。他把手伸到我腿内侧往上摸。我觉得整个过程大概持续了半个小时，但他开始动手动脚的时候，我就找了个借口离开了。我知道我当时很生气。”

“It’s very cloudy to me. I was almost doubting myself. Even as I’m telling you, it seems like it was no big deal. But it stands out in my mind. I remember the feeling surrounding it, the dirty, bleh, horrible feeling surrounding it.”

“我当时脑子一片混乱。我几乎都开始怀疑自己了。即使现在我在跟你说，这件事看起来好像没什么大不了的。但它却一直萦绕在我的脑海里。我记得当时的感觉，那种肮脏、糟糕、可怕的感觉。”

“If you had an eleven-year-old daughter and something like this happened to her, what would you like her to do?”

“如果你有一个十一岁的女儿，她遇到了这样的事情，你希望她怎么做？”

“Wow. I wouldn’t like her to wait a couple of years until she said something, that’s for sure.”

“哇。我肯定不希望她等上几年才说些什么。”

“Why not?”

为什么不呢？

“Because I would want to be able to discuss it with her for starters, and help her to understand all the feelings she was feeling.”

“因为首先我想和她讨论这件事，帮助她理解她所有的感受。”

“And if she didn’t tell you?”

“如果她没告诉你呢？”

“I would think that she was afraid to tell me. I don’t know what I would think….” Jean was holding back tears but wanted to continue with the interview.

“我想她是不敢告诉我。我不知道我会怎么想……”吉恩强忍着泪水，但还是想继续采访。

“You recall your childhood as a happy one.”

“你回忆起自己的童年时，觉得很快乐。”

“Absolutely.”

“绝对地。”

“Tell me about your anorexia.”

“跟我说说你的厌食症吧。”

“I think I was about fifteen. It never was labelled anorexia until later, when it developed into bulimia. I threw out my lunches and I never wanted my breakfast. I was so skinny. My parents worried a lot.”

“我想我当时大概十五岁。直到后来发展成暴食症，才被诊断为厌食症。我把午饭都扔掉，也从来不想吃早饭。我瘦得皮包骨。我父母很担心。”

“Do you know what was in your mind?”

你知道你当时在想什么吗？

“Most of it was the insecurity around body image all teenage girls go through. I don’t remember thinking that I was heavy—I never was. I just thought that I’d be more popular if I was skinnier. My self-worth was based on whether or not people liked me. I wanted everybody to like me.”

“大部分都是所有少女都会经历的身材焦虑。我不记得自己觉得自己胖——我从来都不胖。我只是觉得如果我更瘦一些，就会更受欢迎。我的自我价值感取决于别人是否喜欢我。我希望每个人都喜欢我。”

“How it works, I believe, is that self-worth originates from how valued one feels by one’s parents.”

我认为，自我价值感源于父母对自己的重视程度。

“I felt as though if I didn’t get straight A’s they wouldn’t love me. I have an older sister who at that time was putting my parents through hell, and she was getting all the attention. My sister also had a bleeding disorder, so when we were younger a lot of the focus was on her. She was hospitalized, and they thought she had leukemia for the longest time.”

“我觉得如果我成绩不是全A，他们就不会爱我了。我有个姐姐，那时候她让我爸妈操碎了心，所有的注意力都集中在她身上。我姐姐还有出血性疾病，所以我们小时候，大家的注意力都集中在她身上。她住院了，很长一段时间医生都以为她得了白血病。”

“So let me run this past you again. You were a kid who unless she got A’s felt unloved by her parents, who at age eleven was subjected to an inappropriate sexual advance. She felt sick about it but didn’t tell her parents. At age fifteen you became anorexic. And you had an absolutely happy childhood. What’s wrong with this picture?”

“那我再跟你解释一遍。你小时候，除非考A，否则就感觉不到父母的爱；11岁那年，你遭遇了性骚扰。你为此感到难过，但没有告诉父母。15岁时，你患上了厌食症。而你的童年却无比幸福。这到底有什么问题？”

Jean laughs. “Well, because when I look back on my teenage years, it wasn’t hell. It just wasn’t. The eating disorder was just starting to assert itself…”

珍笑了。“嗯，因为当我回想起我的青少年时期，那并不是地狱。真的不是。饮食失调症才刚刚开始显现……”

“Do you notice you’re avoiding my question?”

“你有没有注意到你在回避我的问题？”

“What’s wrong with that picture? That doesn’t sound like a happy childhood to me. But I don’t think about having an unhappy childhood.”

“这幅图有什么问题？在我看来，这不像是一个快乐的童年。但我并不认为自己有过不快乐的童年。”

Jean’s exclusion of darker memories from recollections of childhood is typical. One study compared the perceptions of multiple sclerosis patients with those of non-MS controls. Subjects were asked to rate their home lives in childhood as unhappy, moderately happy or very happy. 4 Over eighty per cent in both groups said their home lives had been either moderately happy or very happy. It appears the vast majority in both groups, in roughly comparable proportions, remembered having grown up in the Land of Oz. But when people open up about their emotions and their lives, as Jean does here, such idealized images of childhood rarely remain intact.

珍妮在回忆童年时刻意回避那些阴暗的记忆，这很典型。一项研究比较了多发性硬化症患者和非多发性硬化症对照组的童年记忆。研究对象被要求将童年时期的家庭生活评价为不幸福、比较幸福或非常幸福。两组人群中超过80%的人都表示他们的家庭生活比较幸福或非常幸福。似乎两组人群中绝大多数人，且比例大致相当，都记得自己是在奥兹国长大的。但是，当人们像珍妮一样敞开心扉谈论自己的情感和生活时，这种理想化的童年景象很少能保持原样。

“The anorexia was my way of not feeling my feelings. But as to why I dealt with it that way, I don’t know.”

“厌食症是我逃避感受的一种方式。至于我为什么会用这种方式应对，我也不知道。”

“Perhaps you saw your parents as suffering with your sister, and you felt like protecting them. You took on the role of caregiver. You are likely still taking care of people, even when you aren’t aware of it … your parents, your siblings or your husband.”

“或许你看到父母和妹妹一起受苦，你很想保护他们。你承担起了照顾者的角色。即使你没有意识到，你可能仍然在照顾别人……你的父母、兄弟姐妹或丈夫。”

“Or all of them. With my husband, if he is angry or upset, my first thought is, How do I fix it? And it’s not even about me. It’s automatic for me. Right now I’m working on curing his prostate cancer for him. * Aren’t I clever?”

“或者说，所有这些。如果我丈夫生气或难过，我的第一反应就是，我该怎么解决？这甚至跟我自己都没关系。这对我来说是下意识的。我现在正在努力帮他治好前列腺癌。我是不是很聪明？”

“You’re not going to do it. But you might work yourself into a flare-up.”

“你不会那么做的。但你可能会让自己病情恶化。”

“I did last year, when he was first diagnosed. And again, I had a flare-up when my husband’s mother was ill and then died—I was so worried for him that I neglected looking after myself. I didn’t eat right and I didn’t rest enough. And I still do it with my parents. I shield them from all kinds of things that I fear would hurt them if they knew. I’ve never talked with them about the whole eating disorder. I don’t always tell them if I have a flare-up of MS; I play it down because they worry so much.”

“去年他刚确诊的时候，我就是这样。后来，我丈夫的母亲生病去世的时候，我的病情又复发了——我太担心他了，以至于忽略了自己的健康。我饮食不规律，休息也不够。现在我对父母也是这样。我刻意隐瞒各种事情，怕他们知道后会伤心。我从来没跟他们谈过我的饮食失调症。如果我的多发性硬化症复发了，我也不会总是告诉他们；我会尽量轻描淡写，因为他们太担心了。”

Frequently an adult’s recollections of life in her family of origin fail to take into account the hidden price the child had to pay for the parents’ approval and acceptance. Pamela Wallin, the Canadian journalist diagnosed in 2001 with bowel cancer, provides a prime illustration of this in her memoir, Since You Asked . We see in her writing the split between the adult’s recollections and the child’s emotional reality. She cautions the reader early, “I’m warning you now. What follows may read like a travelogue for a town or a paid advertisement for the family, but as far as I am concerned, it’s the truth. I feel I had a close-to-perfect childhood.” It is impossible to reconcile that idealized view with some of the scenes Ms. Wallin (currently Canadian high commissioner in New York) candidly describes.

成年人回忆原生家庭生活时，往往忽略了孩子为了获得父母的认可和接纳所付出的隐性代价。加拿大记者帕梅拉·沃林（Pamela Wallin）于2001年被诊断出肠癌，她在回忆录《既然你问了》（Since You Asked）中对此做了一个典型的例子。从她的文字中，我们可以看到成年人的回忆与孩子真实的情感体验之间的鸿沟。她开篇就告诫读者：“我先提醒你，接下来的内容可能读起来像是一篇小镇游记，或者是一篇家庭广告，但就我而言，这都是事实。我觉得我的童年近乎完美。”然而，沃林女士（现任加拿大驻纽约高级专员）坦诚描述的某些场景，与这种理想化的视角却难以调和。

In one passage Pamela recalls being chronically intimidated by her older sister. Her suppressed rage over that reached such a boiling pitch that once she vindictively wounded her sister on the arm. “Bonnie still carries the scar on her arm from a wound I inflicted deliberately just a day before a big date on which she was to wear a new sleeveless dress. She had to borrow a shawl to hide the unsightly act of revenge.” To this day, Ms. Wallin writes, she blames Bonnie for instilling in her a fear of the dark. To get rid of Pamela when her boyfriend was visiting, Bonnie chased her younger sibling into the bedroom, turned off the light switch and slammed the door. “She knew full well I would be too scared of potential monsters under the bed to make my way across the room in the dark and turn the light back on, so it all but guaranteed I would stay shuddering out of her way for the remainder of the evening.” The story is told with a touch of joviality.

在一段文字中，帕梅拉回忆起自己长期以来一直受到姐姐的恐吓。她压抑已久的愤怒最终爆发，以至于有一次她出于报复，在姐姐的手臂上留下了伤疤。“邦妮手臂上至今还留着那道疤，那是我故意造成的，就在她一个重要约会的前一天，她要穿一件新的无袖连衣裙。她不得不借了一条披肩来遮掩这难看的报复痕迹。”沃林女士写道，直到今天，她仍然责怪邦妮让她害怕黑暗。为了在男友来访时赶走帕梅拉，邦妮把妹妹追进卧室，关掉灯，然后砰地一声关上门。“她很清楚我会害怕床底下可能有怪物，不敢在黑暗中穿过房间去开灯，所以这几乎可以保证我整个晚上都会瑟瑟发抖地躲着她。”这个故事讲述得颇为诙谐。

At work here is a kind of “false memory syndrome” in reverse: on the conscious level, people often remember only the happy parts of childhood. Even if troubling incidents are recalled, the emotional aspects of those events are suppressed. Parental love is legitimately remembered, but the child’s feelings of not being understood or supported emotionally are not. In this case, absent is any recollection of how a child might feel who lacks the safety of confessing to her parents her terror and rage at repeatedly being imprisoned alone in a dark room. This lack of safety was confirmed by a more painful episode that occurred in Pamela’s adolescence, when she did seek her mother’s help and intervention regarding a troubling situation in the classroom. Pamela’s mother was a teacher in the school her daughters attended. “Only once did she chastise me. One of our grade-school teachers was fondling our budding breasts during class, and Mom was reluctant to believe my charges against one of her respected colleagues. She said, and I suppose it reflected the times, that I should explain to the other girls that we should sit in such a way as to make his unwanted groping impossible. We did and simply waited for year’s end so we would move on to the next grade and out of his reach…. But we all seemed to survive the experience without emotional scars.” The problem is in the “seem[ing] to survive.” Emotional scars are most often invisible. But scars of any type are less strong and less resilient than the tissue they replace: they remain potential sites of future pain and disruption, unless they are recognized and tended to.
