这里体现的是一种反向的“虚假记忆综合症”：在意识层面，人们往往只记得童年快乐的部分。即使回忆起令人不安的事件，这些事件中的情感因素也会被压抑。父母的爱会被真实地记住，但孩子不被理解或情感支持的感受却会被忽略。在这种情况下，人们完全无法回忆起一个孩子如果无法向父母倾诉自己反复被单独囚禁在黑暗房间里的恐惧和愤怒，会是什么感受。帕梅拉青春期时发生的一件更痛苦的事证实了这种不安全感。当时，她因为在课堂上遇到棘手的情况而寻求母亲的帮助和干预。帕梅拉的母亲是她女儿就读学校的老师。 “她只责备过我一次。我们小学的一位老师在课堂上摸了我们初露端倪的胸部，妈妈不太相信我对她一位受人尊敬的同事的指控。她说——我想这反映了当时的社会风气——我应该告诉其他女生，我们应该坐得别太委婉，以免被他摸到。我们照做了，然后就一直等到学年结束，升入下一个年级，摆脱他的骚扰……但我们似乎都安然无恙地度过了那段时期，没有留下任何心理创伤。” 问题就在于“似乎安然无恙”。心理创伤通常是看不见的。但任何类型的疤痕都比它们所替代的组织脆弱，缺乏韧性：除非被发现和处理，否则它们仍然是未来痛苦和创伤的潜在来源。

An oblique remark in her book that “kids often find it impossible to talk to their parents openly” is Pamela’s only reference to not having been heard as a child. There is no depiction of the frustration a child feels when the significant adults do not know how to listen. In general, she insists that she had no “personal demons to exorcise,” a remark exemplifying the denial of anxiety, anger and negative emotion that the studies on cancer patients have consistently reported.

帕梅拉在书中含蓄地提到“孩子们常常发现很难与父母坦诚交流”，这是她唯一一次提及自己童年时期不被倾听的经历。书中完全没有描绘当重要的成年人不懂得倾听时，孩子所感受到的挫败感。总的来说，她坚称自己没有“需要驱除的个人心魔”，这种说法恰恰体现了癌症患者研究中反复出现的对焦虑、愤怒和负面情绪的否认。

Tuning out—by, say, daydreaming—enables the child to endure experiences that otherwise may trigger reactions that would land him in trouble. This kind of dissociation is in play when a person retains conscious recall for events in the past but not for their traumatic emotional resonance. It explains many “happy childhoods,” such as Iris with SLE insists she had, despite her father’s tyranny and the emotional absence of her mother.

通过诸如白日梦之类的方式逃避现实，孩子能够忍受那些原本可能引发不良反应的经历，而这些反应可能会让他陷入困境。这种分离状态表现为一个人能够有意识地回忆起过去的事件，但却无法回忆起这些事件带来的创伤性情感共鸣。这可以解释许多“快乐的童年”，例如患有系统性红斑狼疮的艾瑞斯坚称自己拥有快乐的童年，尽管她的父亲专横跋扈，母亲也情感缺失。

“My father had a very short leash on his temper, and when he got angry, you never knew what was going to happen. Dishes could fly, somebody might get kicked.”

“我父亲脾气很暴躁，一旦他生气，你永远不知道会发生什么。盘子可能会乱飞，有人可能会被踢。”

“Did you get kicked?”

你被踢了吗？

“Never. I was my father’s favourite.”

“绝不可能。我是父亲最疼爱的孩子。”

“How did you achieve that status?”

你是如何获得这种地位的？

“I disappeared . I developed that ability early in life.”

“我消失了。我从小就具备这种能力。”

“Do you remember feeling unhappy as a child?”

你还记得小时候感到不快乐的时候吗？

“Unhappy? No.”

“不开心吗？不。”

“Could a child in those circumstances not feel sad or unhappy about things?”

“在这种情况下，孩子难道不会感到悲伤或不快乐吗？”

“You get numb, usually.”

“通常会感到麻木。”

“So you don’t really know if you felt unhappy or sad because you would have numbed it out.”

“所以你其实不知道自己是感到不开心还是难过，因为你会麻木自己。”

“That’s right. I don’t remember huge blocks of my childhood.”

“没错。我几乎不记得童年的任何事情。”

“Why would someone have to numb out? Why couldn’t you just go to somebody and talk about it? What about your mom?”

“为什么一定要麻木自己呢？为什么不能找人倾诉呢？你妈妈呢？”

“Well, no, I couldn’t talk to my mother because I didn’t want her to know I was unhappy, for one thing. For another, she didn’t really exist as a separate entity apart from my father. She was a neutral person.

“嗯，不，我没法跟妈妈说话，一方面是因为我不想让她知道我不开心。另一方面，在她眼里，她就像个局外人，和爸爸没什么两样。她只是个中立的人。”

“A child has very little language. I was numb, but on the other hand I was quite happy in my numbness.”

“孩子语言能力很弱。我当时麻木了，但另一方面，我又很享受这种麻木的状态。”

“Oh?”

“哦？”

“I played with dolls … okay, never mind about that … I was going to say I chewed dolls!”

“我玩过娃娃……好吧，算了……我本来想说我啃过娃娃！”

“What do you mean you chewed them?”

“你说什么？你把它们嚼碎了？”

“They were made out of plastic, and I’d chew their fingers and toes!”

“它们是用塑料做的，我会啃它们的手指和脚趾！”

“You were mutilating them, in your suppressed rage. Consider this—when do we have to numb things out?”

“你压抑着怒火，残忍地残害他们。想想看——我们什么时候必须麻木自己？”

“When you’re in pain …”

“当你感到疼痛时……”

“Eventually when you numb it out enough, you can imagine that you’re happy. You are only happy because you numbed out a huge part of your reality. Which is to say that you’re not really living life to the fullest at all.”

“最终，当你麻木到一定程度，你就会觉得自己很快乐。你之所以快乐，只是因为你麻木了现实中很大一部分。也就是说，你根本没有真正地享受生活。”

“Agreed.”

“同意。”

____

Finally, I come back to Darlene, the insurance broker whose ovarian cancer was diagnosed inadvertently, during an infertility investigation. Nothing in her history could be described as even remotely painful. The only negative experience in her life, as she recounted it, has been her ovarian cancer and its unexpected recurrence despite diagnosis and treatment at a very early stage. The initial prognosis, she said, had been “celebratory,” the recurrence “devastating.”

最后，我想再说说达琳，这位保险经纪人在一次不孕症检查中意外确诊了卵巢癌。她的人生经历中没有任何痛苦可言。据她回忆，她生命中唯一的负面经历就是卵巢癌，以及尽管早期诊断和治疗，癌症还是意外复发。她说，最初的预后“令人欣喜”，而复发却“令人崩溃”。

“I’ve always wanted to be in control of my life, have always taken care of myself. I eat well, exercise, I’m in great shape. I’ve never had any bad habits.” The one risk factor she did have was infertility. Darlene describes her life in terms that, to my ears, sound too good to be true. In all her childhood she cannot recall one single unhappy incident, not one moment of fear, anger, anxiety or sorrow.

“我一直想掌控自己的人生，也一直很注重保养自己。我饮食健康，坚持锻炼，身材保持得很好。我从来没有任何不良习惯。”她唯一的风险因素是不孕。达琳对生活的描述，在我听来简直完美得难以置信。在她的整个童年时期，她都想不起任何不愉快的事情，没有一丝恐惧、愤怒、焦虑或悲伤。

“I’m the oldest of three girls. The three of us are incredibly close, as are my mom and dad, who are still living and very healthy. On top of that, my husband’s family and I are very close. I have been blessed with family and have also been blessed with really good, deep friends—some that I’ve had since I was five years old. My friends and family have been a huge source of inspiration. I think I’ve been very lucky in that respect.”

“我是三姐妹中的老大。我们三姐妹关系非常亲密，我的父母也一样，他们都健在，身体也很健康。此外，我和我丈夫的家人关系也很好。我很幸运拥有一个幸福的家庭，也很幸运拥有许多真挚的好朋友——有些朋友我从五岁起就认识了。我的朋友和家人给了我巨大的灵感。在这方面，我觉得自己非常幸运。”

Darlene’s cancerous right ovary was removed in 1991. She retained her left one, hoping to become pregnant in the future. She did successfully conceive a year later.

1991年，达琳因右侧卵巢癌切除了该卵巢。她保留了左侧卵巢，希望将来能够怀孕。一年后，她成功怀孕。

“We all talk about that five-year mark, and I made it through that. It was about five and a half years after my oophorectomy, and my son was four, when I had what I considered very innocuous symptoms: I was tired, I had lost a little bit of weight—but only five pounds, nothing major. I had a toddler, a career and a busy household. My lower back was sore, but again I thought I was struggling with a toddler, trying to get him in and out of snowsuits.

“我们都在谈论五年这个里程碑，而我挺过来了。大约在我做完卵巢切除手术五年半后，我的儿子四岁的时候，我出现了一些我认为非常轻微的症状：我感到疲倦，体重减轻了一些——但只轻了五磅，没什么大不了的。我当时要照顾蹒跚学步的孩子，还要兼顾工作和繁忙的家务。我的腰背疼痛，但我当时以为是因为要照顾蹒跚学步的孩子，给他穿脱滑雪服而感到吃力。”

“When I was diagnosed again in 1996, and it had metastasized, we were obviously devastated—and the prognosis was very, very different, with spread to the other ovary, the uterus and spots in the lower abdomen.”

“1996 年我再次被确诊，而且癌细胞已经转移，我们当然感到非常沮丧——预后也截然不同，癌细胞扩散到了另一个卵巢、子宫和下腹部。”

“I’m curious, given the past history of ovarian cancer, why these symptoms did not alarm you sooner. What might you have advised a friend with your history and your symptoms?”

“鉴于您曾患卵巢癌，我很好奇为什么这些症状没有让您更早警觉。如果您有类似的病史和症状，您会给朋友提出哪些建议？”

“Oh, well. When it comes to my friends, if they have an ingrown toenail, I send them to a gynecologist.”

“哦，好吧。如果是我朋友的脚趾甲长在脚趾里，我会把她们转诊给妇科医生。”

“This difference in how you treat yourself and how you treat others is one of the hints you’ve given me that not all in your life may have been as you picture it. Another is when you said, ‘I think I’ve been very lucky,’ in describing your relationships. The I think is a qualifier—to me it indicates uncertainty; it reflects an internal debate. Perhaps what you think is not what you feel; otherwise, you simply would have asserted that you feel fortunate.

“你对待自己和对待他人的方式不同，这暗示着你的人生可能并非如你所想的那样。另一个暗示是，你在描述你的人际关系时说‘我觉得我很幸运’。这里的‘我觉得’是一个限定词——在我看来，它表明你并不确定；它反映了你内心的挣扎。也许你的想法和你的感受并不相同；否则，你就会直接说你很幸运了。”

“I also note that you smile when you talk about your pains and aches, as if you’re trying to soften the impact of your words. How and why might you have learned to do that? The reflex of smiling when people talk about physical pain, or about painful events or incidents or thoughts I see all the time. Yet when infants are born, they have no capacity to hide feelings whatsoever. If an infant is uncomfortable or unhappy, she’ll cry, show sadness, show anger. Anything that we do to hide pain or sadness is an acquired response. It may make sense to hide negative emotion in some circumstances, but so many of us do it all the time, and we do it automatically.

我还注意到，你在谈到疼痛时会面带微笑，仿佛想减轻话语的冲击力。你是如何以及为什么学会这样做的呢？我经常看到人们在谈论身体疼痛、痛苦的经历或想法时，都会不自觉地微笑。然而，婴儿出生时根本没有能力隐藏自己的情绪。如果婴儿感到不舒服或不开心，她会哭泣、表达悲伤或愤怒。我们用来掩饰痛苦或悲伤的任何行为都是一种后天习得的反应。在某些情况下，隐藏负面情绪或许情有可原，但我们中的许多人却经常这样做，而且这种行为几乎是下意识的。

“Somehow people are trained—some more than others—into unknowingly taking care of other people’s emotional needs and minimizing their own. They hide their pain and sadness, even from themselves.”

“不知何故，人们——有些人比其他人受到的影响更大——被训练成在不知不觉中照顾他人的情感需求，而忽略了自己的需求。他们隐藏自己的痛苦和悲伤，甚至对自己也如此。”

Darlene listened thoughtfully. She neither agreed nor disagreed. “It’s an interesting perspective. We should definitely bring it up in my ovarian cancer support group. I don’t know how to respond to it right now, and I don’t believe you really need an immediate response. It is intuitive and very thought-provoking. I thank you for that.”

达琳认真地听着，既没有表示赞同，也没有表示反对。“这真是一个有趣的观点。我们一定要在我的卵巢癌互助小组里讨论一下。我现在不知道该如何回应，而且我觉得你也不需要马上得到答复。这很有道理，也很有启发性。谢谢你。”

Developing the courage to think negatively allows us to look at ourselves as we really are. There is a remarkable consistency in people’s coping styles across the many diseases we have considered: the repression of anger, the denial of vulnerability, the “compensatory hyperindependence.” No one chooses these traits deliberately or develops them consciously. Negative thinking helps us to understand just what the conditions were in our lives and how these traits were shaped by our perceptions of our environment. Emotionally draining family relationships have been identified as risk factors in virtually every category of major illness, from degenerative neurological conditions to cancer and autoimmune disease. The purpose is not to blame parents or previous generations or spouses but to enable us to discard beliefs that have proved dangerous to our health.

培养反思的勇气，能让我们更真实地审视自己。在我们所研究的众多疾病中，人们的应对方式有着惊人的相似之处：压抑愤怒、否认脆弱、以及“补偿性过度独立”。没有人会刻意选择或有意识地培养这些特质。反思有助于我们理解自身的生活境况，以及这些特质是如何受到我们对环境认知的影响而形成的。从神经退行性疾病到癌症和自身免疫性疾病，几乎所有类型的重大疾病都已确定为情感消耗巨大的家庭关系的风险因素。其目的并非指责父母、前辈或配偶，而是为了帮助我们摒弃那些已被证明危害健康的观念。

“The power of negative thinking” requires the removal of rose-coloured glasses. Not blame of others but owning responsibility for one’s relationships is the key.

“负面思维的力量”要求我们摘下玫瑰色眼镜。关键不在于责怪他人，而在于承担起自身人际关系的责任。

It is no small matter to ask people with newly diagnosed illness to begin to examine their relationships as a way of understanding their disease. For people unused to expressing their feelings and unaccustomed to recognizing their emotional needs, it is extemely challenging to find the confidence and the words to approach their loved ones both compassionately and assertively. The difficulty is all the greater at the point when they have become more vulnerable and more dependent than ever on others for support.

对于新确诊的病人来说，要求他们开始审视自己的人际关系以更好地理解疾病绝非易事。对于那些不习惯表达情感、也不习惯识别自身情感需求的人来说，要鼓起勇气，找到合适的措辞，既能体贴又能坚定地与亲人沟通，是极其困难的。而当他们比以往任何时候都更加脆弱、更加依赖他人支持时，这种困难就更加突出了。

There is no easy answer to this dilemma but leaving it unresolved will continue to create ongoing sources of stress that will, in turn, generate more illness. No matter what the patient may attempt to do for himself, the psychological load he carries cannot be eased without a clear-headed, compassionate appraisal of the most important relationships in his life.

这个问题没有简单的答案，但如果放任不管，就会持续产生压力，进而引发更多疾病。无论患者如何努力，若不冷静、体贴地审视自己生命中最重要的人际关系，就无法减轻他所承受的心理负担。

As we have seen, it is not others’ expectations and intentions but the perception we have of them that serves as the stressor. Jean, with MS, was driven into a flare-up by worrying about her husband’s prostate cancer and assuming responsibility for his seeking the proper medical care. Ed resented Jean’s “controlling” him but was unable to communicate his feelings to her. Jean’s belief that she needed to be responsible for Ed—and Ed’s belief that she was out to control him—were perceptions based on relationship templates each constructed as young children.

正如我们所见，真正造成压力的并非他人的期望和意图，而是我们对他们的认知。患有多发性硬化症的珍妮，因为担心丈夫的前列腺癌，并承担起让他接受适当治疗的责任，导致病情复发。埃德怨恨珍妮“控制”他，却无法向她表达自己的感受。珍妮认为自己需要对埃德负责，而埃德则认为珍妮想要控制他——这两种认知都源于他们各自幼年时期构建的关系模式。

“Most of our tensions and frustrations stem from compulsive needs to act the role of someone we are not,” wrote Hans Selye. The power of negative thinking requires the strength to accept that we are not as strong as we would like to believe. Our insistently strong self-image was generated to hide a weakness—the relative weakness of the child. Our fragility is nothing to be ashamed of. A person can be strong and still need help, can be powerful in some areas of life and helpless and confused in others. We cannot do all that we thought we could. As many people with illness realize, sometimes too late, the attempt to live up to a self-image of strength and invulnerability generated stress and disrupted their internal harmony. “I can handle anything” was how Don, with bowel cancer, described his pre-illness stance. “I couldn’t try to help all the women with ovarian cancer,” Gilda Radner realized after her recurrence, “and I couldn’t read every letter I received because it was tearing me apart.”

汉斯·塞利写道：“我们大多数的紧张和挫败感都源于强迫性地扮演我们并非真正的人的角色。” 消极思维的力量需要我们有足够的勇气去接受自己并不像想象中那么强大。我们执着于塑造强大的自我形象，是为了掩盖自身的弱点——孩童般的脆弱。我们的脆弱并不可耻。一个人可以很坚强，但仍然需要帮助；可以在生活的某些领域游刃有余，而在另一些领域却感到无助和迷茫。我们无法做到所有我们认为自己能做到的事情。许多患病的人最终都会意识到，有时为时已晚，试图维持坚强和刀枪不入的自我形象反而会造成压力，破坏内心的和谐。“我能应付一切，”患有肠癌的唐在患病前这样描述自己的态度。“我无法帮助所有卵巢癌患者，”吉尔达·拉德纳在癌症复发后意识到，“我也无法阅读收到的每一封信，因为它们让我心如刀绞。”

If we learn to think negatively, we stop minimizing our emotions of loss. Many times in the interviews for this book people qualified their hurts and stresses by words and phrases such as “just a little bit” or “maybe” or “might have.” Recall Véronique, with multiple sclerosis, who dismissed the cumulative stresses of a breakup with an alcoholic boyfriend, financial destitution and other difficult life events as “not necessarily bad.”

如果我们学会消极思考，就会停止淡化失去亲人的痛苦。在本书的访谈中，许多人常常用“只是一点点”、“也许”、“可能”之类的词语来描述自己的伤痛和压力。想想患有多发性硬化症的维罗妮卡，她把与酗酒男友分手、经济拮据以及其他人生困境带来的累积压力轻描淡写地归结为“未必是坏事”。

Do I live my life according to my own deepest truths, or in order to fulfill someone else’s expectations? How much of what I have believed and done is actually my own and how much has been in service to a self-image I originally created in the belief it was necessary to please my parents? Magda, with severe abdominal pain, became a physician against her own inclinations—not because her mother and father overtly demanded or even requested it, but because she had made their beliefs into her own. And she did this long before she was old enough to decide what to do with her life. “Almost all my accomplishments were in one way or another connected not to my aspirations, but to the aspirations of my father,” wrote Dennis Kaye, dying of ALS.

我的生活是遵循内心深处的真理，还是为了满足他人的期望？我所相信和所做的一切，有多少是真正出于我自己的意愿，又有多少是为了迎合我最初为了取悦父母而塑造的自我形象？玛格达患有严重的腹痛，违背自己的意愿成为了一名医生——并非因为她的父母明确要求或请求，而是因为她将他们的信念内化成了自己的信念。而这一切，在她还未成年到足以决定自己的人生方向时，就已经发生了。“我几乎所有的成就，都以某种方式与我父亲的愿望有关，而不是与我自己的愿望有关，”身患渐冻症的丹尼斯·凯写道。

“[I am] not half the woman my mother had been,” wrote former U.S. first lady Betty Ford. “My mother was a wonderful woman, strong and kind and principled, and never let me down. She was also a perfectionist, and tried to program her children for perfection.” 5 The strength to think negatively would have allowed Mrs. Ford to ask herself how kind it really is to try to “program” a child for perfection. Instead of fleeing from her self-judgments into alcoholism and a lifetime of stress that culminated in breast cancer, had she been armed with some negative thinking, Betty would have rejected the impossible standards of perfectionism. “I am not half the woman my mother had been,” she might have said with glee, “and I don’t even want to be a quarter of the woman she was. I just want to be myself.”

“我连我母亲一半都比不上，”美国前第一夫人贝蒂·福特写道。“我母亲是一位了不起的女性，坚强、善良、有原则，从未让我失望。她也是个完美主义者，试图把孩子们培养成完美主义者。” 5 如果福特夫人拥有反思的力量，她或许就能扪心自问，试图“培养”孩子成为完美主义者究竟有多仁慈。如果她当时拥有一些反思的力量，就不会沉溺于自我批判，也不会终生承受压力，最终罹患乳腺癌。她或许会拒绝完美主义那些不切实际的标准。“我连我母亲一半都比不上，”她或许会欣然说道，“我甚至不想成为她四分之一的模样。我只想做我自己。”

Laura, with ALS, felt guilty because she did not want bed-and-breakfast guests while her housekeeper was on vacation. She took on the task of hosting because her fear of guilt was greater than her fear of the stress of looking after guests while disabled.

患有渐冻症的劳拉感到内疚，因为她不想在管家休假期间接待客人。但她最终还是承担了接待客人的任务，因为她害怕内疚，而害怕在行动不便的情况下照顾客人带来的压力。

“I try to help people all the time,” said Ed, with prostate cancer. And if not? “I feel bad about it. Guilty.” For many people, guilt is a signal that they have chosen to do something for themselves . I advise most people with serious medical conditions that there is probably something out of balance if they do not feel guilty. They are still putting their own needs, emotions, interests last. The power of negative thinking could permit people to welcome their guilt rather than shun it. “I feel guilty?” Ed could say. “Wonderful. Hallelujah! It means I must have done something right, acted on my own behalf for a change.”

“我总是尽力帮助别人，”患有前列腺癌的埃德说道。如果没能帮上忙呢？“我会感到内疚，感到愧疚。”对许多人来说，内疚感意味着他们选择为自己做点什么。我建议大多数身患重病的人，如果他们没有感到内疚，那很可能说明他们的身心状态失衡了。他们仍然把自己的需求、情感和利益放在最后。消极思考的力量可能会让人欣然接受内疚感，而不是逃避它。“我感到内疚？”埃德可能会这样说。“太好了！谢天谢地！这意味着我肯定做对了什么，难得为自己做了点什么。”

“The biggest thing is the control factor,” Ed said about his wife Jean’s solicitous mothering of him. “I’m resentful.” And how does he deal with it? “I hide it. “The power of negative thinking could enable Ed to accept the guilt of asserting himself against his wife’s interference with his personal decisions, no matter how well meant. A therapist once said to me, “If you face the choice between feeling guilt and resentment, choose the guilt every time.” It is wisdom I have passed on to many others since. If a refusal saddles you with guilt, while consent leaves resentment in its wake, opt for the guilt. Resentment is soul suicide.

“最大的问题是控制欲，”埃德谈到妻子琼对他的过度呵护时说道，“我很怨恨。” 他是如何应对的呢？“我把它藏起来。” 消极思考的力量或许能让埃德接受因反抗妻子干涉个人决定而产生的内疚感，无论妻子的出发点多么好。一位心理咨询师曾对我说：“如果你要在内疚和怨恨之间做出选择，那就每次都选择内疚。” 从那以后，我把这句智慧传授给了许多人。如果拒绝会让你感到内疚，而同意却会让你心生怨恨，那就选择内疚。怨恨无异于自杀。

Negative thinking allows us to gaze unflinchingly on our own behalf at what does not work. We have seen in study after study that compulsive positive thinkers are more likely to develop disease and less likely to survive. Genuine positive thinking—or, more deeply, positive being —empowers us to know that we have nothing to fear from truth.

消极思考让我们能够毫不畏惧地直面自身不足之处。然而，无数研究表明，强迫性积极思考者更容易患病，生存几率也更低。真正的积极思考——或者更深刻地说，积极的存在——赋予我们力量，让我们明白我们无需惧怕真相。

“Health is not just a matter of thinking happy thoughts,” writes the molecular researcher Candace Pert. “Sometimes the biggest impetus to healing can come from jump-starting the immune system with a burst of long-suppressed anger.” 6

“健康不仅仅是保持乐观心态的问题，”分子研究员坎迪斯·珀特写道。“有时，释放长期压抑的愤怒情绪，反而能最大程度地激活免疫系统，从而促进康复。”

Anger, or the healthy experience of it, is one of the seven A’s of healing. Each of the seven A’s addresses one of the embedded visceral beliefs that predispose to illness and undermine healing. We look at them in our final chapter.

愤怒，或者说健康的愤怒体验，是疗愈七要素之一。这七要素分别对应着一种根深蒂固的、容易导致疾病并阻碍康复的内在信念。我们将在最后一章详细探讨它们。

* Jean’s husband, Ed, has been interviewed regarding his prostate cancer. See chapter 8.

* 珍的丈夫艾德接受了关于他前列腺癌的采访。详见第八章。

19
19
The Seven A’s of Healing
疗愈的七个A

B OTH THE ONSET OF MALIGNANT MELANOMA and the body’s ability to survive it involve the immune system. Despite the potentially fatal prognosis, there are many recorded cases of spontaneous remission in this disease—the cancer disappears without medical treatment. Although it accounts for only 1 per cent of all cancers, malignant melanoma provides for 11 per cent of spontaneous cancer remissions. 1

恶性黑色素瘤的发生和人体的抵抗力都与免疫系统有关。尽管预后可能致命，但已有许多病例记录显示，该疾病可自发缓解——癌症无需治疗即可消失。虽然恶性黑色素瘤仅占所有癌症的1%，但它却占癌症自发缓解病例的11%。

The journal Cancer reported a case of spontaneous healing in a seventy-four-year-old man. His cancer was found in a suspicious-looking mole removed from his chest wall in 1965; he experienced a recurrence seven years later, also on his chest, in the form of numerous small moles. The new lesions resulted from local spread of his original melanoma. However, this time the patient refused all further treatment. Eight months later a follow-up visit showed that the small tumours that had seeded the area were flatter and lighter in colour. The patient permitted a small biopsy to be performed; there was pigmentation at the site but no cancer. The following year further clinical signs of healing were present.

《癌症》杂志报道了一例74岁男性自愈的病例。1965年，他的胸壁上一个可疑的痣被切除，并在那里发现了癌症；七年后，癌症复发，同样出现在胸部，表现为许多小痣。这些新病变是由原发黑色素瘤局部扩散引起的。然而，这一次患者拒绝接受任何进一步的治疗。八个月后的复诊显示，扩散到该区域的小肿瘤变得更扁平，颜色也更浅。患者同意进行小活检；活检部位有色素沉着，但没有癌细胞。第二年，出现了进一步的临床愈合迹象。

The immunologic findings were illuminating. Three things happened: first, lymphocytes had attacked the tumour; then, larger cells called macrophages literally helped to eat up the melanoma; finally, there was an influx of antibodies that also participated in destroying the malignancy. This man’s body had mobilized formidable immune resources to defeat the cancer.

免疫学检查结果令人振奋。发生了三件事：首先，淋巴细胞攻击了肿瘤；其次，一种名为巨噬细胞的较大细胞吞噬了黑色素瘤；最后，大量抗体涌入，也参与了清除恶性肿瘤的过程。这名男子的身体调动了强大的免疫资源来战胜癌症。

Spontaneous remission raises two important questions: why, in some people, are such resources not powerful enough to destroy cancerous cells in the first place, before the clinical development of melanoma; and what enables the immune system in some people to overcome this potentially deadly cancer even after it does arise? We have asked the same questions regarding the highly differing outcomes from one person to another of other diseases, despite the apparent similarities of the pathologies involved.

自发缓解引发了两个重要问题：为什么有些人自身免疫力不足以在黑色素瘤临床发展之前就彻底清除癌细胞？以及，是什么让某些人的免疫系统能够在癌症发生后战胜这种可能致命的疾病？我们曾对其他疾病的预后差异如此之大提出过同样的疑问，尽管这些疾病的病理机制看似相似。

In a series of three studies, researchers in San Francisco looked at the Type C pattern of repressed negative emotion in melanoma patients. During an eighteen-month follow-up, they found a strong correlation between repression and the likelihood of relapse or death. Natural killer cells attack abnormal cells, thus providing a line of defence against cancer. NK cells have a demonstrated capacity to digest melanomas. As in breast cancer, they are less active in emotionally repressed individuals.

旧金山的研究人员开展了三项系列研究，探讨黑色素瘤患者中C型压抑负面情绪模式。在为期18个月的随访中，他们发现压抑情绪与复发或死亡风险之间存在显著相关性。自然杀伤细胞（NK细胞）能够攻击异常细胞，从而构成抵御癌症的一道防线。NK细胞已被证实具有消化黑色素瘤的能力。与乳腺癌类似，在情绪压抑的个体中，NK细胞的活性较低。

One of the studies examined the thickness of the original melanoma in relationship to personality. Thickness of the cancer at first biopsy is correlated with prognosis: the thicker the lesion, the less favourable the outlook. Higher scores on the Type C Melanoma Coping scale were found to be associated with thicker lesions: “Type C Melanoma Coping is characterized by patients’ acceptance of having melanoma, having more concern for family members than for themselves, trying not to think about it, coping by perseverance and trying to keep busy, keeping feelings inside, and being considered strong and capable at handling things.” 2

其中一项研究探讨了原发性黑色素瘤的厚度与人格之间的关系。首次活检时肿瘤的厚度与预后相关：病灶越厚，预后越差。C型黑色素瘤应对量表得分越高，病灶也越厚：“C型黑色素瘤应对的特征是患者接受自己患有黑色素瘤的事实，更关心家人而非自己，尽量不去想它，通过坚持不懈和让自己忙碌来应对，将感受藏在心底，并认为自己坚强且有能力处理事情。”

These San Francisco findings confirmed the conclusions of an earlier 1979 study, that melanoma patients who had a harder time adjusting to the diagnosis—in other words, whose responses were less accepting and resigned—were also less likely to suffer relapse. 3

旧金山的研究结果证实了1979年一项早期研究的结论，即黑色素瘤患者如果更难接受诊断结果（换句话说，他们的反应不那么容易接受和顺从），复发的可能性也更低。

Even rudimentary psychological support can make a difference suggests a pilot study conducted at the UCLA, School of Medicine, by the psychiatrist F. I. Fawzy. Thirty-four people with comparable stage 1 melanoma were enrolled in the experimental and control arms of the study, respectively. “Fawzy’s intervention was strikingly minimal. It consisted of only six structured group sessions over a 6-week period, with each session lasting 1½ hours. The group meetings offered (1) education on melanoma and basic nutritional advice; (2) stress management techniques; (3) enhancement of coping skills; and (4) psychological support from the staff and from other group members” Six years later, ten of the original thirty-four patients of the group that had not received psychological support had died, and three others had had recurrences. In the support group, only three of the thirty-four had died, four had experienced recurrences. 4 Earlier in the study, improved immune function had been demonstrated among the patients in the support group. 5

加州大学洛杉矶分校医学院精神科医生F. I. Fawzy开展的一项初步研究表明，即使是最基本的心理支持也能产生影响。该研究招募了34名病情相近的I期黑色素瘤患者，分别纳入实验组和对照组。“Fawzy的干预措施非常精简。他只在6周内组织了6次结构化的团体会议，每次持续1.5小时。这些会议提供：（1）黑色素瘤相关知识和基础营养建议；（2）压力管理技巧；（3）应对能力提升；以及（4）来自工作人员和其他组员的心理支持。” 六年之后，最初34名未接受心理支持的患者中，有10人去世，另有3人出现复发。在支持组中，34人中只有3人死亡，4人出现复发。 4 该研究早期已证实，支持组患者的免疫功能有所改善。 5

It would stand to reason that people with melanoma and other cancers would enhance their ability to reverse the malignant process if they were helped to understand themselves and to become more self-accepting and assertive in their emotional coping styles. Harriette, a fifty-year-old writer, is convinced that her decision to fight the cancer her own way, including with intensive psychotherapy, is responsible for the remission of the malignant melanoma on her right shin.

不难理解，如果黑色素瘤和其他癌症患者能够更好地了解自己，并在情绪应对方面更加接纳自我、更加自信，那么他们逆转恶性肿瘤的能力就会增强。五十岁的作家哈丽特坚信，正是她决定以自己的方式对抗癌症，包括接受密集的心理治疗，才使得她右小腿上的恶性黑色素瘤得以缓解。

“I didn’t trust doctors much. I did some research and found this alternative clinic in Tijuana. They treated melanoma as a whole-body condition, which was the first thing I liked. Surgery on the leg and nothing to follow up didn’t feel right to me. I went to Mexico, and they treated me with a whole series of things, including a vaccine, diet, tonic and some herbal pastes that they use to burn it off the leg. I went back every month, and then three months and six months, but I started realizing that there was something wrong with the way I was handling things. For starters, I didn’t have a GP in Canada. I resisted the authority of doctors, yet here I was accepting treatment from doctors in Mexico.

“我以前不太信任医生。我做了一些调查，在蒂华纳找到了一家另类疗法诊所。他们把黑色素瘤当作全身性疾病来治疗，这一点我首先就喜欢上了。只做腿部手术，然后就没有任何后续治疗，我觉得不太对劲。我去了墨西哥，他们给我做了一系列治疗，包括疫苗、饮食疗法、补品和一些用来烧灼腿部黑色素瘤的草药膏。我每个月都去，后来改为每三个月、每六个月去一次，但我开始意识到我处理问题的方式有问题。首先，我在加拿大没有家庭医生。我一直不信任医生的权威，可现在我却在墨西哥接受医生的治疗。”

“I thought at least I should get a GP—and that is actually when I met you. You didn’t know me from Adam, but as soon as I mentioned melanoma, you said, ‘You know there is a psychological profile for melanoma patients, don’t you?’ Nobody had ever mentioned it to me before, but when you described it, I completely fitted the picture. You also told me that I should have the surgery and you could arrange it, but that surgery by itself might not help unless I also dealt with my inability to feel my own feelings and with all the other problems.

“我当时想，至少应该找个家庭医生——也就是在那时我遇到了你。你根本不认识我，但我刚一提到黑色素瘤，你就说：‘你知道黑色素瘤患者有心理特征吧？’以前从来没有人跟我提过，但你描述之后，我发现自己完全符合你的描述。你还告诉我应该做手术，你可以安排，但手术本身可能没什么用，除非我同时解决自己无法感受自身情绪以及其他所有问题。”

“So I did therapy for six months. It was very intense. After that, I had the surgery. The plastic surgeon was shocked to see me, because he told me that the biopsy he had originally taken showed that I’d had invasive malignant melanoma, quite advanced, quite deep. He expected the worst. And yet, when he did the surgery, he found that it was just abnormal pigmented tissue but no longer melanoma.”

“所以我接受了六个月的治疗。过程非常艰苦。之后，我做了手术。整形外科医生看到我的样子很震惊，因为他告诉我，他最初做的活检显示我患有侵袭性恶性黑色素瘤，而且病情相当严重，深度也比较深。他当时做好了最坏的打算。然而，手术后他发现，那只是异常的色素组织，不再是黑色素瘤了。”

I wondered whether it was the treatment in Mexico or the therapy Harriette underwent that had made the difference. Although I was unfamiliar with the details of the Mexican regimen, it had likely included the BCG vaccine to stimulate the immune system—an approach that, in some cases, has been successfully used against melanoma. Harriette believes it was a combination of everything. “I do think that the treatment in Mexico was working, but the thing kept tingling, and I kept feeling there was something still there—a tingling and a darkening under the skin.”

我很好奇究竟是墨西哥的治疗还是哈丽特接受的疗法起了作用。虽然我对墨西哥的治疗方案细节并不了解，但很可能包括接种卡介苗来刺激免疫系统——这种方法在某些情况下确实能有效治疗黑色素瘤。哈丽特认为这是多种因素共同作用的结果。“我确实觉得墨西哥的治疗起了作用，但皮肤上还是会一直有刺痛感，总感觉好像还有什么东西残留在那里——皮肤下有刺痛感，而且颜色还在变深。”

“What did you find out in therapy?”

“你在治疗中发现了什么？”

“I had to go back right to the beginning. My mother died when I was a toddler. I was the middle one of three sisters all under four, two of us in diapers. My younger sister was just eight months old and very colicky. None of us got much attention but what little there was my sister got. We were shuffled around from place to place, because my father was a travelling salesman. Within a year he married somebody who looked a lot like my mother. She was the Wicked Witch of the West. She had her own problems. She was awful to us. Finally, she sent us away to a French-Canadian convent.

“我不得不从头说起。我母亲在我蹒跚学步时就去世了。我排行老二，家里有三个姐妹，都不到四岁，其中两个还在用尿布。我的小妹妹当时只有八个月大，而且经常哭闹。我们都没怎么得到关注，只有妹妹得到了一点点。因为我们父亲是推销员，所以我们经常被辗转安置。不到一年，他就娶了一个长得和我母亲很像的女人。她简直就是西方女巫。她自己也有很多问题。她对我们非常恶劣。最后，她把我们送到了一家法裔加拿大修道院。”

“She didn’t like children—she was the eldest of fourteen children and had raised all her younger brothers and sisters. She couldn’t wait to get out of her home. She rose to be a secretary at the Canadian embassy in Costa Rica. She was a very bright woman, but at thirty-three she was becoming a spinster. My father apparently asked every available woman in the English-speaking community of Costa Rica to marry him within the year after my mom’s death, and they all said no. She said yes—she didn’t want children, she didn’t like children, but that was her pact with the devil. And my dad? He was at home fifty-two days the first year they were married. Here she was with three little girls who had all these communicable diseases, one after the other, quarantined. I certainly see her side of it.

“她不喜欢孩子——她是十四个孩子中的老大，把所有的弟弟妹妹都养大了。她迫不及待地想要离开家。后来她在加拿大驻哥斯达黎加大使馆当上了秘书。她非常聪明，但到了三十三岁，她却成了老处女。我父亲显然在我母亲去世后一年内，向哥斯达黎加英语社区里所有单身女性求婚，但她们都拒绝了。她答应了——她不想要孩子，她不喜欢孩子，但这就像她与魔鬼做了交易。而我父亲呢？他们结婚的第一年，他只在家待了五十二天。而她却要照顾三个女儿，她们一个接一个地染上传染病，被隔离起来。我当然能理解她的处境。”

“I remember copying out French poems and leaving them outside the bathroom door when she was in there having a shower. She never, ever responded to them. She never acknowledged them.”

“我记得我抄写了一些法语诗歌，趁她洗澡的时候放在浴室门外。她从来没有回应过，也从来没有注意到过。”

“So you were trying very hard to bring her into a relationship with you.”

“所以你当时很努力地想和她发展恋爱关系。”

“Yes, and it never worked…. My sisters were terrified of her. She locked herself up in her bedroom and would leave us with the maids. I remember when we needed something—and this is a scene that happened over and over again—the three of us would sneak up to her bedroom door and practice trying to say “M …” Finally after standing there for twenty minutes or however long it was and not having the courage—not one of us—to say “Mommy,” we would sneak away again.

“是啊，这招从来没用……我的姐妹们都怕她。她把自己锁在卧室里，把我们留给女佣。我记得我们需要什么东西的时候——这种情况反复发生——我们三个会偷偷摸摸地走到她卧室门口，练习说‘妈……’。最后，我们站在那里二十分钟，或者更久，却始终没有勇气——我们谁也没有——说出‘妈妈’，只好再次偷偷溜走。”

“The sense was that we couldn’t ask for anything. That’s what I learned. I learned not to need or want, not to ask because it wasn’t there, and when we did, we were ridiculed.

“当时的感觉就是我们不能提任何要求。我学到的就是这样。我学会了不要需要或想要什么，不要开口求助，因为根本没有，而当我们开口求助时，却遭到了嘲笑。”

“One of my earliest memories is from around age three or four—sitting in a dress by myself playing with a doll. I was fine playing, but the sense was that there was no connection. There was nobody around; I was completely isolated. This was safe, but there wasn’t a sense of happiness, only that I had figured out how to protect myself.”

“我最早的记忆之一大概是在三四岁的时候——我独自一人穿着裙子，玩着一个娃娃。玩得很开心，但感觉上却没有任何联系。周围没有人；我完全被孤立了。这很安全，但并没有快乐的感觉，只是我找到了保护自己的方法。”

“By being alone.”

“通过独处。”

“By being alone and yes … without feeling contact.

“独自一人，是的……没有感受到任何接触。”

“There are other fragments that come up. For a long time I’ve had this image of lying in what felt like clouds; I was on a bed of clouds with a grey and colourless sky above me and this one ray of sun hitting me, but it was cold. The sense of really being completely alone, that even this ray, which might be love, wasn’t. I saw that learning not to feel was what I had to do in order to survive.”

“还有一些零碎的记忆碎片浮现出来。很长一段时间以来，我脑海中一直浮现出这样一幅画面：我躺在仿佛云朵般的地方；我躺在云床上，头顶是灰蒙蒙的、毫无生气的天空，只有一缕阳光照射在我身上，但却很冷。那种彻底的孤独感，甚至连这缕阳光——或许代表着爱——也并非真正的爱。我意识到，为了生存，我必须学会麻木自己。”

Such experiences—or the conclusions Harriette drew from them—left her isolated in life, or in relationships that, she felt, depleted her more than they nurtured her. Her intensive therapy was aimed at developing emotional competence. Emotional competence is the capacity that enables us to stand in a responsible, non-victimized, and non-self-harming relationship with our environment. * It is the required internal ground for facing life’s inevitable stresses, for avoiding the creation of unnecessary ones and for furthering the healing process. Few of us reach adult age with anything close to full emotional competence. Recognizing our lack of it is not cause for self-judgment, only a call for further development and transformation.

这些经历——或者说哈丽特从中得出的结论——让她在生活中感到孤立，或者身处的关系中，她觉得这些关系对她的消耗远大于滋养。她接受的强化治疗旨在培养她的情绪能力。情绪能力是指我们能够与环境建立一种负责任、不受伤害、不自我伤害的关系的能力。它是面对生活中不可避免的压力、避免制造不必要的压力以及促进疗愈过程所必需的内在基础。我们当中很少有人能在成年时就拥有接近完全的情绪能力。认识到自身情绪能力的不足并非自我评判的理由，而仅仅是对进一步发展和转变的呼唤。

Pursuing the seven A’s of healing will help us grow into emotional competence.

遵循疗愈的七个A原则将帮助我们培养情绪能力。

1. Acceptance

1. 接受

Acceptance is simply the willingness to recognize and accept how things are. It is the courage to permit negative thinking to inform our understanding, without allowing it to define our approach to the future. Acceptance does not demand becoming resigned to the continuation of whatever circumstances may trouble us, but it does require a refusal to deny exactly how things happen to be now. It challenges the deeply held belief that we are not worthy enough or “good” enough to be whole.

接纳，简单来说，就是愿意承认并接受事物的本来面目。它是一种勇气，允许消极的想法影响我们的认知，但又不让它左右我们面对未来的方式。接纳并不意味着要对困扰我们的任何境遇逆来顺受，而是要求我们拒绝否认事物当下的真实面貌。它挑战了我们根深蒂固的信念：我们不够优秀，不够“好”，无法拥有完整的人生。

Acceptance also implies a compassionate relationship with oneself. It means discarding the double standard that, as we have seen, too often characterizes our relationship with the world.

接纳也意味着与自己建立一种充满关爱的关系。它意味着摒弃双重标准，正如我们所见，这种双重标准常常充斥着我们与世界的关系。

As a physician, I have seen much human suffering. It may be futile, attempting to select one patient who has suffered in more ways than any of the others. Yet were I pushed to such a choice, I know immediately which patient that would be. Her story never made it into any of the chapters in this book; her illnesses would have put her in almost every chapter. I will call her Corinne. She’s in her early fifties and has had the following diagnoses: Type II diabetes, morbid obesity, irritable bowel syndrome, depression, coronary vascular disease with two heart attacks, high blood pressure, lupus, fibromyalgia, asthma and—most recently—cancer of the bowel. “I have enough medication,” Corinne says, “that I don’t have to have breakfast; I just have to take all the pills. There are thirteen pills at breakfast time alone.”

作为一名医生，我目睹了无数人间苦难。或许，要从中选出一位比其他病人承受更多痛苦的病人是徒劳的。然而，如果非要我做出这样的选择，我立刻就能想到她。她的故事从未出现在本书的任何章节中；但她所患的疾病几乎足以让她出现在每一章里。我姑且称她为科琳。她五十出头，被诊断出患有以下疾病：二型糖尿病、病态肥胖、肠易激综合征、抑郁症、冠状动脉疾病（曾两次心脏病发作）、高血压、红斑狼疮、纤维肌痛、哮喘，以及——最近——肠癌。“我的药量很大，”科琳说，“我不用吃早餐；我只需要把所有的药片都吞下去就行了。光是早餐就要吃十三片药。”

Corinne was my patient for twenty years. Much of what I learned, I learned from her, and from my other patients who, like Corinne, shared their stories with me. As a child, Corinne experienced every sort of boundary deprivation and violation one can imagine. As an adult, she has been a chronic caregiver not only to her husband, children, siblings and friends but to anyone brought into her home. Until recently, saying no has been impossible. It is still painful even now, despite her dire health status and despite the fact that she can only get around by means of a motorized scooter.

科琳做了我二十年的病人。我学到的很多东西，都来自她，也来自其他像科琳一样与我分享过故事的病人。科琳从小就经历了各种你能想象到的界限剥夺和侵犯。成年后，她一直照顾着丈夫、孩子、兄弟姐妹和朋友，以及所有来到她家的人。直到最近，对她来说，说“不”几乎是不可能的。即使现在她的健康状况很差，而且只能依靠电动代步车出行，说“不”对她来说仍然很痛苦。

“I see myself as a big blob. There is no shape. I can see people’s auras. Mine looks black and grey, and there is no definition. It’s like you’re looking at someone in the fog, and you can sort of see part of an outline, but nothing whole.”

“我把自己看作一大团模糊的东西。没有形状。我能看到别人的光环。我的光环是黑灰色的，没有轮廓。就像你在雾中看人，只能看到一部分轮廓，但看不到完整的人。”

“If you saw somebody else who had difficulty establishing boundaries, would you dismiss them as a big blob?”

“如果你看到另一个难以建立界限的人，你会把他/她看作一个笨蛋吗？”

“No. I know several people who are overweight and I don’t classify them as big blobs. It’s more my own self-image of who I am as a person. I feel like Jell-O when it comes to emotional things.”

“不。我认识好几个超重的人，但我并不觉得他们是胖子。这更多的是我自己对自己形象的看法。在情感方面，我感觉自己像果冻一样软弱无力。”

“So who’s talking to me now? Is this the big blob talking to me? Is there no sense of somebody real at home?”

“所以现在是谁在跟我说话？是这个巨大的虚拟物体在跟我说话吗？难道我感觉不到家里有真人吗？”

“I guess maybe a little bit. I can’t say 100 per cent, no.”

“我想可能有一点吧。但我不能百分之百肯定。”

“Let’s just look at that ‘little bit,’ then.”

“那我们就来看看这‘一小部分’吧。”

“The little bit wants to be in control and not allow other people to decide and make decisions for her without her consent.”

“她内心深处渴望掌控一切，不希望未经她同意就让别人替她做决定。”

“What more can you say about yourself? What are your values?”

“关于你自己，你还有什么想说的吗？你的价值观是什么？”

“That I don’t sleep around, I don’t cheat and I don’t lie and I obey the law of the land and I try to be the best person that I can be to other people.”

“我不乱搞男女关系，我不欺骗他人，我不撒谎，我遵守国家法律，我努力做一个对他人最好的人。”

“Is that only because you don’t know how to say no, or is it genuine caring?”

“是因为你不知道如何拒绝，还是你真的关心我？”

“It’s both. The majority is genuine caring.”

“两者都有。大多数人是真心关心他人。”

“So how can you say you’re just a big blob?”

“那你怎么能说你只是一团大肉球呢？”

“Because I’m Jell-O when it comes to saying no to my mother. Only a few days ago I couldn’t say to her, ‘No, it would be better for you to come in the summer, not now.’ I couldn’t say that to her. I wasn’t willing to make the decision.”

“因为我一遇到事就不好意思拒绝我妈。就在几天前，我都没办法对她说，‘不，你最好夏天来，现在别来。’我没办法对她说。我不愿意做这个决定。”

“If somebody else told you that they had difficulty making such a decision, what would you say?”

“如果别人告诉你他们很难做出这样的决定，你会怎么说？”

“I’d say that you have a lot of difficulty telling your mom what you want to tell her … and that you need to be stronger.”

“我觉得你很难开口跟妈妈说你想说的话……你需要坚强起来。”

“Without necessarily telling them what to do, what would you understand about them?”

“如果不告诉他们该怎么做，你会对他们有什么了解？”

“I would understand they’re scared that if they assert themselves, they’re going to be rejected.”

“我能理解他们害怕如果坚持己见，会被人拒绝。”

“If you cannot say that about yourself, it’s only because you are not paying the kind of compassionate attention to yourself that you would automatically grant somebody else. You cannot force yourself to say no if you don’t know how to. But at least you can give compassionate attention to the individual who is having trouble saying no .

如果你不能这样评价自己，那只是因为你没有像对待别人那样，给予自己同样的关爱和体贴。如果你不知道如何说“不”，就无法强迫自己说“不”。但至少你可以体贴地对待那些难以说“不”的人。

“Let’s look at the bind you put yourself in,” I continued. “On one hand, you don’t know how to say no; on the other hand, you condemn and judge yourself for not being able to say no. You end up calling yourself a big blob. With compassionate attention, you will see yourself as clearly as you see that other person—as someone who’s scared. And you will say that not as a judgment but as a compassionate observation— that person is really scared. That person is really hurt . She has— I have —a hard time saying no, because that brings up the immediate risk of rejection.

“我们来看看你把自己置于何种困境，”我继续说道。“一方面，你不知道如何说‘不’；另一方面，你又因为自己无法说‘不’而谴责和评判自己。最终，你觉得自己像个软弱无能的人。但只要你用同理心去关注，你就能像看待对方一样清晰地看到自己——一个内心充满恐惧的人。你会用同理心的观察而非评判来表达这一点——这个人真的很害怕。这个人真的很受伤。她——我——很难说‘不’，因为那会立刻带来被拒绝的风险。”

“You can’t force yourself to say no any more than you can force someone else to say no, but you can be compassionate toward yourself.”

“你不能强迫自己说‘不’，就像你不能强迫别人说‘不’一样，但你可以善待自己。”

“I would hold someone else’s hand to help them say no—but I wouldn’t hold my hand to help me say no.”

“我会握住别人的手帮助他们说‘不’，但我不会握住自己的手来帮助我说‘不’。”

“And if they didn’t know how to say no, you’d still accept them. You’d say. ‘Look, I understand that it’s really hard for you—you’re not ready.’”

“如果他们不知道如何拒绝，你仍然会接受他们。你会说：‘我知道这对你来说很难——你还没准备好。’”

“But I don’t say that about myself—I get angry at myself.”

“但我不会这样评价自己——我会生自己的气。”

“The thing that would help you the most, I believe, is that quality of compassionate attention toward yourself. You can work on that.”

我认为，对你最有帮助的是培养对自己的关爱和关注。你可以努力做到这一点。

“Will it give me back the energy that I seem to be feeling is zapped from me?”

“它能让我恢复感觉被抽走的精力吗？”

“So much of your energy goes into looking after others, and so much of what remains goes into self-judgments. Being this harsh on yourself takes up a lot of energy.

“你把太多精力放在照顾别人身上，剩下的精力又大部分都用来自我评判。对自己如此苛刻会消耗你大量的精力。”

“The objective fact is that you’re facing many serious medical problems. You are at risk—there’s no question about it. I don’t know how things will go. But with all that you have to deal with, the more compassionate you can be toward yourself, the more able you are to give yourself the best possible chance.”

“客观事实是，你面临着许多严重的健康问题。你处于危险之中——这一点毋庸置疑。我不知道事情最终会如何发展。但是，面对所有这些挑战，你越能善待自己，就越能为自己创造最好的机会。”

Compassionate curiosity about the self does not mean liking everything we find out about ourselves, only that we look at ourselves with the same non-judgmental acceptance we would wish to accord anyone else who suffered and who needed help.

对自我抱有同情的好奇心，并不意味着喜欢我们发现的关于自己的一切，而只是意味着我们以同样的、不带评判的接纳态度来看待自己，就像我们希望给予任何遭受痛苦和需要帮助的人一样。

2. Awareness

2. 意识

All those seeking to heal—or to remain healthy—need to reclaim the lost capacity for emotional truth-recognition, which is wonderfully illustrated by the neurologist Oliver Sacks in his book The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat . Sacks relates an anecdote about a group of aphasic patients responding to a televised address by then-president Ronald Reagan.

所有寻求康复或保持健康的人都需要重新获得识别情感真相的能力，神经学家奥利弗·萨克斯在他的著作《错把妻子当帽子的人》中对此进行了精彩的阐述。萨克斯讲述了一个轶事，一群失语症患者在观看时任总统罗纳德·里根的电视讲话时做出了反应。

Aphasia—from the Greek a (for “not”) and pha (“to speak”)—is the loss of the ability to speak or to understand spoken language. It is the result of focal brain damage, as from a stroke. “There he was, the old Charmer, the Actor, with his practised rhetoric, his histrionisms, his emotional appeal—and all the patients were convulsed with laughter. Well, not all: some looked bewildered, some looked outraged, one or two looked apprehensive, but most looked amused. The President was, as always, moving—but he was moving them, apparently, mainly to laughter. What could they be thinking? Were they failing to understand him? Or did they, perhaps, understand him all too well?” 6

失语症——源自希腊语 a（意为“不”）和 pha（意为“说话”）——是指丧失说话或理解口语的能力。它是局部脑损伤的结果，例如中风。“他就在那里，这位老魅力先生，这位演员，带着他那娴熟的修辞、夸张的表演和动人的情感——所有的病人都笑得前仰后合。嗯，也不全是：有些人一脸茫然，有些人义愤填膺，一两个人显得忧心忡忡，但大多数人看起来都觉得很有趣。总统一如既往地令人感动——但显然，他主要是在逗他们笑。他们到底在想什么？他们是不是没听懂他的话？或者，也许，他们其实太了解他了？”

Sacks’s aphasic patients were reacting to Reagan’s unconscious expressions of Emotion II—tone, body language, facial mannerisms. They found his emotions incongruent with his spoken message: in other words, they saw through his dissembling, conscious or unconscious. They read the emotional reality, not the word-reality Reagan was able to conjure up in his own mind and that he was so adept at conveying to those who, like him, were themselves emotionally shut down. “Either he is brain-damaged or he has something to conceal,” one of Sacks’s patients said. Recall the words of Reagan’s biographer: He feels the opposite of what he says .

萨克斯的失语症患者们对里根无意识表达的第二类情感——语气、肢体语言和面部表情——做出了反应。他们发现里根的情感与他所说的话并不一致：换句话说，他们看穿了他有意或无意的伪装。他们解读的是情感的真实，而不是里根在脑海中构建并巧妙传达给那些和他一样情感封闭的人的言语现实。“他要么脑子有问题，要么有什么事要隐瞒，”萨克斯的一位患者说道。回想一下里根传记作者的话：他的感受与他所说的截然相反。

Animals and young humans are highly competent at picking up on real emotional cues. If we lose that capacity as we acquire language, it is only because we receive confusing messages from our immediate world. The words we hear tell us one thing, the emotional data say something different. If the two are in conflict, one will be repressed. In the same way, when a child’s eyes diverge, the brain will suppress images from one eye in order to avoid double vision. The suppressed eye, unless corrected, will become blind. We repress our emotional intelligence in order to avoid an ongoing war with the crucial people in our lives, a war we cannot possibly win. And so we lose our emotional competence even as we gain verbal intelligence. Aphasiacs, it would appear, go through the reverse process. Much as a blind person will develop an extraordinary capacity to hear, the aphasiac develops an enhanced ability to perceive emotional reality.

动物和幼童都非常擅长捕捉真实的情感信号。如果我们习得语言后失去了这种能力，那仅仅是因为我们从周围环境中接收到了相互矛盾的信息。我们听到的词语告诉我们一件事，而情感信息却告诉我们另一件事。如果两者冲突，其中之一就会被压抑。同样地，当儿童的双眼出现异位时，大脑会抑制其中一只眼睛的图像，以避免出现复视。如果不进行矫正，被抑制的眼睛最终会失明。我们压抑自己的情商，是为了避免与生命中至关重要的人之间持续不断的冲突——一场我们根本无法取胜的冲突。因此，即使我们获得了语言能力，我们的情商却也在下降。而失语症患者似乎经历了相反的过程。正如盲人会发展出非凡的听力一样，失语症患者也会发展出更强的感知情感现实的能力。

“People are usually no better than chance at detecting lies from a liar’s demeanour, even when clues to the deceit are evident from facial expression and tone of voice,” a group of psychiatric researchers reported in Nature magazine in May 2000. “People who can’t understand words are better at picking up lies about emotions.”

“即使从面部表情和语气中可以明显看出谎言的蛛丝马迹，人们通常也很难从说谎者的举止中识破谎言，”一组精神病学研究人员在2000年5月的《自然》杂志上报告说。“那些不理解语言的人反而更容易识破关于情绪的谎言。”

Full awareness would mean that we would regain our lost capacity to perceive emotional reality and that we are ready to let go of the paralyzing belief that we are not strong enough to face the truth about our lives. There is no magic to it. The blind person learns to pay more attention to sound than the sighted. The aphasiac learns to notice his internal reactions to words, since the cognitive parts of the brain can no longer tell him what the message is. Those internal reactions, gut feelings, are what we lost as we “grew up.”

完全觉察意味着我们将重新获得感知情感现实的能力，并准备好放下那种令人麻痹的信念——我们没有足够的力量去面对生活的真相。这并非什么魔法。盲人学会了比视力正常的人更关注声音。失语症患者学会了觉察自己对词语的内在反应，因为大脑的认知部分已经无法告诉他信息的含义。这些内在反应，这些直觉，正是我们在“长大”的过程中失去的。

Clearly, we do not need to lose language skills in order relearn emotional perception. To develop awareness, though, we do have to practise, pay constant attention to our internal states and learn to trust these internal perceptions more than what words—our own or anyone else’s—convey. What is the tone of voice? The pitch? Do the eyes narrow or open? Is the smile relaxed or tight? How do we feel? Where do we feel it?

显然，我们无需丧失语言技能就能重新学习情绪感知。然而，要培养这种意识，我们确实需要练习，持续关注自身的内在状态，并学会更信任这些内在感知，而非言语——无论是我们自己的还是他人的。语气如何？音调如何？眼睛是眯起还是睁大？笑容是放松的还是僵硬的？我们感觉如何？这种感觉在哪里？

Awareness also means learning what the signs of stress are in our own bodies, how our bodies telegraph us when our minds have missed the cues. In both human and animal studies, it has been observed that the physiological stress response is a more accurate gauge of the organism’s real experience than either conscious awareness or observed behaviour. “The pituitary is a much better judge of stress than the intellect,” Hans Selye wrote. “Yet, you can learn to recognize the danger signals fairly well if you know what to look for.”

觉察力也意味着了解我们自身身体的压力信号，了解当我们的大脑错过这些信号时，身体是如何向我们发出警告的。在人类和动物研究中，人们观察到生理压力反应比意识觉察或观察到的行为更能准确地反映机体的真实体验。“垂体比智力更能判断压力，”汉斯·塞利写道。“然而，如果你知道该注意什么，你就能很好地识别危险信号。”

In The Stress of Life , Selye made a compilation of physiological danger signals. He listed physical signs such as pounding of the heart, fatigue, sweating, frequent urination, headaches, backaches, diarrhea or dryness of the mouth; emotional signs such as emotional tension or overalertness, anxiety, loss of joie de vivre; and behavioural expressions such as unusual impulsivity or irritability and a tendency to overreact. We can learn to read symptoms not only as problems to be overcome but as messages to be heeded.

在《生活压力》一书中，塞利列举了一系列生理危险信号。他列举了诸如心跳加速、疲劳、出汗、尿频、头痛、背痛、腹泻或口干等生理症状；诸如情绪紧张或过度警觉、焦虑、丧失生活乐趣等情绪症状；以及诸如异常冲动或易怒、反应过度等行为表现。我们可以学会将这些症状解读为需要重视的信息，而不仅仅是需要克服的问题。

3. Anger

3. 愤怒

“I never get angry,” a Woody Allen character says in one of his movies, “I grow a tumour instead.” Throughout this book we have seen the truth of that droll remark in numerous studies of cancer patients. We have also seen that the repression of anger is a major risk factor for disease because it increases physiological stress on the organism.

伍迪·艾伦电影里的一个角色曾说过：“我从不生气，只会长肿瘤。”本书中，我们通过对众多癌症患者的研究，证实了这句略带讽刺意味的话语的正确性。我们也发现，压抑愤怒是疾病的主要风险因素之一，因为它会增加机体的生理压力。

Not only does the repression of anger predispose to disease but the experience of anger has been shown to promote healing or, at least, to prolong survival. People with cancer who have been able to muster anger at their physicians, for example, have lived longer than their more placid counterparts. In animal experiments the expression of anger has been found to be less physiologically stressful than the suppression of it. In rats who fight others when caged together, slower growth of tumours has been found than in more docile animals.

压抑愤怒不仅会诱发疾病，而且研究表明，体验愤怒还能促进康复，或者至少可以延长生存期。例如，那些能够对医生表达愤怒的癌症患者，比那些情绪较为平和的患者活得更久。动物实验发现，表达愤怒比压抑愤怒在生理上造成的压力更小。在笼养的老鼠中，那些互相争斗的老鼠，其肿瘤生长速度比那些性情温顺的老鼠要慢。

Studies apart, we have seen that every one of the interviewees in the previous chapters acknowledged difficulties around the communication of anger, no matter what their disease or condition. “The way my stepmother raised me, I think I’m not supposed to be angry,” said Shizuko, with rheumatoid arthritis. “I was short-circuiting my visceral expression of anger,” said Magda, with severe abdominal pain.

撇开研究不谈，我们已经看到，前几章中所有受访者都承认，无论患有何种疾病或状况，他们在表达愤怒方面都存在困难。“我继母的教育方式让我觉得我不应该生气，”患有类风湿性关节炎的静子说道。“我一直在压抑自己内心深处的愤怒，”饱受剧烈腹痛折磨的玛格达说道。

Here the issue of anger becomes confusing and raises many questions. How can we encourage people to be angry when we see that children suffer from their parents’ outbursts? In many of the patient histories we have seen a similar pattern: a raging parent, a repressed child. Should Magda’s father have suppressed his anger? “I kept thinking of all the times my father raised his voice,” said Donna, whose brother Jimmy died of malignant melanoma. “I remembered his voice and the screaming and the yelling, and I thought, This is not how you should live. This is not what we should have experienced.”

在这里，愤怒的问题变得复杂起来，引发了许多疑问。当我们看到孩子因父母的情绪爆发而受苦时，我们怎能鼓励人们表达愤怒呢？在许多患者的病史中，我们都看到了类似的模式：一位暴怒的父母，一个压抑的孩子。玛格达的父亲是否应该压抑自己的愤怒呢？“我总是想起父亲大声吼叫的那些时刻，”唐娜说道，她的哥哥吉米死于恶性黑色素瘤。“我记得他的声音，记得他的尖叫和怒吼，我想，你不应该这样生活。我们不应该经历这些。”

On the surface, it seems like a paradox. If the expression of anger is “good,” Magda’s father and the father of Jimmy and Donna were only acting in a healthy fashion. Yet the effect of their anger was corrosive to their children’s self-concept and health. Suppressing anger may have negative consequences, but should we encourage its expression if it harms others?

表面上看，这似乎是一个悖论。如果表达愤怒是“好的”，那么玛格达的父亲以及吉米和唐娜的父亲的行为就完全合乎情理。然而，他们的愤怒却对孩子们的自我认知和身心健康造成了损害。压抑愤怒或许会带来负面后果，但如果愤怒会伤害他人，我们是否应该鼓励它表达出来呢？

The mystery only deepens. Not only is the unbridled outpouring of anger harmful to the recipients or bystanders but it can also be deadly to the one who rages. Heart attacks can follow upon outbursts of rage. In general, high blood pressure and heart disease are more likely to happen in persons who harbour hostility. A study of nearly two hundred men and women conducted at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Baltimore, in 2000 found that hostility and a drive for dominance were “significant independent risk factors for coronary heart disease.” 7 A great volume of research has connected hostility with high blood pressure and coronary disease.

谜团愈发加深。肆意发泄怒火不仅会伤害受害者或旁观者，甚至可能危及发怒者自身。心脏病发作可能紧随怒火爆发之后。一般来说，心怀敌意的人更容易患高血压和心脏病。2000年，巴尔的摩约翰·霍普金斯大学医学院对近200名男女进行的一项研究发现，敌意和支配欲是“冠心病的重要独立危险因素”。大量研究已证实敌意与高血压和冠心病之间存在关联。

As we can readily deduce by now, the relationship between rage and cardiovascular disease is also a function of the psycho-neuro-immune apparatus. The sympathetic nerves are activated in rage states. Narrowing of the blood vessels occurs with excessive sympathetic flight-or-fight activity, increasing the blood pressure and decreasing oxygen supply to the heart. The hormones secreted during the stress response in rage states raise lipid levels, including serum cholesterol. They also activate clotting mechanisms, further heightening the risk of blockages in the arteries.

我们现在很容易推断，愤怒与心血管疾病之间的关系也与心理-神经-免疫系统密切相关。愤怒状态下，交感神经被激活。过度活跃的交感神经应激反应会导致血管收缩，血压升高，心脏供氧减少。愤怒状态下应激反应分泌的激素会升高血脂水平，包括血清胆固醇。这些激素还会激活凝血机制，进一步增加动脉阻塞的风险。

“It was blind rage, I was sure, that had gotten me into this fix with my heart, as well as genetics,” wrote the journalist Lance Morrow in his memoir of heart disease. The blind rage that later triggered Morrow’s heart attacks was the volcanic eruption of the anger a child learned to repress in his family of origin.

“我确信，是盲目的愤怒，以及遗传因素，让我陷入了这种心脏困境，”记者兰斯·莫罗在他的心脏病回忆录中写道。后来引发莫罗心脏病发作的盲目愤怒，是他童年时期在原生家庭中被压抑的愤怒的火山爆发。

How then to resolve the dilemma of anger? If the expression of anger is harmful and so is its repression, how do we hope to attain health and healing?

那么，我们该如何解决愤怒的困境呢？如果表达愤怒有害，压抑愤怒也有害，我们又该如何获得身心健康和疗愈呢？

The repression of anger and the unregulated acting-out of it are both examples of the abnormal release of emotions that is at the root of disease. If in repression the problem is a lack of release, acting out consists of an equally abnormal suppression of release alternating with unregulated and exaggerated venting. I had a fascinating conversation on these two seemingly opposite ways of coping with Allen Kalpin, a physician and psychotherapist in Toronto. He points out that both repression and rage represent a fear of the genuine experience of anger .

压抑愤怒和不受控制地发泄愤怒，都是情绪异常释放的体现，而这正是疾病的根源。如果说压抑愤怒的问题在于缺乏释放，那么发泄愤怒则表现为同样异常的情绪抑制，并伴随着不受控制的、过度的宣泄。我曾与多伦多的医生兼心理治疗师艾伦·卡尔平就这两种看似截然相反的应对方式进行了一次精彩的对话。他指出，压抑和愤怒都源于对真正愤怒体验的恐惧。

I found Kalpin’s description of genuine anger surprising, even as it rang completely true to me. His explanation made me realize the confusion in our commonly received ideas about this emotion. Healthy anger, he says, is an empowerment and a relaxation. The real experience of anger “is physiologic experience without acting out. The experience is one of a surge of power going through the system, along with a mobilization to attack. There is, simultaneously, a complete disappearance of all anxiety .

卡尔平对真正愤怒的描述让我感到惊讶，尽管它完全符合我的感受。他的解释让我意识到我们通常对这种情绪的理解存在诸多误区。他说，健康的愤怒是一种赋能和放松。真正的愤怒体验“是一种生理体验，但不会付诸行动。这种体验是一种力量涌遍全身，同时伴随着攻击的冲动。与此同时，所有的焦虑都会完全消失。”

“When healthy anger is starting to be experienced, you don’t see anything dramatic. What you do see is a decrease of all muscle tension. The mouth is opening wider, because the jaws are more relaxed, the voice is lower in pitch because the vocal cords are more relaxed. The shoulders drop, and you see all signs of muscle tension disappearing.”

“当健康的愤怒开始显现时，你不会看到任何剧烈的变化。你会看到所有肌肉紧张感的减轻。嘴巴张得更大，因为下巴更放松了；声音的音调更低，因为声带更放松了；肩膀下垂，你会看到所有肌肉紧张的迹象都消失了。”

Dr. Kalpin’s mode of therapy works along the lines first developed by Dr. Habib Davanloo of McGill University, Montreal. Davanloo made a practice of videotaping his clients during therapy encounters so that they themselves could see their bodily manifestations of emotion. Kalpin, too, tapes some of his psychotherapy sessions.

卡尔平博士的治疗方法与蒙特利尔麦吉尔大学的哈比卜·达万卢博士最初发展的疗法类似。达万卢博士习惯于在治疗过程中对来访者进行录像，以便他们能够看到自己情绪的身体表现。卡尔平博士也会录制一些心理治疗过程。

“In a tape of one of my clients, he describes powerful surges of electricity going through his body—and he talks about them as they’re happening—but outwardly he’s just sitting there describing it. If you’re watching the tape without the sound on, you’ll see a person looking quite focused and quite relaxed, but you wouldn’t necessarily even guess that the person was angry.”

“在我一位客户的录音带里，他描述了一股强大的电流穿过他的身体——而且他是在电流涌动时就谈论它——但表面上他只是坐在那里描述。如果你把录音带静音观看，你会看到一个人看起来非常专注、非常放松，但你甚至不会想到这个人其实很生气。”

If anger is relaxation, what then is rage? When I am in a rage, my face is tight, my muscles are tense and I am sure I look anything but relaxed. Here Dr. Kalpin makes a crucial distinction. “The question is, What do people really experience when they experience rage? It’s fascinating to ask people. If you really ask, the majority of people will describe anxiety. If you ask in physical, physiologic terms what they are experiencing in their body when they feel rage, for the most part, people will describe anxiety in one form or another.”

如果愤怒是放松，那么狂怒又是什么呢？当我狂怒时，我的脸部肌肉紧绷，肌肉僵硬，我确信自己看起来一点也不放松。卡尔平博士在这里做出了一个关键的区分。“问题是，人们在狂怒时究竟体验到了什么？询问人们这个问题很有意思。如果你真的去问，大多数人会描述焦虑。如果你用生理术语来询问他们在感到狂怒时身体的感受，大多数人都会以某种形式描述焦虑。”

“It’s true,” I said, “tightening of the voice, shallow breathing, muscle tension are signs of anxiety, not of anger.”

“没错，”我说，“声音紧绷、呼吸浅促、肌肉紧张都是焦虑的迹象，而不是愤怒的迹象。”

“Exactly. Their anger is not physiologically experienced, it is only being acted out.”

“没错。他们的愤怒并非生理上的感受，而只是表现出来的。”

Acting out through bursts of rage is a defence against the anxiety that invariably accompanies anger in a child. Anger triggers anxiety because it coexists with positive feelings, with love and the desire for contact. But since anger leads to an attacking energy, it threatens attachment. Thus there is something basically anxiety-provoking about the anger experience , even without external, parental injunctions against anger expression . “Aggressive impulses are suppressed because of guilt, and the guilt exists only because of the simultaneous existence of love, of positive feelings,” says Allen Kalpin. “So, the anger doesn’t exist in a vacuum by itself. It is incredibly anxiety-provoking and guilt-producing for a person to experience aggressive feelings toward a loved one.”

儿童通过爆发性愤怒来发泄情绪，是为了防御伴随愤怒而来的焦虑。愤怒之所以会引发焦虑，是因为它与积极的情感——爱和渴望与人建立联系——并存。但由于愤怒会带来攻击性的能量，它会威胁到依恋关系。因此，即使没有父母禁止孩子表达愤怒的外部禁令，愤怒体验本身也必然会引发焦虑。“攻击性冲动之所以被压抑，是因为内疚感，而内疚感的存在恰恰是因为爱和积极的情感同时存在，”艾伦·卡尔平说道。“所以，愤怒并非孤立存在。对所爱之人产生攻击性情绪，会极大地引发焦虑和内疚感。”

Naturally, the more parents discourage or forbid the experience of anger, the more anxiety-producing that experience will be for the child. In all cases where anger is completely repressed or where chronic repression alternates with explosive eruptions of rage, the early childhood history was one in which the parents were unable to accept the child’s natural anger.

当然，父母越是阻止或禁止孩子体验愤怒，这种体验对孩子来说就越是令人焦虑。在所有愤怒被完全压抑，或长期压抑与爆发性愤怒交替出现的案例中，孩子的早期经历都表明父母无法接受孩子自然流露的愤怒。

If a person unconsciously fears the power of his aggressive impulses, there are various forms of defence available to him. One category of defence is discharge, by which we regress to an early childhood state when we dealt with the intolerable buildup of anger by acting it out. “You see, the acting-out, the yelling, the screaming and even the hitting, all that a person does, serves as a defence against the experience of the anger. It’s a defence against keeping the anger inside where it can be deeply felt. Discharge defends against anger being actually experienced.”

如果一个人潜意识里害怕自己攻击性冲动的力量，他就会采取各种防御机制。其中一种防御机制是发泄，即退回到童年早期那种通过行为来应对难以忍受的愤怒积压的状态。“你看，发泄行为，大喊大叫，甚至打人，所有这些行为都是为了防御愤怒的体验。它是为了防止愤怒被压抑在内心深处，从而避免被强烈地感受到。发泄是为了避免真正体验到愤怒。”

The other way we can avoid the experience of anger is through repression. So repression and discharge are two sides of the same coin. Both represent fear and anxiety, and for that reason, both trigger physiological stress responses regardless of what we consciously feel or do not feel.

避免愤怒体验的另一种方法是压抑。因此，压抑和释放是同一枚硬币的两面。两者都代表恐惧和焦虑，因此，无论我们有意识地感受到什么或没有感受到什么，都会引发生理应激反应。

The paralyzing difficulty many people have with anger toward loved ones is illustrated repeatedly in the interviews we have seen. Jean, unable to tell her parents about being molested at age eleven, idealizes her relationship with them rather than acknowledge her anger. Her husband, Ed, has a corrosive resentment toward what he regards as controlling behaviour from his wife but cannot experience anger openly and directly. Jill, with ovarian cancer, is upset with her doctors for having missed the diagnosis but not at her husband, Chris, for having failed to notice her pain and weight loss over several months. Leslie, with ulcerative colitis, “swallowed” his anger toward his first wife. “No question about it. I couldn’t fight because then she would say, ‘You see, this is a bad marriage.’” He is delighted to find himself in a marriage now where the experience of anger does not threaten the relationship.

许多人难以对亲人表达愤怒，这种令人窒息的困境在我们看到的访谈中反复出现。珍妮11岁时曾遭受性侵，却无法向父母倾诉，她宁愿美化与父母的关系，也不愿承认自己的愤怒。她的丈夫埃德对妻子在他看来是控制欲极强的行为感到愤恨，却无法公开、直接地表达愤怒。吉尔患有卵巢癌，她对医生未能及时诊断感到不满，但并不责怪丈夫克里斯几个月来没有注意到她的疼痛和体重下降。莱斯利患有溃疡性结肠炎，他“压抑”了对前妻的愤怒。“毫无疑问。我不能反抗，因为那样她就会说，‘你看，这就是一段糟糕的婚姻。’”如今，他很高兴自己身处一段不会因愤怒而受到威胁的婚姻中。

The anxiety of anger and other “negative” emotions like sadness and rejection may become deeply bound in the body. Eventually it is transmuted into biological changes through the multiple and infinitely subtle cross-connections of the PNI apparatus, the unifying nexus of body/mind. This is the route that leads to organic disease. When anger is disarmed, so is the immune system. Or when the aggressive energy of anger is diverted inward, the immune system becomes confused. Our physiological defences no longer protect us or may even turn mutinous, attacking the body.

愤怒带来的焦虑以及其他“负面”情绪，例如悲伤和被拒绝感，可能会深深地烙印在身体中。最终，这些焦虑会通过PNI系统（身心统一的枢纽）中无数微妙的交叉连接，转化为生物学上的变化。这就是导致器质性疾病的途径。当愤怒被解除时，免疫系统也会随之失灵。或者，当愤怒的攻击性能量转向自身时，免疫系统就会混乱。我们的生理防御机制不再能够保护我们，甚至可能出现反噬，攻击自身。

“It may prove valuable to regard cancer less as a disease than as a disorder in the body’s biochemical signals,” writes the psychotherapist Luis Ormont, who has worked with mobilizing people’s anger in group therapy with cancer patients. “To alter these signals is to produce an impact on the body’s immunological defenses. It would follow that any form of intervention designed to restore the body to physical health must use more than physical means. Since emotions dramatically influence the biochemical system, one way of providing immunotherapy is by giving psychotherapy to patients.” 8

“或许将癌症视为人体生化信号紊乱而非疾病，会更有价值，”心理治疗师路易斯·奥蒙特写道。他曾在癌症患者的团体治疗中运用愤怒情绪来调动患者的情绪。“改变这些信号会对人体的免疫防御产生影响。由此可见，任何旨在恢复身体健康的干预措施都必须采用除物理手段之外的其他方法。由于情绪对生化系统有着显著的影响，因此，为患者提供心理治疗也是一种免疫疗法。”

People diagnosed with cancer or with autoimmune disease, with chronic fatigue or fibromyalgia, or with potentially debilitating neurological conditions, are often enjoined to relax, to think positively, to lower their stress levels. All that is good advice, but impossible to carry out if one of the major sources of stress is not clearly identified and dealt with: the internalization of anger.

被诊断患有癌症、自身免疫性疾病、慢性疲劳综合征、纤维肌痛或其他可能致残的神经系统疾病的人，常常被建议放松身心、积极思考、降低压力水平。这些建议固然很好，但如果没有明确识别并处理一个主要的压力来源——愤怒的内化——那么这些建议就难以实施。

Anger does not require hostile acting out. First and foremost, it is a physiological process to be experienced. Second, it has cognitive value—it provides essential information. Since anger does not exist in a vacuum, if I feel anger it must be in response to some perception on my part. It may be a response to loss or the threat of it in a personal relationship, or it may signal a real or threatened invasion of my boundaries. I am greatly empowered without harming anyone if I permit myself to experience the anger and to contemplate what may have triggered it. Depending on circumstances, I may choose to manifest the anger in some way or to let go of it. The key is that I have not suppressed the experience of it. I may choose to display my anger as necessary in words or in deeds, but I do not need to act it out in a driven fashion as uncontrolled rage. Healthy anger leaves the individual, not the unbridled emotion, in charge.

愤怒并不一定意味着敌对行为。首先，它是一种需要体验的生理过程。其次，它具有认知价值——它提供重要的信息。愤怒并非凭空产生，如果我感到愤怒，那必然是对我自身某种感知的回应。它可能是对人际关系中损失或损失威胁的反应，也可能预示着我的界限受到了真实或潜在的侵犯。如果我允许自己体验愤怒，并思考可能触发它的原因，我便能获得极大的力量，而不会伤害任何人。根据具体情况，我可以选择以某种方式表达愤怒，或者选择放下它。关键在于我没有压抑这种体验。我可以选择在必要时用言语或行动来表达我的愤怒，但我无需像无法控制的狂怒那样将其发泄出来。健康的愤怒让个体而非不受约束的情绪掌控一切。

“Anger is the energy Mother Nature gives us as little kids to stand forward on our own behalf and say I matter,” says the therapist Joann Peterson, who conducts workshops on Gabriola Island, in British Columbia. “The difference between the healthy energy of anger and the hurtful energy of emotional and physical violence is that anger respects boundaries. Standing forward on your own behalf does not invade anyone else’s boundaries.”

“愤怒是大自然赋予我们孩童时的一种能量，让我们能够挺身而出，捍卫自身权益，表达‘我很重要’，”治疗师乔安·彼得森说道，她在不列颠哥伦比亚省的加布里奥拉岛举办工作坊。“健康的愤怒能量与有害的情感和肢体暴力之间的区别在于，愤怒尊重界限。捍卫自身权益并不会侵犯他人的界限。”

4. Autonomy

4. 自主性

Illness not only has a history but also tells a history. It is a culmination of a lifelong history of struggle for self.

疾病不仅有其历史，它本身也讲述着一段历史。它是人一生为自我奋斗的最终体现。

From a simple biological perspective, it may appear that the survival of the physical organism ought to be nature’s ultimate goal. It would seem, however, that the existence of an autonomous, self-regulating psyche is nature’s higher purpose. Mind and spirit can survive grievous physical injury, but time and again we see that the physical body begins to succumb when psychic integrity and freedom are jeopardized.

从简单的生物学角度来看，似乎维持生物体的生存才是自然界的最终目标。然而，似乎拥有自主、自我调节的精神才是自然界更高的目的。精神和心灵可以承受严重的身体创伤，但我们一次又一次地看到，当精神的完整性和自由受到威胁时，肉体便开始衰败。

Jason has been an insulin-dependent diabetic since he was five. Diabetes mellitus derives its name from the Greek for “sweet urine,” for in this disease excess sugar is filtered by the kidneys from the bloodstream into the urine. In diabetes the gland cells of the pancreas are unable to produce enough insulin, the hormone required to help sugar from digested food to enter the cells. Apart from the immediate physiological risks of high glucose levels, diabetes involves potential damage to many organs of the body.

杰森从五岁起就患有胰岛素依赖型糖尿病。糖尿病（Diabetes mellitus）一词源于希腊语，意为“甜尿”，因为这种疾病会导致过量的糖分通过肾脏从血液中滤出并排入尿液。糖尿病患者的胰腺细胞无法产生足够的胰岛素，而胰岛素是一种帮助消化食物中的糖分进入细胞的激素。除了高血糖带来的直接生理风险外，糖尿病还会对身体的许多器官造成潜在损害。

Now twenty-three, Jason is blind in his right eye from diabetes-induced vascular injury. He also suffers from weakened cardiac muscles, a leaking heart valve and malfunctioning kidneys. At times he is unable to walk, owing to a reversible nerve inflammation called diabetic neuropathy. Jason and his mother, Heather, were my patients for about ten years. In the past twelve months, he has had to be rushed to emergency repeatedly for medical crises including heart failure and meningitis. He may not have many more years to live. According to his internal medicine specialist, his prognosis is “guarded.”

现年23岁的杰森因糖尿病引起的血管损伤导致右眼失明。他还患有心肌衰弱、心脏瓣膜渗漏和肾功能衰竭。有时，由于一种名为糖尿病神经病变的可逆性神经炎症，他甚至无法行走。杰森和他的母亲希瑟曾是我的病人，大约有十年之久。在过去的十二个月里，他因心力衰竭和脑膜炎等突发疾病多次被紧急送往急诊室。他的寿命可能所剩无几。据他的内科专家称，他的预后“不容乐观”。

Heather is in a chronic state of anxiety and exhaustion mingled with resentment, which she believes are due to Jason’s stiff-necked refusal to take care of himself when it comes to eating the right kinds of food, paying close attention to his insulin requirements, attending medical appointments and having a healthy lifestyle. Of course, for a mother, the stakes are high. Her experience has been that when she does not take charge, Jason becomes ill. She has lived many years with the very real possibility that were she to relax her guard, even for a day, Jason could end up in a coma, or worse.

希瑟长期处于焦虑、疲惫和怨恨之中，她认为这一切都是因为杰森固执己见，不愿照顾好自己，比如不吃合适的食物，不注意胰岛素用量，不按时就医，也不养成健康的生活方式。当然，作为母亲，她肩负着重大的责任。她的经验是，一旦她疏忽大意，杰森就会生病。多年来，她一直生活在一种非常现实的恐惧之中：如果她哪怕放松警惕一天，杰森都可能陷入昏迷，甚至更糟。

His most recent hospitalization followed a several-week bout of vomiting that left him weak, dehydrated and in convulsions. Heather was by his bedside one day when Jason had another seizure. “Nurses, residents and specialists came running,” she relates. “Jason’s eyes were rolling backward, and his arms and legs were shaking. They were injecting medications through the IV in his arm when he sat straight up, opened his eyes and looked straight at me. In a loud voice he said, ‘Let go!’ But I can’t let go. I will not let my son die.”

他最近一次住院是因为之前持续呕吐数周，导致他身体虚弱、脱水，并且出现抽搐。一天，杰森再次癫痫发作，希瑟就守在他的床边。“护士、住院医师和专家都跑了过来，”她回忆道，“杰森的眼珠向上翻，四肢颤抖。他们正通过他手臂上的静脉注射药物时，他突然坐了起来，睁开眼睛直直地看着我。他大声说道：‘放手！’但我不能放手。我不能让我的儿子死去。”

Jason does not recall the incident. “I must have been really out of it,” he says.

杰森对这件事毫无印象。“我当时一定是神志不清了，”他说。

“Any idea what you might have meant?” I ask.

“你知道你大概是什么意思吗？”我问。

“The first thing that springs to mind is just to let me go. My saying ‘let me go’ would not have meant to let me die, just ‘stop being so overbearing. Let it go. Let me do what I’m going to do.’ It’s my life. I’ll make my mistakes, but my mom has got to let me do that. Being diabetic and having somebody else try to control me has been such a large part of my life.”

“我首先想到的就是放我走。我说‘放我走’并不是要我死，而是‘别这么专横跋扈，放手吧，让我做我想做的事。’这是我的人生，我会犯错，但我妈妈必须让我犯错。患有糖尿病，还要被别人控制，这已经占据了我人生很大一部分。”

Whatever his mother’s motivation, and no matter how much he has manipulated her into taking care of him, Jason’s salient experience is of a lack of autonomy. He has had no capacity to assert himself openly. His yearning for an autonomous self and his anger towards his mother have taken the form of resistance—including resistance toward his own physical health. “It was always like suffocation,” he told Heather. “No matter what I did, it seemed to be wrong. When I said ‘let go,’ it would have meant ‘just back off. Let me live the way I’m going to live. I’m going to live my way, and of course I’m going to make mistakes—everybody does. I never felt free to make my own mistakes.”

无论他母亲的动机是什么，也无论他如何操纵母亲照顾自己，杰森最深刻的感受都是缺乏自主性。他一直没有能力公开地表达自己的想法。他对自主的渴望和对母亲的愤怒都以反抗的形式表现出来——包括对自己身体健康的反抗。“感觉就像窒息一样，”他告诉希瑟，“无论我做什么，似乎都是错的。我说‘放手’，其实就是‘别管我，让我按自己的方式生活。我要按自己的方式生活，当然我会犯错——每个人都会犯错。’但我从来没有自由去犯错。”

If there is one lesson to draw from the history of Jason and Heather, as from all the personal stories and all the studies we have considered in this book, it is that people suffer when their boundaries are blurred. By treating Jason all his life like a child for whom she must assume all responsibility, Heather has helped to hold him back from real person-hood. By reacting like a child, Jason has held himself back.

如果说杰森和希瑟的故事，以及本书中所有个人经历和案例能给我们带来什么启示，那就是：当人与人之间的界限模糊不清时，人们会遭受痛苦。希瑟一生都把杰森当作孩子，承担着他的一切责任，这阻碍了他成为真正的人。而杰森也因为像个孩子一样行事，而阻碍了自身的成长。

In the final analysis, disease itself is a boundary question. When we look at the research that predicts who is likely to become ill, we find that the people at greatest risk are those who experienced the most severe boundary invasions before they were able to construct an autonomous sense of self. In 1998, The American Journal of Preventive Medicine published the results of the Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE) study. There were over ninety-five hundred adult participants in this research project. Childhood stressors such as emotional or sexual abuse, violence, drug use or mental illness in the family were correlated with adult risk behaviours, health outcomes and death. There was a “strong graded relationship” between dysfunction in the family of origin and adult health status—that is, the greater the exposure to dysfunction had been in childhood, the worse the health status was in the adult and the greater were the chances of untimely death from cancer, heart disease, injury or other causes. 9

归根结底，疾病本身就是一个边界问题。当我们研究预测哪些人可能患病时，会发现风险最高的人群是那些在建立自主自我意识之前经历过最严重的边界侵犯的人。1998年，《美国预防医学杂志》发表了“童年逆境经历”（ACE）研究的结果。这项研究共有超过9500名成年参与者。童年时期家庭中的情感或性虐待、暴力、吸毒或精神疾病等压力因素与成年后的风险行为、健康状况和死亡率相关。原生家庭功能失调与成年后的健康状况之间存在“强烈的等级关系”——也就是说，童年时期遭受的功能失调程度越高，成年后的健康状况就越差，因癌症、心脏病、意外伤害或其他原因过早死亡的风险也就越大。

Most commonly in the lives of children, boundaries are not so much violated as simply not constructed in the first place. Many parents cannot help their child develop boundaries because they themselves were never enabled to do so in their own formative years. We can only do what we know .

在孩子的生活中，最常见的情况并非是界限被违反，而是根本没有建立起界限。许多父母无法帮助孩子建立界限，因为他们自己在成长过程中也从未被赋予过这样的能力。我们只能做我们力所能及的事情。

Without a clear boundary between himself and his parent, the child remains enmeshed in the relationship. That enmeshment is later a template for his way of connecting to the rest of the world. Enmeshment—what Dr. Michael Kerr called a lack of differentiation—comes to dominate one’s intimate relationships. It can take two forms, withdrawal and sullen and self-defeating resistance to authority, like Jason’s, or chronic and compulsive caretaking of others, like Heather’s. In some people the two may co-exist, depending on with whom they happen to be interacting at the moment. Since the immune confusion that leads to disease reflects a failure to distinguish self from non-self, healing has to involve establishing or reclaiming the boundaries of an autonomous self.

如果孩子与父母之间没有清晰的界限，他就会深陷于这种关系之中。这种深陷会成为他日后与外界建立联系的模板。这种深陷——迈克尔·克尔博士称之为“缺乏区分”——会主导一个人的亲密关系。它可以表现为两种形式：一种是像杰森那样，退缩、阴郁且自我挫败地反抗权威；另一种是像希瑟那样，长期且强迫性地照顾他人。在某些人身上，这两种形式可能同时存在，这取决于他们当时正在与谁互动。由于导致疾病的免疫紊乱反映了无法区分自我与非我，因此，康复必须包括建立或重建自主自我的界限。

“Boundaries and autonomy are essential for health,” said the therapist and group leader Joann Peterson during our recent conversation on Gabriola Island. She is director of education at PD Seminars, a holistic healing and psychological growth centre. “We experience life through our bodies. If we are not able to articulate our life experience, our bodies speak what our minds and mouths cannot.”

“界限和自主性对健康至关重要，”治疗师兼团体负责人乔安·彼得森在最近我们于加布里奥拉岛的谈话中说道。她是PD研讨会的教育总监，该中心是一家提供整体疗愈和心理成长服务的中心。“我们通过身体体验生活。如果我们无法清晰地表达自己的生活体验，我们的身体就会替我们表达我们思想和语言无法表达的东西。”

“A personal boundary,” according to Dr. Peterson, “is an energetic experience of myself or the other person. I don’t want to use the word aura because it is a new-age kind of word, but beyond where skin ends we have an energetic expression. We not only communicate boundaries verbally, but I think we have an energetic expression that is non-verbal.” In her book Anger, Boundaries, and Safety , Dr. Peterson explains this concept in greater detail: “Boundaries are invisible, the result of a conscious, internal felt sense defining who I am. Asking yourself, ‘In my life and relationships, what do I desire, want more of, or less of, or what don’t I want, what are my stated limits?’ begins the process…. In this self-definition, we define what we value and want in life at this particular time from a place of internal self-reference; the locus of control is from inside ourselves .”

彼得森博士认为，“个人界限是我或他人的一种能量体验。我不想用‘灵气’这个词，因为它有点新时代的感觉，但超越皮肤之外，我们拥有能量的表达。我们不仅用语言来表达界限，我认为我们还有非语言的能量表达。” 在她的著作《愤怒、界限与安全》中，彼得森博士更详细地解释了这一概念：“界限是无形的，它源于一种有意识的、内在的感受，这种感受定义了我是谁。问问自己：‘在我的生活和人际关系中，我渴望什么？我想要更多什么？更少什么？我不想要什么？我的界限是什么？’这个过程就开始了……在这个自我定义的过程中，我们从内在的自我参照出发，定义了我们此刻在生活中珍视和想要的东西；控制点来自我们内心。”

Autonomy, then, is the development of that internal centre of control.

因此，自主性就是发展这种内部控制中心的过程。

5. Attachment

5.附件

Attachment is our connection with the world. In the earliest attachment relationships, we gain or lose the ability to stay open, self-nurturing and healthy. In those early attachment bonds, we learned to experience anger or to fear it and repress it. There we developed our sense of autonomy or suffered its atrophy. Connection is also vital to healing. Study after study concludes that people without social contact—the lonely ones—are at greatest risk for illness. People who enjoy genuine emotional support face a better prognosis, no matter what the disease.

依恋是我们与世界的联结。在最早的依恋关系中，我们获得或失去保持开放、自我滋养和健康的能力。在那些早期的依恋关系中，我们学会了体验愤怒，或者恐惧愤怒并将其压抑。在那里，我们发展了自主意识，或者自主意识逐渐萎缩。联结对于疗愈也至关重要。一项又一项的研究表明，缺乏社交接触的人——孤独的人——患病的风险最高。无论患何种疾病，那些获得真诚情感支持的人预后都更好。

Ever since a small nodule was found on his prostate fourteen years ago, seventy-one-year-old Derek has had annual PSA tests done. Two years ago he had a biopsy showing cancerous cells. “The oncologist said I was high risk, and he scared me. So I agreed to take six months of hormone therapy, which reduces the tumour. It kills your testosterone completely. You have to get a shot every three months. After the hormone treatment, the oncologist wanted to start radiation for seven weeks. I said no, I don’t want this, because I’ve read so much about it. Radiation and surgery temporarily fix the problem, but after three to five years, it often comes back. And the radiation destroys so much … so many good cells in your body, besides the bad ones.”

自从14年前在前列腺上发现一个小结节后，71岁的德里克每年都做PSA检查。两年前，他的活检结果显示有癌细胞。“肿瘤科医生说我是高危人群，这让我很害怕。所以我同意接受6个月的激素治疗，这种治疗可以缩小肿瘤。它会彻底抑制睾酮分泌。你需要每三个月注射一次。激素治疗结束后，肿瘤科医生想让我接受7周的放射治疗。我说不，我不想做，因为我读过很多关于放射治疗的资料。放射治疗和手术只能暂时解决问题，但三到五年后，癌症往往会复发。而且放射治疗除了会破坏癌细胞外，还会破坏体内很多健康的细胞。”

“What did you go through emotionally when you were diagnosed?”

确诊时，你的情绪经历了怎样的变化？

“Well, you see, that has been the problem with me. I didn’t tell anybody. I didn’t tell any of my friends. I kept it all to myself, except for my wife and my two daughters.

“嗯，你看，这就是我的问题所在。我没告诉任何人。我没告诉我的任何朋友。除了我的妻子和两个女儿，我把一切都藏在心里。”

“Before, I was a recluse. I was very private. Now, I’m very open. I love lots of people around me. Before, I didn’t. I was perfectly happy to find a cave with a lock on the door, and I could live there happily for the rest of my life. My priorities have all changed. Before, I built steam locomotives for a hobby. I used to spend sixteen hours a day in my workshop doing that, and I was absolutely happy. Now, I haven’t been in my workshop for two years, since I got cancer.

“以前我是个隐士，非常注重隐私。现在我变得很开朗，喜欢身边有很多人。以前我可不是这样。我当时只想找个带锁的山洞，舒舒服服地在那里度过余生。我的生活重心完全变了。以前我爱好是造蒸汽机车，每天要在工作室里待十六个小时，而且乐在其中。现在，自从两年前得了癌症，我就再也没去过工作室了。”

“Now, I need lots of people in my life. Cancer people support each other. And that’s what we need —to talk about it. The rest of my life we will all be talking about it. It seems to be something that you have to do.”

“现在，我需要很多人陪伴。癌症患者会互相支持。而这正是我们需要的——谈论它。我余生都会谈论它。这似乎是我们必须要做的事情。”

“Don’t human beings in general need support and the opportunity to share emotions, and to talk about their difficulties, cancer or no cancer? Why do you think cancer would have to teach you this?”

“难道人类普遍都需要支持和分享情感、倾诉困难的机会吗？无论是否患有癌症？你认为为什么癌症一定要教会你这些呢？”

“I wondered that myself. When I was first diagnosed, I built a wall around me, and I didn’t let anybody in because I felt safe inside there. That was a mistake I made. I put all my energies into fighting the cancer, for eleven months. When I finally thought that the cancer was gone, I started to let this wall down, I started telling people about my experience, that I had cancer and that I had got rid of it. I was quite proud of the fact.”

“我自己也想过这个问题。刚确诊的时候，我把自己封闭起来，不让任何人走进我的世界，因为我觉得待在里面很安全。那是我犯的一个错误。我把所有的精力都投入到与癌症的斗争中，整整十一个月。当我最终认为癌症已经消失的时候，我开始放下这道心墙，开始告诉别人我的经历，我曾经得过癌症，也战胜了它。我为此感到非常自豪。”

“You were able to share once you defeated the thing, but not while you were fighting it, when you most needed support. Why did you keep your wife out?”

“你战胜怪物之后才愿意分享，但在与怪物战斗、最需要支持的时候，你却不愿与人分享。你为什么要把你的妻子拒之门外？”

“I never felt that she supported me … and yet … I know she was supporting me … but I wouldn’t let her into my life. I had this wall around me, and I wouldn’t let anybody in.”

“我从未感觉她支持过我……然而……我知道她其实是在支持我……但我却不愿让她走进我的生活。我筑起了一道墙，不让任何人进来。”
